DOC.HEAD: Bierstadt Painting Surfaces After 100 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf, `Ferber did ...,' to UPDATE with worth of comparable painting.
DOC.TEXT: When landscape artist Albert Bierstadt painted a huge canvas of Switzerland's Lake Lucerne in 1858, it was well documented in art literature. Within decades, the painting was lost _ until now. The 6-by-10-foot painting was found two weeks ago in the rural Exeter home of the late Pearl Rose, whose family had owned, but concealed, the canvas for 100 years. During the weekend, experts used writings about the painting to confirm that the scene of the lake, with the Swiss Alps in the background, was Bierstadt's work, said Linda Ferber, curator of American painting at the Brooklyn Museum in New York. ``It's a piece of the Bierstadt puzzle and it's very nice to have it back in the public domain,'' she said. Lewis Peck, who inherited the Bierstadt, said Wednesday the family kept the painting a secret because they owned other artwork and did not want that generally known. ``If you had a bar of gold in your house, would you tell everybody about it?'' he asked in a telephone interview from Exeter, in south central Rhode Island. ``That's about the way we did things.'' The whereabouts of the painting was last known in 1882 when Alvin Adams, of Watertown, Mass., sold it in Boston. In 1890, it was purchased by Mrs. Rose's first husband, William Sunderland, said Peck's wife, Sylvia. Peck, a distant cousin of Mrs. Rose, inherited it in August when she died at age 86. The landscape is so large that when the family moved it to their Exeter home 70 years ago, the roof had to be lifted to get the painting in, Mrs. Peck said Tuesday. When it was removed two weeks ago, ``we took the side of the house off,'' she said. The Pecks will sell the painting at auction on Oct. 6. The painting is typical of Bierstadt's earlier work, according to Ferber, who is assembling an exhibit of Bierstadt's work for early 1991. Ferber did not know what the Lake Lucerne painting was worth. But attorney Christopher Healey said Bierstadt's ``Moteratsch Glacier, Upper Engadine Valley, Pontresina,'' about the same size as the Pecks' painting, brought $990,000 at Sotheby's auction house May 24. Bierstadt, part of the Hudson River group of painters, built his reputation on his panoramic landscapes of the American West. The World Book Encyclopedia calls Bierstadt ``one of the greatest American romantic landscape painters,'' and said he received $25,000 for a painting in the latter half of the 1800s, a record for a painting at that time. Bierstadt was born in Germany and raised in New Bedford, Mass. He studied in Dusseldorf, Germany, from 1853 to 1857, and painted his Lake Lucerne picture in New York, according to Ferber. She said there are other Bierstadt's that are unaccounted for, although ``this was certainly one of the larger ones.'' Bierstadt died in 1902 in New York City.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary to Seek Dissolution of Military Part of Warsaw Pact
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Jozsef Antall said Wednesday he plans to tell Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that the Warsaw Pact is out of step with the political times and as a military alliance should be dissolved by next year. ``We intend to make it clear that the Warsaw Pact as a political organization, reflecting confrontation in Europe, is outdated,'' said Antall, only hours before departure for a key Pact summit in Moscow. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Tuesday that the pact would undertake a ``transformation'' at the Moscow meeting and urged NATO to do the same. ``It has lost its function in Europe,'' Antall said of the pact. ``Therefore, its military aspect can be discarded and, in our view ... dissolved by the end of 1991.'' Expanding on his proposal to transform the seven-nation Soviet-led alliance into a non-military pact, Antall told reporters, ``It is to be attained through ... the Helsinki process and the Vienna disarmament talks.'' The 35-nation Helsinki talks bring together all European nations except Albania, as well as the United States and Canada, to discuss various aspects of security and cooperation in Europe. The 16-member North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact are meeting in Vienna to discuss cutting conventional arms in Europe. Antall, Hungary's first non-Communist prime minister in more than four decades, served notice shortly after assuming office last month that he sought to pull his country out of the pact. He reiterated Wednesday, however, that Hungary would only leave with the agreement of all its pact partners. ``The intentions of the Hungarian people were made clear in 1956,'' he said alluding to the nation's failed attempt to leave the pact during the anti-Stalinist revolution that was crushed by Soviet tanks. ``But that does not mean we can disregard ... international law, politics and military aspects,'' he said, arguing against a renewed attempt on Hungary's part to leave unilaterally. Antall also said he saw no reason for NATO's disbanding. ``Unlike the Warsaw Pact, NATO is not in crisis,'' he said. ``Therefore, the dissolution of the NATO military alliance is not linked to the question of the future of the Warsaw Pact.'' Antall indicated Hungary would seek more independence within the military alliance as long as it remained a member. ``We want to compile as soon as possible a list of all the things we feel impinge upon the sovereignty of member states,'' he said. ``Such stipulations and confrontational elements must be struck from the treaty.''

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Leader Predicts Victory Over Communists
With AM-Rights Conference
DOC.TEXT: The leader of Bulgaria's main opposition alliance Tuesday predicted his group will take at least half the vote in the June 10 elections. Meanwhile, the U.S. Embassy said Ambassador Sol Polansky met in Copenhagen with James A. Baker III in response to a request by the U.S. secretary of state ``to receive an assessment of the prospects for free and fair elections in Bulgaria and in view of the increasing concern about the fairness of the electoral process.'' Baker and other foreign ministers of the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe are in Denmark to attend a CSCE meeting. UDF chairman Zhelyu Zhelev made his electoral forecast in an interview, after his alliance appeared to have suffered a setback because of controversial comments made by another opposition leader. In the interview published in Bulgaria and abroad, Milan Drenchev, head of the Agrarian Party Nikola Petkov, was quoted as saying other UDF leaders understand nothing about politics. He reportedly announced his group would leave the opposition alliance after the June 17 runoff and would run independently in fall municipal elections. Officials of his party issued a denial Tuesday, and Zhelev said Drenchev was misquoted. ``We believe we will win at least 50 percent, we are aiming for more than that,'' Zhelev insisted, despite widespread belief the ruling Communists, who now call themselves the Socialist Party, would give the UDF a close race. He said attendance at recent opposition rallies was two to four times larger than that of comparable events organized by the ruling party. While expressing confidence the voting process would be fair overall, Zhelev said he expects some attempts at manipulation. The ruling party ``came to power with an election fraud, with totally rigged elections in 1946,'' he declared. ``It cannot reconcile itself with the thought of losing power.'' Western governments also have expressed interest recently in keeping the balloting fair. Apart from foreign observers of the voting, including some from the United States, other precautions have been taken, the opposition leader said. At least two UDF representatives will be near each ballot box and ``Free and Fair Election'' student activists will be posted in 1,500 polling stations, about 10 percent of the total.

DOC.HEAD: Cunhal Keeps Portugese Communists on Orthodox Course
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: By PAUL AMES
DOC.TEXT: The winds of change have forced reform on Communists throughout Europe, but veteran leader Alvaro Cunhal is keeping his Portugese party firmly to the traditional course. ``Our party continues to declare itself a Marxist-Leninist party,'' he told 2,000 delegates to the group's congress last month in Loures, a Communist bastion 12 miles from Lisbon. ``Few of our comrades have expressed the opinion that the PCP should follow the path that other Communist parties have trod,'' Cunhal said. Delegates raised clenched fists in salute and cheered their leader, who is 76 and has led the party since 1961. They re-elected him unanimously despite hints earlier this year that he might retire. Cunhal's decision to stay on may worry the growing reform movement, but the congress also chose Carlos Carvalhas, a 48-year-old economist and member of the European Parliament, for the new post of assistant general secretary. The combination of Cunhal and Carvalhas, who is more pragmatic but not a member of the reformist wing, may be an attempt to mend the rift between dissidents and the old guard. Reformers want the party to adapt its political program to reflect the new situation in Eastern Europe, where the Soviet bloc has collapsed, and Portugal's position as a stable democracy within the 12-nation European Community. They also demand greater democracy and openness in party operations. Party leaders have dealt firmly with dissenters. Zita Seabra, a leading campaigner for women's rights, was expelled from the ranks in January after arguing for Cunhal's resignation, a change in the party name and abandonment of traditional ideology. Jose Luis Judas, a trade union official and leading critic of Cunhal, was barred from the Loures congress. Other critics have been dismissed from the party Central Committee. At the congress, Cunhal accused reformers of ``forming factions that act in a conspiratorial and organized way within the party, and carrying out a media campaign that places their action in a wider anti-communist campaign against the party.'' ``This will not be permitted,'' he declared. Dissidents say only reform can halt a decline that has seen the party's share of the national vote drop from 21 percent in 1979 to 14 percent in December, when local elections were held. Some change has resulted from the fall of Communist regimes in Eastern Europe. Cunhal acknowledges his former comrades ``commited serious errors and isolated themselves from their people.'' He has paid lip service to the reforms of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet president, but also said anti-communist forces backed by the West could ``compromise the building of socialism.'' Cunhal's party supported the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and the Kremlin's intervention in Afghanistan, which lasted nearly a decade. It was silent on the brutal repression of China's pro-democracy movement a year ago and sent delegates to the Romanian Communist Party congress before Nicolae Ceausescu's downfall in December. Despite media reports of poor health, Cunhal demonstrated in two lengthy speeches to the congress that he had lost none of his fiery speaking style. Delegates in the Loures' Hall of Peace and Friendship interrupted frequently with applause and chants of ``PCP! PCP!'' Cunhal spent 12 years in prison under the right-wing dictatorship that governed Portugal for nearly half a century before a coup in 1974 opened the way for democracy. His 40 years of resistance to the dictatorship, years in jail and torture by the secret police earned Cunhal legendary status among followers and the respect of political opponents. Judas said recently that Cunhal would continue running the party even after retirement. ``Its a bit like Deng Xiaoping,'' the senior Chinese leader, Judas said. ``Even when he leaves the leadership, it's he who commands.'' He said the party must change because, ``in the future, being a Communist won't be the same thing as being a Communist in 1917. .. . If the Communist parties don't change, adapt, then they'll disappear.''

DOC.HEAD: Rising Nationalism Marks Campaign in Slovakia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Slovak nationalists who would like to create a separate state from the smaller of Czechoslovakia's two republics have campaigned aggressively and noisily for Friday's elections, the first free vote since 1946. While their Slovak National Party is unlikely to finish higher than third in its native region, their cause could become a major headache for the coalition governments likely to emerge at both federal and republican levels after the voting. The chief task of the newly elected federal parliament in its two-year term is to draft a new constitution. Deputies will have to address the thorny question of Slovakia's status. All the parties campaigning in Slovakia have adopted powerful local symbols, slogans and heroes in election posters and ads. The Christian Democrats, front-runners in Slovakia although not nationwide, say outright that they favor a shift from federation to a confederation that would loosen ties between two peoples whose languages are very similar, but whose customs and history differ. Only foreign affairs, defense and finance should be regulated at a national level in future, said Ivan Carnogursky, head of the Slovak Christian Democrat Movement. According to his brother Jan, the Christian Democrats' leading candidate in Slovakia, Slovakia should ultimately enter a united Europe as a separate state. Nobody is advocating a swift separation. Czech and Slovak economies are too intertwined for that. But the new freedom of speech and the full blast of an election campaign mean that ancient rivalry between the dominant Czechs and the more rural Slovaks, who make up about one-third of Czechoslovakia`s 15.5 million people, is getting its fullest airing in more than 40 years. In Czechoslovakia, a federation was formed in 1968. Czechs resented it because it gave half the federal funds to a third of the people. The 21-year rule of Gustav Husak, Communist Party chief, later president, and a Slovak, also brought an influx of Slovaks to Prague. Slovaks were not necessarily happy with what the federal money bought. Much of the industry devised by Communist planners in the name of evening out economic inequities was unsuited to the rural region and blights the air and the eye around big cities such as the capital, Bratislava. Nationalist sentiment first broke out in spring when Czechoslovakia decided to follow other newly liberated east European nations and remove ``Socialist'' from the country`s name. Slovaks first insisted on a hyphen in the name to make a distinction between the Czech and Slovak regions. Thousands demonstrated angrily when the hyphen was not made obligatory in the Czech republic. The dispute eventually was settled by adopting the formal name ``Czech and Slovak Federative Republic`` for the country. The clumsy solution pleased almost nobody, and President Vaclav Havel, a Czech, acknowledged that the name dispute had dispelled the euphoria engendered by last winter's revolution. About 500 Slovak nationalists angrily disrupted Havel's final campaign appearance in Bratislava on Monday, quieting down only when admonished by Alexander Dubcek, the Slovak hero of the 1968 ``Prague Spring.'' He reminded them that totalitarianism had not been overthrown to make way for anarchy, noting that democracy demanded they give the president a hearing. Earlier, Havel was interrupted several times during an appearance in southern Slovakia at Komarno. Latest opinion polls give the Slovak National Party just 7 percent of the vote in the republic. But in Bratislava _ a centuries-old city with a tradition of more openness than Slovakia's sparsely populated mountains and valleys _ their support could go as high as 12 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil Institutes Anti-Smoking Measures
DOC.TEXT: The government has issued a package of anti-smoking measures in an attempt to discourage a habit shared by about a third of the country's 150 million citizens. The measures, which went into effect at the beginning of June, include a ban on cigarette sales to those under 18, a ban on TV advertising for cigarettes between 6 a.m. and 9 p.m., and a ban on free samples. They also include a recommendation to airline companies that smoking be outlawed on flights of less than two hours, and a rule that the warning ``Smoking is prejudicial to your health'' take up 20 percent of the space on print ads and billboards for cigarettes. Current laws prohibiting smoking in elevators, buses, and other public areas are routinely ignored in Brazil, where an estimated 54.6 million people smoke.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Gorbachevs Took Home a Lot, Including Horseshoes
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may have returned to Moscow bearing trade and arms agreements, but he and his wife Raisa were laden with other souvenirs as well _ including two of President Bush's horseshoes. Among the many gifts the Bushes gave the Gorbachevs during the superpower summit was an orange pitching horseshoe mounted on a wooden plaque. It was the lucky shoe that Gorbachev had tossed for a first-time ringer at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains, as he and his wife relaxed there last Saturday with the Bushes. Bush presented the horseshoe plaque to Gorbachev at dinner that night. But the next day, a second horseshoe was discovered missing from the pit. At first, it wasn't clear what had happened, but now the mystery has been solved. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Tuesday that Mrs. Gorbachev, who was with her husband when he pitched his ringer, put the second horseshoe in her purse. ``They took both,'' he said. Fitzwater said Mrs. Gorbachev had been invited to keep the second horseshoe _ which was the one that she had pitched _ by a Bush aide. The president later joked to members of his Cabinet that Gorbachev's visit had cost him two of his favorite horsehoes. The horseshoe-on-a-plaque gift was spontaneous. A more formal exchange of gifts is part of every state visit. Considering how often Bush meets with foreign leaders, coming up with new gift ideas must strain the creativity of White House social planners. The president gave Gorbachev a five-volume biography, ``Life of George Washington'' by former Chief Justice John Marshall. In exchange, the Soviet leader gave Bush an antique painting of Russian birch trees. Mrs. Bush gave Raisa Gorbachev a gold-and-rhinestone-trimmed handbag; in return, she received an enameled tea set. Last year, the Gorbachevs gave the Bushes a box of glass Christmas ornaments and seven children's books. Despite warming U.S.-Soviet relations, American gifts to Soviet leaders just aren't what they used to be. Gorbachev got history books and a horseshoe. Former Soviet leader Leonid Brezhnev was given a Lincoln Continental by then-President Nixon at one of their summits. Sometimes gifts to and from foreign leaders can prove troublesome, such as the two prized jaguars President Andres Rodriguez of Paraguay gave Vice President Dan Quayle earlier this year. It turned out the cats were on the U.S. endangered species list and no American zoo would take them. Quayle had to give them back. He asked Rodriguez to release them in the jungle. And Bush now may wish that he hadn't given leather cowboy boots bearing the flags of Texas and China to Chinese Premier Li Peng. He made the presentation when he visited Beijing last year _ several months before government troops and tanks trampled pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. U.S. law permits federal officials _ from the president on down _ to keep gifts from foreign governments only with a value of $180 or less. Gifts worth more than that must be turned over to the State Department for safekeeping. Barbara Bush used to give a slide show when her husband was vice president. When she would get to the slide of herself and the emir of Bahrain, she would tell audiences: ``The agonized look on my face is because he had just given me $85,000 worth of jewelry, which I immediately gave to the State Department.'' It must be a coincidence, but it's remarkable how many public officials list gifts at just under that $180 threshold on their financial disclosure forms. For instance, Vice President Dan Quayle and his wife Marilyn gave these values on gifts from foreign governments in 1989: a picture and frame from the princess of Thailand, $170; a wooden carved bear from a high-ranking Japanese official, $175; a vase from the government of South Korea, $175; an engraved plate from El Salvador, $175. Likewise, White House chief of staff John Sununu was able to keep the lacquered samovar, two bottles of Russian vodka and four ounces of black caviar that Gorbachev gave him last year. He valued the gifts at $173. Sig Rogich, assistant to the president for special activities, got a like amount of caviar and vodka from Gorbachev, and an art book on impressionism as well. His figured the combined value at $178. Deputy national security adviser Robert M. Gates reported receiving a cinnabar vase and wooden stand from the government of China. He estimated their worth at $160. Fitzwater said there is a process under which foreign gifts worth more than $180 can be bought back from the government at auction. But, he said, ``I'll be honest with you. I've pressed the State Department for 25 years and have never been able to discover how in the world you do that.'' As for himself, Fitzwater told reporters recently, ``I've got a lacquered box from Gorbachev. That's my favorite gift. I can't keep it because of the value, but I can keep it on display in the White House. So it's in my office.'' ``You can look at it any time you like,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Visit a Phenomenon in the Works
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: For millions of Americans it will be a dream realized; for organizers, a logistical nightmare. For eight chosen cities it will be a time of tumult; for Nelson Mandela, simply, a welcome. Freed in February after 27 years in South African jails, Mandela plans an exultant tour of the United States this month, starting with a New York ticker-tape parade and ending with a rally at the Oakland, Calif., Coliseum. Organizers envision gatherings of uncommon size and emotion, including throngs at Yankee Stadium in New York, Tiger Stadium in Detroit and the Los Angeles Coliseum. ``We're asking that the people come to him,'' said New York coordinator Jim Bell, who is overwhelmed with requests for Mandela appearances. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, will pick the fruits of political stardom, as well. He'll meet with President Bush, speak to a joint session of Congress, address the United Nations General Assembly. ``It is a very important political breakthrough,'' one that simultaneously raises the ANC's stature and pressures South Africa to renounce apartheid, its system of racial separation, said ANC spokesman Victor Mashabela. For the ANC, he said, ``All of this is powerful and positive.'' It also is lucrative. Fund-raising is one of Mandela's goals, and the ANC, South Africa's largest anti-apartheid movement, hopes to realize $8 million from the visit. It will charge admission _ $5 to $25 _ to the stadium concert-rallies, charge up to $25,000 per plate at fund-raisers with wealthy sympathizers, even place donation cans to collect change in restaurants. ``The African National Congress has never had such a national, massive campaign for raising funds in this country,'' said Suzanne DuBose, chief fund-raiser for Mayor David Dinkins. ``There has been a real outpouring of support, and all of it is due to Nelson Mandela.'' There also has been an outpouring of invitations. School, church, labor, business and political groups have besieged organizers with requests for Mandela appearances. Celebrities want to appear with him; Marvin Davis, former owner of 20th Century Fox, is to fly him to the United States on his private Boeing-727; a New York limousine service offered its services for free. In Boston, the Copley Plaza Hotel is donating accommodations worth $70,000. In Atlanta, a group of black colleges will give Mandela an honorary degree. In New York, so many religious groups expressed interest that planners have invited 5,000 clergy members to a rally with Mandela at a Manhattan church. ``The interest is a profound interest. It's an incredible interest. It's huge. It's from the grassroots right up to the ivory towers,'' said Carl McCaskill, a tour spokesman. The reason, he suggested, is that as nations other than South Africa move toward democracy, ``This is probably the last great opportunity to get involved in something like this.'' Some participants see the visit in intensely personal as well as historic terms. ``As a black person it gives me great hope to see that this man is a hero to all people, not just black people and South Africans,'' said Colette Phillips, Boston spokeswoman for the tour. ``This is like for me the single most significant thing that I could do in my entire life,'' she said. ``If I died on June 24, the day after Mr. Mandela leaves, I would feel that my life would have been worth something. I could say I have helped rid the world of the scourge of apartheid.'' Mandela, 71, a lawyer, grew to heroic stature as he languished in prison on a life term for sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. He was freed Feb. 11 in a gesture of conciliation by the South African government, which has legalized the ANC and held talks with its leaders. Since his release, Mandela has traveled throughout Africa and visited Europe, but this will be his first visit to the United States. He arrives June 20 and departs June 30, with stops in New York, Boston, Washington, Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland. Mandela underwent surgery last week to have a benign cyst removed from his bladder, and tour organizers said they were concerned about his health and were intent on providing him with rests between appearances. Still, his schedule _ and that of his wife, Winnie, who will travel with him _ is arduous. Plans remain tentative, but motorcades and stadium rallies are possible in each city. Mandela will meet with business leaders, whom he will urge to boycott South Africa until apartheid ends. He will meet with civil rights leaders, urging them to continue their anti-apartheid efforts. And, in the midst of it all, there will be a family affair: In Boston, Mandela will visit two of his daughters, Zenani Mandela-Dlamini, 31, and Makaziwe Mandela, 36, both college students. At a recent news conference, Dlamini worried that her parents would have scant time for the reunion. ``So if anyone is offended that they can't see them,'' she said, ``just think of me.''

DOC.HEAD: A Record Box-Office Year for Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Broadway set a box-office record for the third consecutive year, selling $283 million in tickets during the 1989-90 season. The figure was up 8 percent from the previous season when sales totaled $262 million, the League of American Theaters and Producers said Tuesday. Attendance climbed to 8.03 million during the season that ended Sunday, from 7.97 million the previous season but lower than the 8.14 million tickets sold two years ago. There were more new plays, more new musicals and more revivals on Broadway during the recently concluded season than in the previous season. Thirty-five productions opened during the 1989-90 season including 15 new plays, eight new musicals, six revivals of plays, four revivals of musicals and two special attractions. But ticket prices also climbed, with the average paid admission for all shows at $35.25, up 7 percent from the 1988-89 season when the average was $32.90. The top price was $60 for ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway,'' with most other big musicals charging $55. Receipts for Broadway touring shows jumped to $367 million, up from $256 million the previous year, a hike of 43 percent. Contributing to the increase were two productions of ``The Phantom of the Opera,'' doing great business in Los Angeles and Toronto. The number of theatergoers for touring shows climbed from 9.7 million to 12.9 million. Among the hits of the season were such diverse shows as the musical ``City of Angels,'' the revival of ``Cat on a Hot Tin Roof,'' and ``Lettice & Lovage,'' a British comedy starring Maggie Smith. There was strong competition for best play in last Sunday's Tony Awards between ``The Piano Lesson,'' ``Prelude to a Kiss'' and ``The Grapes of Wrath,'' the eventual winner. Among the other stars who appeared on Broadway during the 1989-90 season were Dustin Hoffman, Vanessa Redgrave, Kathleen Turner, the late Rex Harrison, Glynis Johns, Stewart Granger, Sting, Sid Caesar, Timothy Hutton, Tom Hulce and Robert Morse.

DOC.HEAD: Washington's Newest Think Tank Promises to be Different
DOC.TEXT: Hungry for more studies analyzing the ``big issues'' of our time, but tired of the predictable pap from established research organizations? Clyde Prestowitz has just what you need _ a new think tank. But in a town with a think tank on nearly every corner, a new kid on the block has to find a niche. According to its creators, the Economic Strategy Institute will be the first research organization geared to the post-Cold War era, a time when America's standing will be based not on its nuclear arsenal but on its ability to compete economically with countries such as Japan. ``When you consider the question of international trade and international economics, virtually all of the think tanks are saying the same thing,'' Prestowitz told a news conference Tuesday. ``We see a vacuum out there in terms of useful analysis to help guide policymakers in an era that will be dominated by geo-economics rather than geo-politics,'' he said. ``We are going to be the think tank of the 90s, the think tank for America,'' said Ronald A. Morse, the institute's executive vice president. The institute hopes to use its $1.4 million in donations from corporations, labor unions and foundations to promote productivity and competitiveness _ two current buzzwords in a country plagued by fears of declining ability to measure up in the global marketplace. Given Prestowitz's history, it is likely that the institute's views will be controversial. A top-ranking trade negotiator during the Reagan administration's first term, he later wrote a best-selling book on his experiences titled ``Trading Places: How We are Giving Our Future to Japan and How to Reclaim It.'' Prestowitz charged in his book that wrongheaded policies caused soaring trade deficits and suggested that instead of trying to Americanize the Japanese system, U.S. policymakers should copy Japan's approach of fostering homegrown industry. Critics have accused Prestowitz of promoting an America-first approach to policymaking that could topple the world into a round of trade wars and protectionist barriers, killing off the free-trade principles that have guided U.S. policy since the end of World War II. Prestowitz says labels such as protectionist and free trade are too simplistic. ``Neither of those (labels) exist in the real world. The reality is somewhere in between,'' he said. ``We are trying to challenge the old shibboleths.'' To address the country's lagging competitiveness, Prestowitz said government needs to boost woefully low business investment and to re-orient American corporations toward longer-term objectives. The committee hosting Tuesday's inaugural dinner for the institute included House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. Dole said he saw the new institute as a ``wake-up call to American leaders who seem to think that our economic strength can continue to erode without threatening our national security, our prosperity and our very way of life.'' Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, who has lost several battles inside the administration pushing for more economic support for U.S. industry, sent best wishes. Among the new institute's financial backers are Ford Motor Co., Chrysler Corp., TRW Inc. and Motorola Inc. Among union backers are the AFL-CIO, the United Auto Workers and the United Steelworkers. Prestowitz, who has argued in the past about heavy Japanese spending on Washington lobbying, said the institute had not received any financial backing from Japan. But ``we wouldn't turn it down, if it showed up on our doorstep,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Suicide Machine: Doctor Defends Death Device
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with husband's news conference, contents of suicide note, picks up 24th graf pvs, `The device...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT2
DOC.TEXT: An Alzheimer's patient traveled 2,000 miles to commit suicide with the help of a doctor who built a device that gave her a lethal dose of chemicals. The last thing Janet Adkins told Dr. Jack Kevorkian on Monday was, ``You just make my case known.'' Then, he said, she pressed a button on the contraption and released the lethal mixture. Some medical ethicists called the doctor's actions immoral and perhaps illegal. A prosecutor said he would wait for autopsy results before deciding whether to charge Kevorkian, and will seek an injunction to prevent the doctor from using the device again. Kevorkian told The Associated Press in a telephone interview late Tuesday that it was the first time he had used the device to assist a suicide. The Portland, Ore., woman's husband defended his wife's right to die. ``She loved life. She just lived life to the fullest,'' Ron Adkins said Tuesday night in a news conference in Portland. ``She was a powerful woman and she was an intelligent woman. ``I was the weak one. She was strong. She had made up her mind.'' One of the couple's three sons, Neil, said, ``She was in a very good state of mind, that's the amazing thing. ``It was not a desperate thing or a depressed situation. She was the one that helped us all through it,'' Neil Adkins told KGW-TV in Portland. Kevorkian said Mrs. Adkins traveled to Michigan during the weekend to use his suicide device. He drove the 54-year-old woman in his van to a park in northern Oakland County on Monday afternoon. According to Kevorkian, he and one of his relatives attached Mrs. Adkins to a heart monitor, then put an intravenous tube in her arm. The tube first delivered a saline solution. Kevorkian said Mrs. Adkins then pressed a button that injected thiopental, a coma-inducing drug, followed moments later by potassium chloride, which stops the heart within minutes. He said she was unconscious in 25 seconds, and died in five or six minutes. ``It simulates exactly the judicial executions that we do now with legal executions, except with this device the person does it himself by pushing a button,'' Kevorkian told The Detroit News on Monday. ``The last thing Janet Adkins said was, `You just make my case known,''' said Kevorkian. The doctor is a retired pathologist and an outspoken advocate of what he calls doctor-assisted suicide. ``Physicians should not be killers, even in cases where the patient requests it and there is a compassionate reason behind the act,'' said Susan Wolf of the Hastings Center for bio-medical research in Briarcliff, N.Y. ``They take an oath to do no harm, and taking a life is doing harm.'' Kevorkian said in March that he expected to be prosecuted after the first use of the drug-injecting device. He also said he would not charge patients and that he might use it to take his own life some day. Adkins and her husband spent several hours by themselves before she and the doctor drove to the park, Kevorkian said late Tuesday. ``I wasn't there, but from what I understand, it was very emotional and very prolonged. Obviously, this was the last time they would see each other,'' he said. After Mrs. Adkins died, Kevorkian notified police. Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson said he won't decide if he will bring charges against the doctor until he gets an autopsy report and state police finish their investigation. The police have the device, Thompson added. Kevorkian said Adkins came to Michigan with her husband and a friend, both of whom stayed at a motel while she died and caught a flight back to Oregon later Monday night. In Oregon, providing the means to commit suicide is a felony, but Michigan has no law against suicide assisted by a physician. Kevorkian said the Adkinses contacted him in October after learning about his device, and he recommended treatment with an experimental drug at a Seattle hospital. But it didn't work, Ron Adkins said. His wife of 34 years left a suicide letter, which read, in part: ``I have Alzheimer's disease and do not want to let it progress any farther. I don't choose to put my family or myself through the agony of this terrible disease.'' The device itself _ an aluminum frame with three suspended bottles and a small electric motor _ is not illegal, said Gerald Poisson, assistant Oakland County prosecutor. But in certain cases, the person who made it available to the suicide victim could be charged with homicide, he said Tuesday. Jim Baughman of the Wayne County Prosecutor's Office in Detroit said last year that helping someone die would not be a crime if the patient injected the drugs. But two lawyers specializing in medical ethics, after hearing details of the Kevorkian case, said his actions were improper. ``What this physician did was way over the line,'' said Wolf. ``It was unethical and may well have been illegal.'' According to the American Medical Association, passive euthanasia is ethical, said Reinhard Priester of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota. Passive euthanasia might, for example, involve withholding food from a comatose patient believed to have no chance of recovery, he said. But Priester said Kevorkian, by arranging a suicide ostensibly with the patient's consent, appeared to have participated in active euthanasia _ which the AMA has deemed morally inappropriate. ``The clear intent of providing those two chemicals was to hasten the patient's death,'' Priester said. The New York City-based Society for the Right to Die supports people's right to refuse medical treatment, but in general doesn't support assisted suicide, said director Rose Gasner. ``He's pushing the boundaries,'' she said. ``It's uncharted legal territory.''

DOC.HEAD: New Test Promising in Diagnosing Alzheimer's Disease, Researchers Say
With PM-Suicide Machine, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A lab test to diagnose Alzheimer's disease in the living could be developed within two years using a new technique that has been highly accurate on brain tissue from cadavers, scientists say. Currently, there is no precise way of diagnosing the memory-robbing disease in the living. Doctors make a diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms. After death, an autopsy can help confirm the diagnosis, but the technique now in use is inexact. The new test measures a protein that is believed to be associated with Alzheimer's and has not been detected in the brains of normal people and those with other neurological disorders, said neurobiochemist Hossein A. Ghanbari, lead author of the study in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``The importance of this finding is that the protein can be used later on as a model to come up with a diagnostic test in spinal fluid,'' said Ghanbari, senior research scientist at Abbott Laboratories in suburban North Chicago. The test for living patients could come within two years but would need to be 1,000 times more sensitive, Ghanbari said in a telephone interview Tuesday. The protein, which researchers call the Alzheimer's disease-related protein, was found in 48 of 56 Alzheimer's patients, the scientists reported. No detectable levels of the protein were found in autopsied brain tissue from 27 patients free of neurological disease and 28 patients with neurological diseases other than Alzheimer's, the researchers said. Since they submitted their report, they have tested about 240 more brain samples and ``still have about a 90 percent agreement with the diagnosis,'' Ghanbari said. An estimated 4 million U.S. adults, mostly over age 65, have Alzheimer's a degenerative brain and nerve disorder. Death usually comes in five to 10 years after complications from bed sores, feeding problems and pneumonia. Diagnosis depends mostly on looking for symptoms, which begin with memory loss and difficulty speaking and progress to personality changes and loss of ability to function. Doctors adopt the process of elimination, ruling out one by one other causes of the dementia, such as syphillis or poisoning. Even after autopsy, current methods are inexact for diagnosing Alzheimer's. Confirming the diagnosis in patients who have died requires dissecting the brain, examining stained samples under a microscope and counting the characteristic nerve tangles and hardened deposits, or plaques, of Alzheimer's. ``The neuropathologist has to decide which ones to count and which ones not to count,'' said Creighton Phelps, vice president for medical and scientific affairs with the Chicago-based Alzheimer's Association. ``It's subjective. ``This new test would remove the subjective component _ either it's there or it's not,'' Phelps said. As such, it would be ``the only quantitative test that we have.'' The test will need confirmation by other scientists, said Phelps, a former program director at the National Institute on Aging's Neuroscience and Neuropsychology of Aging Program. Using the test now on brain samples from living patients makes little sense, since no cure and no effective treatment for Alzheimer's exists, and brain biopsy involves some risk, Ghanbari said. The protein identified in the study includes a sub-protein called A68 described in 1986 as a possible marker for Alzheimer's by researcher Peter Davies of Albert Einstein College of Medicine of Yeshiva University in New York, Ghanbari said. Davies was a co-author of the new study, funded partly by Abbott and supported by the National Institute of Mental Health. The protein differs from a defective blood protein called transferrin described last month in the British journal Lancet by scientists who thought it might help lead to a diagnostic test for the disease, Ghanbari said.

DOC.HEAD: With Threat of Soviet Blockade Fading, West Berlin Wants to Scrap Reserves
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: For more than four decades, West Berliners have been stockpiling huge quantities of provisions to keep the city alive in case of another Soviet blockade. City officials now say that changing times have made the warehouses _ filled with sugar, grain, bandages, toothpaste and hundreds of other items _ unnecessary. ``This is a relic of the Cold War,'' said Gerhard Erbe, the city official in charge of supervising a large portion of the emergency reserves. The Germans began stockpiling on the orders of the victorious Western Allies _ the United States, France and Britain _ after the Berlin Airlift broke the traumatic Soviet blockade in May 1949. West Berlin's leftist leaders say the federal government in Bonn should ask the allies for permission to scrap the whole program for the city of 2 million people. City government economics chief Peter Mitzscherling has even suggested giving the food and other supplies to Eastern European nations, where democracy has replaced Cold War Stalinism. West Berlin officials decline to give a breakdown of how much is stored, saying it's still kept top secret to keep the ``potential enemy'' from learning details of the plans. ``The goal is, in the event of another blockade, to provide the city with all necessary goods,'' Erbe said. ``It was also to have a calming effect on the people.'' Erbe said the goods, stored in 200 separate locations, are to last as rations for a ``long period of time,'' but he declined to specify how long. One of the storehouses is located in teeming Westhafen along the Spandau shipping canal, where sacks of sugar, medicines and thousands of cases of jarred of fruit are carefully stored. Horst Kleffel, who supervises part of the program for the federal government, said the plan was to have enough food on hand for six months. But he concedes that ``Some things we now have in smaller quantities.'' The Berliner Morgenpost newspaper has reported that 166,444 tons of grain, 38,752 tons of canned vegetables and 493,668 tons of light heating oil are stored. The goods are routinely sold off and restocked to ensure that everything is usable. Over the years the stockpiled goods have provided great comfort to Berliners, especially the elderly, who remember how their city was torn apart by the collapse of Nazi Germany in 1945 and shut off from the world by the Soviet blockade three years later. The Soviets tried to starve the Western part of the city into submission, blocking passengers and traffic starting in June 1948. For 10{ months, a massive Western airlift organized by the United States kept the city alive. Even though the Four Power agreement of 1971 set aside many of the disputes with the Soviets, the emergency reserves stayed in this city 100 miles within then-Communist East Germany. The federal government in Bonn provides about $125 million a year to maintain the reserves, which could be worth up to $1.6 billion. As officials look around to save money during the enormously expensive unification process, the reserves have become a likely target for savings. They have also been the subject of sarcasm. ``The West Berlin city government even wanted to start getting rid of the huge supplies of toilet paper, since according to state secretary (Juergen) Dittberner, people could just use a newspaper in an emergency,'' the Frankfurter Rundschau quoted the city's No. 2 economics official as saying. ``But at the prompting of the federal government, the toilet paper stayed,'' the newspaper said. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government must study the request to halt the program before deciding whether to pass it on to the Western Allies. Anthony W. Sariti, U.S. diplomatic spokesman in Berlin, said it is not certain what answer the Allies will give, but ``given the tenor of the times, I can't imagine we would give it unsympathetic hearing.'' Selling off the stockpiles could take three or more years. The list of stockpiled items includes soap, cleaning materials, coffee, fish, meat as well as clothing for children. Erbe said one thing is missing: dog food to feed Berliners' adored pooches. ``People would have to share their own rations with their dogs,'' he said with a laugh.

DOC.HEAD: Consultant Convicted of Conspiracy in Procurement Case
DOC.TEXT: A former defense consultant was convicted of conspiring to funnel sensitive military procurement data to a corporation bidding on a $100 million project. A U.S. District Court jury on Tuesday found Mark C. Saunders guilty of conspiracy, conversion of government property and six counts of wire fraud. He was the fourth person convicted by trial in the Operation Ill Wind investigation into Pentagon fraud. The jury found that Saunders was a middleman in a scheme to pass confidential government information from George G. Stone, a Navy procurement director, to Thomas Muldoon, a defense consultant for Norden Systems Inc. Witnesses said Muldoon then sold the information to Norden, one of 10 companies competing for a contract to design sophisticated radar and communications systems for the Marine Corps. Norden, which was one of the final four companies considered for the contract, dropped out of the competition when the investigation began. Thirty-four individuals and corporations have pleaded guilty as a result of the Ill Wind investigation, which began nearly two years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Police Arrest Black Activist in `Wanted' Posters Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Willye is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Police charged a black critic of school desegregation with distributing ``wanted'' posters offering $10,000 for the slayings of seven blacks negotiating an integration plan. Ralph Leon Stephens, 47, was arrested Tuesday and jailed on charges of soliciting murder. He also was charged with extortion. ``This is a very serious matter,'' State Attorney Ed Austin said. ``But it is just a crime. It is not a racially motivated crime.'' ``It appears to be a struggle in the black community,'' Sheriff Jim McMillan said. The posters declared the seven black leaders were ``wanted dead or alive for self-serving crimes, murdering our kids future! Shoot on sight. $10,000 price guarantee.'' The seven are key players in negotiations with school officials to devise a desegregation plan that complies with a federal court order. Stephens is a member of a committee opposed to local desegregation plans, the sheriff said. School security officials, the sheriff's office and the FBI began investigating the posters after they appeared on May 26. Police began hourly patrols around the homes of those named on the posters: School Board members Wendell Holmes and Samuel Nesbitt, National Association for the Advancement of Colored People education chairman Fred Matthews, Jacksonville Urban League President Ronnie Ferguson, the Rev. Rudolph Missick, Assistant Superintendent Alvin White and Willye Dennis, president of the local chapter of the NAACP. In December, a package bomb similiar to those that killed a federal appeals court judge and a Savannah, Ga., lawyer was intercepted at Mrs. Dennis' office before it exploded. ``There is no connection at all to the earlier bombing threat to Mrs. Dennis and the NAACP,'' McMillan said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Report Says Children Face Greater Risks From Pollution
DOC.TEXT: Children face far greater risks from global pollution than do adults, a United Nations report says. ``Children are too often the victims of pollution _ their young bodies make them far more vulnerable than adults to the poisons we spew into the air, and toxins we sow on Earth,'' said the UNICEF report. The report by the U.N. Children's Fund, titled ``Children and the Environment,'' was compiled in association with the U.N. Environment Program and was released on Tuesday, World Environment Day. It listed many of the ills facing children in developing and developed countries alike. Forty thousand children under the age of five die daily, it said. About 100 million children live on the streets, where they are forced to scavenge, steal and often fall prey to drugs, prostitution and gangs, it said. An increasing number of children are AIDS orphans, whose parents have died from the dread disease, it said. The number of children living in poverty in the United States has risen by more than 3 million over the last 10 years, the report said. Despite the discouraging news of poverty, sickness and death, the report said improved international cooperation on the environment offers hope, as does the thawing of the Cold War. ``The ending of the Cold War provides a unique opportunity for the great powers to confront the real threats to planetary survival,'' the report said. Sir Richard Attenborough, speaking at a London news conference where the report was introduced, called on governments and banks in developed countries to work together on the Third World's ``appalling debt.'' ``We give less to the Third World than we receive. Ten years ago $40 billion went from the developed world to developing countries; now that figure is $60 billion but it's going in the opposite direction. It is a shaming thought,'' said Attenborough, who received an Academy Award for directing the 1982 film ``Gandhi.'' The report emphasized ``our generation's responsibility to protect the Earth we bequeath our children'' and suggested that priority be given to improving infant mortality rates and education in developing countries. ``Efforts to lower births, however well planned, cannot fully succeed unless they are accompanied by basic programs to protect child health and ensure child survival,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Easing Lending Restrictions on S&Ls
DOC.TEXT: Under pressure from builders and Congress, federal regulators are moving to ease lending restrictions imposed on savings and loans under last year's bailout law. The Office of Thrift Supervision is proposing to temporarily quadruple to 60 percent the percentage of capital that a qualified thrift institution may lend to one borrower, an agency official said Tuesday. The office was under intense pressure from lawmakers who were inundated with complaints from builders that the rule was forcing them to curtail projects, putting their employees out of work. Last year's S&L legislation had sharply reduced the lending limit, aiming to sever the cozy relationship between highflying S&Ls and some developers. In the past, loan limits were so high that the default of a single loan could bankrupt a thrift. However, builders complained that the shift was too abrupt and left many reputable builders unable to arrange alternative financing for sound projects. Last month, the National Association of Homebuilders cited the regulation as one element in a credit crunch they predicted would cut housing construction nationally by 100,000 units to 1.28 million this year. Under a draft regulation submitted by the thrift agency to the Treasury Department and the Office of Management and Budget, the strongest S&Ls would be allowed to lend up to 60 percent of their capital to a single U.S. developer for residential construction. That is four times the 15 percent limit imposed by S&L bailout legislation enacted last August. The limit would drop to 30 percent before returning to the 15 percent mark at the end of 1991, said the thrift office official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Before passage of the S&L bailout law, thrifts had been allowed to lend 100 percent of their capital to one borrower. The new transition rule would not apply to commercial projects, and only S&Ls currently meeting strict capital standards effective in 1995 would be eligible. The thrift office official said 1,185 of the nation's 2,502 solvent S&Ls meet the test. ``This will give us some breathing room,'' said economist David Seiders of the homebuilders group. ``We think it will provide a lot of help.'' The association had been pushing for a somewhat longer transition period and had wanted regulators to make a larger group of thrifts eligible for the relaxation. But, Seiders said, ``This is a step in the right direction.'' The homebuilders had mounted a campaign in Congress, where legislators in both chambers were preparing amendments to the S&L law. A transition rule proposed by Rep. Peter Hoagland, D-Neb., had attracted more than 60 cosponsors. However, Seiders said the builders all along had been looking for relief from regulators rather than having to wait months for Congress to change the law. Details of the loan-to-one-borrower proposal were first reported in Tuesday editions of American Banker, a trade newspaper. The thrift office hopes to formally announce the policy by the end of the month, the agency official said. Regulators, in testimony to a House Banking subcommittee in February, indicated that last year's law left them with no discretion to issue a transition rule. However, Treasury Undersecretary Robert Glauber told the Senate Banking Committee in May that thrift office lawyers were working to establish their authority to interpret the law. Seiders praised Timothy Ryan, the new director of the thrift office, for his willingness to review the matter after taking office two months ago. ``We think it's a good sign in terms of (prospects for) working with Ryan'' and the agency, the homebuilders official said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Baucus Wins Renomination; Republicans Vie To Challenge Him
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Kolstad winning, results; picks up after dash. Matter below dash will stand.
DOC.TEXT: Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad on Tuesday defeated three fellow Republicans for the right to challenge Sen. Max Baucus in a bid to repeat the GOP's 1988 feat of knocking off a Democratic incumbent. Baucus, seeking his third term, had no trouble turning back a challenge for the Democratic nomination from John Driscoll, a Public Service Commission member, and evangelist Curly Thornton. With 694 of 967 precincts reporting, Kolstad had 27,250 votes, or 42 percent, to 23,352 votes, or 36 percent, for businessman and scientist Bruce Vorhauer; 8,569 votes, or 13 percent for state Sen. Bill Farrell; and 4,981 votes, or 8 percent, for former business executive John Domenech. In the Democratic race, Baucus had 61,054 votes, or 83 percent, to 9,538 votes for Driscoll, or 13 percent, and 3,192 votes for Thornton, or 4 percent.

The Senate race was the only major contest on the Montana ballot. Republicans are hoping for a replay this fall of the 1988 general election, when Conrad Burns, a relatively unknown county commissioner from Billings, toppled veteran Democratic Sen. John Melcher. National Republicans, including President Bush and former President Ronald Reagan, searched for a well-known Republican to challenge Baucus. They recruited Kolstad, 58, who became lieutenant governor only 17 months ago. Kolstad emphasized his farming background, his 20 years in the state Legislature and his lifelong ties to Montana. The emphasis also was a slap at Vorhauer, who moved his legal residence to Montana only last fall. Vorhauer, 48, is best known as the inventor of the Today contraceptive sponge. His campaign stressed his engineering and science background as qualifying him to bring high-tech businesses to the state. Farrell, 41, a trucking company owner, touted his working-man image. Domenech, 36, campaigned for a national health plan. Baucus ran a quiet primary campaign, with neither of his challengers having much money or elaborate organizations. Baucus has raised about $2 million, citing the Republican challenge he will face this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Festival of Robbin's Ballets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will stand for PMs.
DOC.TEXT: ``Jerome Robbins' Broadway'' is on Broadway. Jerome Robbins' Ballet is at the New York State Theater in Lincoln Center. There, the New York City Ballet began ``A Festival of Jerome Robbins' Ballets'' on Tuesday night. It will last through June 17. Seven programs are danced twice and one only once. Two impressions burst out at Tuesday's opening. Wow, what a choreographer. Golly, what a company. The evening began with Robbins' famous ``Fancy Free,'' his first ballet, with music by Leonard Bernstein and scenery by Oliver Smith. Three sailors, feeling the emotion of the title, are on shore leave in New York on a hot summer night in 1944, the year Robbins choreographed it. The sailors who danced, chased girls and then teased and flirted with them were Damian Woetzel, Tom Gold and Robert LaFosse. They weren't as exuberant as some we've seen dance this ballet but their dancing was so crisp and their characterizations so good they looked like they'd been drilled by Robbins. The original trio of sailors was Harold Lang, John Kriza and Robbins. This performance was dedicated to the memory of Kriza. ``Ives, Songs,'' from 1988 was very different. Much of it is nostalgic. Maria Calegari and Stephanie Saland were listed as stars but all 39 who danced looked so good one would like to list them all. David Evitts, accompanied by James Winn, sang poems by Ives, his wife, Longfellow, Whittier, Lord Byron and Keats that Ives set to music. Three ``little girls'' and two ``little boys'' played as a man with gray hair watched, adding to the poignance as the audience watched both. ``Tom Sails Away'' was another poignant song, as a sailor's family group assembles, in his memory. Then he steps away from them. In ``Ives, Songs,'' Robbins did some very clever things, created some calm and beautiful moments, made some interesting abstract dances. The evening's final ballet was ``Fanfare,'' from 1945, created to celebrate the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II. The music is Britten's ``The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra.'' Dancers, representing the instruments, dance short variations while narrator David Jaffe says which instrument is being heard _ and seen. Robbins, a choreographer who can make an audience laugh, created funny parts for the bassoons, Tracy Bennett and Albert Evans, and percussion, Jean-Pierre Frohlick, Peter Boal and LaFosse. A minute of silence was observed before ``Fanfare'' in support of the National Endowment for the Arts. The audience hoped to see Robbins take a bow but he did not.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Michael Jackson, hospitalized for chest pains, has been under pressure to finish an album and was distressed by the deaths of his grandmother, AIDS victim Ryan White and Sammy Davis Jr., says a spokesman. Jackson, 31, had been ill several days when he suffered pains Sunday at home and was brought to St. John's Hospital and Health Center. Jackson's cardiologist said a ``temporary setback'' in his condition Monday delayed tests to find the cause of his pain, and the singer may have to remain in the hospital for another day or two, spokesman Bob Jones said Tuesday. ``In the meantime, Mr. Jackson remains under observation. His condition is stable and he is resting comfortably,'' Jones said at a news conference. It wasn't believed that Jackson, described by Jones as ``a health nut,'' had a heart attack.

Amid speculation that he is ready to quit television to run for the U.S. Senate, Phil Donahue says don't count on it _ yet. ``I'm obliged to do the show until 1992, so any political plans I might make would not go into effect until the 1994 elections,'' the talk show host said in the June 9 issue of TV Guide. ``I'm really very undecided at this time.'' The 23-year TV veteran, a Democrat, said he wonders ``how electable I'd be in the age of `read my lips.' I'm pro-choice. I support gay rights. I think the invasion of Panama was a bad idea, and I think we ought to be able to burn the flag.''

Joe Isuzu will be selling Isuzu vehicles FOREVER. (Oh no he won't.) Joe, the pathological liar played by actor David Leisure, won't be back in American Isuzu Motors Inc. commercials when the carmaker introduces its 1991 lineup of vehicles, said the Della Femina, McNamee WCRS advertising agency. The agency created Joe Isuzu in commercials that began in 1986. The ads poked fun at carmaker claims. Joe would lie outrageously in touting Isuzu vehicles. The ads usually carried subtitles correcting his claims. Leisure has found other work on television, however. He stars in the NBC comedy ``Empty Nest.'' (Honest.)

``Gonzo'' journalist Hunter S. Thompson says he's tired after his near-miss with a drug trial, though he believes he would have crushed the prosecution ``like rotten eggs.'' ``It was going to be fun,'' Thompson said this week after eating a 3 p.m. breakfast at the Woody Creek Tavern. ``We were going to cut them into small chunks and slivers.'' Four felony drug and explosives charges and three misdemeanor charges against Thompson were dropped last week. Thompson, 53, was charged after Gail Palmer-Slater, a former porn film producer, accused him of grabbing her breast and throwing a drink at her when she visited his home Feb. 21 to interview him for a story she planned to write. Prosecutors decided they didn't have enough evidence to convict him. ``Frankly, I'm suffering a letdown,'' Thompson said. ``I was just getting in the mood to get on their level. We would have crushed them like eggs, rotten eggs.''

Dean Stockwell, who dropped out of the public eye at age 15 after appearing on Broadway and in several movies, found nobody wanted him when he was ready to drop back in _ until he ran into David Lynch. And Lynch, co-producer of ABC's ``Twin Peaks,'' told TV Guide in its June 9 issue that he had presumed Stockwell was dead. Now Stockwell's career is very much alive. He won a Golden Globe award for his work on NBC's ``Quantum Leap.'' Stockwell, 54, first acted professionally at 6 in a Broadway play and was signed to a seven-year MGM contract. He made several films, including ``The Boy with Green Hair.'' But he hated the attention and at age 15 dropped out ``to become anonymous, to disappear,'' Stockwell said. When he tried to make a comeback, ``I couldn't get work for a long, long time,'' he said. Then Lynch ran into him in Mexico City while working on a movie. ``This person looked familiar, but (I told myself) it couldn't be who I thought it was, and it made me feel a little nutty,'' Lynch said. ``Then I realized it was Dean, and he was alive.'' Lynch eventually cast Stockwell in the movie ``Dune'' and later in ``Blue Velvet.''

Charlie Rose is leaving the overnight CBS interview program ``Nightwatch'' for a daily interview show on the Fox network. The Emmy winner who has headed ``Nightwatch'' since it began in 1984 will join ``Personalities'' as its anchorman, Fox announced Tuesday. Rose also has been anchorman on ``Face the Nation,'' ``CBS Morning News,'' ``CBS This Morning'' and ``Newsbreak.''

Ex-fighter Joey Barnum says he offered a story from his boxing career for the upcoming ``Rocky V'' movie _ and Sylvester Stallone stole it. Barnum filed a plagiarism lawsuit Tuesday in federal court against Stallone; Stallone's mother, Jacqueline; Stallone's brother, Frank; and other defendants, including MGM-UA Distribution Co. Barnum, now a bail bondsman, seeks $600,000 damages plus gross receipts from ``Rocky V.'' Barnum, once the No. 3 lightweight contender during the 1940s, became a trainer and got in an argument with a boxer who broke training rules. The boxer cut Barnum's lip and Barnum sold all his managing contracts to get in the ring with him, said Joe Seide, Barnum's manager. ``It was one of the biggest grudge fights of the late '40s. Joey Barnum won and cut him up bad,'' Seide said. The story was the subject of a TV special in 1955, Seide said. More recently, ``He submitted the story idea to Stallone. He was good friends with Jacqueline and Frank,'' Seide said. Stallone spokesman Paul Bloch said that he was unaware of the lawsuit and that the defendants had no comment.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Says British Beef is Safe
DOC.TEXT:
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher says the French and West German bans on British beef are ``quite illegal'' and insists there was no health danger. ``British beef is safe,'' the prime minister said in the House of Commons Tuesday. ``Those who have banned it have done so more as a measure of protection for their own farmers.'' France and West Germany both banned the import of British beef after the discovery that some cattle were infected with bovie spongiform encephlopathy, or mad cow disease. The disease, identified in Britain in 1986, is blamed for killing 13,648 cows here.
The British government warned Tuesday that it would be forced to retaliate in kind against the bans if they are not lifted at today's emergency meeting of the European Community agriculture ministers in Brussels. Conservative Party lawmaker John Watts said it would be improper for Britain to respond in kind, but he urged British consumers to use their purchasing power to boycott French goods, including ``appalling French Golden Delicious apples.'' Another Tory, Alan Amos, was cheered when he said he had eaten British beef for lunch and medical evidence showed it was ``perfectly safe.'' French beef producers told their government Tuesday that they wanted the ban on imports extended to beef from Ireland, which has had 19 cases of bovie spongiform encephlopathy. The cause of ``mad cow'' disease is unknown. Because the symptoms are similar to scrapie, a sheep disease, it is assumed the disease was transmitted through cattle feeds.

DOC.HEAD: Intelligence Center Plan Draws Congressional Criticism
DOC.TEXT: The administration's plan to create a new National Drug Intelligence Center to coordinate information on drug traffickers is being criticized on Capitol Hill as an improper use of scarce money. Justice Department officials briefed congressional appropriations panels and other executive agencies Tuesday on a detailed plan for NDIC, which was proposed in President Bush's National Drug Control Strategy earlier this year. Several lawmakers questioned the proposal to spend money for the center when some law enforcement agencies don't have enough money to hire needed agents, one congressional aide said later. ``There is a general concern that this was not one of the No. 1 priorities, that the top priority should be staffing up the law enforcement agencies on the street,'' said the staffer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``There's still a lot of questions, things that are unanswered, such as how are we going to pay for it,'' another aide said. The plan outlined in a Justice Department study calls for no money to be spent this fiscal year, ending Sept. 30. However, NDIC would cost about $8.1 million next year and $45.9 million in fiscal 1992, when it would be fully operational with 150 employees. The first two years include many non-recurring costs for such things as computer equipment, so the estimated annual cost after that would drop to $26.7 million, the report said. The study said the money should come from the special forfeiture fund in the Office of National Drug Control Policy, headed by William J. Bennett. That money is seized from drug traffickers. The NDIC came in for criticism even before the Justice Department presented its report. Last month, three members of the House Armed Services investigations subcommittee said that instead of creating a new center, the El Paso Intelligence Center in Texas should be improved. That facility, run by the Drug Enforcement Administration, coordinates tactical information to be used immediately, such as the location of a possibly drug-laden aircraft. It does not provide long-range strategic information. ``There is a propensity to proliferate intelligence fusion centers, as if the administration believed the more intelligence centers we created, the better intelligence product we would gain,'' Reps. Nicholas Mavroules, D-Mass.; Lane Evans, D-Ill.; and Jim McCrery, R-La., said in a report. ``But quantity is not quality.'' Privately, some Justice Department officials agreed but said Bennett's office had pushed hard for the new intelligence center and the proposal reflects a good compromise. Justice Department spokeswoman Harri J. Kramer said the need for NDIC became apparent ``in the course of involving other non-traditional agencies in the drug war, such as the Defense Department.'' ``An enhanced mechanism for coordinating interaction between the intelligence community and the law enforcement community were also needed,'' Kramer said. ``The NDIC will play an important role in addressing these two gaps as well as to refine the process of establishing intelligence collection priorities.'' Bennett's office applauded the Justice Department proposal. ``It is exactly what the president calls for'' in his drug control strategy, spokeswoman Amy Brown said. NDIC will involve the DEA, FBI, Immigration and Naturalization Service, Customs Service, Coast Guard, CIA, National Security Agency and the State, Defense and Treasury departments.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Finally Burying the West _ By Fax
DOC.TEXT: The Soviets are making good on Nikita Khrushchev's prediction that they'll bury the West. But they're doing it with fax paper. ``If politically countries are changing, why should information agencies work in the same manner, the old manner,'' said Alexander Malyshkin, senior information officer for the Soviet Embassy. The Soviets, it seems, have discovered what everyone from pro-democracy dissidents in China to American restaurants learned before _ that the fax machine is a quick and stealthy way to get your information where it hasn't gone before. It's glasnost for the information age, and the Soviets used it with a vengeance during last week's superpower summit. ``I have been just inundated. ... Our fax machine has been going almost constantly,'' Frank Partsch, editorial page editor of the Omaha World-Herald, said Tuesday. Partsch said he was holding 30 to 40 pages of Soviet material, about half what spewed out of his facsimile machine during the summit. ``It's the first time I've ever seen this,'' said Bob Haring, executive editor of the Tulsa World, who received 20 to 30 pages of faxed material from the Soviet Embassy in Washington. The Soviets say it's nothing unusual, just another embassy using technology _ a Japanese-made fax machine, that is _ to reach the media. ``It's very effective,'' said embassy spokesman Boris Malakhov, who said the embassy press office fax was in use ``constantly'' to issue press advisories on President Mikhail Gorbachev's visit. But getting a fax from behind the Iron Curtain strikes some recipients as unusual, and the Soviets say they're restructuring their use of technology to get the word out about changes inside their country. ``We're using modern know-how to reach newspapers,'' Malyshkin said. ``American media is very fast, you know.'' He said his office has one fax machine and aides work all the time to relay articles by the official Novosti Press Agency, opinion pieces by Soviet officials and even lighthearted features on life in the Soviet republics. Malyshkin said he didn't know how many faxes his office sent out last week. But if calls to a handful of newspapers are any indication, there may be more openness than the American media can handle. ``I haven't had a chance to do anything with them,'' said Virginia Hall, opinion pages editor of the Kansas City Star, where about 10 Soviet faxes on various topics arrived. ``I haven't had a chance to read it,'' Partsch said from Omaha. ``There's a lot of it and I don't like faxes.''

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Pilot Pleads Guilty to Five Felony Charges
DOC.TEXT: Thomas Root, the lawyer whose mysterious Atlantic Ocean plane crash last year came amid a probe of his law practice, faces up to 35 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines on his guilty plea to felony charges of misrepresenting clients. Root, an Alexandria, Va., communications attorney, pleaded guilty to five felony counts in federal court Tuesday. The charges involved clients who were seeking broadcast licenses from the Federal Communications Commission. He was indicted Monday by a grand jury in North Carolina on 455 counts of securities fraud and other charges. A federal grand jury in Washington had returned a 33-count indictment against Root in March. Root, 37, declined comment after entering his plea. Root's attorney, Eugene Propper, said Root ``feels he's getting a lot more attention'' than he otherwise would because of the July 13, 1989, flight. Root's Cessna 210 airplane crashed in the Atlantic off the Bahamas after a mysterious six-hour flight in which he said he blacked out and the plane continued on autopilot until it hit the water. But Navy fighter pilots who intercepted the flight said they saw Root moving in the cockpit. Rescuers discovered Root had a gunshot wound to his stomach, which still has not been explained. Root says he does not know how he got shot. Root has denied that financial and legal troubles were connected with the flight. Indicted with Root by the Nash Country, N.C., grand jury, were Sonrise Management Services, Telemedia Inc. and three other men identified as co-owners of the two businesses. Root handled radio license applications for investors of Sonrise Management. The indictments allege the companies violated securities laws by not registering securities, failing to register sales agents, engaging in false and deceptive sales practices and conspiring to violate securities laws. In the federal case, Root on Tuesday admitted giving the FCC a counterfeit document stating that the Federal Aviation Administration had approved a proposed Missouri site for a radio tower. He also said he gave a North Carolina client a forged FCC document indicating its license application had been reinstated, and defrauded another North Carolina client by settling a claim against a competitor for one-fifth the authorized amount. Root pleaded guilty to giving a false document to a New York client seeking a site on Long Island for a radio station, and falsely telling another client he would get an FCC application reinstated when he had sought the dismissal. The former Missouri client, Monte Hanson, president of Northern Missouri Christian Broadcasting Co. of Kirksville, said his company had retained a new attorney and is still seeking an FCC license for its proposed station. ``We're still working with the FCC and FAA to iron out the problems that (Root) caused,'' Hanson said. The Columbus, Ga.-based Sonrise Management, which touted Christian principles in sales literature and issued business cards inscribed with crosses, went out of business several months ago. North Carolina Secretary of State Rufus Edmisten said only a handful of Sonrise Management investors ever received FCC licenses. ``In all, 1,018 people in North Carolina contributed more than $8 million to this organization,'' Edmisten said. ``Nationally, more than $16 million was invested by people from 25 states.'' Edmisten said there was little chance investors would recoup their money.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.: No Marine Involvement In Liberian Civil War
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines are waiting off the coast of Liberia in case they are needed to evacuate American citizens from that nation's strife, but not to support either side in the civil war, U.S. officials say. ``The U.S. military has no role to play in this conflict,'' State Department spokesman Richard Boucher told reporters Tuesday. Despite pleas from embattled President Samuel Doe that the United States ``come to the aid'' of the Liberian people, officials in Washington reject the idea of U.S. military involvement. ``Our primary concern is protecting U.S. citizens,'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said. In addition, though, the United States agreed to evacuate Soviet diplomats from Liberia if necessary, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said in an interview Tuesday with Hearst Newspapers. ``It hasn't been required yet, but the fact of the matter is they (the Soviets) have asked for _ and we have agreed _ to provide assistance to their people in Liberia,'' Cheney said in the interview. Between 10 and 15 Soviet diplomats remained in Liberia, the Hearst report said. Boucher, in a statement read to reporters, said the United States ``is taking appropriate steps to assist American citizens to leave Liberia in the event that they are in more immediate danger and no longer able to leave the country by other means.'' The Navy's four-ship flotilla in international waters off the Liberian coast ``solely on a contingency basis to evacuate American citizens if it becomes necessary,'' Boucher said. Fitzwater reported that 70 U.S. officials and about 1,200 American private citizens were left in the country. President Bush dispatched the warships from the Mediterranean-based 6th Fleet over the weekend in case the struggle between forces loyal to Doe and those supporting rebel leader Charles Taylor bar any Americans from leaving. The USS Saipan, an amphibious assault ship; the USS Ponce, an amphibious transport dock ship; the USS Sumter, a tank landing ship, and the USS Peterson, an escort destroyer, are off the Liberian coast. As transport or evacuation aircraft, ships like the Saipan usually carry nine CH-53 ``Sea Stallion'' helicopters and 12 CH-46 ``Sea Knight'' helicopters.
