Such assault ships also carry AV-8B Harrier jets, which serve as light attack and close air support aircraft. All of the ships are homeported in Norfolk, Va., and carry about 170 officers and about 2,100 enlisted Marines, the Navy said. Boucher said the rebels continued to advance towards the capital of Monrovia and that flights had been suspended from Roberts International Airport, where there were reports of fighting. The spokesman said commercial aircraft were continuing to use Spriggs Payne Airfield, about five miles from the center of the capital city, and that the road to Sierra Leone ``remains usable.'' At the Pentagon, spokesman Pete Williams stressed the precautionary nature of the deployment of the Marine group. He said he couldn't define any ``trigger'' that might bring them ashore to assist in an evacuation, including the event that all air travel would be stopped. He said he had no indication that there were Americans who wanted to leave but couldn't. Williams declined to outline any plan for a possible evacuation, citing security concerns. But he said the Marines could be used for such things as ``providing security at the airport, or assisting Americans in leaving from some other point _ out to the ships, or to another country.''

DOC.HEAD: `Simpsons' Ahead of `Cosby' on Repeat Week
With PM-Nielsens-List
DOC.TEXT: Television's most churlish family, ``The Simpsons,'' outdrew the loving Huxtables of ``The Cosby Show'' and finished fourth in the ratings last week, the first time Fox Broadcasting has broken into the top 10. Two other Sunday night Fox shows, ``Married ... With Children'' and ``In Living Color,'' were 11th and 19th, respectively, the first time the fledgling network has had three shows in the top 20. NBC's ``Cosby,'' which airs on Thursdays, tied for eighth in the ratings, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. figures Tuesday. ``Cosby'' and ``The Simpsons'' will go head to head next season on Thursday nights. Reruns of NBC's ``Cheers'' and ABC's ``Roseanne'' took the top two spots. The premiere of comedian Jerry Seinfeld's half-hour series on NBC was No. 3, while CBS' ``Dave Thomas Comedy Show'' tied for 59th place. They were two of the few fresh shows broadcast last week as the summer rerun season set in. NBC won the weekly ratings with an average of 10.9, followed by ABC with 10.3 and CBS with 8.9. Each ratings point represents 921,000 households. A repeat of a tribute to Sammy Davis Jr., taped a few months before his death on May 16, took 29th place for ABC. Most of the program aired Sunday night against the Tony Awards ceremony on CBS, which tied for 61st. Several ties indicated viewer drift as post-season blahs set in. Here are the Top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``Cheers,'' NBC, 18.1; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 18.0; ``Seinfeld,'' NBC, 16.2; ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, (tied with) ``The Simpsons,'' Fox, 15.7; ``60 Minutes,'' CBS, 15.6; ``The Wonder Years,'' ABC, 15.5; ``A Different World,'' NBC, (tied with) ``The Cosby Show,'' NBC, (tied with) ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC, 15.3. In the evening news, ABC was first for the 21st week in a row with an average rating of 9.5. CBS and NBC tied at 7.5 each.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Apology, Compensation to Victims of Nuclear Testing
DOC.TEXT: More than 40 years after exposing thousands of Americans to dangerous radiation from nuclear testing programs, the government is close to offering an apology and compensation to those who have cancer. A bill approved by the House on voice vote Tuesday would set up a $100 million fund to pay victims of radiation disease brought on by the atmospheric nuclear testing program conducted in Nevada from 1945 to 1963 and the mining of uranium for the tests. The measure also carries a formal apology ``to the American people that were subjected and sacrificed for the Cold War nuclear weapons,'' said Rep. Wayne Owens, D-Utah, sponsor of the bill. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act is awaiting floor action in the Senate. Proponents of the bill described radioactive fallout that fell like snow from the skies near the nuclear test site in Nevada. ``I remember as a child growing up in southern Utah watching the sky light up with various colors from the nuclear explosions at the Nevada test site just 100 crow-flying miles away,'' Owens said. He likened it to a Fourth of July fireworks display and said, ``The only difference was that instead of celebrating our independence, years later, we were mourning the death of our friends from the epidemic of leukemias and other cancers in southern Utah,'' he said. Owens said the government claimed at the time that no one's health was endangered by the tests. The bill would affect people who lived in Nevada, Colorado, New Mexico, Arizona, Utah and Wyoming. The legislation stems in part from work by Stewart Udall, former congressman and interior secretary, who represented the uranium miners in a lawsuit against the government in 1979. He started a drive for congressional action after the courts ruled that the government was immune from prosecution because national security needs dictated an uninterrupted flow of great quantities of uranium ore. Owens was part of a team of lawyers who sued the government on behalf of the so-called downwinders. Judges in that case ruled similarly to the one involving the miners. Udall said that despite the rulings, some of the judges who handled the case wrote opinions that counseled the plaintiffs to seek redress from Congress. ``Today, the House of Representatives restores our nation's honor by holding the government responsible for Cold War abuses that have stained our collective consciences by causing death and injury to its own people,'' Owens said. ``The Cold War can't be over until we have paid the debt to the civilian victims.'' During the atmospheric atomic weapons testing, an estimated 220,000 military personnel and 150,000 civilians were exposed to radiation. Those in the military who became ill have received disability benefits. Udall said about 950 to 1,300 miners or their families would receive compensation. Under the bill, the Justice Department would establish the amounts people would be paid based on medical documentation. To be eligible, individuals would have to have been in areas downwind from the Nevada test site for at least a year between 1951 and 1958, or between June and July 1962. Miners who worked in uranium mines between 1947 and 1971 would be eligible if they were exposed to a specific amount of radiation.

DOC.HEAD: Lugar Firmly Opposing Boosts in Target Prices, Loan Rates
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee is getting strong opposition from its ranking Republican to any increases in target prices or loan rates in the 1990 farm bill. Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., said Tuesday he was standing firm on freezing target prices and loan rates. And he said he was unwilling to take more acreage out of production or accept shifts in finances to create the illusion of deficit reduction. ``I've been infinitely flexible in other things (in the bill),'' Lugar said. But he said these four areas were not negotiable and would lead to a floor fight if the Democratic majority on the committee insists in keeping them in the bill. ``The Democrats have to decide `do we want an issue, or do we want a bill?''' said Lugar. ``If an issue is what they want, then my guess is we will have a one-year extension'' in the 1985 farm bill expiring this year. Lugar commented at a breakfast meeting with reporters immediately before he went into a session with a bipartisan task force created by Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., to work out a compromise on commodities supports. The task force also includes Sens. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb.; David Pryor, D-Ark.; Bob Dole, R-Kan.; and Thad Cochran, R-Miss. Not all members were present and little was accomplished at Tuesday's meeting, sources close to the committee said. The Democrats want to increase target prices 1 percent, with other increases possible in the last four years of the program depending on inflation. Congress passes a farm bill every five years to set agriculture policy, including the degree to which government will subsidize farmers through target prices and loan rates. Current law expires in December, but the Bush administration has said repeatedly that it would accept a one-year extension of existing policies. That is viewed by many in Congress as a strategy which would help U.S. negotiators at the international trade talks known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. The United States is trying to get other countries to remove subsidies from agricultural products that distort world market prices. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who is actively involved in those talks, has said that U.S. subsidies may have to be adjusted to comply with whatever agreement develops. They are expected to be completed by the end of this year. Lugar mentioned the trade talks in his talk with reporters, but he said his main objection to the Democrats' proposal for increasing target prices is budgetary. ``At a time when it is fairly likely people may be asked to pay more taxes, for the farm program to be asking for more money is not prudent,'' he said. The House Agriculture Committee, meanwhile, has voted to freeze target prices.

The guesswork will be taken out of agricultural finance when guidelines developed through the American Bankers Association are in effect, say members of task force that developed the program. Standardized methods for figuring farm expenses will help make farmers more competitive by giving them better information as to how their operations stack up financially with all others, the task force said Tuesday. ``The producers have been looking for help,'' said Steve Hofing, a consultant from Champaign, Ill., who served on the panel. He said farm business has been hindered because each creditor and farmer has his own set of forms and method of record-keeping. ``We need guidelines so net farm income means the same thing in Maryland as in Washington state,'' said Hofing. This will be achieved by standardization of farm financial ratio calculations, definitions and reporting formats. Jim McGrann of Texas A&M University, a member of the task force, said farmer are increasingly using computers and that software companies are big supporters of the standardization. McGrann said that use of standard financial reporting will give the government a more exact idea of the economic condition of agriculture when it comes time to develop the five-year farm bill. Stanley Forbes, chairman of the task force, said the guidelines could be fully adopted by farmers and financial institutions within five years.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Teacher Lobbyist Leads in Close Democratic Gubernatorial Primary
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Hubbert winning spot in runoff, results; picks up 11th graf pvs, `The English-language ...'
DOC.TEXT: Teacher lobbyist Paul Hubbert won a place in the Democratic runoff for the nomination to oppose Gov. Guy Hunt, but the primary Tuesday was too close to call the second spot. Hunt, a preacher-farmer thrust into the state's top office four years ago when he became the first Republican elected to the post this century, easily defeated two minor candidates to win the GOP nomination. No Democratic candidate won a majority, making a runoff June 26 necessary. With 3,014 precincts of 4,196 reporting in the Democratic primary, Hubbert had 164,993 votes, or 32 percent, to 125,518 votes, or 24 percent, for Attorney General Don Siegelman; 114,852 votes, or 22 percent, for former Gov. Fob James; and 91,791 votes, or 18 percent, for U.S. Rep. Ronnie Flippo. State Sen. Charles Bishop received 21,759 votes, or 4 percent, and prison employee Ed Daw had 2,514 votes, or less than 1 percent. None of the candidates trailing Hubbert conceded defeat Tuesday evening. ``We're not through with this fight yet,'' said Flippo. ``This is no place for the faint-hearted, and there's nobody faint-hearted here.'' In the Republican primary, Hunt had 92,799 votes, or 96 percent, to 2,430 votes, or 3 percent, for retired businessman Jim Watley; and 1,897 votes, or 2 percent, for state Highway Department employee Jack Pollard, with 2,783 precincts of 4,196 reporting. Sen. Howell Heflin, a Democrat, overcame token opposition to win renomination to a third term. With 2,794 precincts of 4,196 reporting, Heflin had 338,018 votes, or 81 percent, to 79,828 votes, or 19 percent, for Mrs. Frank Ross Stewart. Heflin's Republican challenger, state Sen. Bill Cabaniss, was unopposed for the GOP nomination. A constitutional amendment to make English the state's official language was overwhelmingly approved. With 1,670 precincts of 4,196 reporting, there were 181,558 votes, or 90 percent, in favor of the proposal to 20,953 votes, or 10 percent, against. The English-language amendment gives Alabama residents the right to sue if it is violated, but does not define what constitutes a violation.

Hunt, 56, a Primitive Baptist minister who regularly preaches near his north Alabama fruit farm, benefitted four years ago from a bitter Democratic runoff. This time the leading Democrats mostly avoided the kind of personal attacks that marked the 1986 campaign. James, 55, based his campaign in part on holdover support from 1978, when he was elected governor. He chose not to seek a second term in 1982, then lost a comeback bid in 1986. He spent much of the 1990 campaign seeking to emphasize his achievements during his administration, which was depicted by critics as being fumble-prone. Hubbert, 54, and Siegelman, 44, appeared to be battling for some of the same votes, including those of blacks and organized labor. Flippo, 52, gave up a safe congressional seat in north Alabama to seek the governor's seat.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0459, changing cycle designator.
Safety Board Calls For Underwater Bridge Inspections
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ Federal safety investigators say thousands of bridges need to be inspected by underwater divers to see if they face the same danger that caused a Tennessee bridge to collapse last year, killing eight motorists. The National Transportation Safety Board on Tuesday blamed erosion from a shifting river channel for the April 1, 1989, collapse of a U.S. 51 bridge over the Hatchie River, 45 miles north of Memphis. ``It certainly raises a serious concern with me about how much damage may have been done with flooding in Texas and the South,'' said NTSB Chairman James Kolstad. ``I'm concerned that some of these bridges may be put back into service without adequate inspection.'' The board called for a modification of federal bridge inspections standards to require underwater inspection of bridge parts exposed to ``excessive water depth or turbidity.'' It also asked the Tennessee Department of Transportation to follow up bridge inspections with further work by divers when there are doubts about submerged elements. The board cited the 54-year-old Hatchie bridge's simple design as a contributing factor in the accident that caused vehicles to plunge into the river from the highway's two northbound lanes. A newer southbound span remained intact, but board investigators said its construction in 1974 accelerated movement of the river channel, which had changed 83 feet from the time the northbound bridge was constructed in 1936. The board cited the Tennessee Department of Transportation for failing to evaluate and correct problems found in inspections dating back to 1979. NTSB investigators said they did not know how many of the nation's 500,000 bridges might require underwater inspection and other steps to ensure their safety. But investigator Claude Harris said the number needing additional scrutiny would number in the thousands. A survey last year by the National Association of Counties estimated that 165,000 bridges need repair or replacement, with some states having up to 90 percent defective bridges. The board voted 3-1 on the probable cause in the Tennessee collapse and 4-0 on a set of recommendations to federal and state officials. Board member Jim Burnett said he would not support the conclusion until missing bridge parts are recovered and further inspections are made. The NTSB's investigation remains open, said Kolstad, and could be revised if evidence surfaces that points to further deficiencies in the bridge. Investigators told the board that bridge parts might be raised from the water in about two weeks. The board said the bridge failed ``most likely'' from the deterioration of timber piles that were originally buried and not designed to be in water. Board members also cautioned Tennessee authorities against allowing so many exemptions to vehicle weight restrictions on bridges _ about 70 a month for the Hatchie bridge before it collapsed _ and called for closer scrutiny of overweight trucks and their impact on bridge safety.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Has $50 Billion in Unspent Money
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon has not spent $50 billion in money appropriated to it, and congressional investigators fear it could be used at will by the department for major programs such as the B-2 bomber and attack submarine. ``The existence of these accounts hampers the Congress' ability to control obligations,'' staff investigators for a House subcommittee said in a draft version of testimony to be delivered today. The Agency for International Development also has more than $11 billion in unspent money and the Energy Department has about $325 million, the investigators said. But the Pentagon has the largest reserve of unspent cash in two accounts _ one known as the ``M'' account, the other called a merged surplus authority account. Money appropriated by Congress must be obligated or spent during a specific time period. If not, the funds lapse and the money is returned to the general fund of the U.S. Treasury. The ``M'' account includes unspent money that is maintained by an agency or department and is used to pay previous obligations. The merged surplus authority account is a Treasury Department account maintained by the appropriate agency and used for similar purposes. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations, earlier this year accused the Pentagon of maintaining ``semi-secret slush funds.'' The Pentagon, in a statement released Tuesday, said the accounts are ``neither a `secret' nor a `slush' fund.'' ``Any significant use of such balances requires congressional approval (each adjustment after first $25 million),'' said the Pentagon, which noted that requirements for their use of the money is more stringent than for other federal agencies. Congress created the accounts in 1956 to avoid appropriating additional money every year to pay for prior obligations. ``They were intended to relieve Congress of having to get involved in numerous nickel-and-dime transactions that the U.S. government was validly obligated to pay,'' investigators for Dingell's subcommittee said of the accounts. ``No one envisioned these accounts would grow into a $100 billion fund ... which could be drawn upon whenever the agency concluded these monies could be used to fund obligations within the scope of existing contracts.'' Investigators from the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations said they had evidence that the Navy's Aviation Supply Office had ``selectively purged'' many of its records in the ``M'' account. The result is that the Defense Contract Service Administration is paying bills totaling $123 million that the Navy cannot determine is valid, investigators said. In addition, the Air Force recently used $500 million from the two accounts to correct problems with the B-1B bomber. The investigators suggested that the Pentagon could take a similar approach in correcting problems with the DDG-51 guided-missile destroyer, the B-2 stealth bomber and the SSN-21 submarine. ``What is troubling is that this expired authority could be converted into paying the bills to correct these deficiencies without the approval of Congress,'' the investigators said. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., in a March letter to the House Budget Committee, called for legislation to the appropriations bill to end the accounts. ``With the existence of these slush funds, the Congress could virtually kill a weapons program and find out years later that it was still being funded from these accounts,'' the congressman said.

DOC.HEAD: Long-Awaited Rain Hits Parched North Dakota
DOC.TEXT: After more than two years of praying for rain _ in homes, churches and on the steps of the state Capitol _ North Dakotans can see puddles in their wheat fields. Now they're giving thanks, even though it's too early to say the drought is over. ``It was so bleak and dry for so long that when we got the rain last week everyone came in with sunshine on their faces,'' said Gertrude Buscher, executive vice president of the Bank of Beulah. Some folks are calling it the ``million-dollar rain.'' Sanford Williams, who farms 2,200 acres near Wing in central North Dakota, said 4 inches of rain in the past few days are giving his crops new life. ``Two years ago, we didn't pull the combine out at all. Last year, we used the oats for hay,'' said Alvin Braun, who farms with his father near Bismarck. Braun got .95 inch of rain over the weekend _ not as much as he needs but enough to give him hope. ``The drought is hard financially on everybody, but I think the mental stress is worse. Just knowing it can rain is really a help,'' he said. Most of the rain has fallen in the eastern part of the state. Fargo has reported 5 inches since March 25, nearly half an inch above normal. The area got more than 2 inches during a soaking last weekend. Farther west, Minot has seen 4{ inches of rain, slightly below average, and Dickinson has had 2.9 inches, a little more than an inch below normal. ``I think most people in the state are cautiously optimistic,'' Lt. Gov. Lloyd Omdahl said Tuesday. ``There's no doubt it's done an awful lot for morale, but they realize they need a lot more.'' The prospect of a third year of drought prompted more than 100 people to gather on the steps of the Capitol last month to pray for rain. A rain dance also was held. ``We feel Christians responded seriously and God has honored that,'' said the Rev. Dom Vetter of Bismarck, organizer of the prayer service. While the rain is the main topic of discussion in coffee shops and on street corners, farm experts warn the drought is far from over. The rain has moistened dry topsoil but it has done little to restore soil reserves. A study this week found moisture under the top 4 inches of soil still short over 97 percent of the state. ``We're starting to catch up in precipitation, but it's spotty,'' said Mark Ewens, a National Weather Service forecaster in Fargo. Last year, North Dakota crops looked good until July 1, when temperatures in the 90s and three weeks of no rain burned up the fields. That could happen again, warned James Helm, a North Dakota State University agronomist. So far, temperatures have been cool, with highs in the 70s. The cool, wet weather also has hurt one bumper crop _ an unwanted one _ by slowing the hatching of grasshoppers that invade during dry spells.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs College Disclosure Requirements
DOC.TEXT: Federally funded colleges and universities would have to report graduation rates for student athletes and others under a House-passed bill described as ``a consumer rights bill.'' The bill cleared the House on a voice vote Tuesday and was returned to the Senate, which earlier approved a different version. Under the bill, federally supported institutions would have to report to the Education Department their overall graduation rates, student-athlete graduation rates, revenues from intercollegiate athletics, campus security policies, campus crime statistics and information about results of campus disciplinary hearings. The graduation rates would pertain only to fulltime, degree-seeking students. ``It provides students with information which will assist them in making decisions concerning college attendance and ... information they need to protect themselves against becoming crime victims,'' Rep. Bill Goodling, R-Pa., said. Much of the debate focused on provisions dealing with intercollegiate athletics. Student athletes have a right to know whether a school will treat them ``as chattel properties'' or as genuine students in need of preparation for life beyond the playing field, said Rep. Paul Henry, R-Mich. ``Sports are the top public relations vehicle for many colleges and universities,'' Henry said. ``Thus, fielding winning teams becomes to a very large extent the consuming purpose of athletic programs. The better the team, the better the exposure, regardless of the cost.'' Reporting requirements recently set by the National Collegiate Athletic Association are ``too limited,'' focusing only on the big-money sports of football and basketball, said Rep. Ed Towns, D-N.Y. ``Other sports must be covered as well,'' Towns said. ``If we can report the on-time arrivals of airlines, surely we can let the general public know whether or not students are getting a useful degree at a university.'' Too many high-school athletes dreaming of professional careers enroll at major universities where they can't handle the academics, said Rep. Tom McMillen, D-Md., a former college and NBA basketball star. ``Unfortunately, most have a better chance of becoming a brain surgeon than a professional athlete,'' he said. ``The dream is in fact an impossible dream for most. We have a responsibility to these young people ... to instill in them the concept that if they want to punt on the field, they can't punt in the classroom.'' ``It's a consumer rights bill for students,'' Goodling, who said his interest, especially in the crime-statistics provision, arose from the murder of Jeanne Clery, whose parents live in his district, at Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pa., in 1986. ``The truth is students are raped, assaulted and murdered on college campuses,'' he said. The bill won't solve those problems but ``can ensure students are as aware of crimes on campus as you and I are of crimes in our neighborhoods or in the cities where we work,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: House Passes Stock Market Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version also on business news wire
DOC.TEXT: The Securities and Exchange Commission would be empowered to curb the practice of program trading during stock market emergencies under legislation approved by the House. The Securities Markets Reform Act would allow the SEC to limit program trading ``during periods of extraordinary market volatility'' _ the sharp climbs or drops in stock prices. The measure, introduced last year, was adopted by the House on a voice vote Tuesday. A similar market reform bill awaiting action by the Senate does not contain a program trading curb. Critics of program trading _ rapid-fire transactions through computerized buy and sell programs _ blame it for worsening the 1987 stock market crash and the 190-point market slide last Oct. 13. They are especially critical of one form of program trading, index arbitrage, in which speculators try to take advantage of small, brief price differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling them in the other. Critics say that strategy and the volatility that often seems to accompany it have driven small investors out of the stock market. Last March, the Treasury Department wrote the House Energy and Commerce Committee opposing a program trading ban, saying the measure's language was ``overly broad and potentially harmful'' to market reform. But the measure was voted out of committee anyway on March 13. ``We are not talking about banning computers or legitimate program trading strategies. Far from it,'' said Rep. Edward J. Markey, D-Mass., chairman of the finance subcommittee that oversees the SEC and one of the bill's coauthors. ``We are giving the SEC the tools to protect the securities markets from manipulative trading strategies'' and to prohibit trading tactics that ``threaten fair and orderly markets'' in times of market volatility, he said. In addition to the program trading curb, the bipartisan bill: _Expands the authority of the SEC chairman to shut down the securities markets, with the president's permission, in times of market emergency. _Requires large securities traders to report their market positions to the SEC. _Gives the SEC authority to assess the financial health of the parent holding companies of broker-dealers. The collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the one-time junk bond giant of Wall Street, was precipitated in February by the failure of its parent holding company. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden has complained that under current law, the agency did not have adequate information about Drexel's holding company before the firm's collapse and that information about large stock trades was inadequate for government decision-makers during the Oct. 13 market slide. The program trading amendment in the House bill would require the SEC to determine _ through its often-lengthy rule-making process _ what types of activities cause or contribute to extraordinary volatility before it could halt them.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Seize Rubber Plantation Offices, Effectively Close Airport
DOC.TEXT: Rebel forces have seized the headquarters of the world's largest rubber plantation, Liberia's biggest employer, and are now believed to control every major industrial concern in the country. On Tuesday, the insurgents gathered outside the gates of Liberia's international airport _ 25 miles from the capital of Monrovia _ after seizing the headquarters of the adjoining rubber plantation. Their presence effectively closed the airport. President Samuel Doe met with religious leaders in an attempt at peaceful negotiations to end the insurgency, which began in December in northeastern Nimba County and became a serious challenge after reported reprisals against civilians by government troops. Amnesty International says soldiers killed hundreds of civilians from the Gio and Mano ethnic groups. The civil war has pitted members of the Krahn and Mandingo groups, from which Doe draws support, against the Gio and Mano peoples, who have largely backed rebel leader Charles Taylor. Doe is a Krahn. The rebels took the headquarters of the 120,000-acre Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. plantation Tuesday after attacking government troops with mortars and automatic weapons. Plantation residents said dozens of rebels crossed the Farmington River _ the last natural barrier before Monrovia _ and moved onto the plantation. Diplomatic sources said about 15 or 20 soldiers briefly returned fire, then fled toward the capital. It has become a familiar story in the war, with some soldiers abandoning key posts before the rebel advance. Diplomats say about 50 percent of a soldier corps they describe as ill-trained and poorly paid have deserted. Government forces now are believed to number about the same as the rebels _ 3,000 to 4,000. Monrovia residents have been fleeing in fear for nearly a week. Insurgents now control every major industrial concern in the West African country of 2.5 million people, except possibly the Bong iron ore mine, which has been cut off for days from Monrovia and believed behind rebel lines. In Akron, Ohio, a spokesman for Bridgestone-Firestone Inc. said the company wants to keep the plantation operating and that the Americans operating it did not plan to evacuate. The spokesman, Trevor Hoskins, referred to the guerrillas as ``freedom fighters.'' He said the rebels occupied the management offices in the company town of Harbel after surrounding the plantation's factory late Monday, stopping rubber production. Hoskins said the rebels have told plantation managing director Don Ensminger that ``the fight was not with him or the plantation employees and they do not intend any destruction.'' The plantation employs 8,500 Liberians and produces about 100 million pounds of rubbers a year. Diplomatic sources in Monrovia, a city of about 400,000 people, said they had no reports of casualties in fighting Tuesday. Late Tuesday, Harbel residents said by telephone that there were reports the rebels killed two Mandingo civilians. The reports could not be independently confirmed. Rebels are accused of killing dozens of Mandingo and Krahns. Meanwhile, off Monrovia, four U.S. warships carrying 2,000 Marines remained ready to evacuate Americans and other foreigners, including the 10 to 15 Soviet diplomats in Liberia, officials said. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said 33 Americans were evacuated Monday and thousands had left earlier. He said 70 U.S. officials and about 1,200 private American citizens remained. Washington has accused Taylor, the rebel leader, of getting support from Libya, but it also has said U.S. Marines will not move to support Doe, who seized power in a bloody coup 10 years ago. Most of the rebels entered Liberia from neighboring Ivory Coast in late December. They accuse Doe's administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. Taylor had been a close aide of Doe, heading the government agency responsible for disbursing public funds. He fled the country after the Liberian leader accused him of stealing $1 million from state coffers. Taylor denies the charges, but Doe says he will not negotiate with a criminal. Descendants of freed U.S. slaves founded Liberia in 1822, and it became black Africa's first independent country in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Recommends Delay in Reopening Colorado Nuclear Weapons Plant
DOC.TEXT: Restarting production of nuclear weapons components at the Rocky Flats plant near Denver should be delayed until at least October, an advisory committee says. The Energy Department had tentatively planned to resume production this month at the plant, which is the only source of plutonium triggers for nuclear weapons. ``The committee believes that the necessary changes and training will take significantly longer to complete than previously forecast,'' said a letter to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins from the department's advisory committee on nuclear facilities safety. ``So much remains to be done that restart on the schedule indicated to us appears impractical,'' said the letter sent Monday and signed by Chairman John F. Ahearne, a former member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. A department official made portions of the letter available Tuesday on condition of anonymity. In March, the department approved a plan by the contract operator of the plant, EG&G Inc., to resume production sometime in June, and even if that date slipped a summer resumption has been expected. Watkins has not given the final go-ahead, and his decision is expected any day. The plant has been closed for safety and management improvements since November, and the FBI has been investigating the handling of nuclear waste there. The Navy has testified that if production at Rocky Flats is not resumed soon, it will be unable to load the latest Trident 2 submarines with the most modern warhead, the W-88, atop the new D-5 missiles.

DOC.HEAD: Avenson Wins Democratic Bid To Oppose Branstad for Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE results. Material below graf will stand.
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Don Avenson on Tuesday won a spirited, five-way Democratic contest for the right to oppose two-term Republican Gov. Terry Branstad, who ran unopposed in his party's primary. With 2,566 of 2,567 precincts reporting, Avenson had 78,767 votes, or 39 percent; to 63,129 votes, or 32 percent, for Attorney General Tom Miller; and 52,031 votes, or 26 percent, for former banker John Chrystal. Lt. Gov. Joann Zimmerman had 4,512 votes, or 2 percent, and retiree Darold Powers received 1,272 votes, or 1 percent. An Iowa Poll conducted for the Des Moines Register the last week of the campaign showed Avenson leading with 32 percent of likely Democratic voters, followed by Miller at 25 percent and Chrystal at 19 percent. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 3.9 percentage points.

The primary began as a referendum on abortion but became more complicated in the closing days. Branstad focused on raising money and had $2.5 million, more than double the combined total of the Democratic field. Miller opposes abortion; Chrystal and Avenson are pro-choice. Polls had shown a majority of voters considered themselves pro-choice but abortion rights activists worried that two candidates would split the vote. Branstad also opposes abortion. Avenson, 45, had the support of the National Organization for Women and the National Abortion Rights Action League, which ran television commercials and sent mail on his behalf. Miller, 45, charged that out-of-state special-interest groups were trying to influence the outcome of the election. He discounted the abortion issue, saying he would approve only limited restrictions, such as requiring parents be notified. Miller sought to deflect attention by focusing on tighter restrictions against drunken driving, and saying Avenson ``identifies with the drunk driver.'' Avenson called Miller's proposal ``insane'' and said it would make criminals of people who have two beers. Chrystal, 64, urged the two to talk about more serious issues, pushing his plan to improve trade with the Soviet Union. The health of the candidates became an issue in the closing weeks, when Avenson was hospitalized for emergency medical procedures to clear a clogged artery in his heart.

DOC.HEAD: Mother of Former Prime Minister Dead at 81
DOC.TEXT: Phoebe Lange, the outspoken mother of former Prime Minister David Lange, has died in Auckland at the age of 81. Mrs. Lange, who underwent surgery for cancer earlier this year, attracted publicity last year when she spoke out against her son, who had left his wife and their three children to live with his speechwriter, Margaret Pope. At the time, Mrs. Lange said her heart was ``full of hatred'' for her son and that she did not want to speak to him. Asked if she really meant that, she said: ``Yes, I do. At present I do. But I think I will get over it.'' The cause of death was not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Dems Cite Evidence That White House Aide Schemed Against Convention
DOC.TEXT: Democrats leaders say they have evidence suggesting a White House aide pulled a political dirty trick and instigated a police union protest that disrupted the party's state convention. The aide, Ron Kaufman, a special assistant to President Bush and his deputy personnel director, denied he had anything to do with the demonstration. The protest disrupted the Democratic convention Saturday at the Springfield Civic Center, nearly forcing its cancellation. James Roosevelt, chief counsel for the state Democratic Party, said suspicions of collusion by Kaufman have been bolstered by word that Kaufman met a few weeks before the convention with the president of the Springfield police union. ``I think what you have is some irresponsible police officers working with a political operative who got carried away,'' Roosevelt said. State Democratic officials said they would sue Kaufman, adding his name to a Superior Court lawsuit already initiated against the union. The Democrats claim the protest violated the civil rights of party delegates, obstructing their ability to gather for a political assembly. The union picketed outside the civic center for several hours. Thousands of delegates refused to cross the picket line and remained outside in wilting heat. Some delegates said they were manhandled by police when they tried to enter. Democratic leaders insist the union broke an agreement not to picket the convention hall, and they suspect Kaufman was the instigator. ``Something inspired those police to break the agreement,'' Roosevelt said. The Democrats noted that the union endorsed George Bush in the 1988 presidential election. Kaufman and state Republican Party Executive Director Alexander Tennant were in Springfield during the convention. Tennant said the two were meeting with delegates who might support Republicans in November. Kaufman also acknowledged he had a brief conversation Friday night with Robert Jacobson, president of the union. But Kaufman said in a telephone interview Tuesday that he ``unequivocably'' had nothing to do with the protest. Tennant said there was no evidence of a conspiracy, and he accused the Democrats of trying to duck responsibility for their own fiasco. On the evening before the demonstration, Kaufman said, he was in front of the convention center and Jacobson showed him a squad car that was in poor condition. ``That was the extent of it,'' he said. Kaufman also acknowledged that he met with Jacobson a few weeks before the convention, but ``we did not talk anything about labor movements in Springfield.'' Jacobson said, ``I can categorically deny that I ever spoke to Kaufman about this convention picket.'' The union president insisted no politics were involved in the police protest. The city has been mired in a labor dispute with its police, and the union was threatening for weeks to picket the convention center. On Friday night, however, officials announced an agreement under which police would conduct only an informational picket if Mayor Mary Hurley would not speak at the convention.The union claimed Hurley broke the agreement by entering the convention hall Friday night. ``They're making this out to be like it was Chicago '68,'' said Jacobson, referring to the tumultuous Democratic national convention 22 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Distributors Recalling Toys
DOC.TEXT: A major toy distributor is recalling 16,000 musical instruments because the paint on them contains too much lead. The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Tuesday that New Jersey-based Toys ``R'' Us is voluntarily recalling its multicolored plastic Music Master Xylophone toys because they contain ``lead in excess of the allowable limit established by federal law.'' The instruments were sold nationwide since 1988 and are labeled ``SX-305, SKN 421944, Shinnihon,'' the commission said. The agency said also that General Toys of Los Angeles was recalling approximately 2,400 windup plastic toys because they may pose both a fatal choking or puncture wound hazard to small children. The second recall includes: The Happy Flapping Car, models 8668 and 8228; The Happy Tricycle Police & Thief Motorcycle, model 636; Cycling Bear, model 6968; Naughty Bear, model 6976 and Ice Cream Van, model 6973. The toys were sold nationwide before March of this year. The CPSC said there had been no reports of injuries involving any of the toys. Consumers should take them away from children and return them to the store where purchased for a refund, officials said.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Considering Dismissing Secord Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge is considering whether to dismiss a $38 million libel suit filed against two journalists by Iran-Contra figure Richard V. Secord. Lawyer Dean Ringel told Judge George H. Revercombe on Tuesday that Secord's suit against Leslie and Andrew Cockburn and the Atlantic Monthly Press should be dismissed because no actual malice has been proved. But W. Michael Kramer, attorney for the former Air Force major general, contended that the authors falsely linked Secord in a 1988 book to narcotics trafficking as part of the effort to finance the Contra rebels. Kramer asked the judge for additional time to take depositions and search for further evidence in the case. Revercombe took both motions under advisement. Kramer contended that the clear intent of the book, ``Out of Control: The Story of the Reagan Administration's Secret War in Nicaragua,'' was to exploit the Iran-Contra affair by putting the administration and its key players in the worst possible light. Ringel argued that Secord ``seems to assume that since the book takes a political position opposite to that of the previous administration, that is evidence of malice.''
DOC.HEAD: Census Count Nearing 90 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Census officials say 87 percent of American households have been counted this year. Spokesman Ray Bancroft said the 90 percent level could be reached within a week, but cautioned that ``the last 10 percent is the hardest to count.'' People who mailed back their census forms in March were the easiest to tally, and census workers have added to that total by visiting the homes of those who didn't get forms in the mail or failed to send them back. Now they are trying to count people who are reluctant to cooperate with government officials, are away from home or are so busy working that they are hard to find.
DOC.HEAD: European, Asian, Latam Experts Joining U.S. Election Observers
DOC.TEXT: An international delegation cosponsored by arms of the Democratic and Republican parties plans to observe the balloting in Czechoslovakia's first multiparty parliamentary election next weekend. A dozen political dignitaries or experts from Europe, Asia, Australia and Latin America have been invited to join more than 40 U.S. observers in the Central European country, said a joint announcement Tuesday from the Democratic and Republican Institutes for International Affairs. The delegates plan to watch the voting in seven regions of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Peruvians Deeply Divided in Presidential Runoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Wednesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The campaign for Peru's presidential runoff Sunday is passionate and angry. But poll-takers say voters' energies are devoted more toward defeating the candidate they dislike than electing someone they support. Many Peruvians are uneasy with both Mario Vargas Llosa, Peru's celebrated novelist, and his opponent, Alberto Fujimori. Pollsters say each candidate inspires millions with emotions of disappointment and distrust. ``At least half of Fujimori's supporters are people who are scared of Vargas Llosa,'' said Alfredo Torres, of the polling firm Apoyo. ``Of those who support Vargas Llosa, at least a third are voting against Fujimori.'' Polls show Fujimori with a slim but firm lead over Vargas Llosa, a novelist-turned-politician who champions the free market. Most polls show Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrant parents, with a 5-point lead nationally. Vargas Llosa may have cut into that lead after his performance Sunday night in a nationally broadcast debate with Fujimori. An Apoyo poll of 1,080 television viewers in Lima and six other cities showed Vargas Llosa winning 48 to 37 percent. The heated, 2{-hour debate was marked by personal attacks. Fujimori accused Vargas Llosa of spreading ``insults and calumnies'' against him. The novelist said his opponent offered only ``generalities and banalities'' in his campaign. An agricultural engineer and former university rector with no political experience, Fujimori was the surprise of first-round elections April 8. He surged past seven opponents to nearly tie Vargas Llosa. Vargas Llosa received 27.6 percent of the vote to Fujimori's 24.6 percent. A runoff was required because no candidate received a majority. Vargas Llosa has detailed plans for resolving Peru's worst economic crisis of the century and for battling a savage leftist insurgency. Like Vargas Llosa, Fujimori favors getting back on good terms with the international financial community by renewing payments on Peru's $19 billion foreign debt. Vargas Llosa and Fujimori both advocate economic development rather than police action to wean peasants away from Peru's billion-dollar cocaine trade. Unlike the novelist, Fujimori has avoided discussing in detail his plans to reverse Peru's slide into economic chaos and civil war. Vargas Llosa favors privatization of Peru's state-owned companies, elimination of price controls and import barriers and an economic ``shock'' program to combat inflation. Fujimori opposes all three and thereby scores points with workers who fear for their jobs and with businesses that defend protective trade laws. Vargas Llosa has questioned Fujimori's competence. Vargas Llosa's allies say Fujimori is a puppet of the discredited left-of-center Aprista Party of President Alan Garcia. Even the Roman Catholic Church has joined in. Upset that much of Fujimori's support comes from Peru's small but growing evangelical community, the Catholic church has attacked the evangelicals and analysts say Fujimori is the real target. The campaign against Fujimori has received wide coverage by Lima's pro-Vargas Llosa television stations. In little more than a month the novelist turned a 13-point deficit into a 5-point lead among voters in this city of 7 million. But for Vargas Llosa, the televised offensive has limits because fewer than half of Peru's 22 million people have access to television. The anti-Vargas Llosa sentiment is especially strong in Lima's sprawling shantytowns and the impoverished countryside. In the brutal campaign for the first-round elections, Garcia's Aprista Party painted the novelist as the candidate of the rich, white elite. The effort was largely successful, according to pollsters. Vargas Llosa's harsh anti-left rhetoric also frightened away potential supporters among Peru's traditionally left-leaning electorate. The result is a voting population deeply split along class lines. Most of Vargas Llosa's gain has been among Lima's upper and middle classes. The poor remain solidly opposed to him, apparently unimpressed by the novelist's recent campaign sweeps through their dusty shantytowns. ``The poor are going to vote for the `little chinaman,''' said Ina Ramirez, 23, a sidewalk vendor of used clothing, referring to Fujimori by his nickname. ``That other man is for the rich.'' As Fujimori has become more aware of his constituency, his rhetoric has become more populist. He promises to simultaneously create hundreds of thousands of jobs and sharply cut Peru's 2,000 percent annual inflation. He doesn't say how he'll do it. The winner will inherit an economy ravaged by hyperinflation and a bankrupt government paralyzed by strikes. And in recent years the Maoist Shining Path rebels have spread from their mountain stronghold throughout much of Peru. Political violence has claimed more than 18,500 lives over the past decade.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Index, Dollar Rise
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange recovered from morning losses Wednesday ending higher, and the dollar rose slightly against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 152.60 yen, up 0.17 yen from Tuesday's 152.43-yen finish. It opened at 152.45 yen and ranged between 152.27 yen and 152.60 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 31.88 points, or 0.1 percent, ending the day at 32,953.50. The index was a 74.53-point loser at the end of the morning session before rebounding in the afternoon. It rose 3.75 points the previous day. Traders said the index's fluctuation mainly resulted from position adjustments ahead of the last trading day for June future issues Thursday. Satoru Nagayoshi, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said the fluctuation in the stock index followed arbitrage selling and buying by major securities companies in an attempt to take profits between the spot and future markets. ``A majority of participants, however, remained on the sidelines trying to avoid major moves,'' he said. Currency dealers said the yen-dollar rate was moving narrowly in the absence of market-affecting news. Kouhei Kuroda, a dealer with Fuji Bank, said the dollar was likely to stay in its current range until the release next week of U.S. figures for consumer and producer prices for May.

DOC.HEAD: N.M. Democrats Nominate Former Gov. King for Third Term, Bond Wins GOP Nod
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE gubernatorial results, UPDATE with Udall winning. Picks up matter below dash.
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Bruce King, who has served longer than any other New Mexico governor, on Tuesday defeated three rivals for the Democratic nomination in his quest for a third term. Former state Rep. Frank Bond outpolled three other Republicans to take his party's primary. King and Bond will meet in a Nov. 6 general election that will provide the state with its first governor eligible to run for a second, consecutive four-year term. King's closest opponent, former Attorney General Paul Bardacke, conceded defeat shortly after 9 p.m. With 1,267 of 1,400 precincts reporting, King had 82,270 votes, or 52 percent, to 61,917 votes, or 39 percent for Bardacke; 7,484 votes, or 5 percent, for former Supreme Court Justice Tony Scarborough; and 5,616 votes, or 4 percent, for former Economic Development Secretary Bob Gold. In the Republican primary, Bond had 41,241 votes, or 55 percent, to 25,113 votes, or 34 percent, for state Senate Republican Leader Les Houston; 4,252 votes, or 6 percent for state Sen. James Caudell; and 4,069 votes, or 5 percent, for former Albuquerque Mayor Harry Kinney, with 1,263 precincts reporting of 1,400. In other races, U.S. Sen. Pete Domenici won the Republican nomination in an uncontested primary, as did Democratic state Sen. Tom Benavides. Tom Udall, son of former Arizona congressman and former Interior Secretary Stewart Udall, defeated three fellow Albuquerque lawyers for the Democratic nomination for state attorney general. With 1,206 precincts of 1,400 reporting, Udall had 49,229 votes, or 36 percent, to 42,275 votes, or 31 percent, for former state District Judge Patricia Madrid; 25,142 votes, or 18 percent, for state Rep. Dick Minzner; and 21,904 votes, or 16 percent for Patrick Apodaca, former associate counsel to President Carter.

New Mexico governors used to serve two-year terms. The term was doubled to four years in 1970, but with the proviso that no one could serve a second consecutive term. King, a 66-year-old rancher and businessman, served from 1971-75 and 1979-83. He offered voters the experience of 36 years in politics. Bardacke, 45, pushed youth and new ideas, urging New Mexicans to ``choose the future.'' The Republican race featured a contrast between Houston's rough-and-tumble style and Bond's positive leadership theme. Houston, 54, has been a flamboyant figure in legislative politics for the past decade. Bond, 46, offered a continuation of the upbeat style of incumbent Republican Gov. Garrey Carruthers, who is barred by the old law from seeking a second consecutive term.

DOC.HEAD: West German Leader Says Unified Germany Will Never Isolate Itself
LaserPhoto NY310
DOC.TEXT: West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl says a reunified Germany will be anything but neutral and isolationist, instead seeking a central role in a new European security order. In his first speech since the superpower summit, Kohl also forcefully reiterated his commitment to a united Germany maintaining close ties with the United States through NATO membership. ``We do not want to be forced into isolation because our experience shows that this leads to a loss of stability and peace in Europe,'' he told about 5,000 people Tuesday night at a dinner held by the 38-year-old American Council on Germany. ``We do not seek neutrality or demilitarization, and we reject a non-aligned status,'' said Kohl. He called continued close ties with the United States ``of vital importance'' to the Germans. Kohl acknowledged the anxiety _ most strongly expressed by Soviets _ over a strong and united German state of 80 million people at the heart of Europe. The Soviet Union lost 20 million people in World War II. ``This has been a terrible century, with wars, with tears and the Germans had a part in this,'' the West German leader said. But he said, ``Let me tell you, you can trust the Germans.'' He said they want a central role in creating a Europe of closer economic and political cooperation. ``We Germans are determined to go this road so we can prove that we have learned the lessons of history,'' Kohl said. ``Peace must emanate from the soil of Germany.'' Kohl arrived in the United States on Tuesday for a four-day visit. He was to meet with Wall Street executives today, deliver the commencement address at Harvard University on Thursday day and meet with President Bush at the White House on Friday. While reiterating his commitment to NATO, Kohl expressed gratitude to Bush for ``clearly stating'' _ with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at his side on Sunday _ that ``it is the right of the Germans that they should alone determine what alliance they want to be a member of.'' The Soviet Union opposes the membership of a reunified Germany in the Western military alliance, and the Soviet and U.S. leaders made little progress on the issue during the Washington summit. Kohl offered no new proposals on how to satisfy Soviet concerns. The stalemate is stymying progress on the reduction of conventional and nuclear forces in Europe, including the withdrawal of the 380,000 Soviet troops from East Germany. He noted that Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia endorse a united Germany's membership in NATO as promoting European security. All three are in the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact, a military alliance that is falling apart now that its members are stripping the Communists of power. Kohl expressed support for proposals endorsed by Soviet leaders for a stronger role for the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe as a forum for greater understanding and cooperation among nations. U.S. officials have expressed concern that a stronger CSCE could supplant NATO and the Warsaw Pact, and Kohl stressed that he did not envision the Western alliance crumbling as a result.

DOC.HEAD: Trump-Bashing Mag Kicks Donald While He's Down
DOC.TEXT: Buddy, can you spare a dime? And three pennies? Things are nowhere near that bad for Donald Trump, but the fabulously wealthy developer recently cashed a 13-cent check to become co-winner of Spy magazine's search for ``America's cheapest zillionaire.'' Trump and fellow multimillionaire Adnan Khashoggi _ a man with his own problems _ were the only two of 13 well-to-do sorts stung by the satirical magazine. Spy created a legally incorporated company, the National Refund Clearinghouse, and opened a checking account. The magazine then zipped out refund checks of $1.11 to 58 ``well-known, well-heeled Americans.'' Twenty-six people _ including Khashoggi, Trump, Cher, Harry Helmsley, Michael Douglas, Shirley MacLaine and Kurt Vonnegut _ cashed the checks. Woody Allen, Dustin Hoffman, Billy Joel and John McEnroe were among those who did not. The magazine went back to the people who cashed the check, then sent each one a 64-cent check to cover a ``computer error.'' Thirteen people cashed these, including Trump and Khashoggi, prompting a showdown for the title. All 13 received a third check, this one for 13 cents; only Trump and Khashoggi cashed them. Khashoggi, who is on trial with Imelda Marcos in federal court, personally endorsed his check. ``These habits of thriftiness will stand these men in good stead when they are behind bars or out in the street and find it necessary to assemble the funds to buy cigarettes or a cheese sandwich,'' the magazine said. Trump's lenders in recent days have raised concern that his holdings, which include hotels, casinos and airplanes, aren't generating enough cash to support his empire's debts.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Urge People to Question Communist Party, Reject Political Pluralism
DOC.TEXT: The leaders of Albania say the ruling Communist Party now stands ready to accept criticism and advice from the people, but they ruled out ending the party's political monopoly. Albania's state-run ATA news agency, in a dispatch from the country's capital of Tirana Tuesday, quoted remarks by Communist Party leader Ramiz Alia and Nexhmija Hoxa, widow of Enver Hoxa, the founder of Communist Albania. It quoted the two as urging the country's Communist-dominated Democratic Front mass organization to be more independent of the ruling party. The country's leaders have in recent weeks begun to move away from the rigid Stalinism that has made Albania the most controlled and isolated country in Europe during the postwar period. Like similar organizations set up elsewhere in Eastern Europe where Communists consolidated power after World War II, the Democratic Front was set up in Albania ostensibly to give non-Communists a forum. But in Albania, the Front's real function was to endorse Communist policies. Ms. Hoxa, the Front's chairwoman, was quoted by ATA as saying that Albanians ``are invited to the open party meetings, with the right of demanding explanations and discussing on an equal footing with the Communists.'' ``The fact that the masses are invited and urged not only to have their say, but to have the power to make decisions, testified to the great political trust the party has in them,'' she was quoted as saying. In separate comments, Alia urged Front members to show more independence, saying ``it is only natural that there will be a diversity of opinions, even a pluralist treatment'' of issues within the organization, the agency said. Ms. Hoxha, however, drew clear lines as to how far pluralism could go, rejecting ``artificially created parties, which represent nobody,'' ATA said. Albania has moved this spring to reform some of the most restrictive aspects of its social and economic system, while pledging to open itself more to the outside world. Officials have said that travel abroad _ difficult if not impossible for decades _ would be made freer for average citizens. They also abolished the death penalty for those trying to flee the country, and announced they were seeking to establish ties to European organizations and mend relations with the superpowers. Religion, officially banned for decades, has again become acceptable. Ms. Hoxha emphasized the new stance at the meeting, ATA said, quoting her as saying ``the right to believe or not is a matter of conscience for everybody.''

DOC.HEAD: Avenson Wins Democratic Nomination to Oppose Branstad
DOC.TEXT: House Speaker Don Avenson rode a pro-choice abortion campaign to the Democratic nomination for governor, foreshadowing a general election debate on abortion with Republican Gov. Terry Branstad. ``You have nominated yourself a tiger, a tiger for the ordinary people,'' Avenson told cheering supporters as he claimed victory in Tuesday's primary. Avenson outdistanced an anti-abortion Democrat, Attorney General Tom Miller, and another pro-choice candidate, former banker John Chrystal. Avenson was strongly supported by pro-choice groups. With 99 percent of the state's precincts reporting, Avenson had 78,767 votes, or 39 percent, to Miller's 63,129, or 32 percent, and Chrystal's 52,031, or 26 percent. Two minor candidates split the remainder. Chrystal said the pro-choice groups, particularly the National Abortion Rights Action League, had made the difference for Avenson. ``NARAL's endorsement really brought votes to Avenson,'' Chrystal said. Branstad opposes abortion and faced no primary contest. Avenson said he will turn immediately to the uphill fight in November. He conceded that Branstad has a huge financial edge. Branstad has raised more than $2.5 million, while Avenson is essentially broke. He said he has pledges for $65,000 to begin the fight. Branstad responded to the primary results by sounding a theme likely to be repeated this fall _ that Avenson had won with the help of a ``typical special-interest type of support.'' Miller urged his backers to unite behind Avenson, and all three Democratic candidates called for party unity. ``Put the primary behind us _ it's over,'' Miller said. ``I'll do anything I can to help win this campaign, to win the governor's race. This is the end of one campaign but the beginning of another.'' Shelley Bain, of the Iowa NARAL affiliate, said voters will now have a choice over abortion policy in the November governor's race. Still, she insisted that other issues had played a role in Avenson's victory. Abortion, she said, ``was important, but it wasn't everything.'' Abortion foes discounted the election, saying Miller waffled on the issue and didn't make a strong appeal. ``Tom Miller was really, at best, a weak candidate from the pro-life standpoint,'' said Mona Smit of the Iowa Right to Life Committee. ``Our position is NARAL didn't beat Miller, Tom Miller beat Tom Miller.''

DOC.HEAD: Bradley Handily Defeats Primary Opponent
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Sen. Bill Bradley looked ahead to his fall campaign against Republican challenger Christine Todd Whitman after swamping an unknown in the Democratic primary. With 5,290 of 5,845 precincts reporting in Tuesday's Democratic primary, the two-term senator had 176,213 votes, or 93 percent, to 14,235 votes, or 7 percent, for Daniel Seyler. Mrs. Whitman, who was unopposed, drew 98,153 votes with 5,289 precincts reporting. Bradley indicated Tuesday night that he was taking nothing for granted despite being the overwhelming favorite in the general election and having amassed a $10 million-plus warchest, 75 percent of it from out of state. ``You take every race you're in seriously, just like you took every game you were in seriously,'' said the former New York Knicks basketball star. The surprise of the primary was the 12th District GOP upset in the battle to succeed retiring Rep. James Courter, who decided not to run for re-election after losing the gubernatorial race to Democrat Jim Florio. Former New York Giants wide receiver Phil McConkey pulled into second place, dividing the moderate vote and allowing state Sen. Richard A. Zimmer _ a fiscal conservative and environmentalist _ to defeat the favorite, Assemblymen Rodney Frelinghuysen, and grab the party nomination. Zimmer will face Democrat Marguerite Chandler on the November ballot. Camden Democrat Robert Andrews easily won a four-way contest for the nomination to seek Florio's congressional seat in the 1st District. He faces Gloucester County Freeholder Daniel Mangini, who ran unopposed for the GOP nomination, in November. Andrews also won the party's nomination to run in the special election to serve the rest of Florio's eighth term, which ends in January. Mrs. Whitman has vowed to run a clean, issues-oriented race, but some political observers believe her campaign could tarnish Bradley as a future presidential contender. Bradley, 46, continued to sidestep talk that he might seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 1992, saying he planned to serve out his six-year Senate term if he wins re-election. During the primary campaign, Mrs. Whitman, 43, focused on Bradley's campaign spending. She expects to spend $1.5 million. Mrs. Whitman entered her first race for statewide elected office after the state GOP took a battering in last year's gubernatorial election, but denied she agreed to run in exchange for party support in a future bid for governor.

DOC.HEAD: Veteran GOP Politician Prepares To Take On Baucus
DOC.TEXT: Montana Republicans tapped Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad to challenge Democratic U.S. Sen. Max Baucus, who brushed aside his primary opposition but said he's taking nothing for granted in November. Baucus, raised more than $2 million in campaign money even before Tuesday's primary victory, but recalled the 1988 upset of Democratic Sen. John Melcher by upstart Republican Conrad Burns. ``One never takes anything for granted _ ever,'' said Baucus, 48. Kolstad, a 58-year-old farmer-rancher and 20-year veteran of Montana politics, bested three rivals in a hotly contested GOP primary. With 98 percent of 967 precincts reporting early today, Kolstad had 36,897 votes, or 43 percent; to 30,451 votes, or 36 percent, for scientist-businessman Bruce Vorhauer; 11,484, or 13 percent, for state Sen. Bill Farrell; and 6,525, or 8 percent, for businessman John Domenech. Kolstad promised a campaign that would ``keep Senator Baucus up against the ropes right from the beginning.'' ``We're just going to have to outwork him,'' he said. ``We're used to putting in a lot of 16- and 18-hour days on the ranch. We're going to convert that energy into the campaign.'' Baucus had 79,131 votes, or 83 percent, to 12,444 votes, or 13 percent for state Public Service Commissioner John Driscoll; and 4,321 votes, or 5 percent, for evangelist Curly Thornton. Kolstad was recruited by national Republicans, including President Bush and former President Reagan. Baucus, pointing to the national GOP involvement, predicted that Kolstad's campaign would be run from Washington. Kolstad, emphasized his farming background and his lifelong ties to Montana. The emphasis also was a slap at Vorhauer, who moved his legal residence to Montana only last fall. Vorhauer, 48, is best known as the inventor of the Today contraceptive sponge. His campaign stressed his engineering and science background as qualifying him to bring high-tech businesses to the state. Farrell, 41, who operates a small independent trucking firm, touted his working-man image. Domenech, 36, campaigned for a national health plan. Baucus ran a quiet primary campaign, with neither of his challengrs having much in the way of money or organizations.

DOC.HEAD: N.J. School-Funding System Deemed Unfair; Texas Closer to Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey joined a dozen states where courts have struck down school-funding systems for shortchanging the poor. In one of those states, Texas, an education-finance overhaul package was speeding through the Legislature. In a 7-0 ruling Tuesday, New Jersey's Supreme Court ordered lawmakers to ensure by the 1991-92 school year that poor districts are able to spend about as much per student as wealthier districts in the 1.3 million-student system. The decision is widely expected to force lawmakers to raise taxes, as has happened in Kentucky, Arkansas, Wyoming and other states. Texas' House and Senate approved tax increases Tuesday. The wave of court orders rejecting the way states fund schools is a legacy of the rich-get-richer, poor-get-poorer 1980s, one expert said. ``Since 1980, the gap between rich districts and poor districts has been increasing, that's why we have this trend. The poor are more hard-pressed than they were during the 1970s,'' said Arthur Wise, director of the Washington-based RAND Center for the Study of the Teaching Profession. In most states, schools are supported primarily by local property taxes. The New Jersey court found the setup unconstitutional. It ruled, in effect, that determining school funding based on property tax revenue is unfair. ``The evidence compels but one conclusion: the poorer the district and the greater its need, the less the money available, and the worse the education,'' Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz wrote. ``These students simply cannot possibly enter the same market or the same society as their peers educated in wealthier districts.'' The court estimated the state needs to add $440 million to its $3.5 billion schools budget to end the disparities. Lawmakers may devise any remedy they wish but cannot force poor districts to raise property taxes, the court said. Gov. Jim Florio called the ruling ``a clear victory for the children of New Jersey.'' ``The court has recognized that the current school funding system is leading us to be two New Jerseys _ where some youngsters head for the best colleges, and others go down a road to nowhere,'' he said. The governor last week unveiled a plan to increase income taxes to raise $1 billion for more aid to middle-income and poor districts. Under the plan, aid to wealthier school systems would be reduced or eliminated. State supreme courts in Montana, Kentucky and Texas have struck down school-funding systems in the past 18 months. Courts also have overturned funding systems in Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming and Arkansas. Lawsuits are pending in several other states, including Alaska, Connecticut and Oregon. ``I think we are re-entering a period of school finance litigation,'' said Chris Pipho, director of state relations for the Denver-based Education Commission of the States. The Texas Supreme Court in October declared that state's system unconstitutional, and lawmakers have been meeting under a court deadline since February to devise a remedy. On Tuesday the Senate approved and sent to the House a $528 million education reform bill. And both chambers passed a bill that would raise sales taxes by a quarter-cent and increase taxes on mixed drinks and tobacco to pay for the reforms. The Kentucky Supreme Court overturned that state's funding system last year, forcing lawmakers to raise taxes to pay for $500 million more in education aid. The Education Law Center in Newark, N.J., filed the lawsuit in 1981 that led to Tuesday's ruling on behalf of children in such poor areas as Camden, Jersey City and East Orange. Former Gov. Thomas H. Kean had fought the lawsuit and defended the funding system. The court found that in 1984, New Jersey districts spent an average of $4,030 per pupil, while the poorest school systems spent only about $2,860 per pupil. ``The fact is that a large part of our society is disintegrating, so large a part that it cannot help but affect the rest,'' the court said. ``Everyone's future is at stake, and not just the poor's.''

DOC.HEAD: Stock Index Gains Against Yen
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index, recovering from a morning setback, closed slightly higher today, while the dollar gained against the Japanese yen for the seventh consecutive trading day. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 31.88 points, or 0.1 percent, closing at 32,953.50. The index, which rose 3.75 points Tuesday, was down 74.53 points at the end of the morning session before rebounding in the afternoon. Traders said investors mainly were making position adjustments on the eve of the last trading day for June futures issues. Yoshiro Inoue, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co., said most market players avoided major moves other than position adjustments. ``Transactions in the spot market were relatively small as many market players are now selling June futures issues and buying September issues. As long as arbitrage selling of spot issues is not involved, there is little negative impact on the Nikkei,'' he said. Volume on the first section was estimated at 600 million shares, unchanged from Tuesday. The dollar's stability above 152 yen also contributed to the relative inacticity, Inoue added. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 152.60 yen, up 0.17 yen from Tuesday's 152.43-yen finish. It opened at 152.45 yen and ranged between 152.27 yen and 152.60 yen. The dollar now has gained 3.15 yen in the last seven days, although it has moved only slightly in the last few days. ``Market players were mainly trading the yen and the West German mark,'' said Eiichi Seino, a dealer with Fuji Bank. ``Market players generally believe the U.S. economy is slowing down and are reluctant to buy the dollar, but participants are inclined to pick up the currency whenever it falls near the 152-yen line,'' he said. Seino said the dollar-yen will remain within the 152-153 yen range until next week's scheduled announcement of a series of U.S. economic data. Some $7.53 billion changed hands in spot trading. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds slipped to 87.81 points at 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT) from Tuesday's 88.11-point finish. The yield rose to 6.990 percent from the previous day's 6.945 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Temblor Shakes Pacific Nation
DOC.TEXT: A pair of earthquakes damaged homes and caused landslides on Vanuatu's Mere Lava Island, Radio Vanuatu reported. There were no reports of casualties in the quake Tuesday. A Richter scale measurement of the quake's force was not immediately available. Davidson Lilip, secretary to the Banks-Torres local government council, said today that most of the damage was at Tasmat village, where about 400 people live. He said most of the damage was caused by the second, stronger earthquake, which followed the first temblor by about 90 minutes. He added that a series of aftershocks was keeping residents' nerves on edge. Vanuatu is a double chain of about 80 islands some 1,350 miles northeast of Sydney, Australia.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``This has been a terrible century, with wars, with tears and the Germans had a part in this. ... Let me tell you, you can trust the Germans.'' _ West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, trying to lay to rest fears a unified Germany represents a threat to Europe.

``It would be a great blow if we lost Greyhound everywhere. ... An awful lot of people who cannot or would not fly, I don't know how they would get around.'' _ Lera Dwyer, owner of Skylark Transportation in Wichita Falls, Texas, discussing the difficulty of intercity transportation in rural America.

``If politically countries are changing, why should information agencies work in the same manner, the old manner.'' _ Alexander Malyshkin, senior information officer for the Soviet Embassy, making good on Nikita Khrushchev's prediction to bury the West, but with press releases sent via fax machines.

DOC.HEAD: Generation Gap Marks New Mexico Governor's Race
DOC.TEXT: The fall campaign for governor will be a generational contest between former Gov. Bruce King, a Democrat who's already the state's longest-serving governor, and a younger Republican, Frank Bond. Each of the men, who are both ranchers and businessmen, defeated three rivals Tuesday to win their parties' nominations. Incumbent Gov. Garrey Carruthers, a Republican, is prohibited by state law from seeking a second term in the Nov. 6 general election. In a victory speech, the 66-year-old King stressed that he ``won't need any on-the-job training, so we'll begin immediately to doing the things that need to be done for all of the people of New Mexico.'' He served two four-year terms as governor, from 1971 to 1975 and from 1979 to 1983. Bond, 46, set the tone of his campaign with remarks in which he promised younger, fresher leadership. ``We don't want to turn back any political clock,'' he said. King held off former Attorney General Paul Bardacke in the four-way Democratic contest. With all but 38 of the state's 1,400 precincts reporting, he had 91,330 votes to Bardacke's 68,190, a 52-to-39 percent margin. Bond trounced state Senate Republican leader Les Houston by 55 percent to 33 percent. With all but 42 of the state's 1,400 precincts reporting, Bond had 44,047 votes to Houston's 26,595 votes. Also in the primary, Tom Udall, the son of former Arizona congresman and Interior Secretary Stewart Udall, was nominated as the Democratic candidate for attorney general. He will run against Republican state Sen. Bill Davis, who was unopposed in Tuesday's primary. Under a change in the state constitution, the governor elected in November will be the first allowed to run for a second, consecutive four-year term. Since 1970, governors were limited to one four-year term in a row; before that, New Mexico governors served two-year terms.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Reassure North Koreans on Ties with South
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government news agency has sought to reassure North Korea that the Kremlin will not let its relations with the Communist state be damaged by Soviet moves to establish ties with South Korea. Tass said in a commentary Tuesday that Mikhail S. Gorbachev's meeting with President Roh Tae-woo of South Korea had been described by Western media as a ``political sensation'' marking ``drastic changes'' in Moscow's Asia policy. The commentary, by political analyst Yuri Kornilov, did not specify which news outlets were making those claims.
