Roh told reporters after meeting the Soviet leader in San Francisco Monday that the two countries would establish diplomatic ties. But Gorbachev was vague on the prospects of South Korean-Soviet ties, saying only, ``We will let the fruit grow ripe, and when the fruit grows ripe, we will eat it.'' The Tass commentary was an effort to reassure North Korea that the Soviet Union has no intention of doing anything to hurt its relations with the Communist state, which is ruled by Kim Il Sung. Kornilov said the Roh-Gorbachev meeting was a sensation only because it was the first between leaders of the Soviet Union and South Korea _ not because it signals any change in Soviet policy. ``As to prospects for the establishment of diplomatic relations, of which much is being written and said in the West nowadays, the Soviet stand is well known and remains unchanged: this issue can be considered only in connection with further improvement of the situation in the Korean peninsula.'' Kornilov continued: ``Of course, the removal of ideological blinkers from our foreign policy and the course towards broader economic contacts and political dialogue with other countries in no way means that we give up our principled positions and priorities or forgo the interests of third countries.'' And he reassured North Korea, ``Our country will continue to maintain and promote in all ways its traditionally close political, economic and other ties'' with North Korea. The Tass analyst said the Soviet Union continues to support North Korean proposals for peace on the peninsula. Korea was divided in 1945 at the end of World War II, when Soviet and U.S. Troops ended Japan's colonial rule. The division deepened after the two Koreas fought a war in 1950-53. In South Korea, newspapers reported today that the country's foreign minister, Choi Ho-Joong, plans to visit Moscow next month to discuss terms of establishing formal ties. Dong-A Ilbo and Joong-ang Ilbo, in dispatches by correspondents who accompanied Roh on his U.S. visit, said Choi plans to meet Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. They said Shevardnadze would then be invited to visit Seoul about a month later to finalize terms for opening formal diplomatic relations. Roh was to meet with President Bush in Washington today. Despite the lack of diplomatic relations, South Korea and the Soviet Union have greatly increased trade and investment in recent years. Their trade jumped 10 times from 1985 to $600 million last year and is expected to top $1 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0452 to fix category code.
Presbyterians Adopt Statement on Sexual Equality, Environment
DOC.TEXT: The corporate merger of the northern and southern branches of the Presbyterian Church in 1983 has become a theological merger. Cheers rang out at the Salt Palace in this Mormon heartland after commissioners to the 202nd General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) approved 499-25 a new statement of faith Tuesday that combines traditional Christian beliefs with contemporary concerns for the environment and sexual equality. ``For the first time, this denomination speaks for itself as a theological body. That to me is of epochal significance,'' said the Rev. M. Douglas Harper, a Houston pastor who served on the drafting committee. If the document is approved by two-thirds of the denomination's 177 regional presbyteries and again by the 1991 General Assembly, it will become the 11th statement of faith in the 2.9 million-member church's Book of Confessions. The new statement of faith is the denomination's first since the merger healed a 122-year-old split dating to the Civil War and the slavery issue. ``As far as we know, this is the first confession of the church that declares as a matter of faith women are called to all ministries of the church,'' said Jane Dempsey Douglass, vice-chairwoman of the drafting committee. The confession also likens God to both a mother who will not forsake her nursing child and a father ``who runs to welcome the prodigal home.'' On the environment, the confession says humans deserve God's condemnation for the way they ``threaten death to the planet entrusted to our care.'' At the same time, the statement upholds centuries-old church teachings that Jesus Christ was both fully human and fully God, and that God raised Jesus from the dead to offer eternal life. Some church leaders said the confession is vital for the denomination, which has lost a third of its members in the past quarter century amid criticism it lacked a strong identity. ``The theological integrity of the Presbyterian Church depends on the statement of faith,'' said the Rev. Jack L. Stotts, chairman of the committee that developed the confession. In other business, the assembly voted to allocate $1 million for a five-year program to set up self-help programs for black men. The church is less than 2 percent black. The church leaders also voted 395-52 to work toward normalized relations with Cuba, including reducing trade and travel restrictions. A call for free elections there was defeated.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor's Suicide Machine Kills Alzheimer's Patient
LaserPhotos PD1, PD2
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors today weighed criminal charges against a doctor who hooked an Alzheimer's patient to a poison-injecting suicide machine that let her take her life with the press of a button. Janet Adkins, a 54-year-old Portland, Ore., woman, died Monday after traveling 2,000 miles to use the device built by Dr. Jack Kevorkian, a retired pathologist and outspoken advocate of what he calls doctor-assisted suicide. ``Her last words to me were something like, `Thank you, thank you very much,''' he said. ``I wished her a good trip, and as I leaned over her she seemed like she was rising to meet me, perhaps to give me a kiss of gratitude.'' The 62-year-old suburban Detroit doctor also said the woman told him, ``You just make my case known.'' As it became known, prosecutors considered whether it was illegal and medical professionals debated whether it was ethical. Prosecutors seized the machine and said they would seek a court order today banning use of the device while the case is considered. ``There are many issues here,'' County Prosecutor Richard Thompson said Tuesday. ``Suicide is not a crime in Michigan. ... But it's not the desire of the deceased that's in question, it's the actions of those involved.'' Case law in Michigan is unclear on whether assisting a suicide is a crime, Thompson said. In Oregon, providing the means to commit suicide is a felony. Mrs. Adkins' husband called the device humane and said his wife had the right to take her life. ``She loved life. She just lived life to the fullest,'' Ron Adkins said Tuesday in Portland. ``She was a powerful woman and she was an intelligent woman. I was the weak one. She was strong. She had made up her mind.'' Adkins released a note his wife had written: ``I have Alzheimer's disease and do not want to let it progress any farther. I don't choose to put my family or myself through the agony of this terrible disease.'' One of the couple's three sons, Neil, told KGW-TV in Portland, ``She was in a very good state of mind, that's the amazing thing. It was not a desperate thing or a depressed situation. She was the one that helped us all through it.'' Diana Smith of the Hemlock Society, which advocates suicide rights, said: `It's unfortunate that Mrs. Adkins had to go so far to get the assistance she desired.'' Smith said Kevorkian used Michigan as a testing ground because it is the only state that doesn't have specific laws against assisting a suicide. Some ethicists said the doctor acted in violation of the Hippocratic Oath. ``Physicians should not be killers, even in cases where the patient requests it and there is a compassionate reason behind the act,'' said Susan Wolf of the Hastings Center for biomedical research in Briarcliff, N.Y. ``They take an oath to do no harm, and taking a life is doing harm.'' Kevorkian said the Adkinses, members of the National Hemlock Society, traveled to Michigan with a friend on Friday. On Monday, he drove her in his van to a park. Her husband stayed behind at the couple's motel. ``She was anxious and didn't want to delay,'' Kevorkian said. ``But she was the calm _ the calmest one involved with the procedure. I can tell you from experience, it was rough.'' Kevorkian said he and one of his relatives attached Mrs. Adkins to a heart monitor, then put an intravenous tube in her arm. The machine consists of a motor and an aluminum frame from which tubes of chemicals are suspended. The tube first delivered a saline solution. Kevorkian said Mrs. Adkins then pressed a button that injected thiopental, a coma-inducing drug, followed moments later by potassium chloride, which stops the heart within minutes. He said she was unconscious in 25 seconds and died in five or six minutes. After Mrs. Adkins' death, Kevorkian notified police, who confiscated both his Volkswagen van and the device. Mrs. Adkins was diagnosed with Alzheimer's a year ago and decided then she would end her life, her 57-year-old husband said. Alzheimer's is a degenerative brain and nerve disorder that robs people of their memories and their ability to function. An estimated 4 million U.S. adults, mostly over age 65, have the disease. Kevorkian said he developed the device last fall, inspired by a quadriplegic in Michigan who fought 18 years for the right to die. He died last year. The doctor said in March that he expected to be prosecuted after the first use of the device. He also said he would not charge patients and that he might use it to take his own life some day. ``It's dignified, humane and painless, and the patient can do it in the comfort of their own home at any time they want,'' he said last year. ``I'm here to help anybody who's in distress, or thinks he is. I couldn't let dogs suffer like that, how can I let a human?''

DOC.HEAD: Striking Canadian Truckers Reject Offer; Border Blockades Removed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollar figures are Canadian.
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,500 independent British Columbia truckers shouted down a settlement offer, putting back into gear a strike that has slowed deliveries of food and fuel across the U.S. border. The truckers warned of new forms of protest, after a court injunction forced them to stop using their rigs to block border crossings. The settlement offer was presented to more than 1,500 truckers Tuesday night at a fairground in this Vancouver suburb. The truckers didn't even bother using ballots they were handed and overwhelmingly shouted the offer down. More talks were set for today. There are about 3,000 independent truckers in British Columbia, about one-quarter of all truckers in the province. The proposal, crafted with help from a mediator, would have set a minimum hauling rate of $35 an hour, going up to $40 by January. The truckers want $40 now. The independents, who pay their own running costs and maintain their vehicles, are paid $26 to $35 an hour. Earlier Tuesday, truckers removed their rigs blocking most commercial traffic at the border between Washington state and British Columbia. The drivers were served with an injunction late Monday. The blockades had been in place since Thursday at crossings north of Blaine, Oroville, Sumas and Lynden in Washington, and at two major Canadian highways. The blockades were the most serious in a series of escalating job actions since independent truckers went on strike in late May. The roadblocks resulted in food and fuel shortages in the province and in Point Roberts, a small Washington state peninsula accessible overland only through British Columbia. The blockades also forced a Burnaby truck manufacturer to lay off 450 employees Monday for lack of parts from the United States. Garnet Zimmerman, a spokesman for the Teamsters union, which supports striking members of the Western Owner-Operators Association, said new job actions are planned. Organizers want truckers to set up protests at highway scale stations, travel in convoys or gather their rigs at shopping malls to tell the public about their wage demands, he said. Teamsters official Don McGill blamed the breakdown on several large trucking companies that he said have refused to come to the bargaining table. About one-third of the 180 trucking companies in the dispute have been represented during talks. McGill said the truckers want all firms included in any contract. Last month, independent truckers in Ontario and Quebec blocked border crossings, costing the Big Three automakers millions of dollars and threatening food shortages. The blockades were part of the truckers' fight for higher rates.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Plains; Some Rain in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms lingered in the northern and central Plains early today, and dry weather prevailed across much of the rest of the nation. Rain fell in the Northwest and along Lake Erie. Parts of the Northeast had cool overnight temperatures. Thunderstorms were expected across the upper Midwest into the New England mountains. Scattered thunderstorms are also likely along the Gulf coast and Florida. Rain and stormy weather were likely in the lower Ohio Valley. In the desert Southwest, temperatures were expected to pass 110 degrees for the third time this week, and the upper Plains also were to be unseasonably hot. The West was expected to be dry, with clear skies, except for showers in parts of the Northwest. Overcast skies were forecast east of the Mississippi, with the exception of a swath across the Deep South. On Tuesday, a powerful late spring storm swept across the central and eastern United States. Rain and thunderstorms were scattered from Florida to Louisiana. A few showers were over Maine, western Texas and Oregon. Blustery northwest winds prevailed across the Northeast. Afternoon highs were only in the upper 40s to lower 60s in the Great Lakes region. The nation's high on Tuesday was 114 at Bullhead City and Gila Bend, both in Arizona. DOC.HEAD: Supervisors to Appeal Federal Ruling
DOC.TEXT: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors will appeal a federal judge's ruling that it illegally diluted Hispanic voting strength in drawing district boundaries in 1981. The board's conservative majority voted 3-0 Tuesday to continue the 2-year-old, $3 million court battle. Of the five-member board's two liberal members, one dissented but left before the vote, and the other abstained. Conservative Pete Schabarum, who is retiring, accused U.S. District Judge David Kenyon of exerting ``extraordinary personal bias'' in Monday's ruling. Kenyon said the board members conspired to ``protect their incumbencies and that of their allies'' when they redrew the county's voting districts in 1981. In so doing, Kenyon added, the supervisors violated the 1965 federal Voting Rights Act and the equal protection clause of the 14th Amendment to the Constitution. A lawsuit filed in 1988 accused the supervisors of deliberately spreading the county's Hispanic population across several districts. The plaintiffs included a Hispanic organization and the U.S. Justice Department. Hispanics make up about 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million people. No Hispanic has been elected to the board in more than 100 years. Kenyon scheduled a conference for Thursday to discuss options, such as ordering an immediate redrawing of district boundaries. Plaintiffs in the lawsuit have said the results of Tuesday's elections in two districts should be thrown out.

DOC.HEAD: Perpich Gets The `Why Minnesota?' Question Answered By Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rudy Perpich had the same question many others have asked _ why Minnesota? But unlike many others, he got to ask Mikhail Gorbachev himself during the Soviet president's visit on Sunday. The answer: ``Warm feelings.'' ``One of the first questions I asked was ... `Why did you pick Minnesota?''' Perpich told a crowd Tuesday at the family farm Gorbachev dropped from his itinerary at the last minute. ``He said, `I decided to come to Minnesota.' Then he talked about reasons why he came to Minnesota. He said over the years, in various conversations and meetings, he's had a warm feeling toward Minnesota,'' Perpich said. The Soviet Union has had had strong business to Minnesota over the years, buying such things as computers from Control Data Corp. Perpich was at the dairy farm owned by Richard and Cecilia Brand to watch the release of a bald eagle into the wild. It had been hoped that Gorbachev would release the bird himself to symbolize U.S.-Soviet friendship. The bird had been captured March, suffering from insecticide poisoning. It had been recovering at the University of Minnesota's Raptor Center before Brand cradled it in his arms and tossed it to freedom. ``I'm more comfortable with cows,'' quipped Brand, a dairy farmer. Perpich said he did not know exactly why the farm visit was canceled. But he offered lunch at the governor's mansion for the Brand family and all who helped out with the farm preparations to make up for the disappointment. Mrs. Brand said that would be very nice. Her husband emphasized that he was not bitter about being skipped. ``At least I got some work done,'' he said, referring to the help he got from the advance team in sprucing up the farm. Brand said he spent more than $1,000 to make the place look better and hire extra hands to do chores. Asked if the Brands would be reimbursed, the governor said he would bring it up with the committee that arranged the visit, adding, ``That's a good point.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Lower, Gold Rises
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was lower against other major foreign currencies in quiet European trading today. Gold prices rose. Although the dollar was below its late Tuesday levels, the currency was rising from lows reached in Asia earlier in the day, dealers said. They said the dollar was getting support from statements of several U.S. Federal Reserve officials that interest rates weren't likely to decline soon. They said it also was being boosted by the news of further violent clashes in the Soviet Union's central Asian republic of Kirghizia and reports of continued demonstrations in China marking the first anniversary of the military quashing of the student demonstrations. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.17 yen to a closing 152.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 152.65 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6865 West German marks, down from 1.6910 _1.4285 Swiss francs, down from 1.4340 _5.6877 French francs, down from 5.7020 _1.9000 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9070 _1,240.50 Italian lire, down from 1,244.25 _1.1737 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1752 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6855, compared with $1.6820 late Tuesday. Gold bullion opened in London today at a bid price of $359.25 a troy ounce, unchanged from late Tuesday. Dealers later fixed a recommended price of $359.80 a troy ounce. In Zurich, the bid price was $359.80, up from $358.60 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $1.55 to close at a bid $361.42. Silver was unchanged in London at a bid price of $5.08 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Swastikas, Blood and Human Bones In Classroom
DOC.TEXT: Vandals broke into a high school, painted swastikas on the walls and left behind blood-soaked human skulls and bones, police said today. The vandalism was discovered Tuesday when students returned after a three-day holiday weekend to the Bernard-Palissy high school in Gien, on the Loire River about 75 miles south of Paris. The intruders, who apparently climbed in through a window, painted swastikas and Jewish Stars of David on the ground floor, cut telephone cords, then went to the second floor and left blood-covered human bones, including about six skulls, police said. Slogans were written on the walls in German. Tests were being conducted to determine when the bones were dug up and where the blood came from. There has been a wave of neo-Nazi and anti-Semitic vandalism across France in the past four weeks, following the discovery May 10 of a macabre desecration at a Jewish cemetery in the southern town of Carpentras. Thirty-four tombs there were vandalized, and the body of an elderly man was dug up and impaled on an umbrella handle.

DOC.HEAD: Ethical, Legal Debates Swirl After Suicide Machine is Used
With PM-Suicide Machine, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: When Alzheimer's patient Janet Adkins pressed the button on a suicide machine and chose death over mental degeneration, she stirred debate over the ethics of euthanasia and sent prosecutors to the law books. The 54-year-old Portland, Ore., woman on Monday became the first person to die using Dr. Jack Kevorkian's suicide device. After her husband of 34 years told her once more that he loved her, Mrs. Adkins had Kevorkian hook her intravenously to the machine inside his van parked in a suburban park. She hit the button, coma-inducing thiopental and a lethal dose of potassium chloride dripped into her veins, and within six minutes she was dead. She and her husband, Ron, were members of the Hemlock Society, which supports the option of sucide for the terminally ill. But assisting someone's suicide is explicitly illegal in Oregon; the Adkinses flew to Michigan, where the law is not so clear, after they read about Kevorkian's device and after experimental Alzheimer's cures failed. ``It's unfortunate that Mrs. Adkins had to go so far to get the assistance she desired,'' Hemlock Society spokeswoman Diana Smith said from the group's office in Eugene, Ore. ``Since Michigan is the only state in the union that doesn't have specific laws against people who assist in suicide, Kevorkian used it as a testing ground,'' Smith said. ``What happened Monday kind of opens the door for seeing these laws are outdated and need to be changed.'' Other vehemently disagreed. ``This ghoulish event illustrates the lengths that medicine can go once doctors violate the Hippocratic Oath and tradition which separates the killer from the care-giver,'' said Mary Senander, director of the International Anti-Euthanasia Task Force of Steubenville, Ohio. The American Medical Association considers passive euthanasia ethical, said lawyer Reinhard Priester of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota. Passive euthanasia might, for example, involve the withholding of food to a comatose patient believed to have no chance of recovery, he said. But Priester said that Kevorkian, by arranging a suicide with the patient's consent, appeared to have participated in active euthanasia _ which the AMA has deemed morally inappropriate. ``Clearly, what he provided her is not something that would relieve her pain and suffering,'' Priester said. ``The clear intent of providing those two chemicals was to hasten the patient's death.'' Whether Kevorkian's action is legal in Michigan is what Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson is now trying to decide. He said Tuesday he believes a 1920 Michigan Supreme Court decision makes abetting a suicide illegal, although he hasn't decided whether to bring charges. In 1920, the court upheld the murder conviction of a man who placed a bottle of poison within reach of his wife, who wanted to commit suicide, Thompson said. But a 1983 state Court of Appeals decision said a man who gave a gun to a friend who used it to commit suicide shouldn't have been charged, he said. ``The state Supreme Court refused to hear the 1983 case, saying that if the 1920 decision were no longer the law of the land, then it was the high court that should have made the decision. It did not,'' Thompson said. Kevorkian, a longtime advocate of euthanasia, said Tuesday he expected to be prosecuted. ``What I am doing was ethical even in Hippocrates' day. I guess highly emotional people would call it murder,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Begins Sentence at Child-Find Agency
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `Last July...', to FIX second reference to Pfeiffer to Pigeon. Trims.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who refuses to tell a judge the whereabouts of her two granddaughters has begun serving a sentence at a missing-children's agency. The judge said he hoped 15 hours a week at the agency would persuade 76-year-old Mary Pigeon to lead authorities to the girls and their mother, who left their Warwick home five years ago. ``I don't know where she is,'' Pigeon said Tuesday after leaving work at the Society for Young Victims, a small office across from City Hall with photos of missing children plastered across the windows. ``I wish I knew.'' Pigeon has said that all along, but Superior Court Judge Mark Pfeiffer said he ``absolutely'' has evidence Pigeon knows where her daughter took the children, and he imposed the sentence Monday in hopes of forcing her to comply. Elaine Yates left home in 1985 with her daughters _ 3{-year-old Kimberly and 10-month-old Kelly _ after she found her husband in bed with another woman. Russell Yates Jr. was awarded custody of his daughters after his wife failed to return to contest his request. He then sued his mother-in-law to compel her to disclose the whereabouts of the children. Last July, Pfeiffer ruled that Pigeon took part in the abduction and knew where her daughter and grandchildren were. He found her in contempt. The judge said he hoped Pigeon's time at the Newport agency would show her the anguish parents of missing children endure. ``If she sees firsthand working at this center 60 hours a month the kind of harm this does to families, hopefully within her conscience she will come forward,'' Pfeiffer said. The judge will call Pigeon back into court June 29 to review the case. Yates' attorney, Neil Philbin, said if she does not cooperate then, he will push the judge to jail her, as he did this week as well.

DOC.HEAD: China Frees 97, Including Student Leaders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf with 1 graf to CORRECT that Yao still in Shanghai. Pickup 7th graf `Rumors that...'
DOC.TEXT: China announced today it had freed 97 more participants in last year's democracy movement after the anniversary of the movement's bloody demise passed with only a few small protests. The releases bring to 881 the number freed in the past six months, out of thousands arrested. But new arrests have been reported as recently as last week. For the first time, two top student leaders were among those freed. Xiong Wei and Zhou Fengsuo, both students at Qinghua University, were on the government's list of 21 most-wanted students and were arrested last June. Zhou was turned in by his sister and Xiong surrendered in his mother's company, according to official accounts. The No. 1 student on the list, Wang Dan, remains in jail. Five others on the list escaped abroad. Of the 97 released, 21 had been jailed in Shanghai, a brief Xinhua News Agency report said. They included Yao Yongzhan, a Hong Kong student who was released Tuesday, the Hong Kong government reported. There was no word on when he would be allowed to return home. Rumors that a release was imminent circulated in Beijing last week. The government waited until after the anniversary Sunday and Monday of last year's army attack on student-led protesters in Beijing, in which hundreds and possibly thousands of people died. Soldiers and police patrolled Beijing in force on both days to head off any commemorative protests, and were largely successful. The only major incident, a rally Sunday night by hundreds of Beijing University students, was confined to the campus. Students on other campuses expressed their anger by smashing beer bottles, and several non-students held small protests near Tiananmen Square. Xinhua said the 97 were given lenient treatment after having ``voluntarily confessed their wrongdoings and expressed a willingness to repent.'' None had been charged or tried. ``Those who obstinately stick to an incorrect course and refuse to repent will be punished strictly in accordance with the law,'' Xinhua said. The protests last year began as a student movement and escalated into a massive nationwide outcry against the Communist Party's heavy-handed ad increasingly corrupt rule. Senior leader Deng Xiaoping and other aging revolutionaries who ordered the crackdown maintain that a small group of plotters orchestrated the protests in an effort to topple the party. They have rejected Western descriptions of the jailed protesters as political prisoners, and sentenced many to long terms. Twenty people have been executed, according to official reports, and many more by unofficial accounts. The releases did not signify a softening on the part of the party, but an attempt to put the turmoil behind it, ease deep-seated domestic anger over the crackdown and restore badly damaged relations with the West. Many of those freed earlier remain under forms of probation, and many have lost their jobs or been expelled from school _ harsh punishment in a system where most jobs are assigned. China announced in January that it had freed 573 people and in May that a second group of 211 were released, including several well-known academics and a famous journalist, Dai Qing. It said then that only 431 people were still being held for investigation. That figure left thousands unaccounted for, suggesting that it did not include those already sentenced. Among the most prominent people still jailed are Chen Zimin, the head of a non-government social research institute that has since been closed down; Liu Xiaobo, 34, a college lecturer; and Bao Zunxin, a fellow at the Institute of History of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. Six students on the most-wanted list are known to be still jailed. Five escaped abroad, and the whereabouts of eight are not known.

DOC.HEAD: Fighting Continues in Cambodia Despite Tokyo Peace Conference
DOC.TEXT: Forces loyal to Prince Nordom Sihanouk were engaged in heavy combat inside Cambodia today, despite Sihanouk's pledge a day earlier that his guerrillas no longer would fight in the 11-year-old conflict. Rocket and artillery fire could be heard from this Thai border province as Sihanouk forces engaged those of the Hun Sen government in Cambodia. ``There is heavy fighting now,'' said Roland Eng, spokesman for Sihanouk's guerrilla faction. ``Nothing will change for now. In Tokyo there was only an agreement, not implementation of a cease-fire. The fighting will continue.'' Sihanouk and Premier Hun Sen signed a communique in Tokyo on Tuesday that said Cambodia's warring factions ``should refrain from all offensive actions'' and that there should be measures to ensure a ``military standstill.'' Although the vaguely worded communique fell short of being a cease-fire agreement, Sihanouk told a news conference that his own forces and those of his non-Communist ally, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, would not take part in fighting inside Cambodia. Sihanouk said the war would continue between Hun Sen forces and the thrid faction of his resistance coalition, the Communist Khmer Rouge, which boycotted the Tokyo conference sessions and did not sign the communique. In Tokyo, Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said Japan still hopes the Khmer Rouge will join the agreement. He said Japan will ask for Chinese and Thai help to bring the radical faction into a cease-fire, news reports said. China is the main backer of the Khmer Rouge. ``The way is always open (for the Khmer Rouge) to join the joint agreement,'' Kyodo News Service quoted Nakayama as saying today. In Bangkok, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Igor Rogachev said he hoped further Cambodian peace talks expected to be held in Paris this summer could result in a freezing of arms supplies to all sides in the conflict. Eng said no orders had been received from Sihanouk in Tokyo to halt battlefield activity. He said it was his understanding that the Tokyo communique would not actually go into effect until a later date. Guerrilla sources said Cambodian government troops were trying to push back a 2,000-man guerrilla offensive that seized much of a strategic highway in Bantey Meanchey province in northwestern Cambodia. In recent days, press releases from Sihanouk's group in Thailand have claimed major victories in that province and other areas of Cambodia. One release said that on Tuesday, two of Sihanouk's units staged raids on Samrong, the capital of Bantey Meanchey. In addition, Western diplomats and Thai intelligence sources have confirmed some Khmer Rouge claims of major victories inside Cambodia in recent days.

DOC.HEAD: Precede: NICOSIA
Rafsanjani Wants U.S. To Pressure Israel To Free `Hostages'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with call for release of ``hostages'' held by Israel and Kuwait. Pickup 8th pvs, `Rafsanjani said...' CHANGES byline.
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani said today that Washington must pressure Israel and Kuwait to free Moslem prisoners if it wants help in gaining the release of the 16 Westerners held by kidnappers in Lebanon. ``The irresponsible, arrogant attitude of the United States has created further difficulties'' in resolving the hostage crisis, the turbaned Rafsanjani told a news conference for 200 foreign and local journalists. Iran's leaders and Shiite leaders in Lebanon have often demanded that the United States urge Israel to release 350 Moslem prisoners held in Israel and in Israel's self-declared security zone in southern Lebanon. However, it was the first time in some months that an Iranian leader referred to 15 Shiite Moslems jailed in Kuwait in 1984 for car bombings in that country that killed five people and wounded 86. Two American educators, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, were released by their pro-Iranian kidnappers at Tehran's bidding in April, and Iran said Washington should make a gesture in return. ``An appropriate response was expected after the Lebanese unconditionally set free the hostages _ release of hostages in Kuwait and Israel,'' Rafsanjani said without elaborating. ``Why don't you help increase the necessary public pressure on those governments to release these hostages, so that the Western hostages can be freed in return?'' the Iranian president asked the journalists. ``If the United States is serious about wanting relations with Iran in the future, it must begin to act, because talking is not enough,'' he added. Polhill and Reed were the first U.S. captives to be released in 3{ years. Six Americans are among the 16 Westerners still held by pro-Iranian kidnappers in Lebanon. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for the Associated Press, who was abducted in March 1985. Rafsanjani also said he did not rule out a peace summit with President Saddam Hussein of Iraq. But he said that will happen only after lower-level Iraqi-Iranian meetings are held to discuss reaching a permanent settlement to the Persian Gulf war, which ended in a cease-fire in August 1988. Referring to Iran's death threats against British author Salman Rushdie, he said ties with London could be resumed if Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher condemns his book ``The Satanic Verses.'' But he said there was no question of lifting the death decree on Rushdie, whose book Iran says defames Islam. Rafsanjani said Iran's policy was ``to help secure the release of all the hostages, whether they be Western, Lebanese or Iranian.'' The Iranian president reiterated his country's claim that four Iranians _ two diplomats, a journalist and a driver _ who were kidnapped by the Christian Lebanese Forces militia in 1982 are still alive. ``We have learned officially from a government, and from reliable sources in east Beirut, that the Iranian hostages are alive,'' Rafsanjani said. ``The special envoy of a certain government has informed us.'' He did not identify the country. The Bush administration recently provided Iran with information through the Swiss government which it said indicated the four men had been killed. Sources in the Lebanese Forces have said the Iranians were killed soon after they were seized. Rafsanjani has said repeatedly that if the West wants help in releasing hostages, it must help determine the fate of the four.

DOC.HEAD: Kayaker Missing After Paddling Over Niagara Falls
DOC.TEXT: A man who paddled a kayak over Niagara Falls in a stunt was still missing this morning and parks police resumed their search. The red kayak of Jessie W. Sharp, 28, of Ocoee, Tenn., was recovered Tuesday afternoon below Horseshoe Falls on the Canadian side. The kayak was ``all in one piece ... in fairly good condition, all things considered,'' said Maureen Quinn, a constable with the Niagara Parks Police. ``Our regular patrol is watching the river,'' Sgt. Jim Dugos said this morning. He said police can't dive there to look for a body. Asked if the man were presumed dead, he said: ``You never know. Sometimes these people turn up.'' Ken Kitchen was working in a tower overlooking the Niagara river when he saw Sharp in his kayak. Trying to stop him, the utility closed the dam gates, reducing the water flow to the falls, Kitchen said. The man's boat grounded, but he picked it up and moved it into the middle of the water. ``We did what we could to try and stop him, but there wasn't much time,'' Kitchen said. ``He was gone before our help could get there. All we could do was sit and watch helplessly.'' The Canadian falls are 181 feet high, or about as tall as a 13-story building. Sharp, who was last seen at about 1:45 p.m., was trying to complete a stunt that had been planned for about 10 years, said constable Kim Davis. Police said nobody before had ever tried to kayak over the falls. ``Barrels, yes,'' Quinn said of other attempts to go safely over the falls in enclosed capsules. But, she said, ``it doesn't seem plausible he could do it (and survive).'' Since 1901, at least 10 people have gone over the falls in barrels or rubber balls; seven have survived.

DOC.HEAD: Retired Police Officer Killed, Wife Injured in Belfast Car Bomb
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in the car of a retired police officer today as he drove near a primary school, killing the man and seriously injuring his wife, police said. Two other people walking along the road where the blast occurred in north Belfast were slightly injured, said a police spokesman, speaking anonymously in keeping with British custom. No organization claimed responsibility, but police said it bears similarities to previous bombings by the Irish Republican Army, the mainly Roman Catholic group fighting to end British rule of Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland. The bombing came two days after Protestant gunmen killed a Roman Catholic man, which followed the IRA killings of two British soldiers since Friday. A Roman Catholic priest today urged against a spiral of retaliation. Rescue workers cut the elderly couple from their wrecked car, but the man died later in hospital, police said. Their names were not released, but officials said the man was a 65-year-old retired member of the Royal Ulster Constabulary Reserve Force, police said. His wife, also in her 60s, was in critical condition in an intensive care unit, said a Mater Hospital spokesman. A passenger in a taxi driving behind the car said: ``The bomb seemed to go off under the driver's seat. The driver seemed to be in a bad way. It was a horrible sight.'' In Annaghmore, County Armagh, a Catholic priest told mourners at the funeral of the Catholic man killed on Monday that the burial should be a starting point for building a new, peaceful way of life. ``Forget about retaliation because retaliation brings nothing, only violence and more violence,'' said the Rev. Seamus McGinley. Patrick Boyle, 60, was gunned down at his home near Portdadown, 25 miles southwest of Belfast, on Monday. The Ulster Volunteer Force, an illegal Protestant organization, claimed responsibility for the killing. Boyle's two sons were also shot and wounded. The IRA wants to unite Northern Ireland, a British province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland.

DOC.HEAD: Michigan Governor Says He'll Run for Third Term
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James Blanchard has made it official _ he'll run for a third four-year term. Blanchard returned to his hometown Tuesday to make the announcement. He told a crowd of about 150 supporters that Michigan has turned itself around during his eight years in office, but there's much yet to be done. ``The fight for Michigan's future is not finished. Any politician can make promises. I offer something different _ not promises, but real solutions,'' Blanchard said in an apparent swipe at the all-but-certain Republican nominee, state Senate Majority Leader John Engler. Engler, who declared his candidacy in February, has hit hard at Blanchard. He claims the Democratic governor overstates Michigan's progress and that it is time for a new leader. Blanchard first was elected governor in 1982 after serving eight years in the U.S. House. John Lauve, a Grosse Pointe engineer, has also filed for the Republican nomination. No other Democrats filed for the Aug. 7 primary.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Bill To Ban Tobacco Advertising
DOC.TEXT: The government today proposed legislation that would give France one of the world's toughest anti-smoking laws and impose a total ban on tobacco ads in 1993. The bill approved today by the Cabinet also would severely restrict advertising for alcoholic beverages. Ads for hard liquor would be allowed only in publications geared specifically toward adults and must carry a message about the health hazards of drinking. Under the law, expected to win easy approval in the National Assembly, cigarette packs will have to carry a health warning and smoking will be banned in a wide range of public places. A separate bill is expected to be introduced soon that would raise cigarette prices by 15 percent _ the biggest single increase ever in France. The government sets cigarette prices. ``100,000 people die prematurely in France each year because of tobacco and excess alcohol consumption,'' said Cabinet spokesman Louis Le Pensac. ``This is an intolerable human, social and economic cost.'' Under the legislation, submitted by Health Minister Claude Evin, all direct and indirect tobacco advertising will be banned as of Jan. 1, 1993, including the sponsorship of sports and cultural events by tobacco companies. Even the use of cigarette trademarks as logos on non-tobacco items _ such as clothing or luggage _ will be banned, Le Pensac said. Cigarette manufacturers have contended that a ban on tobacco advertising would not affect consumption, but they estimate the proposed price increase will lower sales by 10 percent. Ironically, the government is a major producer of cigarettes. The government's wholly owned tobacco company produces such brands as Gauloises and Gitanes and controls about 51 percent of the cigarette market.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Affiliates March on Capitol Hill
DOC.TEXT: NBC affiliate executives wrap up their first-ever convention today, but Capitol Hill likely will be hearing from them again. The executives will be doing follow-ups to their mass visit Tuesday with their congressmen and senators on broadcasting issues, said Cyril Vetter, a spokesman for the group. About 300 of them went to Capitol Hill, some for the first time, seeking help for their stations and NBC in competing with cable and Hollywood studios. The trip was made ``because we wanted to be more of a part of the legislative process than we have in the past,'' said Vetter, a Baton Rouge, La., broadcaster who heads NBC's affiliate government affairs board. The march on Congress had two basic goals, said Vetter. One was to urge support for a possible change in Federal Communications Commission rules barring networks from the lucrative program syndication market and from a financial interest in shows others produce. The FCC may begin reconsideration of those rules on June 14 unless the networks can work out a compromise on them with Hollywood studios and producers. NBC station executives also sought help from Congress in resolving a problem bothering many stations _ the transmission of their broadcast signals by cable systems that aren't now required by law to pay for the signals. ``This is the beginning of the process of getting our oar in the water,'' said Pep Cooney, president of KPNX-TV in Phoenix. He spoke after leading a delegation of Arizona and New Mexico station officials to the office of Sen. Dennis DeContini, D-Ariz. The scene there was similar to 26 other regional gatherings on Capitol Hill, where congressmen and senators were shown an eight-minute videotape outlining the affiliates' problems. The tape portrayed the networks as unfairly bound by rules that don't apply to the major studios and a strong cable industry that is steadily taking viewers away from the networks and their local stations. Cooney described the visits as ``educational.'' He said the affiliates weren't seeking legislation, but were trying to get Congress ``to join the process of making a level playing field'' that would equalize the competition between the networks and their rivals.

DOC.HEAD: White House Modifies Budget Request for National Endowment
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with White House comments
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, seeking to quiet the clamor over government funding of allegedly obscene art, will seek a one-year interim budget for the National Endowment for the Arts instead of five years, a White House spokeswoman said today. Deputy press secretary Alixe Glen called it ``the prudent thing to do.'' It will allow an independent commission time to review the arts agency's grant-making procedures, she said. The White House had been seeking a five-year budget reauthorization for the arts agency with no restrictions on its grant-making procedures. But conservatives on Capitol Hill have sought to write new restrictions into law to prevent the agency from patronizing what they view as obscene or blasphemous art, such as exhibits of the late Robert Mapplethorpe's homoerotic photographs or Andres Serrano's shot of a crucifix in urine. President Bush has said previously he opposed legal restrictions on the NEA's grant-making authority, but preferred to rely on the good judgment of NEA Chairman John Frohnmayer. A 12-member advisory commission was meeting today for the first time to review the agency's grant-making procedures. ``By calling for a one-year reauthorization, we are basically doing the prudent thing,'' said Ms. Glen. She said that this approach is intended to ensure that the arts endowment does not run out of funds over the next year, and it ``provides the independent arts commission time to do its study and report back to the president.'' ``Given the political climate, this isn't something we want to do hastily,'' she said. ``Our position remains that we would like to see a five-year, clean reauthorization with no restrictions,'' she said, but that did not appear possible now. The one-year plan was decided upon at a meeting Tuesday including White House officials and Frohnmayer, who told The Washington Post it affords a chance to come up with ``a reasonable solution, rather than a hysterical response.'' The endowment has been embroiled in debate over federal funding of the arts and freedom of expression since June 1989 because of grants awarded for an exhibit of Mapplethorpe photographs that some considered obscene. Congress affixed restrictions on ``obscene'' art to the NEA's fiscal 1990 appropriation, drawing protests over the constitutionality of the language.

DOC.HEAD: California Voters Approve Unprecedented Tax Increase
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with amount of tax increase, ADDS Malibu cityhood. Picks up 13th graf pvs: `Lawmakers put .. .'
DOC.TEXT: California voters approved the state's largest tax increase ever in doubling gas taxes to pay for an $18.5 billion freeway construction program. Proposition 111, a symbolic end to the tax revolt that began with passage of Proposition 13 in 1978, was approved Tuesday along with a companion measure to provide $1 billion in bond funding for commuter trains. California voters also rejected two redistricting measures that would have helped Republicans. An ethics-in-government proposition won by a wide margin. And a prosecutor-sponsored initiative to shorten trials, narrow defendants' rights and expand the death penalty, was approved. In local elections, San Francisco voters approved a record $332 million bond issue to help pay for repairs from last October's earthquake. Voters in two San Francisco Bay area counties _ Alameda and Marin _ voted down measures to create or strengthen ``nuclear free zones.'' Known for its sun, surf and celebrities, Malibu added cityhood to its string of alliterative claims to fame. Residents of the fabled seaside community voted to break free from Los Angeles County's direct rule by incorporating as a city in a lopsided vote, 3,797 to 708. The chic neighborhood's residents include such high-profile personalities as Johnny Carson, Michael Landon, Martin Sheen, Shirley MacLaine and Olivia Newton John. But the stars, for the most part, sat the election out, preferring to let the beach community residents decide their own fate without celebrity influence playing an undue role. With 91 percent of precincts reporting, Proposition 111, the highway and rail building proposal that raises gasoline taxes from 9 to 18 cents and championed by Gov. George Deukmejian and a coalition of business and labor, gained approval, 53 percent to 47 percent. The measure proved most popular in the freeway-laced urban regions. Rural voters showed they solidly disliked the measure. Proposition 111's companion measure, Proposition 108, won approval, 56 percent to 44 percent. Voters also approved Proposition 116, a $1.99 billion bond levy for mass-transit rail building, by 53 percent to 47 percent. Voters rebuffed GOP leaders by a roughly 2-1 margin two measures they hoped would reign in the Democrats' ability to use redistricting to maintain or increase their strength in the Legislature and Congress. ``It's sad for California. This wasn't a Republican Party measure; this was a people measure,'' said state Republican Chairman Frank Visco. Republicans called the measures long-overdue reforms to an unjust system. Assembly Speaker Willie Brown and other Democrats labeled the initiatives GOP power plays. An ethics proposition won a clear-cut victory, 63 percent to 37 percent. Lawmakers put Proposition 112 on the ballot last September to help restore public confidence in the Legislature in the wake of an FBI corruption probe that resulted in the conviction of one state senator and the indictment of a state tax board member who is a former lawmaker. ``This is outstanding news. The voters are going to get control of their government again,'' said Jim Wheaton, executive director of California Common Cause. The measure prohibits legislators and other state elected officials from receiving speaking fees, requires the Legislature to pass laws banning or strictly limiting gifts to elected state officials, calls for tougher conflict-of-interest penalties for legislators, and directs the Legislature to prohibit legislators and state officials from lobbying for a year after leaving office. California prosecutors scored a political victory by getting voters to approve their Speedy Trial Initiative, Proposition 115, by 57 to 43 percent. The measure repeals independent state constitutional rights for criminal defendants; shortens court proceedings, particularly preliminary hearings and questioning of prospective jurors; allows 16-year-old killers to be sentenced to life without parole, and expands the state's death penalty law for the first time since 1978. Backers called on the voters to finish the job that started with the 1986 removal of Chief Justice Rose Bird and two state Supreme Court colleagues, the first California justices defeated in 50 years. Many provisions of the initiative overturn rulings of the liberal Bird court. Opponents predicted rushing criminal cases to trial will push civil suits aside and that the changes will cause chaos and constitutional challenges.

DOC.HEAD: Mayor Loses Bid for Fourth Term; Runoff Set
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to add that race is non-partisan, and runoff required when no one candidate gets 50 percent. Picks up 4th graf, `As the...'.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Lionel Wilson lost his bid for a fourth term, apparently the victim of a botched attempt to return the Raiders football team to their birthplace in Oakland. None of his seven rivals in the non-partisan election won a majority, forcing a runoff in November between the two top vote-getters, state Assemblyman Elihu Harris and city Councilman Wilson Riles Jr. Wilson, the underdog going into the election, came in third. Harris had 32,830 votes, or 46 percent, Riles had 17,607 votes or 25 percent, and Wilson had 12,232 votes, or 17 percent. As the early returns came in, Wilson had said he was confident he would face Harris in arunoff but was prepared for disappointment. ``When I get into any game, I get into it to win, but I also understand the realities of politics,'' he said. The Raiders' move to Los Angeles in 1982 dealt a crushing blow to Oakland's pride, but many residents opposed expensive proposals this year to lure them back. Wilson, 75, a former judge who has been mayor for 16 years, had initially backed a proposal that offered Raiders owner Al Davis $602 million, including guaranteed ticket income and up-front payments. Critics charged the city and Alameda County would have to pay millions if Raiders games didn't sell out. In April, after 15 months of negotiations with the team, Wilson and the City Council withdrew the proposal, prompted by a petition drive that gathered 30,000 signatures to put the deal on the city ballot. A recent joint poll by the Tribune and the Gallup Organization showed that 63 percent of voters don't think a deal to bring the Raiders home to Oakland is important.

DOC.HEAD: Eisenhower's Son Honors Slain Invasion Troops
DOC.TEXT: On the anniversary of D-Day, the son of Dwight D. Eisenhower planted an oak sapling today at the beachside cemetery where 9,800 of the U.S. invasion troops commanded by his father are buried. Scores of Americans and Britons, some of them D-Day veterans, followed John Eisenhower and other dignitaries through wind and rain for a series of ceremonies marking the 46th anniversary of the Normandy invasion. This year, the commemorations featured remembrances of General Eisenhower, the supreme commander of Allied forces during World War II, because 1990 is the centennial of his birth. Many of those at the ceremonies wore ``I Like Ike'' buttons on their jackets. The Eisenhower entourage began the day in the medieval town of Bayeux, which miraculously escaped major damage during the Battle of Normandy, then flew by helicopter to the U.S. cemetery on a bluff overlooking Omaha Beach, site of the heaviest fighting with Nazi German forces on D-Day. Later, the group was to visit the second American landing site _ Utah Beach _ and also inaugurate an Eisenhower memorial at Tournieres, where the general set up his headquarters after the invasion. Among those in the entourage were France's tourism minister, Olivier Stirn, and the U.S. ambassador to France, Walter Curley. The D-Day observances began Monday in Britain with the unveiling of a plaque at Norfolk House, Eisenhower's pre-invasion headquarters. Among those at the ceremony was NATO commander Gen. John R. Galvin, whose job was first held by Eisenhower. Galvin said Eisenhower faced difficult decisions at Norfolk House _ the last being the decision to strike during a short break in the weather on June 6, 1944. ``Ike is remembered after that for the great smile, for the great symbol of confidence that he was,'' said Galvin. ``But this was before the smile really became famous. As the statue here in Grosvenor Square shows, there was a grim determination involved too. For me, these days here at Norfolk House, were the hardest days of all.''

DOC.HEAD: Census Raising Pay to Hire More Workers
DOC.TEXT: Census workers are getting a raise, some of them at least. Pay rates will increase between 50 cents and $2 an hour in selected locations across the country where the bureau has had problems attracting staff. Currently workers are paid between $5 and $8 an hour depending on local wage rates and staff needs. While the bureau has sufficient job applicants nationally, shortages exist in localities where few people are out of work and available for such temporary employment. In those areas, the higher pay is aimed both at recruiting more employees and keeping those already on the job, officials said. The door-to-door census count is scheduled to continue at least through June 30 and some local follow-up and processing will continue through the end of summer. Among the areas where the higher pay rates will be offered are the New York, Boston, Atlanta, the Washington, D.C., suburbs, Kansas City, Charlotte, N.C., Arizona, San Diego, Los Angeles and San Francisco. The census, mandated every 10 years by the Constitution, is used to redistribute seats in the House of Representatives and to divide up billions of dollars in federal aid among the state and communities.

DOC.HEAD: Kayaker Missing After Paddling Over Niagara Falls
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf, `Since 1901... to CORRECT number of attempts to 12, sted 10, and number of survivors as nine, sted seven; ADDS 4 grafs to UPDATE detail.
DOC.TEXT: A man who paddled a kayak over Niagara Falls in a stunt was still missing this morning and parks police resumed their search. The red kayak of Jessie W. Sharp, 28, of Ocoee, Tenn., was recovered Tuesday afternoon below Horseshoe Falls on the Canadian side. The kayak was ``all in one piece ... in fairly good condition, all things considered,'' said Maureen Quinn, a constable with the Niagara Parks Police. ``Our regular patrol is watching the river,'' Sgt. Jim Dugos said this morning. He said police can't dive there to look for a body. Asked if the man were presumed dead, he said: ``You never know. Sometimes these people turn up.'' Ken Kitchen was working in a tower overlooking the Niagara river when he saw Sharp in his kayak. Trying to stop him, the utility closed the dam gates, reducing the water flow to the falls, Kitchen said. The man's boat grounded, but he picked it up and moved it into the middle of the water. ``We did what we could to try and stop him, but there wasn't much time,'' Kitchen said. ``He was gone before our help could get there. All we could do was sit and watch helplessly.'' The Canadian falls are 181 feet high, or about as tall as a 13-story building. Sharp, who was last seen at about 1:45 p.m., was trying to complete a stunt that had been planned for about 10 years, said constable Kim Davis. Police said nobody before had ever tried to kayak over the falls. ``Barrels, yes,'' Quinn said of other attempts to go safely over the falls in enclosed capsules. But, she said, ``it doesn't seem plausible he could do it (and survive).'' Since 1901, at least 12 people have gone over the falls in barrels or rubber balls; nine have survived. ``It's beyond me why anyone would attempt this,'' said George Bailey of the Niagara Parks Commission. ``He obviously doesn't know our falls.'' Bailey said the man was accompanied by a film crew and a friend who took photographs. ``He had all the confidence in the world, according to his friend,'' Bailey said. During a press conference Tuesday, police showed a videotape of the kayaker shot by a tourist. The tape shows a man in a boat emblazoned with ``Rapidman'' on one side successfully negotiating the rapids of the Niagara River just before the falls. Then, he disappears.

DOC.HEAD: N.C. Democrats Pick Black Former Mayor To Challenge Helms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `With all ...' to UPDATE with 100 percent of returns.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Primaries Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Harvey Gantt, a former Charlotte mayor accustomed to breaking racial barriers, proclaimed ``a new day in North Carolina'' after he won the Democratic nomination to challenge Jesse Helms for the U.S. Senate. ``I want to tell you that God is good, yes he is,'' Gantt told supporters Tuesday after he beat Brunswick County District Attorney Mike Easley 57 percent to 43 percent in a runoff. The victory for Gantt, who is black, broke a string of defeats in which minority candidates in North Carolina have led primaries with several white candidates, then lost runoffs with a single white candidate. With all returns in, Gantt had 273,347 votes, or 57 percent, to Easley's 207,329, or 43 percent. The figures indicated about a quarter of the state's more than 2 million registered Democrats voted. Gantt led the May 8 primary over Easley in a six-way race, but failed to capture the 40 percent necessary to keep Easley from calling for a runoff. The state election law had just been changed to lower the threshold from 50 percent, a provision that had stymied black aspirations for statewide office. Gantt, the first black to win the nomination for U.S. Senate in North Carolina this century, was the first black to attend Clemson University in South Carolina. He served two terms as the first black mayor of North Carolina's largest city, which is 75 percent white and usually votes Republican. A 47-year old architect with a master's degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Gantt said his background growing up in poverty in Charleston, S.C., led him to run for the Senate. ``One of the reasons I want to do this is because America has been good to me,'' he said. ``I'm someone who came from humble circumstances and I cannot say I live in humble circumstances now. That is what promise did for me, this belief, this hard work, this effort. I don't want to see that snuffed out for a lot of other people.'' Gantt on Tuesday night emphasized his support for abortion rights, an issue on which he and Helms are opposed. ``It's not the business of government to interfere with a woman's right to choose,'' Gantt said, drawing a loud cheer from the crowd. Easley, who left his own supporters to visit Gantt's victory celebration, said Democrats needed a candidate who can appeal to urban, rural and suburban voters. ``We have found him. He has my full support,'' Easley said. ``I'll campaign hard for him _ Harvey Gantt.'' Helms issued congratulations ``on a hard-earned victory,'' and said in a statement, ``I congratulate Mike Easley on a hard-fought race.'' Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina, said it was crucial for Gantt to keep control of the agenda in his race against the three-term incumbent. ``He has to deflect, divert and de-everything else the tradition of Helms setting the agenda and then making people measure up to that agenda,'' Beyle said. Helms already has amassed more than $5.3 million for the Senate campaign. Beyle said Gantt could face a more difficult time than former Gov. Jim Hunt, who was defeated by Helms in 1984, in raising money. ``But he'll get a lot of the ABH _ Anybody But Helms _ money out there,'' Beyle said. Gannt said he wants to campaign on problems that affect working people _ health care, public education and the environment. He said his campaign will be about vision, not color. ``In Jesse's vision of America,'' Gantt said while campaigning, ``I wouldn't even have been allowed to vote.'' The primary victory was a comeback for Gantt, who lost his mayoral re-election campaign in 1987 to Republican Sue Myrick by less than 1,000 votes. ``That was the worst moment I've had in politics,'' he said. ``We lost the race because we didn't put enough effort forward.'' Gantt and his wife, Cindy, have been married for 25 years. Their oldest daughter, Sonja, 24, is a television journalist in Charlotte. Erika, 19, is a student at the University of North Carolina, and Angela, 17, and Adam 14, attend public school in Charlotte. Gantt sings baritone in his Baptist church choir.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Say Poindexter Should Be Imprisoned
DOC.TEXT: Former national security adviser John M. Poindexter should be imprisoned for feeding Congress a ``diet of lies'' about the Iran-Contra affair, prosecutors said today. Poindexter ``did violence to this nation's fundamental principles of government'' by trying to cover up details of U.S.-Iran arms sales and covert aid to the Nicaraguan rebels, the prosecutors said in a sentencing memo made public today. ``That system relies fundamentally upon the exchange of truthful information,'' the memo said. ``If, as occurred in this case, high-ranking officials of one branch of government feel free to feed the other branch a diet of lies, then the constitutional system will surely sicken and eventually die,'' said the memo by independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh. Poindexter, who served as President Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until his resignation when the Iran-Contra affair was exposed in November 1986, is scheduled to be sentenced Monday for lying to Congress and destroying documents. He could receive up to 25 years imprisonment and fined as much as $1.25 million for five felony convictions of conspiracy, making false statements and obstruction. Walsh's office said Poindexter should be given ``a period of incarceration'' because ``his crimes severely threaten the integrity of our system of government'' and ``to warn other high-ranking public officials that criminal violations of the public trust will result in more than mere loss of public employment.'' The sentencing memo was made public as one of Poindexter's former aides, retired Marine Lt. Col. Oliver L. North, continued testifying before a newly empaneled federal grand jury that is continuing to investigate the Iran-Contra affair. It is trying o determine if other Reagan administration officials participated in efforts to conceal from Congress the covert arms supply network North operated to assist the Nicaraguan Contras when U.S. military aid was cut off. North, a former National Security Council staff aide, is appealing his conviction on related Iran-Contra crimes. North was placed on probation and ordered to perform community service. In its sentencing memo, the prosecution urged U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene to disregard arguments that Poindexter deserves leniency because neither North nor former national security adviser Robert McFarlane were given prison terms for their Iran-Contra convictions. ``There can be no serious argument... that the defendant is entitled to leniency because he was a mere subordinate,'' the prosecution said in contrasting Poindexter with North. Poindexter ``occupied a position where his judgment was critical and in many instances _ if former President Reagan's deposition testimony is any guide _ final,'' it said. Unlike McFarlane, who pleaded guilty to four misdemeanor charges of withholding information from Congress, Poindexter did not cooperate with prosecutors or accept his guilt.

DOC.HEAD: 40 Killed in Ethnic Violence in Soviet Central Asia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to move up reference to violence today. Pickup 8th graf `He said...'; SUBS 22nd graf `Baktiyor Hamidov...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with official comment on land dispute. Pickup 23rd graf ``They began...''
DOC.TEXT: More violence broke out today in a republic of Soviet Central Asia, where a land dispute between ethnic groups has left 40 people dead and more than 200 injured in the past three days, an official said. Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet legislature, gave the figures in a report to lawmakers on the latest outbreak of ethnic fighting to confront the government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Lukyanov did not give a breakdown of the deaths by ethnic groups in the republic of Kirghizia, where fighting began Monday between Kirghiz and Uzbeks. The Tass news agency has said only 32 people have died in the clashes and 200 were injured. No breakdown was given in its report either. Police fired on members of both ethnic groups who tried to storm police stations in the city of Osh, in the densely populated western part of the republic, near its border with Uzbekistan, the Tass news agency said today. ``The difficult process of regulating the conflict is going on,'' Lukyanov told lawmakers. He asked deputies from the two republics to appeal for calm. The violence continued for a third day today, and the casualties included 21 members of law enforcement agencies, Lukyanov said. He did not give any further details or say how many of the 21 had been killed and how many injured. He said Osh itself was calm, but that the violence had moved to three other nearby areas outside the city. Ethnic Uzbeks from the Fergana Valley of Uzbekistan arrived in the area to help their comrades fight, Lukyanov said, adding the Soviet Defense Ministry dispatched reinforcements from the republic of Turkmenia to the Osh area. The clashes spread to the nearby town of Uzgen, where six of the deaths and 18 injuries were reported. Police in Frunze, the capital of Kirghizia, were placed on alert. A duty officer of the Osh police said most shops and factories reopened today after being shut down on Tuesday. The officer, who spoke in a telephone intervew, refused to give his name. Tass reported that helicopters hovered over Osh and armored personnel carriers rolled through the streets in the city of 210,000 people. Armed Kirghiz and Uzbeks tried to attack regional civil defense headquarters and police stations in three districts of the city on Tuesday, forcing police to open fire, Interfax said. A state of emergency and a 10 p.m.-6 a.m. curfew remained in effect after the rioting began late Monday in a dispute between the two Sunni Moslem ethnic groups over plots of land for housing. Hundreds rampaged through the streets of Osh, setting fire to at least 10 houses, as well as several shops and cars. Tass reported that police and Interior Ministry troops set up roadblocks and restricted entry to the city. The Soviet army newspaper Red Star reported the only enterprise that had opened Tuesday in Osh was a large bakery. In Uzgen, 35 miles from Osh, the deaths and injuries occurred when the district police headquarters was attacked, the newspaper said. Two submachine guns were confiscated. Ethnic tensions spread to Frunze, where police were put on alert and a soccer match by a visiting team from Uzbekistan was canceled for fear of violence, according to the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda. Lukyanov said youths studying in Frunze had tried to rally in the streets of the capital but had been persuaded to give up the idea. He did not specify their nationality or their goal. Absamat Masaliyev, head of Kirghizia's Parliament, said in an address broadcast late Tuesday that authorities were trying to resolve the land dispute, Tass said. Housing is critically short in Soviet Central Asia, among the poorest regions of the nation. Lukyanov said the violence was triggered by a dispute over the ownership of 79 acres of uncultivated land. But Baktiyor Hamidov, head of the economic department of Uzbekistan's mission in Moscow, said in an interview that there is much more land at issue. He said 618,000 acres of cotton fields near the border is being made available by the Uzbek government and local Kirghiz authorities are controlling it. ``They began dividing it between the families'' of mostly Kirghiz descent, he said, and the Uzbeks demanded it be divided evenly. Hamidov said the region was among the nation's most densely populated, with 500 to 1,125 people per square mile. He said disputes over land date back to 1924, when traditional boundaries were blurred by Stalin. Leaders of Uzbek groups also demanded that an autonomous region be set up inside Kirghizia, but negotiations on this subject produced no results, Tass reported without elaboration. About one-third of Osh's residents are Uzbek.

DOC.HEAD: Astronaut Gregory to Chair Delegation to Madagascar
DOC.TEXT: The White House said today that astronaut Frederick D. Gregory will chair the U.S. delegation to Madagascar to the island's June 26 celebration of its 30th anniversary of independence. Gregory, an Air Force colonel from Texas, is of Madagascaran ancestry. The U.S. ambassador to Madagascar, Howard Walker, will also represent the United States at the festivities. Gregory will be joined by his wife, Barbara, on the trip.

DOC.HEAD: Bellmon Named to Observe Bulgarian Elections
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today formally named Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon to head his delegation to observe Sunday's elections in Bulgaria, where the United States has already expressed concern about intimidation by the former Communist Party. The U.S. ambassador to Bulgaria, Sol Polansky, was also named to the delegation, along with: former U.S. ambassador to Bulgaria Jack Perry, now a political science professor at Davidson College in North Carolina; Richard D. McLellan, a lawyer from Michigan; Marshall L. Miller, a lawyer from Washington, D.C., and Eunice B. Whittlesey, a Republican National Committeewoman from New York. Polansky flew to Copenhagen, Sweden, Tuesday to brief Secretary of State James Baker III on the latest developments in the election campaign. The State Department has charged the Bulgarian Socialist Party, formerly the communists, with engaging in a pattern of campaign irregularities. Last week it deplored violence in the build-up to what will be the first multiparty elections in Bulgaria since World War II. An army officer allegedly shot an election canvasser for the opposition party to death in the town of Shumen, and there have been other reported acts of violence. The State Department also expressed concern over anonymous threats to opposition candidates and supporters and criticized a shortage of newsprint for opposition party newspapers. Bellmon will be joined by his wife, Shirley, on the June 7-12 mission, which the governor announced Tuesday at a news conference in Oklahoma.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Does Fueling Test To Find Leak Source
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with leak apparently in or near two metal plates between orbiter and tank, test completed and fuel being drained from external tank. Picks up 5th graf pvs, ```This test ...'.
DOC.TEXT: A hydrogen leak that postponed Columbia's astronomy mission reappeared during a test today, and NASA officials were analyzing the data to pinpoint the source of the escaping fuel. Officials hoped to know by late Thursday how to repair the leak and reschedule Columbia's mission, said George Diller, spokesman for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``It seems to be a given now that any time we go into filling the tank with hydrogen ... that the leak will reappear when we reach a certain temperature, which is approximately minus 420 degrees,'' said Diller. ``The theory was that the leak would only manifest itself in the super-cold conditions of liquid hydrogen and that has been the case,'' he said. About one-sixth of Columbia's external tank was filled with liquid hydrogen. Traces of the fuel were detected in the aft engine compartment. The leak appears to be in or near a tight cavity between two metal plates that connect the orbiter and external tank, Diller said. Twenty-one sensors were placed around the suspected area, a 17-inch-diameter valve in a pipe that runs through both plates. The external tank was drained following the 2{-hour test. ``This test should really point us to it,'' said Bascom Murrah, a NASA official in charge of Columbia's prelaunch operations. ``If we don't find it, we're going to be one unhappy puppy.'' NASA officials fear Columbia will have to be returned to the hangar for repairs, which would delay its trip into orbit with the $150 million Astro observatory by about a month. A launch attempt last week was scrubbed because of a hydrogen leak in the engine compartment during fueling with liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. The mission already was two weeks late because of cooling system repairs. Workers were cleared from the launch pad during today's hazardous test. Hydrogen is highly combustible.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Blast D.C. Mayor's Leak Charge; Jury Selection Continues
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf to UPDATE with jury selection resuming, judge placing time limit on questioning; picks up 3rd graf pvs, On Monday...
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors in the drug and perjury trial of Mayor Marion Barry say Barry has tried to ``infect'' the jury by accusing the government of leaking a videotape that allegedly shows him smoking crack cocaine. As jury selection continued slowly and U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson complained of falling ``way, way behind schedule,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts complained that Barry was generating negative publicity and turning sentiment toward him before his trial began. The selection process resumed today with the questioning of three prospective jurors. Jackson ordered prosecutors and defense attorneys to limit their questioning to five minutes for each prospective juror, in an attempt to speed up the process. On Monday, Barry said in a local radio interview that the government leaked to a television station a copy of the FBI tape that allegedly shows him smoking crack at a Washington hotel on the night of his arrest last Jan. 18. Roberts suggested to Jackson in court Tuesday that Barry had engaged in an attempt to ``infect the jury pool'' with his broadcast remarks. He said the mayor's statements were inaccurate and that in generating ``negative editorial publicity,'' he ``makes these comments at his own peril.'' U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens told reporters later that the government's copy of the tape ``was locked up securely. I can assure you of that.'' By the end of the day, only 12 of a pool of 250 potential jurors had been questioned. Among the nine of that group tentatively selected as jurors were a 70-year-old woman who says she believes politicians are dishonest, an FBI clerk, two Washington lawyers, a District of Columbia government worker, a journalist and two retirees. Also in the group was a private school art teacher who initially said ``it would be an effort'' to overcome her feeling that Barry was guilty of at least some of the charges against him. Barry, who has pleaded innocent to the 14 charges against him, says the government's case was the result of overreaching by federal prosecutors. Defense lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy tried to exclude the art teacher and the elderly woman from the jury pool, but Jackson said the nine appear sufficiently impartial and rejected the request. The elderly woman asserted she would judge Barry as an individual, not as a politician. The art teacher promised she would heed the judge's instructions to presume Barry's innocence, despite her personal feelings based on news accounts. Roberts and Mundy asked several potential jurors for their views of FBI sting operations and electronic surveillance. Both techniques were used in the Barry case, in which authorities burst into the hotel room after allegedly watching the mayor smoke crack. A jury of 12 jurors and six alternates will be selected from a pool that probably will number 35 to 45 Washington residents. Barry's lawyers said they may call his campaign manager and an indicted former city official as defense witnesses at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. Mundy said in court that he wanted Anita Bonds, the campaign manager, added to the list of possible witnesses. Bonds sat next to Barry at the defense table during much of the day's proceedings. Also added to the list was David Rivers, the former director of the city's Department of Human Services and a close friend of Barry.
