Rivers is on trial in the same courthouse, accused of illegally steering city contracts to friends and business associates. Barry is charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, three counts of lying to a grand jury and one count of conspiracy. The three perjury counts are felonies, the others misdemeanors.

DOC.HEAD: Employers, Chamber of Commerce Call on Workers to Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to CORRECT that strike to begin next week. Pickup 8th graf `Under the...'
DOC.TEXT: East German retailers, restaurant owners and other businessmen today called on their workers to strike next week because many will lose their jobs when the German states merge their economies next month. Three associations representing thousands of small and medium-sized businesses said perhaps half East Germany's enterprises would be unable to compete under the terms of the economic treaty between the Germanys. Klaus Noack, head of the Association for Independent Businesses, said 350,000 workers would lose their jobs this summer and 3 million more jobs would be threatened. Some analysts have put the figure even higher. Noack, leaders from the Chamber of Commerce and other business groups will call a strike on East Germany's Baltic Sea island of Reugen Tuesday, and a nationwide strike the following week unless Parliament acts on their demands. ``We feel that all along we have been abandoned,'' Dieter Froese, head of the Association for Independent Businesses, said in an interview Wednesday with the East Berlin newspaper Berliner Zeitung. The East German newspaper Berliner Zeitung had reported the city strike would be on Friday and the nationwide strike on Saturday. However, officials later said at a news conference the strikes would not be called this week. The German states are to merge their economies on July 2, when East Germany will officially become a free market. Businesses once controlled by the former Communist government will be free to compete, but many sell products that are increasingly shunned by East Germans. The call to strike came despite the government's announcement a day earlier that it will spend $1.25 billion to retrain workers and pay them compensatory wages for lost or reduced salaries. Under the government's program announced Tuesday, East German industries will reduce wages and hours of many workers rather than lay them off, said Labor and Social Minister Regine Hildebrandt. Workers will receive compensation payments for time spent receiving retraining. Their reduced wages and the supplemental payments combined will likely be lower than their wages, but higher than jobless benefits, said Mrs. Hildebrandt. Government figures released Tuesday showed joblessness tripled last month.At the end of June, 100,000 people were officially unemployed, about 1 percent of the work force, but nearly three times the 35,000 recorded in mid-April, Mrs. Hildebrandt said. Even though a 1 percent jobless rate is minuscule by Western standards, the speed with which it materialized is alarming in a nation where joblessness was once officially non-existent, she said. She predicted high unemployment in the coming months. ``We must build a dam against unemployment,'' said West German Labor Minister Norbert Bluem in an interview published today in the West German newspaper Bild. East Germany is to officially shed four decades of socialism on July 2 when it merges its economy and social institutions with West Germany _ the biggest and most difficult stage of full German unification. Officials in both German states are counting on a flood of Western investment to create new employment. But many East Germans are not waiting to find out. West Germany said Tuesday that East Germans are still fleeing to West Germany at a rate of 2,000 a week, and that more than 180,000 have done so this year alone. Hundreds of thousands fled last year, an exodus that opened the Berlin Wall and helped bring down the former socialist regime in October. Western firms already have begun taking over parts of the East German economy. Western food imports, for example, fill East German grocery stores and many East Germans have been buying Western clothing and electronics. The effect has been to speed the decline of many East German industries.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. June 4 The Dallas Morning News on honorariums: Apparently, the political liabilities connected with accepting speaking fees have become too great for 34 senators. A spot check by Congressional Quarterly magazine has found that the lawmakers are either declining all honorariums from outside groups or directing the money to charity. That number is 15 more than last year. For many voters, the practice among lawmakers of accepting speaking fees from the same special interests that seek to influence them has become a striking symbol of what is wrong with Congress. Last year, House members, in exchange for a pay raise, voted to ban honorariums beginning in 1991. But the Senate refused to follow suit. Instead, the senators adopted a wimpish plan to abolish speaking fees gradually, reducing the amount they can keep each year by the amount they receive in cost-of-living salary increases. Judging by the Congressional Quarterly survey, however, a fair number have taken it upon themselves to end the payoffs immediately. Good for them. ... Ideally, the Senate will come to its senses soon and ban honorariums altogether, with or without a pay raise. Until then, one can only hope that these examples of self-denial catch on.

May 31 The News-Review, Roseburg, Ore., on Navy sexual harassment: Adm. Carlisle Trost, chief of naval operations, is to be commended for his tough stand against sexual harassment. That's something the Navy just won't tolerate, he says. Unfortunately, Trost's assurance comes too late to help Gwen Marie Dreyer. Dreyer, a 19-year-old midshipman at the U.S. Naval Academy, resigned in protest because she felt the Navy dealt too leniently with male colleagues who abused, assaulted and harassed her. She was dragged from her dormitory room in Annapolis, Md., by two male midshipmen and handcuffed to a urinal in a men's rest room while others jeered and took photographs. Incredibly, academy superintendent Rear Adm. Virgil Hill concluded after an investigation that the incident was not premeditated and therefore did not constitute sexual harassment. The view of the academy was that it was a student prank, nothing more than spontaneous high jinks. The punishment was commensurably light. ... There is good reason to believe that this incident was far removed from an innocent, spontaneous prank. The very fact that Dreyer was taken to a men's rest room takes this episode beyond hazing to sexual harassment. The Navy has the responsibility to review the Dreyer case, not the least because it appears to condone intolerable behavior. ... The leaders of tomorrow's Navy should be persons of sensitivity and understanding, not boors who revel in the humiliation of others.

June 2 Marinette (Wis.) Eagle-Star on the Iowa explosion investigation: Thumbs down to the U.S. Navy for blowing a smokescreen in front of the death of a sailor aboard the U.S.S. Iowa last year. New evidence ... casts serious doubts upon the Navy's theory that the explosion in one of the ship's gun turrets was caused by a suicidal sailor. It now appears the explosion that killed 47 was an accident. This case is one of several in recent memory where the Navy has tried to pass the buck for the death of one of its own. ... It seems naive for the Navy to think they could get away with these coverups. Their actions are causing pain, suffering and embarrassment to the families involved and erode the framework on an institution that is supposed to stand for honor.

May 31 The Phoenix Gazette on criminal restitution: To the average person, it is unfortunate when a white-collar criminal avoids prison, but it is at least understandable when the price for that avoidance is to pay restitution to the persons victimized. Thus a swindler could pay back the millions of dollars he stole and get a light sentence or no prison time at all. Well, the U.S. Supreme Court has just thrown a little monkey wrench into the equation. The court, by a 7-2 vote, decided that criminals may avoid paying restitution if they file bankruptcy, since the bankruptcy law makes no mention of an exception for court-ordered restitution. The court probably reads the law correctly, but the law is wrong. Congress should fix this loophole before the courts are faced with dozens of white-collar criminals from the S&L collapse, all accepting restitution with their fingers crossed behind them.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: behind them.
DOC.TEXT: May 30 The Bakersfield (Calif.) Californian on Kohl and a unified Germany: A funny thing happened on Helmut Kohl's way to the presidency of a united Germany. Since the Berlin Wall began to figuratively crumble, public opinion polls have shown that the West German chancellor was the preference of East and West Germans to lead a unified Germany. ... Sensing a delay in a vote might prevent him from heading a single Germany, Kohl now wants the unity election in December, six months sooner than he planned. ... The politically savvy Kohl is not waiting to get a firm figure on unification costs. He wants the prestige of being the first unified German leader since World War II. Delay, he knows, could be deadly for him. Besides the threat of defecting West German voters, Kohl has to consider the East German voters. ... (His) backing could erode if expected massive unemployment sends East Germans rushing to the arms of the Social Democrats who traditionally appeal to disadvantaged workers. ... The West German chancellor will try everything he can to get elected president of a unified Germany in 1990. He knows that come 1991 he may no longer be the favorite.

June 5 The Albuquerque (N.M.) Tribune on China: When the late Chou En-lai, Chinese Communist elder statesman, was asked to assess the impact of the French Revolution of 1789, he is said to have answered: ``Too soon to tell.'' No doubt he would scorn attempts to capture the meaning of Tiananmen Square after just one year. Yet it is fair to speculate. We are convinced, for example, that the brutal suppression of peaceful pro-democracy demonstrators by China's communist government a year ago ... helped prevent a similar use of force in Eastern Europe. The Tiananmen Square massacre occurred at a key moment in the unfolding ferment of European communism. We don't know exactly why Moscow decided to let Eastern Europe go. Generational change in the leadership is surely fundamental. But we suspect it helped that the images of Tiananmen Square were fresh in Soviet leaders' minds when they had to choose between holding Eastern Europe by force and watching it break free.

May 31 The Providence (R.I.) Journal Bulletin on Boris Yeltsin: There may now be, in effect, two leaders of the Soviet ``Union'': Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin. In winning the presidency of Russia, the USSR's largest republic, ... Yeltsin has established himself as a formidable rival to the floundering Soviet president. And his victory has cast into further doubt the future unity of the Soviet empire. ... It should be emphasized that nobody exactly knows what sort of an animal ... Yeltsin is; his views on many policies are contradictory and confused. ... Equally important to remember is that ... Yeltsin has actually been elected by the people through landslide victories in legislative races. ... Gorbachev, on the other hand, has never had to undergo an open, contested election. Perhaps ... Gorbachev will take the Yeltsin election as a sign that he's running out of time, and so needs to step up the pace of reform.

June 5 The Saginaw (Mich.) News on the summit: The events of the next several years will provide a measuring stick for President Bush's laid-back approach to the U.S.-Soviet summit. Bush was dealing from a position of strength in his talks with the beleaguered Mikhail Gorbachev, but he didn't play his trump cards. Gorbachev came away with two big prizes. He received a political prop through the telecasts of the ceremonial pomp back home. And, in the process, Bush gave him a trade agreement to sate a population that desires not only political freedom, but Western products. For Bush, however, the pot was virtually empty. He did not press hard for an end to the Soviet economic embargo of Lithuania, even though Gorbachev was desperate for the trade pact. The weapons accord is rooted in the fluff of general long-range goals, with the tough detail work to come later. ... But if the United States props up Gorbachev and helps him survive, and if the Soviet leader grows stronger in his push for reforms, then historians will laud Bush for a display of wisdom. ... Indeed, it is in America's best interest to assist Gorbachev, who for the most part has reduced hostilities and oppression. It isn't a question of ``trusting'' him; the proof rests in his actions, and most have been positive.

June 2 Valley News, Lebanon, N.H., on the summit: (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev's visit, of course, has provided a wonderful opportunity for analysts to speculate on his chances for survival. Such speculation makes for interesting reading, but seems to be an exercise with less certainty than guessing next week's weather. Whatever transpires, Gorbachev's visit serves as a reminder of how much he has already accomplished. One can criticize him on a range of issues, but the fact remains that he has catalyzed an unimaginable amount of change, much of it exceeding Americans' wildest dreams.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein Wins Democratic Governor's Primary; Voters Double State Gas Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf to UPDATE vote totals to 99 percent from 96.
DOC.TEXT: Former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, whose campaign was sputtering less than a year ago, roared back to win the Democratic nomination to face U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson in the November election for governor. On a primary day that bucked tradition, Californians also voted Tuesday to double their gasoline taxes, oust an incumbent mayor and spend billions of dollars on transportation improvements. Feinstein's victory over Attorney General John Van de Kamp took her as close as any woman has ever stood to winning the California governorship _ a feat all the more remarkable for a politician from Northern California, not the more populous south. ``Well, we did it,'' Feinstein told supporters at her San Francisco campaign headquarters. ``One mission completed. One more to go. I think we have shown tonight that we are one state, not northerners versus southerners. We are one state and proud of it.'' Van de Kamp, conceding defeat in Los Angeles, said the former San Francisco mayor had hammered out ``an extraordinary victory,'' running a campaign that overwhelmed his own. ``I feel a little tonight like the auto mechanic who was run over by a Corvette, (who says) `I think my leg is broken, but did you see that car?''' he told supporters. Wilson, who cruised to victory against token opposition, congratulated Feinstein even before Van de Kamp conceded defeated. But he issued a warning to the Democratic nominee. ``My friends in the Democratic Party: Whoop it up tonight because this is your last victory party of the 1990s,'' Wilson said in his victory speech. Feinstein's victory came months after her campaign was all but written off by most political leaders. But a savvy advertising campaign _ and an infusion of money, much of it her own _ helped rescue her candidacy and put it on the road to victory. With 99 percent of the precincts reporting early today, Feinstein had 1,288,749 votes to Van de Kamp's 1,007,251 _ a 52-to-41 percent margin. Nine lesser-known Democrats split the remaining 7 percent. Wilson, California's junior U.S. senator, swamped three lesser-known GOP rivals to capture 89 percent of the vote. Proposition 111, the measure to raise the state gasoline tax from 9 cents to 18 cents per gallon, won by a 53-to-47 percent margin. A companion $1 billion rail bond measure won by 56 percent to 44 percent, while a rival $1.99 billion rail bond measure won by a 53 percent to 47 percent. Voters rejected two ballot measures that would have stripped the Democratic Legislature of much of its power to set the boundaries of California legislative districts. Several races featured new political faces with familiar family names. Incumbent Tom Hayes defeated Angela ``Bay'' Buchanan, former U.S. treasurer and sister of conservative commentator Pat Buchanan, by a 3-2 margin for the Republican nomination for state treasurer. Kathleen Brown, daughter of former Gov. Pat Brown and sister of former Gov. Jerry Brown, won the Democratic nomination for treasurer by a similar margin. Secretary of State March Fong Eu won the Democratic nomination in her quest to serve a fifth term as the state's chief election officer, while her son, Matt Fong, was unopposed in his bid for the Republican nomination for state controller. Oakland Mayor Lionel Wilson, criticized for his failed attempt to lure the Los Angeles Raiders football team back to his city, lost in his bid for a fifth term. Two rivals, state Assemblyman Elihu Harris and city Councilman Wilson Riles Jr., were forced into a November runoff. California's 45 congressional races included several interesting contests: _Democratic incumbent Rep. Jim Bates, who was challenged in the Democratic primary after being rebuked by the House Ethics Committee for sexual harassment of women employees, won renomination for a fifth term. _Actor Ralph Waite, ``Papa Walton'' of the old ``The Waltons'' TV series, won the Democratic nomination for a seat now held by Republican Al McCandless in the Palm Springs area. _Tim Stoen, former attorney for People's Temple before the cult's mass suicide with 912 deaths over a decade ago, lost the Republican nomination to oppose Democratic incumbent Doug Bosco in California's north coast redwood country. Frank Riggs won by a 79-21 percent margin.

DOC.HEAD: American Held After Pan Am Bomb Threat
DOC.TEXT: An American arrested after an alleged bomb threat against a Pan Am jetliner has been charged under Britain's aviation safety laws, police said today. Swaeid Ebrahimi, 37, from Long Beach, Calif. made a brief court appearance and was ordered to remain in custody for seven days, said prosecutor Will Andrew. Ebrahimi was not required to enter a plea. His court-appointed attorney, Robert Campbell, said he denies all offenses and denies that he told anyone there were explosives on a Pan Am Boeing 747. Ebrahimi was arrested Tuesday after Flight 61 from Frankfurt, West Germany, to Washington, D.C., made an emergency landing that night at Scotland's Prestwick Airport after a bomb scare. A statement issued by Strathclyde police, based in Glasgow, said: ``the crew received an allegation that there was possibly an explosive device on board.'' Police blew up two pieces of baggage taken from the plane but said they found no explosives. The officials declined to say who owned the luggage. After a five-hour delay the flight continued across the Atlantic with 208 passengers and crewmembers, said Strathclyde police. Ebrahimi, a self-employed architectural model maker, is charged with violating Section 3 of the Aviation Security Act of 1982, Campbell said. ``Section 3 is an offense to intentionally communicate any false information which endangers the safety of an aircraft in flight,'' Andrew said. Police and court officials refused any further comment on the case.

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: wildest dreams.
DOC.TEXT: June 4 Il Tempo, Rome, on the summit: George Bush wished his guest ``good luck'' as (Michael Gorbachev) boarded his limousine. It was the last one-liner of the Soviet-U.S. summit, the one that summarizes it best. ... Gorbachev will need a lot of luck to stay where he is and to win the many challenges lying in wait as he returns to Moscow. ... Speculation? No. Gorbachev himself spoke to the matter in the closing press conference: the difficulties and delays of perestroika, the rebellion of Boris Yeltsin, recently installed president of the Russian republic, the obstinance of secessionist Lithuania, the fury of a population faced with empty stores, and the loss of authority. ... Gorbachev left Washington in approximately the same state of mind as Richard Nixon, when he left Moscow 16 years ago. He took back home the feeling of having gained additional time. Hounded by Watergate, Nixon lasted a few months. How many will there be for Gorbachev?

June 4 Times of India, New Delhi, on Soviet economic reforms: (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev's decision to submit his proposals for revamping the economy to a public referendum will be seen by many to be a desperate gamble. The Soviet economy is in a shambles. ... This has pushed most of his economic advisers into ever greater pessimism about the possibility of effectively ``reforming'' the socialist economy as distinct from simply abandoning it altogether in favor of a full-fledged market system. ... Gorbachev's effort to seek public endorsement via a referendum and his hyperbole about the economic reform he is promoting being as profound a matter as the consequences of the October Revolution itself shows how fragile his own situation is. ... It is almost certain that his new economic package will not do the trick. All efforts at decentralizing the socialist economy ... have ultimately failed. ... But if ... Gorbachev goes in for Polish-style ``shock therapy'' he will almost certainly provoke mass upsurges from an industrial work force which in numerical terms is the largest in the world.

June 3 Daily Telegraph, London, on China: A year after the Beijing massacre, China is subdued. The old men who ordered the crushing of the pro-democracy movement have little to fear in the immediate future. ... The drying up of foreign credit has hurt the economy, which in turn makes the party's hold on power less secure. Politically, Western disapproval has marginalized China, in stark contrast to the period during which it was wooed as a standard-bearer of communist reform. ... As the anniversary of the massacre passes, Western governments may well decide to relax their sanctions _ in particular, to reopen lines of credit to Beijing. As a response to real need, this would be acceptable, provided the donors reiterate their condemnations of China's human rights record, whether in conducting vendettas at home, harassing exiled dissidents, interfering in Hong Kong's internal affairs or brutally crushing unrest in Tibet. Dealing with fading ideologues in Beijing may be a necessity, but there is no reason for the West to go out of its way to be friendly.

May 30 Asahi Shimbun, Tokyo, on Burma's elections: Aung San Suu Kyi led the National League for Democracy, the main opposition to Burma's military government, to victory in the country's first multiparty election in 30 years. It won by a substantial majority, which was not predicted before the election. The election showed clearly that the will of Burma's people, seeking democracy, will not be confined by power. ... Japan, which is Burma's largest supporter in aid, should see the situation accurately and play a role to back up the step for democratization, which may be full of turns and twists from now on.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Senator Visits Grave of Late Brother on Anniversary of Assassination
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Edward Kennedy visited the grave of his late brother, Sen. Robert Kennedy, at Arlington National Cemetery today on the 22nd anniversary of his assassination. The Massachusetts Democrat stood alone, his arms folded and head bowed, at his older brother's grave. He laid a flower on the grave, said a prayer and then paid a visit to President John F. Kennedy's grave nearby. Robert Kennedy, attorney general under President Kennedy and a New York senator, was shot to death in 1968 in Los Angeles just minutes after declaring victory in the California Democratic presidential primary. Sirhan Sirhan is serving a life prison sentence in California for the slaying.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Sailor's Family Challenges Rule That Bars Lawsuits
DOC.TEXT: The family of a sailor who drowned during a rescue drill is challenging the legal doctrine that bans lawsuits against the military for deaths or injuries ``incident to service.'' The U.S. Supreme Court laid down what is called the Feres doctrine in 1950 when it refused to let survivors of Rudolf J. Feres, a soldier killed in a barracks fire, sue the government under the Federal Tort Claims Act. In action filed Monday, a lawyer for the family of Airman Recruit Lee Mirecki urged U.S. District Judge Winston Arnow to overrule the Feres doctrine claiming it is contrary to the intent of Congress, as well as unfair and irrational. Failing that, wrote Martin Levin, Arnow should rule the doctrine doesn't apply to the Mirecki case either because his death at the Navy Rescue Swimmer School was not incident to service or because he had withdrawn from the Navy _ which he was allowed by contract to do _ by repeatedly shouting ``I quit'' as instructors forced him back into a training pool. ``When the military personnel know, or should know, that they are violating the clear constitutional rights of a serviceman, the court should rule that the acts ... are so egregious that it cannot be said that the injury resulted `incident to service,''' Levin wrote. Mirecki, 19, of Appleton, Wis., died March 2, 1988, at the Pensacola Naval Air Station of drowning and heart failure induced by fear, a Navy pathologist testified during a subsequent court martial. One instructor was convicted of negligent homicide and sentenced to 90 days in the brig. A second trial cleared the officer in charge of the school of dereliction of duty. Four other instructors received administrative penalties. The commander of the Naval Aviation Schools Command was reprimanded. Mirecki's mother, Elaine M. Kitowski, and the sailor's estate are seeking $7.5 million. The government has asked that the lawsuit be dismissed because of the Feres doctrine. Arnow will rule on that motion after the government responds to Levin's argument. Mirecki had signed a statement permitting him to ``drop on request'' from Rescue Swimmer School.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Leader Briefs Bush on Meeting with Gorbachev
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 7 grafs new with additional Roh comments, picks up 3rd graf pvs, Roh said.
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo said today that he and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have agreed to undertake a joint effort to ``melt down the ice'' that still exists from the Cold War. Speaking to reporters after conferring with President Bush, Roh also said a peace settlement on the Korean peninsula could lead to further reductions or reallocations of American forces in South Korea. Roh met with Bush two days after his groundbreaking meeting with Gorbachev in San Francisco, the first such encounter since Korea was divided after World War II. Roh said he and Gorbachev agreed to cooperate ``so that we can melt down the ice that still exists from the cold war years.'' Asked about prospects for reunification with North Korea, Roh said that country must first open up and embark on a reform process. He said Gorbachev ``agreed to combine efforts along that line.'' He said the meeting will help reduce tensions on the peninsula and expressed hope it will ``help greatly the process of reunification.'' Earlier, as the two leaders posed for photographers in the Oval Office, Bush described as ``very important'' the San Francisco meeting. Roh said he was pleased that the meeting with Gorbachev took place in the United States. Bush received Roh after the South Korean had breakfast with Vice President Dan Quayle. There was a sense of optimism as Roh flew here Tuesday from San Francisco to brief Bush on his meeting. ``This historic meeting has improved prospects for peace on the Korean peninsula and eventual Korean unification,'' State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said. Roh predicted the meeting eventually will lead to full diplomatic relations with Moscow. The administration is hopeful that, absent the unswerving support of Soviet Union, communist North Korea will be more likely to seek friendlier ties with South Korea and the industrialized West. In his remarks Monday, Roh noted that the Gorbachev era in Moscow has brought a generalized easing of East-West tensions except in Korea. ``The Korean peninsula remains the last area of tension in the Cold War,'' he said. ``The Cold War on the Korean peninsula now begins to crack.'' On Tuesday, Roh called the meeting ``the greatest diplomatic event'' in South Korean history and said efforts would be made to establish ties with another longtime rival, China. U.S. officials expressed delight with the prospective accommodation between Seoul and Moscow, recalling that it was less than seven years ago that a Soviet missile shot down a Korea commercial jetliner, killing all 269 people aboard. In the aftermath, Soviet-American relations hit a low point. The Bush administration attached significance to the Roh-Gorbachev meeting because Korea has long been viewed as one of the most likely areas for an East-West showdown. It is an area where tensions often have run high, where there are heavy concentrations of military weapons and where both Moscow and Washington have vital interests. The meeting with Gorbachev occurred just three weeks short of the 40th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean War, a conflict in which the Kremlin was the major arms supplier of North Korea while the United States provided arms and troops for the South. The weapons deliveries by the two superpowers have continued unabated ever since. One potential benefit of an eventual accommodation between the two Koreas would be the withdrawal of the 40,000 American troops stationed in South Korea. The meeting also came at a time of some indications by North Korea of interest in improving relations with the United States. Just last week, it returned the remains of five American servicemen killed during the Korean war, the first such gesture since 1954.

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein To Face Pete Wilson In California; Gantt Against Helms in NC
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with fresh quotes, Alabama runoff in top 10 grafs; updates returns in grafs 12, 19, 22.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos RA1, FX3
DOC.TEXT: Dianne Feinstein, savoring success in California's Democratic primary for governor, embarked on her fall campaign today against well-financed GOP rival Pete Wilson. North Carolina Democrats picked a black man to try to dethrone GOP Sen. Jesse Helms. In the longest count of a nine-state primary election, Alabama Attorney General Don Siegelman squeezed into a runoff for the Democratic nomination for governor with teacher lobbyist Paul Hubbert after an all-night vote tally. The winner of the June 26 balloting will face GOP Gov. Guy Hunt. Seven senators gained nominations for new terms. GOP Sen. Thad Cochran of Mississippi was arguably the biggest winner among them. He faces no Democratic opposition in the fall and is thus assured of a new term. Democrats Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Howell Heflin of Alabama and Max Baucus of Montana easily overcame challenges within their party, while Democrat Tom Harkin of Iowa and Republicans Larry Pressler of South Dakota and Pete Domenici of New Mexico were unopposed. Incumbent governors in Iowa and South Dakota also were renominated, along with Hunt in Alabama. In California, both Feinstein and Wilson, a second-term senator, were kicking off their fall campaigns with breakfast appearances. ``Whoop it up tonight because this is your last victory party of the 1990s,'' Wilson told the Democrats late Tuesday night after breezing to his nomination. Democratic national chairman Ron Brown hailed Feinstein's success and called the defeat of two Republican-backed redistricting referenda a ``blowout for us.'' ``They are going to have a money advantage,'' he said, referring to Wilson's $3 million warchest. But, he added, ``issues are going to prevail.'' It was the California Democratic primary for governor that drew most of the nationwide attention, both for the size of the state and because the next governor will play a large role in determining which party benefits from a census that may increase the state's congressional delegation by a half-dozen seats. ``One mission completed, one to go,'' former San Francisco Mayor Feinstein told supporters after securing her victory in a hard-fought primary. With 99 percent of the precincts counted, she had 52 percent of the vote, to 41 percent for Attorney General John Van de Kamp. Nine other candidates split the remaining votes. Wilson breezed to an easy primary victory on the GOP side, and said he'd keep the governor's office in Republican hands. He decided to run for the job when GOP Gov. George Deukmejian declined to seek a third term. Feinstein praised Van de Kamp in her victory speech and said the fall campaign will be a choice between two Californias. ``One ... with a declining quality of life, more crime, more traffic ... It is content with caretaker government,'' she said. ``But our California is a ... bold place.'' In North Carolina, Helms congratulated Harvey Gantt on ``a hard-earned victory.'' ``How sweet it is,'' a jubilant Gantt told supporters after dispatching prosecutor Mike Easley with 57 percent of the vote. His victory made him the first of his race to win a Senate nomination this century in North Carolina. ``I want to tell you that God is good, yes he is. It's a new day in North Carolina,'' said Gantt, a former mayor of Charlotte. Alabama boasted the closest race of the night, a Democratic primary to pick an opponent for incumbent GOP Gov. Guy Hunt. Education Association lobbyist Hubbert and Siegelman claimed the right to face off in the runoff. With 96 percent of precincts reporting, Hubbert was winning 32 percent of the vote and Siegelman 25 percent, followed by former Gov. Fob James with 22 percent and Rep. Ronnie Flippo 17 percent. Two other candidates trailed. ``This is no place for the faint-hearted,'' said Flippo as the long count continued. In an Iowa primary contest viewed as a referendum on abortion, House Speaker Don Avenson claimed the Democratic nomination for governor against GOP incumbent Terry Branstad, who opposes abortion. Avenson, who favors abortion rights, won 40 percent of the vote to defeat anti-abortion Democrat Tom Miller and three other contenders. The National Organization for Women and the National Abortion Rights ActionLeague, both of which endorsed Avenson, had feared he would split the vote with other pro-choice contenders and permit Miller to win. In addition to picking candidates for governor, Californians voted to raise the state gasoline tax from 9 to 18 cents a gallon to finance badly needed highway repair. Supporters said approval of the measure would mark a symbolic end to the tax revolt that began in 1978 with passage of Proposition 13. With 98 percent of precincts counted, the proposal was gaining 52 percent of the vote. The lines were drawn for what shape up as some of the nation's most contested Senate elections in November, when Republicans seek to cut into the current 55-45 Democratic advantage. Republicans count Harkin as among the most vulnerable Democrats, and Rep. Tom Tauke has been campaigning against him even in advance of formally claiming the GOP nomination Tuesday night. Republicans profess hope for knocking off two-term Democrat Max Baucus in Montana, as well. The victor in a four-way GOP race was Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad, who entered the race at the urging of the national Republican leadership. In New Jersey, Christine Todd Whitman was unopposed for the GOP nomination to oppose Bradley. In Alabama, state Sen. Bill Cabannis had no GOP opposition for the chance to challenge Heflin. GOP Sen. Domenici in New Mexico will face Democratic State Sen. Tom Benavides, who was unopposed for his party's nomination. On the other side of the aisle, Democrats eye Pressler of South Dakota as a potential victim for the fall. Ted Muenster, who had no primary opposition, will run against him. In New Mexico's governor's race, former Gov. Bruce King won the Democratic nomination in a bid to regain the office he's held for eight years _ longer than anyone in state history. Former state Rep. Frank Bond won the Republican nomination. Each man defeated three rivals.

DOC.HEAD: Famous East-West Berlin Border Checkpoint to Be Dismantled
DOC.TEXT: Checkpoint Charlie, the most famous crossing through the now-crumbling Berlin Wall, is going to be dismantled, the U.S. military said today. ``Plans are in motion for the eventual removal of Allied Checkpoint Charlie. We will announce the date of the ceremony and the disposition of the building when a final decision is made,'' said a statement from the U.S. Command Berlin. Capt. Pete Pierce, spokesman for the U.S. military, said he could not confirm German news media reports that the checkpoint will be taken down this month. ``No decision has been made on the date,'' Pierce told The Associated Press. German officials have already said they will end all passport and identity card checks at the Berlin Wall next month, when the West German mark officially replaces the East German currency and the two countries start to merge their economies. That completely free passage by itself will make Checkpoint Charlie obsolete.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian President Gets Singed at Drug Burning
DOC.TEXT: The script called for President Fernando Collor de Mello to set fire to a pile of seized cocaine and marijuana to promote his anti-drug campaign, but it didn't work out that way. Instead, TV viewers saw the gas-soaked pile of drugs explode in flames as Collor dropped a torch onto it, and the president cover his face and run back. Fortunately, the heat only singed Collor's right ear, hair and forearm, and he was not seriously hurt, the government news agency said Wednesday. Federal police chief Romeu Tuma said the explosion occurred at a ranch in remote western Brazil on Tuesday because ``the wind shifted.'' The ranch is in the Pantanal region, a transit point for illegal drugs near Brazil's border with Bolivia.

DOC.HEAD: Whites Arrested in Arson Attack on Historic Building in South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Five white men were arrested in connection with a politically motivated arson attack on a historic building, the government said Wednesday. Three of the men were held and the other two were released after questioning, the office of the Minister of Law and Order Adriaan Vlok said. The men were arrested last weekend in connection with the May 23 nighttime attack on Melrose House in Pretoria. Police linked the attack to right-wing groups that oppose the government's plans to end apartheid. A treaty marking the 1902 surrender of the Boer (Afrikaner) Republics to the British was signed at Melrose House. It is seen by right-wing groups as a symbol of Afrikaner humiliation.

DOC.HEAD: Bellmon Named to Observe Bulgarian Elections
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf, Polansky flew... to CORRECT Sweden to Denmark
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today formally named Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon to head his delegation to observe Sunday's elections in Bulgaria, where the United States has already expressed concern about intimidation by the former Communist Party. The U.S. ambassador to Bulgaria, Sol Polansky, was also named to the delegation, along with: former U.S. ambassador to Bulgaria Jack Perry, now a political science professor at Davidson College in North Carolina; Richard D. McLellan, a lawyer from Michigan; Marshall L. Miller, a lawyer from Washington, D.C., and Eunice B. Whittlesey, a Republican National Committeewoman from New York. Polansky flew to Copenhagen, Denmark, Tuesday to brief Secretary of State James A. Baker III on the latest developments in the election campaign. The State Department has charged the Bulgarian Socialist Party, formerly the communists, with engaging in a pattern of campaign irregularities. Last week it deplored violence in the build-up to what will be the first multiparty elections in Bulgaria since World War II. An army officer allegedly shot an election canvasser for the opposition party to death in the town of Shumen, and there have been other reported acts of violence. The State Department also expressed concern over anonymous threats to opposition candidates and supporters and criticized a shortage of newsprint for opposition party newspapers. Bellmon will be joined by his wife, Shirley, on the June 7-12 mission, which the governor announced Tuesday at a news conference in Oklahoma.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Runoff in Governor's Race; Hunt and Heflin Big Winners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout UPDATE with Siegelman, Hubbert in runoff and latest vote totals. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Teacher lobbyist Paul Hubbert led the Democratic primary for governor and Attorney General Don Siegelman ran second to set the stage for a runoff in three weeks. A Hubbert-Siegelman matchup was a wish come true for Gov. Guy Hunt, who won renomination Tuesday in a Republican primary landslide. He billed the two Democrats as liberals out of step with Alabama voters. Another landslide victor was Democratic U.S. Sen. Howell Heflin, who used the primary as a warm-up for his general election campaign against Republican state Sen. Bill Cabaniss. Alabama voters also gave lopsided approval to a proposed constitutional amendment making English the state's official language. The measure gives state residents the right to sue if the amendment is violated, but does not define what constitutes a violation. Former Gov. Fob James trailed Siegelman in the unofficial and fell short of a spot in the June 26 runoff, as did U.S. Rep. Ronnie Flippo. ``We'll beat whoever they put in there,'' said Hubbert, cheered on by supporters as he turned his first statewide race for public office into a success. The 54-year-old Alabama Education Association's executive director, he promised ``new leadership'' and a progressive Statehouse to rival those in other Southern states. With 97 of the precincts reporting, Hubbert had 227,430 votes, or 32 percent; Siegelman 176,609, or 25 percent; James 156,476, or 22 percent; Flippo 123,692, or 17 percent; state Sen. Charles Bishop 31,190, or 4 percent; and Ed Daw with 3,357, or less than 1 percent. A runnoff between the two top vote-getters is held if no one candidate gets 50 percent of the vote. With 80 percent of the precincts reporting, results in the GOP primary showed 115,861 votes, or 96 percent, for Hunt, to 3,117 votes, or 3 percent, for retired businessman Jim Watley's; and 2,283, or 2 percent, for highway employee Jack Pollard. In the Democratic Senate primary, Heflin had 407,714 votes, or 81 percent, to 96,323, or 19 percent, for Mrs. Frank Ross Stewart. Cabaniss was unopposed in the GOP primary. The proposed English-language amendment received 329,827 votes, or 89 percent, to 41,133, or 11 percent, with 2,240 of 4,196 precincts reporting.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Torture Routine in Police Custody in Nepal
DOC.TEXT: Torture has been routine in Nepalese police stations, especially during the unrest that followed the birth of the nation's pro-democracy movement in February, Amnesty International said Wednesday. Many victims suffered broken limbs, had pins stuck under fingernails, toenails ripped off and canes inserted into body orifices, it said. ``Beatings, including on the soles of the feet, were widespread,'' the worldwide human rights organization said. It said the findings were based on more than 80 interviews with alleged victims by an Amnesty team that visited the Himalayan kingdom in April. The team included a forensic expert familiar with torture cases, it said. The charges were contained in a memorandum it said was being presented to Nepal's prime minister, Krishna Prasad Bhattarai. In April, a new government led by opposition figures took office as part of the political reforms undertaken by King Birendra, who previously held the monopoly on power. The army was called out in April after police fired on pro-democracy demonstrators marching on Birendra's palace. Amnesty International's statement said the number of fatalities was not known, but that estimates ranged from fewer than 20 to more than 600 on April 6 alone. It said its team found evidence that police several times ignored the rules on using live ammunition against demonstrations. ``In a number of cases, demonstrators were shot in the head, shoulders or chest, apparently in contravention of the specific obligation ... not to shoot above the knees,'' it said. ``Police officers also repeatedly obstructed doctors trying to help the victims.'' Amnesty International said thousands of people were arrested during the disturbances and often kept in ``overcrowded and unhygienic conditions.'' It said its team was told of prisoners being refused access to family and lawyers. In some cases their detention was not recorded, raising ``the danger that detained people will go `missing' within the system,'' the statement said. Amnesty International acknowledged that the difficulty of maintaining proper records during mass arrests. It also noted that since April 6 most uncharged political prisoners have been released and that the outgoing government promised compensation to relatives of the dead and injured. But it said some prisoners remained in custody, including Christians jailed for proselytizing. The statement called on Bhattarai's government to write human rights safeguards into Nepalese law, and outlaw torture, incommunicado detention and summary executions.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Primary Voting
DOC.TEXT:
Here at a glance are highlights of primary elections Tuesday.
ALABAMA= Governor: State teacher lobbyist Paul Hubbert led a four-way Democratic race, but fell short of a majority and faces a June 26 runoff with Attorney General Don Siegelman. Former Gov. Fob James trailed Siegelman slightly, followed by U.S. Rep. Ronnie Flippo. Republican Gov. Guy Hunt was renominated. Senate: Democratic Sen. Howell Heflin defeated token opposition and was nominated for a third term. State Sen. Bill Cabaniss was unopposed for the GOP nomination.
CALIFORNIA= Governor: Former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein defeated Attorney General John Van de Kamp for the Democratic nomination. Republican Sen. Pete Wilson defeated minor opposition from within his party. Oakland Mayor: Sixteen-year incumbent Lionel Wilson was defeated by state Assemblyman Elihu Harris and city Councilman Wilson Riles Jr., who face a November runoff. Ballot measures: Voters approved a measure to double the gasoline tax to renew a financially starved highway building program, and defeated two others that would have stripped the Democrat-controlled Legislature of much authority to reapportion congressional and legislative districts.
IOWA= Governor: In a three-way race, House Speaker Don Avenson won the Democratic nomination. Gov. Terry Branstad was unopposed for the GOP nomination.
MONTANA= Senate: Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad won the GOP nomination over three competitors. Democratic Sen. Max Baucus overcame two little-known challengers.
NEW JERSEY= Senate: Democratic Sen. Bill Bradley easily won renomination. Republican Christine Todd Whitman was unopposed.
NEW MEXICO= Governor: Former Gov. Bruce King won the Democratic nomination and former state Rep. Frank Bond got the GOP nod. Each defeated three other candidates for their party nominations.
NORTH CAROLINA= Senate: Former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt defeated Mike Easley, the Brunswick County district attorney, in the runoff for the Democratic nomination and will face GOP Sen. Jesse Helms.

DOC.SECOND: Appeals Court Hears Arguments in Embryo-Divorce Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Three state appeals today sought to cut through the philosophical arguments surrounding the fate of seven frozen human embryos to reach a practical resolution. ``We have to make a decision about what to do with these embryos,'' said presiding Judge Clifford E. Sanders as the Court of Appeals heard arguments on a divorce decision that gave the embryos to the wife. ``We're dealing with a very narrow issue here, and that's what to do with these embryos,'' Judge Herschel P. Franks said, interrupting a statement by one of the lawyers on the impact the case could have on birth control methods. ``Let's keep to that issue.'' Janet Mayfield, the attorney for Junior Davis, said Davis wants control over whether he becomes a parent. She argued that he has a constitutional right to make that decision. Kurt Erlenbach, the attorney for Mary Sue Davis Stowe, said his client wants control of the embryos so she can give them up for donation to some other infertile couple. Mrs. Stowe had said during the divorce trial last year she wanted the embryos for implantation in her womb in an effort to give birth. Since their divorce eight months ago, Davis, 31, and his 29-year-old ex-wife both have remarried. But their battle to control the embryos continues. The embryos are in cryogenic storage at the Knoxville in vitro fertilization clinic where they were created in December 1988. Custody of the embryos was awarded to Mrs. Stowe on Sept. 21 by Blount County Judge W. Dale Young, who treated the embryos as if they were children in a custody dispute. Young ruled that life begins at conception, and said the embryos thus deserved legal status and protection. Davis appealed, claiming the judge stepped beyond his bounds. During their four-day trial in August, Davis and Mrs. Stowe said they would not consider the option of donating the embryos to some other childless couple. In her response filed last week, however, Mrs. Stowe said she no longer wants to use the embryos in an attempt to have children. She now asks for control of the embryos so she can donate them for use by someone else, according to Erlenbach's response. The appeals court is expected to take at least six weeks to reach a decision. In Tennessee the state court of appeals is the intermediate step between the Circuit Court, where the case was heard, and the state Supreme Court.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Urge Prison Term for Poindexter
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors said Wednesday that former national security adviser John M. Poindexter should to go prison because he subverted democratic principles by feeding Congress a ``diet of lies'' about the Iran-Contra affair. A prison term would ``warn other high-ranking officials that criminal violations of the public trust will result in more than mere loss of public employment,'' prosecutors in the office of independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh said in a memo to U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene. Poindexter, President Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until the Iran-Contra affair unraveled in November 1986, is scheduled to be sentenced Monday on five felony convictions. The retired Navy rear admiral faces up to 25 years in prison and fines up to $1.25 million. He was convicted April 7 of conspiracy, making false statements and obstructing congressional inquiries into the sale of U.S. arms to Iran and covert aid to Nicaraguan Contras. Poindexter's lies, misleading statements and destruction of documents ``did violence to this nation's fundamental principles of government,'' prosecutors said. It is, they said, a ``system that relies fundamentally upon the exchange of truthful information.'' ``If, as occurred in this case, high-ranking officials of one branch of government feel free to feed the other branch a diet of lies, then the constitutional system will surely sicken and, eventually, die,'' prosecutors said. The sentencing memo was filed as one of Poindexter's former subordinates, retired Marine Lt. Col. Oliver L. North, resumed testifying before a newly empaneled grand jury continuing to investigate the Iran-Contra affair. North, a former National Security Council aide, gave seven hours of testimony last week. He is appealing his own Iran-Contra convictions. The grand jury is trying to determine if other Reagan administration officials participated in efforts to conceal details of the U.S.-Iran arms sales and the diversion of profits to the Contras. The grand jury also is expected to try to make a final assessment of the exact roles of Reagan and then-Vice President Bush in the affair. Poindexter is expected to be subpoenaed to testify. In their sentencing memo, prosecutors urged the judge to ignore pleas for leniency on the ground that neither North nor Robert McFarlane, who preceded Poindexter as national security adviser, was imprisoned for Iran-Contra convictions. Poindexter, prosecutors said, ``occupied a position where his judgment was critical and in many instances _ if former President Reagan's deposition testimony is any guide _ final.'' Prosecutors said that McFarlane, unlike Poindexter, accepted responsibility for his actions by pleading guilty to four misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress and cooperating with the investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Blood Demand Falls During 1980s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: The use of blood transfusions began to fall in U.S. hospitals during the 1980s, largely because of fear of passing on AIDS, a nationwide study shows. The study found that transfusions of whole blood and red cells began declining after a peak of 12.2 million pints in 1986. During the mid-1980s, people have sharply increased the practice of setting aside their own blood for use during operations. The study, directed by Dr. Douglas M. Surgenor of the Center for Blood Research in Boston, was based on a survey of about 5,800 hospitals and blood centers. It was published in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. Among the findings: _Transfusions of whole blood and red cells fell to 11.6 million pints in 1987 and continued to decline in 1988, the last year of the survey. _Transfusions of blood plasma dropped almost 9 percent during the decade. _Donations of autologous blood _ the practice of setting aside blood for one's own use _ increased from 30,000 pints in 1982 to 397,000 pints in 1987. _The supply of blood donated for others was unchanged between 1986 and 1988. The researchers attributed the changes to fear of passing on the AIDS virus through transfusions. The chance of catching the disease from a transfusion has been slight since blood banks began screening for the virus in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communist Chief Jakes, Four Others, Detained Two Days Before Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to ADD details of detentions; Pickup 15th, `The Czechoslovak...'
DOC.TEXT: Police detained former Communist party chief Milos Jakes and at least four other ousted Communist leaders, the official news agency said today, just two days before the first free elections since 1946. Those taken into custody for questioning also included Vasil Bilak, a former Communist party ideology chief accused of having invited Soviet troops to Czechoslovakia in 1968. The others detained were former premier Jozef Lenart, and former senior Communist Party leaders Michal Stefanak and Rudolf Hegenbart. The detentions were certain to deal another blow to the Communists' credibility before the election Friday and Saturday for the federal parliament and the Czech and Slovak legislatures. The official CTK news agency said Bilak was detained on suspicion of ``committing serious criminal activity.'' It gave no reason for the other detentions and did not say where they were being held. Bilak, 72, was picked up at midnight Tuesday from his home in the Slovak capital of Bratislava, deputy interior minister Andrej Samel said. He was detained for 48 hours, an official who identified himself only as Secansky said from the general prosecutor`s office in Bratislava. Jakes, Stefanak and Hegenbart, answered summons from police this morning, Samel said. He said he did not know how long the four would be interrogated. Jakes was Communist Party chief until Nov. 24, when he was ousted along with all senior figures who had enforced orthodox Communist rule after the Warsaw Pact invasion of August 1968 crushed the ``Prague Spring'' reforms. Hegenbart was named last week in a British Broadcasting Corp. documentary that claimed he was involved in an alleged scheme with the Soviet KGB to oust Jakes last November. ``The public is going to be informed about the future course of the investigation,'' the terse CTK report that focused on Bilak said. Samel said the four summoned for interrogation were asked to help police to ``clarify their activities related to the 1968 invasion and possibly other criminal activities as well. ``They could have refused the summons, but willingly complied,'' he said. Jakes, Bilak and Lenart were all expelled from the party after the November revolution that brought President Vaclav Havel to power. In this week's election, Havel's Civic Forum, which helped lead the anti-Communist revolt, is expected to emerge as a strong force, although not to win an outright majority. In April this year, Czechoslovak prosecutors launched an investigation into the 1968 Soviet-led invasion. The investigation was to clarify what prosecutors have termed ``all circumstances of this criminal offense against peace.'' That offense carries a maximum sentence of 15 years in jail. Lubomir Veleta, deputy general prosecutor said April 7 the main aim of the investigation was to identify people responsible for inviting the Soviet troops into Czechoslovakia. Bilak has long been accused to be the official who requested that Soviet troops intervene, but he has denied the charges. The Czechoslovak government has officially requested that Soviet authorities release all documents related to the invasion, but the Kremlin has refused. ``The invasion of Soviet troops into Czechoslovakia in 1968 was not decided on the basis of this or that appeal of individuals, if there ever was such a thing,'' Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman Vadim Perfiliev was quoted in a czechoslovak paper on May 29 as saying. After the 1968 invasion, Bilak rose under the leadership of fellow Slovak Gustav Husak to be chief Communist Party ideologue.

DOC.HEAD: Hands Off the Sweets, It's Candy Art
DOC.TEXT: Please don't eat the art exhibit. Museum-goers may feel like kids in a candy store when viewing an exhibit on the history of using sugar, chocolate and other sweets to create works of art. Highlights of the show at the California Museum of Science and Industry are a jelly-bean rendition of the Statue of Liberty, a house of chocolate chip cookies and a chocolate bust of Albert Einstein. On display are ``more than 200 culinary masterpieces,'' curators said. ``It's not a superscientific exhibit, but it's kind of frothy for summer,'' museum spokeswoman Sue Glad said. ``The Confectioner's Art'' exhibit opened Monday for an eight-week run.

DOC.HEAD: Vets Return to Omaha Beach for I Like Ike Ceremony
LaserPhoto PAR17
DOC.TEXT: Allied veterans armed with video recorders returned to one of World War II's greatest battlefields Wednesday to commemorate the man who sent them ashore to defeat Nazi Germany, Dwight D. Eisenhower. Wind-driven rain lashed the Normandy beaches as veterans and dignitaries from a dozen countries paid tribute to Eisenhower on the 100th year of his birth and the 46th anniversary of D-Day. ``I don't think there's any doubt that giving the order for this operation was the most difficult decision my father ever made,'' said John Eisenhower, the general's son. ``But he never looked back.'' U.S. Army, Navy and Air Force brass and veterans of all ranks appeared in solemn wreath-laying ceremonies at the American National Cemetery on a bluff overlooking Omaha Beach. The annual D-Day commemoration took on a special meaning this year as the Defense Department saluted the man who ordered the biggest seaborne invasion in history. Some 200,000 predominantly American, British and Canadian soldiers stormed onto the Normandy coast in landings coordinated with paratroop drops, starting a campaign that less than a year later toppled Adolf Hitler's Nazi regime. One million men eventually landed on five Normandy beaches. Gen. John Galvin, commander of NATO forces in Europe, said Eisenhower's dream of a peaceful Europe _ begun with the liberation of Western Europe and the creation of NATO _ was near realization due to the democratic changes sweeping Eastern Europe and various U.S.-Soviet arms control agreements. ``As we look ahead now to a protracted peace and the great opportunities that present themselves,'' said Galvin, ``I hope we can honor the fighters who lay in this field, who died on the beaches of France.'' The immaculately manicured lawns hold the graves of 9,386 U.S. servicemen. The field overlooks the sandy dunes where many of them died in the bloodiest fighting of the D-Day landings. One Omaha Beach veteran who came to remember was Jack Boardman, 66, of Chicago. In the early hours of June 6, 1944, a transport ship dropped his amphibious tank 10,000 yards out to sea. The first tank in his batallion of 30 sank in the choppy English Channel. ``We went up the beach with the infantrymen,'' said Boardman, wearing an Indiana Jones-style hat and a regimental patch on his bush jacket. ``The tank commander hit me on the back and said, `Shoot. Shoot.' ``I didn't know what to shoot at. Finally, I saw a dark rectangle. It was one of the pillboxes,'' cement fortication housing artillery or machineguns. ``So I just started shooting.'' Later in the day, his tank lost both treads. His crew climbed out and waded through bodies of dead U.S. soldiers three deep, mown down by German mortar, artillary and machine-gun fire. Boardman is now close friends with one of those Germans, Heinrich Severloh, of Metzingen, West Germany. Severloh, 67, remembers ``terror'' when dawn broke and he saw an Allied fleet of 7,000 warships heading straight at him. ``Shells were dropping everywhere,'' he recalled. ``Thank God they were dropping behind us. I was a machine gunner. We waited for the Americans to come ashore. When they were knee-deep, my officer gave the order to fire.'' Severloh's unit fell back that evening with no radio, ammunition or commanding officer. A veteran of the Russian front, Severloh was captured the next day. ``There are no enemies anymore,'' he said, putting an arm around Boardman's shoulders. A flight of F-14 fighters from the Navy aircraft carrier U.S.S. Eisenhower roared overhead as the 2,000 spectators looked on. Wreaths were placed later at the Pointe du Hoc, a formidable German artillary position lying between Omaha Beach and the other American landing sight, Utah Beach, to the north. A commando force of 270 U.S. Rangers scaled the razor-like cliffs of the Pointe just before the landings to knock out what commanders feared could be a devastating firing point against the vulnerable soldiers wading up both beaches. A day later, only 90 of the Rangers were able to carry a weapon. John Eisenhower dedicated a monument to his father in an overgrown farmer's field between Utah Beach and St. Lo where Gen. Eisenhower set up his first field headquarters on the continent, and where he first met Gen. Charles de Gaulle in France. This was the fourth stop on the ``journey to victory'' commemoration organized by the U.S. Department of Defense in honor of the 100th anniversary of Eisenhower's birth. The events, culminating at the Arc de Triomph in Paris Friday, were timed to coincide with the 46th anniversary of the invasion rather than Eisenhower's birthday on Oct. 14. Previous ceremonies were held in Britain and on the English Channel aboard the carrier Eisenhower.

DOC.HEAD: Dissidents' Son Says Parents' Spirits Good After Year in Embassy
DOC.TEXT: Astrophysicist-turned-dissident Fang Lizhi longs to see the sky but writes that he and his wife are in good spirits and pursuing scientific research inside the U.S. Embassy in Beijing, their son said. One year ago Tuesday, the two ``were forced to take refuge in the U.S. Embassy in Beijing by a brutal and bloody situation and increasing violation of their freedoms and human rights,'' said their son Fang Ke, a physics student at Wayne State University in Detroit. He communicates with his parents by letters. Little about Fang and his wife, Li Shuxian, is known since they entered the embassy because they have declined to talk with reporters. The embassy has refused to answer nearly all questions about them. Their son spoke Tuesday night to a group gathered to mark the publication of ``Children of the Dragon: The Story of Tiananmen Square.'' The book was compiled by the New York-based group Human Rights in China about last year's pro-democracy movement that ended in violent military suppression June 3-4. Fang Lizhi and his wife, also a physicist, became well known for their advocacy of democracy and human rights in China before last year's demonstrations. The couple took refuge after being accused of inciting the student-lead protests. The government has said they are counterrevolutionaries. Letters from his parents reveal both frustration and hope, Fang said. ``Once my father said, `I am an astronomer and I cannot see the sky,''' he said. But both have continued their research with help from overseas colleagues, and they have written 10 literary and scientific articles that will be published in Western magazines, he said. ``Their spirits are strong,'' Fang said in an interview. In one letter, he said his father wrote, ``We will create a new life no matter how unbearable the condition is.'' Their son said free speech is among the freedoms enshrined in the Chinese constitution. ``A few people like my father dare to exercise and enjoy this kind of freedom and rights and so are accused of being criminals. Actually they were accused because of their conscience and beliefs,'' he said. Some Chinese are displeased with Fang and Li for seeking refuge in the embassy, and with student leaders who fled overseas. They feel they have betrayed the Chinese people by not enduring through the period that followed the demonstrations in Tiananmen Square. Fang said his parents, who have another son in China, were reluctant to go to the embassy because they did not want to hurt the pro-democracy movement, but they realized their lives may have been at stake. Fang said he speaks for himself, not as an official spokesman for his parents. ``I have the confidence, as well as my father and my mother, that we will win eventually,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Said To Retract Threat Against Jewish Emigration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 12 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. official saying Soviets retract threat on emigration. Pickup 3rd graf ``I don't...'' of a0536, AM-Baker, 1st Ld-Writethru to ADD pvs copy. EDITS thereafter to TRIM
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has retracted what appeared to be a threat by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to suspend Jewish emigration to Israel, a senior U.S. official said today. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at a meeting Tuesday in Copenhagen, Denmark, he was concerned about Gorbachev's statement at the Washington summit, the official said. In reply, Shevardnadze told Baker that the Soviet ``had no plan to change their approach, they are committed to that,'' said the official, who briefed reporters on condition that he not be identified. Baker flew to Turnberry from the Danish capital, where he and Shevardnadze attended a 35-nation human rights conference. In Scotland, Baker is to talk with NATO ministers on the latest U.S. and Soviet moves toward an agreement on the military future of a reunified Germany. The senior U.S. official also said Shevardnadze advised Baker the Israeli government would be informed that emigration policy was not being altered. The foreign minister did not say how Moscow was informing Israel, the official said. There are no formal relations between the two countries but diplomats have exchanged visits. The senior official volunteered the account of the conversation, held at the Soviet Embassy in Copenhagen, when he briefed reporters aboard Baker's U.S. Air Force jet. Gorbachev, speaking Sunday at a joint news conference with President Bush at the end of the four-day Washington summit, said Israel should heed the advice of the two leaders and not settle Soviet Jews on the occupied West Bank or in Gaza. ``We are facing the following situation,'' Gorbachev said. ``Either after these (summit) meetings our concern is heeded in Israel and they will make certain conclusions or else we must give further thought to it in terms of what we do in issuing permits for exit.'' Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is at a record high. About 20,000 permits were issued last month. The United States is taking in about 70,000 Soviet Jews this year. Most of the others go to Israel, where their rising numbers perturbs the Arabs. Also today, Baker said he would take to the NATO allies a Soviet proposal for an agreement with the Warsaw Pact on the military future of a reunited Germany. Baker said that even though Shevardnadze had provided him with only a few details, ``I hope we are making progress'' in persuading Moscow to give up its objections to German membership in the Western alliance. ``I don't feel at liberty to get into the details,'' Baker told reporters at a Copenhagen news conference. ``After all,'' he said, ``this is an alliance-to-alliance matter if it ever comes to anything.'' Baker said the Soviets wanted ``confidence-building measures'' as part of any settlement on Germany. Other U.S. officials said the measures under discussion also involved accelerating negotiations for reducing non-nuclear arms in Europe. Before flying to Turnberry, Baker called in a speech for strengthening the rule of law in Central European countries that are shaking off Soviet influence. ``The watchword of reformers everywhere is the rule of law,'' Baker said, quoting the late Soviet dissident and Nobel laureate Andrei Sakharov. ``Democratic change must be accomplished through democratic methods _ peacefully, through legal processes.'' His speech to a 35-nation human rights conference contained scant mention of the situation in the Baltics. The Soviet republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are at various stages in their quest for independence, and are encountering stiff resistance from Moscow. In the address, Baker did not confront the Soviets directly but urged them to initiate ``a systematic dialogue'' with leaders of the independence movements ``so that the aspirations of the Baltic peoples can be achieved.'' On another topic, Baker offered the most optimistic U.S. forecast yet about completing a treaty to sharply reduce U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks, artillery and other non-nuclear weapons in Europe. He said that ``at the CSCE summit, we would expect to sign a CFE agreement, and President Gorbachev last week indicated he shared this view.'' The French government, the host, proposed on Tuesday to hold the summit of the 35-nation Conference on European Security and Cooperation in Paris in December. The Bush administration has made completion of the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty a precondition for the event. Describing his talks on Germany with Shevardnadze, Baker said the Soviet government had to develop its proposal more fully before the Western allies could respond to it formally. Still, Baker said, enough had been made clear by Shevardnadze in their two-hour meeting at the Soviet Embassy on Tuesday to know ``what they are talking about is an agreement between the Warsaw Pact and the NATO alliance.'' He said he hoped to have more details from Moscow at a meeting on Germany's future planned for June 22 in Berlin. The four World War II allies _ the United States, Britain, France, and the Soviet Unikon _ will attend along with the foreign ministers of the two German states.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Takes Soviet Proposal On NATO To Allies
LaserPhoto Staffing
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Wednesday presented a Soviet proposal on Germany's military future to the 15 U.S. allies in NATO as having the potential to break an East-West deadlock. ``I hope we are making progress,'' Baker said before leaving Copenhagen, where he discussed the idea for two hours Tuesday night with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. He then flew to this small town on the western coast of Scotland where Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher had invited the NATO foreign ministers to meet on Germany and other East-West issues. Baker will see Mrs. Thatcher on Thursday and confer with the foreign ministers through Saturday. A month from now President Bush and the heads of the 15 governments will meet at a NATO summit in London. The key issue in all these sessions is the impending union of East Germany and West Germany, producing a powerful nation that the allies _ and even some members of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact _ want enrolled in NATO. The problem is persuading Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to acquiesce. The Soviets are losing East Germany as a staunch ally and buffer and will now be confronted by a country with which they fought two world wars this century. Bush's prescription is to anchor Germany in NATO as a protection against any unilateral move by the Germans. Baker offered Shevardnadze a nine-point package of assurances, including a German promise not to acquire nuclear or chemical weapons or to seek to expand its borders. At their meeting Tuesday night in Copenhagen the Soviet foreign minister went into some detail about what Baker called ``confidence-building measures.'' The Soviet idea is to have NATO and the Warsaw Pact, which begins a meeting Thursday in Moscow, exchange political assurances. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany, who attended a 35-nation human rights conference in Copenhagen with Baker and Shevardnadze, said in a speech there that ``the democratic Europe must be a Europe of tolerance.'' He said ``ideological blindness, nationalism, racism, fascism and anti-Semitism have caused inhuman terror and untold suffering on our continent.'' The foreign minister, leader of West Germany's liberal Free Democratic party, said: ``We Germans know that we cannot cope with our future without the will to remember the past.'' He said Germany and all other European nations must be alert to any hint of anti-Semitism and ``to resolutely nip any such developments in the bud.'' Baker told reporters he was ``not at liberty to get into the details'' of the Soviet proposal. ``After all,'' he said, ``this is an alliance-to-alliance matter if it ever comes to anything.'' In his speech at the human rights conference, Baker called for free elections and free-market economies throughout Eastern and Central Europe. ``The watchword of reformers everywhere is the rule of law,'' he said, quoting the late Soviet dissident and Nobel laureate Andrei Sakharov. ``Democratic change must be accomplished through democratic methods _ peacefully, through legal processes.'' He mentioned only briefly the Baltic republics, where independence movements are running into Soviet roadblocks. Baker urged Moscow to initiate ``a systematic dialogue'' with the leaders of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania ``so that the aspirations of the Baltic peoples can be achieved.'' There was no hint of stronger action against Moscow, as urged by many members of Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Pledge Unity, Look Ahead to Helms
DOC.TEXT: Democrats rallied around Harvey Gantt on Wednesday as North Carolina's first black U.S. Senate nominee embraced his defeated challenger and prepared to take on Republican Sen. Jesse Helms. ``The Democratic Party is ready to go forward unified just like we promised,'' Gantt told supporters at Democratic Party headquarters after he defeated Brunswick County District Attorney Mike Easley in Tuesday's runoff. He laughed and joked with Easley, saying,``He sounded exactly like me on so many things, I wondered how I'd beat this guy.'' But after the two exchanged congratulations on a positive, issue-oriented campaign, talk turned to their expectations that the gloves would come off when Helms starts throwing political punches. ``I think it's very important that we not allow this campaign to drift off into those hot-button, emotional issues that I call Jesse Helms' pasture,'' Gantt said. ``I'm going to talk about the issues of working families _ education for liberal and conservative families, the importance of affordable health care, protecting the environment,'' he said. ``If wanting to challenge North Carolinians and Americans to address those challenges makes me a liberal, so be it.'' Helms issued a terse statement Tuesday night congratulating Gantt for his ``hard-fought'' victory. In final, unofficial returns, Gantt had 273,347 votes, or 57 percent, to Easley's 207,329, or 43 percent.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING TO FIX CYCLE DESIGNATOR
Soviets Retract Apparent Threat to Suspend Exit Permits
With AM-Israel-Soviet Jews, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has retracted what appeared to be a threat by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to suspend Jewish emigration to Israel, a senior U.S. official said Wednesday. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze at a meeting Tuesday in Copenhagen, Denmark, he was concerned by Gorbachev's statement at the Washington summit, the official said. In reply, Shevardnadze told Baker Soviet officials ``had no plan to change their approach, they are committed to that,'' the official said on condition of annonymity. The official spoke to reporters aboard Baker's U.S. Air Force jet. He said Shevardnadze told Baker that the Israeli government would be advised that the Soviet emigration policy was not being altered. The foreign minister did not say how Moscow would inform Israel. The two countries do not have formal relations, but diplomats have exchanged visits. Baker flew to Turnberry, where he and Shevardnadze were to attend a meeting of the North Atlantic Council. Both Baker and his Soviet counterpart had been in Copenhagen for a 35-nation human rights conference. Speaking at a joint news conference with President Bush at the end of the four-day Washington summit on Sunday, Gorbachev said Israel should not settle Soviet jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank or Gaza Strip. Bush also objected to Soviet Jews being settled in the territories. Gorbachev said that if Israel did not heed the two leaders' advice, the Soviet Union might further restrict exit permits. ``Either after these (summit) meetings our concern is heeded in Israel and they will make certain conclusions, or we must give further thought to it in terms of what we do in issuing permits for exit,'' Gorbachev said. Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union is at an all-time high. About 20,000 permits were issued last month, but an estimated 1 million Soviets are waiting to emigrate. The United States will take in 70,000 Soviet Jews this year and most of the others will go to Israel. An estimated 750,000 are expected to flood into that country in the next years. Arab nations have expressed concern about a possible mass settlement of Soviet Jews in the occupied lands, captured by Israel from the Arabs in the 1967 Middle East war. Gorbachev said two Arab leaders, Presidents Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Hafez Assad of Syria, ``raised in acute terms, the question of Israeli guarantees now.''
