Israeli officials say only about 200 Soviet Jews have settled in the territories, home to 1.7 million Palestinians and 70,000 Jewish settlers. Israeli Minister of Immigrant Absorption Yitzhak Peretz has denied Israel is settling immigrants there.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Eyeing Multinational Forces in a United Germany
With AM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States and its NATO allies are considering the increased use of multinational military units as a way of making Western troops more acceptable in a unified Germany, analysts say. Richard Fieldhouse, senior research associate at the Natural Resources Defense Council in Washington, described the push for forces with soldiers from many nations as ``an attempt to maintain some sort of NATO forces within Germany.'' ``All of this comes out of the desire to present stationed forces in a way which is more palatable to Germany and the Soviet Union,'' said Hans Binnendijk, director of studies at the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. The idea of multinational forces got a boost last month when U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and other defense chiefs of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization called for an alliance study of their use. They said in a final statement that they attached ``particular importance'' to the task. Multinational forces _ air, sea or ground units carrying the flags of a variety of nations _ are nothing new to NATO. But the new attention reflects the alliance's campaign to revamp its military strategy with the diminished threat from the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Moreover, it must deal with the prospects of a unified Germany. West Germany belongs to NATO, but its eastern neighbor is part of the crumbling Warsaw Pact. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union has opposed NATO membership for a united Germany. He recently suggested it could remain in the Western alliance but must withdraw from its integrated military structure. France and Spain, both NATO allies, are outside the joint military command. In the changing situation, Fieldhouse said it would be difficult for the United States to make a case for keeping a large contingent of troops in Germany. ``What role does the United States have as a NATO nation in Germany?'' he asked. Binnendijk said West Germans doesn't want to be different from their European neighbors. ``Stationed forces make them abnormal,'' he said. As a result, Fieldhouse predicted, ``Germans probably won't be interested in having 195,000 Americans stationed on their soil in a relatively short period of time.'' The United States has an estimated 239,000 soldiers in West Germany, and the Soviet Union has 380,000 Red Army troops on East German soil. Washington and Moscow have settled on a plan, as part of arms control talks in Vienna, that would reduce their forces stationed in Central Europe to 195,000 soldiers on each side. The United States would maintain an additional 30,000 troops in Britain and southern Europe. Fieldhouse also argued that the continued presence of NATO troops in Germany would enable its allies to ``keep some form of influence in German affairs.'' ``This would be perhaps one answer to any German interest in building up a military,'' he said. Some in Europe worry about the resurgence of a militaristic Germany in the strategic center of their continent. U.S. Gen. John Galvin, the supreme commander of alliance forces in Europe, said NATO's air and sea forces already are made up of units from various nations. ``It is really only the ground forces that are somewhat lacking in multinationality,'' he said in a recent interview. Galvin suggested it might be best to form multinational ground units at the corps level. A corps is usually made up of three divisions of 15,000 to 20,000 soldiers each. Each division would be drawn from a different nation. He said he was concerned a smaller unit would be inefficient. ``There is a certain level at which multinationality begins not to work very well,' he said. He said it was difficult, for instance, to have a multinational crew in an airplane partly because of differences in language and training. ``It's hard to change that in an aircraft where you need to be in constant communication making quick decisions,'' he said. In 1960, NATO formed the ACE Mobile Force, which draws air and ground troops from Belgium, Canada, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Britain and the United States. Their mission is to respond rapidly in an emergency. There are about 5,000 soldiers in the land unit and two to four squadrons, with about 20 or so planes in each squadron, in the air force. Last year, the NATO Composite Force was created to react quickly to an attack in northern Norway. It is made up of troops from Canada, West Germany, Norway and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Original Playboy Mansion up for Sale
DOC.TEXT: For Sale: Stately 72-room, 87-year-old home featuring an indoor swimming pool and bowling alley. Asking price: $6 million. Historical significance: Once home to Hugh Hefner and a brood of Playboy bunnies. It's been an art school dormitory for the last five years, but the original Playboy Mansion is remembered more for scantily-clad women and it's robed, pipe-smoking lord and master than dorm keggers and food fights. The mansion is being sold by the School of the Art Institute in Chicago. The Chicago-based Playboy Enterprises Inc. donated use of the building to the school in 1984. Playboy officials promised the school title to the property if it was maintained for five years. School officials received the deed in February, but said the building was too expensive to maintain as a dormitory. Hefner, Playboy's founder, bought the mansion in 1959 and lived there until 1971, when he moved to a palatial mansion in Los Angeles. University real estate officials said they have received numerous proposals for the property, including one to convert it into luxury condominiums.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.NOTE: Eds: First item for release at 6 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Move over, Johnny and Dave. Arsenio is the fairest in late-night TV talk show land these days. At least that's how US magazine readers see it. US magazine's third annual readers' poll, which surveyed 3,600 people, showed its readers to be a fickle lot. Just last year, they chose Roseanne Barr as the best TV actress, but this year she was named worst TV actress. She also was named ``most overexposed actress'' and her show, ``Roseanne,'' was ``the worst TV series.'' On the other hand, they love ``Roseanne'' co-star John Goodman, although not his fashion sense. He was named ``best TV actor'' and ``worst dressed actor'' by readers responding to a ballot published in the March 5 issue. Other picks: Best movie actor: Tom Cruise. Worst: Sylvester Stallone. Best movie actress: Bette Midler. Worst: Madonna. Hottest New Actress: Julia Roberts of ``Pretty Woman.'' Hottest New Actor: Richard Grieco, star of TV's ``Booker.'' Best Movie: ``Born on the Fourth of July.'' Worst: ``Batman.'' Best TV actor: John Goodman. Worst: Bill Cosby. Best TV actress: Candice Bergen. Worst: Roseanne Barr. Entertainer of the Year and best late night talk show host: Arsenio Hall. Best Musical Group: New Kids On The Block. Worst: Guns N' Roses. Best male singer: Richard Marx. Worst: Prince. Best female singer: Paula Abdul (who also won best hairdo honors). Worst: Madonna. And in the ``make up your mind'' category, readers chose Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner as this year's best movie couple and Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner as the worst.

Country music giants Randy Travis, Loretta Lynn and Clint Black helped lure about 20,000 people eager for a chance to rub elbows with stars to the 19th annual International Country Music Fan Fair. Travis attracted one of the largest crowds Tuesday afternoon, with people lined up around a building to take a picture with the singing star, get an autograph or simply shake hands. Cameras clicked furiously and the crowd oohed and aahed when a youngster in full cowboy regalia was lifted onto a counter next to Black. Zachary Bingham will be 3 this month and is a big country music fan already, says his mother, Sonja Bingham. ``His favorite song is (Black's) `Nobody's Home' and he puts on his boots and his hat along with the words,'' Mrs. Bingham said. Charley Pride also was a hit at the celebrity show-off event at the Tennessee State Fairgrounds. Beside star contact, the weeklong fair's $70 registration fee lets fans see 40 hours of concerts, visit the Opryland USA showpark and tour the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum. More than 24,000 people registered for the fan festival, said Country Music Association spokeswoman Kelly Gattis.

Rock star Madonna canceled a Wednesday concert on doctors' orders because of lingering throat trouble. The sultry singer had canceled a Chicago concert because of unspecified throat problems before she performed two sellout shows at the Worcester Centrum this week. Two physicians told her that unless she took several days off, she risked permanent damage to her voice and vocal chords, forcing her to cancel the third Worcester show slated for Wednesday, promoters of her Blond Ambition tour said.

A concert pavilion is the latest to ban concerts by the Grateful Dead because of its fans. Merriweather Post Pavilion granted a police request to end scheduling of concerts by the veteran rock 'n' roll band and the Jerry Garcia Band, headed by the Grateful Dead's lead singer, said Jean Parker, general manager of the 14,000-seat amphitheater. Grateful Dead spokesman Dennis McNally dismissed the pavilion's decision, saying drug arrests at concerts reflect a problem in society and should not be blamed on the bands. ``The same arrests are made at football games and baseball games,'' McNally said. In California, Stanford University and the University of California, Berkeley banned the group in April because of recurring drug-related arrests at concerts. The San Francisco-based band, which formed in the 1960s, has a large following of so-called Dead Heads. Many have followed the band from show to show, peddling T-shirts and other Grateful Dead souvenirs. Hoping to boost its image, the band recently banned all vending outside their concerts.

DOC.HEAD: Democratic Leader Says Crime Bill Could Be Scuttled
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Leader George Mitchell said Wednesday an anticrime bill curbing semiautomatic weapons could be scuttled unless senators put a time limit on debate this week. ``This is the vote on the crime bill,'' Mitchell said as senators prepared for a vote Thursday to limit debate to 30 hours. Sponsors of the bill have been saying that, without the time limit, debating more than 241 proposed amendments would mean open-ended delays and make it impossible to vote on the overall legislation. The bill would bar the import or domestic manufacture of nine semiautomatic assault rifles, pistols and shotguns. It also would provide for the death penalty for 30 federal crimes, allow courts to consider evidence gathered with faulty warrants in some cases and move to end decade-long delays in carrying out death sentences. Mitchell was asked what would happen if the Senate on Thursday balked at a time limit on debate. ``That's it,'' the Maine senator said sharply. He suggested that the Senate would then move on to other business and not return to the measure. The campaign against military-looking semiautomatic weapons began in January 1989 after a deranged man with an AK-47 rifle opened fire on a Stockton, Calif., school yard, leaving five dead and 30 injured. The National Rifle Association has been against the plan, saying that the ``assault weapons'' that would be restricted differ only in appearance from ordinary semiautomatic hunting rifles with their traditional brown wood stocks. It says the bill would be unfair to hunters, gun collectors and target shooters. After senators rebuffed the NRA two weeks ago and refused to drop the curbs, lawmakers introduced scores of amendments. But the Senate on Tuesday voted 54-37 in favor of invoking cloture, or imposing a time limit, six votes short of the 60 needed. The Senate shelved further action on the crime package until after the Thursday vote. Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss., said on the floor Wednesday that he ``can't understand why the crime package is being put off.'' He said lawmakers had introduced ``some very good amendments to this issue.'' ``The American people feel very strongly that the scales have tipped too much in favor of the criminals and against the victims and against the rights of society,'' Lott said. He said there was ``nobody who is trying to delay this issue just because of the gun-control question.'' ``Let's don't invoke cloture on Thursday, let's deal with these important amendments,'' Lott said. He said Americans ``don't understand parliamentary maneuver that prohibits amendments that are very important to them and should be on it.''

DOC.HEAD: Greek Premier Visits White House for First Time in 26 Years
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with quotes, details from meeting; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush pressed Greek Premier Constantine Mitsotakis today for extradition of a Palestinian wanted for the 1982 bombing of a Pan Am plane over Hawaii. The new conservative Greek leader, the first to visit the White House in 26 years, urged Bush to prod Turkey to withdraw troops from Cyprus. Mitsokakis, after talks in the Oval Office and a luncheon in Bush's residence, told reporters, ``I think I was pretty convincing when I told the president that both as a human being and as a politician I will do my very best to combat terrorism.'' Mitsokakis' son-in-law, Pavlos Bakoyannis, a member of parliament, was assassinated on an Athens street by terrorists last September. His widow, Dora, who subsequently won his seat in parliament, accompanied her father to the White House. On the U.S. extradition request for Mohammed Rashid, wanted for a 1982 jet bombing that killed a Japanese teen-ager and wounded 15 others, Mitsotakis said he told Bush, ``we're looking into it and we will decide before September.'' The Greek Supreme Court has upheld a lower court's extradition order. The decision now rests with the country's minister of justice. Rashid was arrested at the Athens airport in May 1988 on a fake passport. On the subject of Cyprus, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush ``made clear that the status quo on the island is not satisfactory and that the United States is committed to active suport for the (United Nations) secretary general's efforts to achieve'' a settlement. Asked about the possibility of an American initiative to break the deadlock, Fitzwater said the United States believes ``the best course of doing that is within the U.N.'' Fitzwater said the two leaders agreed on the importance of international cooperation in fighting terrorism and narcotics. Mitsotakis told The Washington Post beforehand that he would urge Bush to prod the Turkish government to cut its occupation forces in half on Cyprus. The island has been partitioned since a 1974 Turkish invasion. Mitsotakis told reporters on the White House driveway, ``I asked him to use all his influence in order to help settle the Cyprus issue. I told him that presently we are at a dead end and some gesture, acting like a catalyst, should be made from the Turkish side.'' He said he felt Bush was ``highly interested in the matter.'' The United States often had strained ties with Mitsotakis' socialist predecesor, Andreas Papandreou, during his eight-year ternure. In the two months since Mitsotakis' New Democracy Party took power, Greece and the United States have already initialed a new defense agreement. Fitzwater said, ``The two presidents agreed that this visit was important for a new beginning of an old friendship.'' Mitsotakis said it ``inaugurates a new period of relations between the two countries.'' He said Bush had accepted an invitation to visit Greece, and invited Mitsotakis back to Washington for an official visit. No dates were set. A base agreement initialed after just two rounds of talks will allow the U.S. military presence in Greece to continue. But two of the four U.S. bases in Greece _ Hellenikon Air Force Base near Athens and a naval communications station _ will be closed. Mitsotakis's New Democracy Party has 150 seats in the 300-member Parliament. One deputy who represents a small conservative grouping is backing Mitsotakis' party. The terms of the agreement will be made public once mutually acceptable translations are completed. Formal signing is expected in July. During the Papandreou government, the two sides were unable to conclude a base agreement despite 17 rounds of negotiations. As a NATO ally, Greece is slated to receive $345 million in military aid during the next fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: Pauley's Husband Was Ready to `Slash and Burn' NBC Execs
DOC.TEXT: Jane Pauley still insists NBC was not trying to force her out by bringing Deborah Norville aboard ``Today'' but her husband, ``Doonesbury'' cartoonist Garry Trudeau, wasn't so sure. ``His initial reaction to NBC's handling of the whole thing was `slash and burn,''' Pauley said in an interview in July's issue of Ladies' Home Journal. ``I remember him telling someone that most people in my position would have left tire tracks on Deborah's back.'' But not Jane. In fact she says she admires the way Norville has handled all the negative publicity. ``If it had been me getting all that criticism, I would not have been functioning professionally. I probably wouldn't have wanted to show my face.'' Pauley says she loves what she's doing now, substituting for Tom Brokaw and developing prime-time specials, but loves getting to spend time with her three children, twins Ross and Rachel, 6, and Thomas, 3, even more. ``If I stayed on the show,'' she said, ``I knew I would have less time with the twins because they were in school. I didn't feel they'd hold their mother personally accountable for not being there ... but I felt guilty because I didn't have the time and, increasingly, the energy to give to them.'' One of the first things she discovered when she stopped doing ``Today'' was that her kids never tuned in to see mommy on TV; ``They watch Gumby and Bugs Bunny.''

DOC.HEAD: Study Wants Schools to Compete for Students
DOC.TEXT: Each school should be able to structure its own program because student achievement is being stifled by ``heavy-handed politics and high-handed bureaucracy,'' said a study released Wednesday. John Chubb, a senior fellow at Brookings Institution, and Stanford University political scientist Terry Moe said in the study that states should provide the schools with tax-funded scholarships for every eligible student enrolled. Parents and students, they said, then would be free to select either public or private schools in any district. ``We found that America's current system of public education stifles student achievement because of heavy-handed politics and high-handed bureaucracy,'' Chubb said. School performance, he said, is unrelated to how much is spent on each student, teacher salaries, class size and graduation requirements _ ``the very things the government has worked for 30 years to change.'' However, California Schools Superintendent Bill Honig responded to the study by saying that improvements have been made in student achievement _ especially when educators use a comprehensive approach that includes strengthening the curriculum and teaching material, improving teacher salaries and training, and giving principals more control. Honig called the scholarship idea a voucher system that will isolate poor and minority children, and will cost more because parents now paying for private-school education will be subsidized by the government. Chubb and Moe spent 10 years studying American high schools, using surveys of more than 20,000 principals, teachers and students at about 500 high schools nationwide. It is considered the largest survey of its kind ever conducted. According to the study, ``Politics, Markets, and America's Schools,'' an average student at an effective school has a 52 percent chance of taking an academic program of study, while that same student has only half that chance at an ineffective schools. Effective schools, according to the study, have 20 percent to 50 percent less interference from superintendents and central offices in matters related to curriculum, instruction, hiring, firing and discipline. Acknowledging that their proposals are controversial, the authors included reports on successful experiments with public school choice in Minnesota, and in school districts in East Harlem, New York and Cambridge, Mass. Schools can improve only if given the freedom and incentives to organize more effectively, Chubb said. ``Let the people who are in the best position to know what is good for students _ parents, teachers and principals _ make the key decisions and let competition hold them accountable,'' he said. Under the Chubb-Moe plan, each school would be given sole authority to determine its own governing structure, and the state could not dictate a school's internal organization. Gary Watts of the National Education Association called the proposal impractical. ``The lawsuits alone could keep an army of lawyers busy for years'' tackling such questions as: ``Who owns school buildings, what if a private entrepreneur takes over a school or what if one school only wants a high quality football team'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Presbyterians Keep The Peace At Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Presbyterians aimed for unity by promoting harmony during their 202nd General Assembly, which ended Wednesday. Newly elected Moderator Price Henderson Gwynn III of Charlotte, N.C., set the tone for the meeting of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), saying the church can reverse its membership slide of the last quarter-century as long as members stop fighting each other. ``If we shoot ourselves in the foot because of internecine warfare or denominational myopia, we are going to have to answer for it,'' he said. The 2.9 million-member denomination has lost a third of its members since the mid-1960s. The more than 600 commissioners to the annual meeting overwhelmingly approved a new statement of faith, postponed action on altering church stands on abortion and homosexuality and agreed to explore further relations with the Mormon Church. In the land where Brigham Young established the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, the assembly approved the denomination's first statement of faith since a 1983 merger healed a Civil-War era split over slavery. The document, which mixes traditional Christian beliefs with environmental concerns and images of God as both father and mother, will be sent to the denomination's 177 presbyteries. If the confession is approved by two-thirds of the regional groups and by the 1991 General Assembly, it will become the 11th statement of faith in the denomination's Book of Confessions. While noting the discrimination faced by non-Mormons in Utah, the assembly also accepted a report calling for opening up an informal dialogue with the Mormon Church. Several resolutions relating to abortion and homosexuality were postponed until 1991, when a special Task Force on Human Sexuality is scheduled to make its report. The denomination supports legalized abortion, and opposes the ordination of homosexuals. ``They seem to be bending over backwards to be kind to one another and avoid controversial issues,'' Parker T. Williamson of The Presbyterian Layman said after the votes to defer action. But in a move criticized by several commissioners as avoiding dispute at the price of suppressing dissent, the assembly voted to take away semi-official church status from 21 Presbyterian organizations, including some of the denomination's staunchest liberal and conservative critics. The discussion was sparked by an uproar caused last summer when Presbyterians for Lesbian-Gay Concerns distributed sexually explicit pamphlets to high school and college youths at a church meeting. The assembly vote, which still must be approved by a majority of the regional presbyteries, would take away the right to be officially represented at church meeting from not only the homosexual caucus but other liberal groups such as The Witherspoon Society and conservative groups such as the Presbyterian Lay Committee and Presbyterians Pro-Life.

Former New York Giants wide receiver Phil McConkey fell short of the goal in his political debut, a Republican congressional primary that he lost to state Sen. Richard Zimmer. McConkey, who finished second in Tuesday's four-way race, played the conservative spoiler, helping to shove the expected frontrunner, state Assemblyman Rodney Felinghuysen, into third place. The football pro said he wasn't giving up on the political game. ``I'm here to stay,'' McConkey told supporters. The northwest New Jersey congressional seat is being abandoned by Rep. James Courter, the Republican who was drubbed in last November's governor's race. Zimmer will face Democrat Marguerite Chandler in November.

Alabama voters overwhelmingly ratified a constitutional amendment making English the state's ``official language.'' Similar measures have been passed in at least 17 other states, although an English-only measure in Arizona was overturned by a judge in Feburary. A critic of Alabama's law predicted Wednesday that it suffer the same fate, but supporters said they weren't worried about lawsuits. The measure was favored by nearly 90 percent of the voters. Tom Doron of Birmingham, director of the Alabama English Committee, said no other state has passed an English language measure by such a wide margin. The amendment states that the Legislature shall ``enforce this amendment by appropriate legislation,'' but does not spell out what might constitute a violation or what forms of English are acceptable. Doron said there are few non-English speakers in Alabama, anyway.

Mayor Lionel Wilson, damaged by his ill-fated effort to lure back the Raiders football team, lost his bid for a fourth term at the helm of this East Bay city. Assemblyman Elihu Harris and City Councilman Wilson Riles Jr. finished 1-2 in the balloting Tuesday, and will compete in a runoff in the November election. ``Everything has a beginning and an end,'' Wilson, 75, said early Wednesday, as he toasted his supporters with a glass of champagne. Harris, 42, received 32,830 votes, or 46 percent. Riles, 44, tallied 17,607 votes, or 25 percent. Wilson, a one-time Superior Court judge, finished with 12,232 votes, or 17 percent. Five other candidates split the remainder. Wilson acknowledged that the Raiders issue had hurt his chances for re-election, but said he still believed he acted correctly in supporting a controversial $602 million deal to bring the team back from Los Angeles.

This seaside community known for its army of celebrity residents is now a city. Malibu voters overwhelmingly agreed Tuesday to incorporate as an independent city. Previously, the town had been an unincorporated area of Los Angeles County. In final, unofficial returns, the cityhood measure had passed by 3,797 to 708. The chic neighborhood's 20,000 residents include such high-profile personalities as Johnny Carson, Michael Landon, Martin Sheen, Shirley MacLaine and Olivia Newton-John. For the most part, however, the rich and famous kept a low profile in the campaign.

Supporters hope City Hall will be reformed by a comprehensive measure approved by voters to reduce the influence of special interests by limiting outside income, gifts and honorariums that some elected officials can accept. A key provision provides public matching funds to politicians who restrict spending to specified levels. Its seeds were planted more than a year ago after questions were raised about income Mayor Tom Bradley received from two local banks. With all but two precincts counted, the measure had 204,573 votes, or more than 56 percent of the total cast.

Supporters of an advisory measure to fight AIDS by legalizing hypodermic needles promised Wednesday to immediately draft a letter to state legislators after voters approved the ballot item. San Francisco voters approved the ``Clean Needle'' measure by a 54-to-46 percent margin. It asks lawmakers to eliminate criminal and civil penalties on the manufacture, use, sale and distribution of needles. Although the measure was intended by supporters to fight the spread of AIDS, the proposition lacked the backing of major AIDS activists. Critics said it lacked the support of a comprehensive public health program.

Actor Ralph Waite, the wise patriarch on the television series ``The Waltons,'' passed his first test in a long-shot bid to unseat a veteran Republican congressman. Waite easily defeated Moreno Valley account manager Jeffrey Jacobs on Tuesday to win the Democratic nomination and the right to face Rep. Al McCandless. Waite wants to join the troupe of actors who have won state, federal or local offices in California, including Ronald Reagan, George Murphy, Clint Eastwood and Sonny Bono. In final, unofficial returns, Waite had 38,599 votes, or 71 percent, to Jacobs' 15,599 votes, or 29 percent.

Tim Stoen, a former legal adviser to Peoples Temple leader Jim Jones, was soundly defeated in his bid to win the Republican nomination to oppose incumbent Democratic Rep. Doug Bosco. With all the votes counted, Stoen, who left the church before Jones and more than 900 followers died in a Guyanese jungle encampment, got only 23 percent of the votes cast to 77 percent for Frank Riggs.

DOC.HEAD: Unification Fears Grip Small East German Businesses
DOC.TEXT: Groups representing thousands of small East German businesses said on Wednesday that the terms of German unification will force them to lay off 350,000 workers this summer. Klaus Noack, leader of an independent business association, said half of the nation's 500,000 small and medium-sized businesses may have to declare bankruptcy this year. Noack and two other groups, the Chamber of Commerce and the Entrepreneur's Association, said they would call a ``warning strike'' on the Baltic Sea island of Ruegen on Tuesday and a nationwide strike the next day unless Parliament acted on their demands. The main complaint is a key provision of an economic treaty under which East Germany and West Germany are to merge their economies on July 2, the principal stage of full unification. The treaty, which still must be ratified by both parliaments, calls for East Germany's essentially worthless currency to be replaced by the powerful West German mark. Workers will have their wages converted to West German marks at an equal 1-1 exchange. But business bank accounts will be converted at a 2-1 rate, in effect halving their cash reserves in relation to their employee payrolls. Noack said that will force perhaps half of the small and medium-sized businesses to file for bankruptcy and immediately eliminate 350,000 jobs. He claimed the treaty would eventually threaten almost 3 million of East Germany's 10 million workers. The business groups said at a news conference that they also need the property on which their businesses stand to be protected from Western investers. The German governments are still negotiating how to transfer the vast publicly owned property in the country to the private sector. Many East Germans fear that West Germans will buy up their property. Noack said the businesses need their property to use as collateral to obtain loans to keep operating and become competitive with Western firms already selling their products in East Germany. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere's Cabinet met on Wednesday and endorsed a plan to promote small businesses that includes extending credit to them, said spokesman Klaus-Peter Bigalke. But he said there were no details worked out. Analysts say that between 500,000 and 4 million East Germans will lose their jobs as outmoded, overstaffed factories and other businesses are forced to compete with Western businesses. East German Labor Minister Regine Hildebrandt said Wednesday that she expected 1 million to lose their jobs. Much of the unemployment is expected to hit the vast industrial sector, where the huge state-run factories, many of which are considered environmental hazards, are expected to lure little private investment or be able to compete with leaner Western industries. Both German governments are counting on Western investment to create new jobs in East Germany and alleviate the initial effects of the country's move to a free market.

DOC.HEAD: Roh Says Gorbachev Will `Melt Down the Ice' of Korean Cold War
DOC.TEXT: South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, reporting at the White House on groundbreaking talks with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, said Wednesday that the Soviet president had agreed to help ``melt down the ice'' from the Cold War on the troubled Korean peninsula. After briefing President Bush, Roh said his talks with Gorbachev ``definitely ... will help'' reduce tensions between North and South Korea and ``help greatly the process of reunification.'' Bush said Roh's meeting with Gorbachev was ``very appropriate'' and ``very important.'' If a peace settlement is reached with communist North Korea, Roh told reporters later, ``we can talk about further reductions or reallocation'' of the 40,000 American troops stationed in South Korea. Roh met with Gorbachev in San Francisco on Monday as the Soviet leader wrapped up a six-day visit in the United States. It was the first high-level encounter between the two nations since Korea was divided after World War II. The administration hopes that without the unswerving support of Moscow, North Korea will be inclined to seek friendlier ties with South Korea and the industrialized West. However, the White House said there was no warming in U.S. ties with North Korea along the lines of improved relations between Seoul and Moscow. ``We have always indicated a willingness to improve relations with North Korea but we have not seen any reciprocal response on their part,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. ``At this point, I can't report any movement.'' Roh, talking with reporters outside the White House, said he had sought Gorbachev's help in bringing North Korea closer to South Korea. The South Korean leader said they had agreed that ``we have to cooperate so that we can melt down the ice which still exists from the Cold War years.'' Asked about prospects for reunification, Roh said North Korea must first open up and embark on a reform process. He said Gorbachev ``agreed to combine efforts along that line.'' The South Korean leader's meeting with Gorbachev occurred just three weeks short of the 40th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean War, in which Moscow was the major arms supplier of North Korea while Washington played the same role for South Korea. The weapons deliveries by the two superpowers have continued unabated ever since. Relations between Moscow and Seoul hit a low point seven years ago when a Soviet warplane shot down a Korean commercial airliner that had strayed over Soviet territory. All 269 people aboard were killed.

DOC.BYLINE: Church Groups Hail Court's Equal Access Approval ^By GEORGE W. CORNELL
DOC.TEXT: A wide cross-section of American churches have praised the U.S. Supreme Court decision allowing high school religious clubs, saying it checks discrimination against religion. The reactions came from mainline and evangelical denominations, Protestants, Eastern Orthodox and Roman Catholics. However, Jewish groups demurred. ``Millions of American students are the real winners in this case,'' a coalition of Protestants said Tuesday. ``They now can claim the right of equal access for their religious, political and philosophical speech.'' The decision Monday upholds equal rights of students to form religion clubs if any kind of extracurricular clubs are allowed. Congress in 1984 called for such equal access but many schools circumvented it. Commenting on the court's decision, the Protestant organizations said it helps corrects ``an almost paranoid fear of faith'' shown by some schools, and added: ``Some school districts have gone so far as to single out student religious groups for discriminatory treatment by telling them that they alone cannot hold on-campus meetings before or after school.'' But the court decision makes clear that such a policy ``violates federal law'' and the decision also ``restores a proper balance'' between church-state separation and guarantees of free exercise of religion, the organizations said. They included the National Council of Churches, embracing mainline denominations, the National Association of Evangelicals, the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, and the Christian Legal Society. The U.S. Catholic Conference on Wednesday joined Protestants in hailing the decision, saying that it modified ``a trend toward exclusion of religion from the public schools.'' The American Jewish Congress called the decision ``regrettable.'' ``The decision will open up the nation's public high schools to proselytizing from organized student religion clubs,'' and create ``religious divisiveness,'' said AJC president Robert K. Lifton.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts Feinstein quote after 3rd graf, CORRECTS Helms' previous race to 1984 from 1964 in 16th pvs bgng ``Gantt will''
DOC.HEAD: Democrats Feinstein and Gantt Now Face Well-Heeled Republicans
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: Cash-strapped Democrats Dianne Feinstein and Harvey Gantt had little time Wednesday to savor primary victories as they plunged into campaigns against well-financed Republicans. The Democratic Party chairman conceded the money advantage but proclaimed ``issues are going to prevail'' in November. Sen. Pete Wilson, sitting on a $3.5 million campaign war chest after coasting to victory in the Republican primary for governor of California, welcomed Feinstein to the fray and warned that her election night celebration would be ``your last victory party of the 1990s.'' Feinstein, who quickly won a pledge of support from her defeated primary rival, said she was optimistic about the fall: ``We do have a united Democratic Party that's now able to appeal to the independents and the Republicans.'' North Carolina Democrats gave Gantt, the black former mayor of Charlotte, a strong sendoff into a Senate challenge to conservative Republican Jesse Helms. Regarded as the underdog in the Democratic primary runoff, Gantt picked up 57 percent of the vote to roll over prosecutor Mike Easley. ``You're talking about a newly awakened voter in North Carolina,'' said national Democratic Party Chairman Ronald H. Brown. ``You're talking about a candidate who has touched some chords there.'' While candidates who competed in primaries in nine states celebrated their victories or licked their wounds, much of the post-election attention centered not on a candidate but on voter approval of a California ballot initiative that will double the state gasoline tax over the next five years. Supporters as well as some opponents of the ballot proposition touted the vote as the end of the tax revolt that began in 1978 when California voters passed Proposition 13 that cut property taxes in half and put a lid on future increases. ``It really does end the tax revolt in California and sends a message to Washington which I dislike intensely,'' said anti-tax economist Arthur Laffer. Brown was more cautious. ``I'm not sure we ought to read too much into it,'' he said of the California tax vote. ``Folks are saying we want a cleaner environment and do something about gridlock on the freeways.'' But the Democratic chairman was celebrating the decisive defeat of two Republican-sponsored California ballot initiatives that would have stripped the state legislature of most of its power to redraw political boundaries to conform to the 1990 Census. The Democrats control both chambers of the California Legislature. Incumbents were uniformly successful on Tuesday, including seven senators, four governors, and all House members who sought renomination. The success stories included Rep. Jim Bates of California, who survived a Democratic primary challenge despite having been rebuked by the House Ethics Committee for sexual harassment of women employees. One race that remained to be decided was in Alabama, where teachers union official Paul Hubbert and attorney general Don Siegelman will clash in a June 26 runoff for the Democratic nomination to oppose Republican Gov. Guy Hunt. While Wilson was expected to raise and spend up to $20 million in an effort to keep the California governor's office in Republican control, Feinstein emerged from her bruising primary against Attorney General John Van de Kamp with an empty campaign treasury. The former San Francisco mayor spent about $6 million in the primary, including $3 million she and Richard Blum, her investment banker husband poured into the campaign. Gantt will be up against a conservative senator with one of the nation's most successful fund-raising networks. Helms spent $17 million on his 1984 re-election campaign. ``They are going to have a money advantage,'' said Brown of the Republicans. ``The issues are going to prevail,'' he added. At a rally in Raleigh, N.C., Gantt challenged Helms to join him in joint appearances at every courthouse in the state to campaign ``the old-fashioned way.'' ``I hope we don't get into those obscene amounts of money we saw in 1984,'' said the Democratic candidate. Gantt lost no time focusing on the issues he felt would work against Helms _ education, the environment and abortion. ``We have a senator in Washington who just hasn't been paying attention, who hasn't been paying attention to the problem of our young people's education in this state,'' Gantt said. Gantt drew a clear contrast to Helms' opposition to abortion. ``It's not the business of government to interfere with a woman's right to choose,'' he said, staking out a position parallel to that taken last year by fellow Democrat L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia when he became the first black elected governor of any state.

DOC.HEAD: Eisenhower Conference Examines Race Relations Then And Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Brown on second reference cq
DOC.TEXT: They don't look back with bitterness. But people who lived through pivotal civil rights battlefields of the 1950s reunited this week and said the nation still hasn't conquered racism. ``After 36 years, to me it's very disheartening to see that the struggle continues,'' said Linda Brown Buckner, who as a child had to walk across town, past white schools, to a attend one of Topeka's black schools. Her name went on the lawsuit that prompted the U.S. Supreme Court to rule in 1954 that segregated schools were unconstitutional. Brown appeared Tuesday on a panel that discussed the 1954 case. The event was part of a conference on President Eisenhower's role in the civil rights movement. Brown noted that the Brown vs. Topeka Board of Education lawsuit still isn't resolved. It was reopened 11 years ago, and federal courts have ruled that the board still hasn't removed a pattern of unequal schools. ``I think the vestiges of segregation are alive and well. All you have to do is look at Topeka to see that the east side is mainly black and the west side is mainly white,'' she said. Former Arkansas Gov. Orval Faubus, who in 1957 used the National Guard to block nine black children from a Little Rock high school, also appeared on a panel with four of those students. Eisenhower drew international attention to race relations in the South by sending the 101st Airborne Division into Little Rock so the nine could attend Central High. The conference was at Eisenhower's presidential library in this east-central Kansas town of Abilene, which he called home. Hugh Speer, a key plaintiff witness in the Brown case, criticized the current Topeka Board of Education for continuing to fight court orders to desegregate. ``The big question is whether Topeka has lived up to the 1954 decision when they still have three or four schools that are predominantly minority,'' Speer said. He said the board was spending more on appealing the reopened case to the U.S. Supreme Court than it would cost to simply comply with the integration orders. The high court has yet to decide whether to hear the reopened case. The Little Rock panelists, some of them meeting Faubus for the first time, agreed that racism was far from solved. ``We have to remove our own cases of apartheid,'' said Ernest Green. Faubus, 80, defended his action aimed at blocking implementation of the Brown case. ``It was my responsibility to maintain order as much as possible and see that no one was injured and there was no property damage,'' he said. ``We came out all right. We're all here.''

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Want to Join International Monetary Fund
DOC.TEXT: Switzerland wants to join the 152 countries in the International Monetary Fund, which plays a key role in the world's financial system, fund officials said Wednesday. Switzerland, concerned for its traditional neutrality, has been reluctant to join international organizations. In 1982, a government plan to join the fund was postponed after a Swiss voters defeated a proposal to join the United Nations. However, the Swiss government has had close informal relations with the fund. The fund's Board of Directors will consider the application, and a fund spokesman said formalities could be completed by the end of the year. All members of the fund also join its sister organization, the World Bank, the biggest source of loans to the Third World. Applications also are pending from Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria; China, Poland, Hungary and Romania already are members. The Soviet Union has said it would like to join, but the Bush administration has objected.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Violence Spreads in Soviet Central Asia
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic violence that has left at least 35 people dead in the republic of Kirghizia spread on Wednesday, with gangs of youths marauding on horseback and authorities reported helpless against rioters. Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the national legislature, told lawmakers on Wednesday that ``nearly 40'' people died in rioting in the Central Asian republic. The official Tass news agency put the death toll at 35, and about 300 have been reported injured in clashes between ethnic Uzbeks and Kirghiz. The unrest, triggered by a land dispute, was the latest in a series of ethnic outbreaks fueled by poverty or political conflict to trouble the government of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The violence in Kirghizia spread on Wednesday to the republic's capital, Frunze, when a rally turned into a riot, and protesters pelted with stones a Communist Party official who tried to speak to the crowd, Tass reported. ``There are cases of marauding, robbery and violence,'' it said. Several Uzbeks were beaten in the Frunze marketplace, and Uzbek students were evacuated from the city's university to a nearby military unit to prevent clashes. At the rally, ``speakers called upon the crowd to start pogroms of the Uzbek residents' homes and flats,'' city Communist Party official Ivan Pavlov said in a telephone interview. He said rioters ``jumped on a man who looked like an Uzbek and started beating him savagely.'' In the city of Osh, 75 miles east of Frunze, where the violence broke out Monday night between the two predominantly Moslem ethnic groups, ``The situation is complicated by numerous groups of Kirghiz youths on horseback converging on the city,'' the government newspaper Izvestia reported. ``Local organs of power, including the local party committee, have not managed to take control of the situation and are in a state of disarray,'' it said. Police fired on Kirghiz and Uzbeks trying to storm police stations on Tuesday in and around Osh, according to Tass. The city is in the densely populated western part of Kirghizia on the border with Uzbekistan. Soviet media, including the TV news program ``Vremya,'' Wednesday blamed the violence on widespread unemployment among youth in the region and general poverty. Housing is also critically short in Soviet Central Asia, and the land dispute centered on plots where individual houses could be built. Lukyanov, speaking Wednesday to the Supreme Soviet, said: ``The difficult process of regulating the conflict is going on.'' He asked deputies from the republics of Kirghizia and Uzbekistan to appeal for calm. He said 21 law officers were among the casualties, but did not give a breakdown of dead and injured. Ethnic Uzbeks from the Fergana Valley of Uzbekistan had arrived in the area to join their comrades in the fight, Lukyanov said, adding that the Soviet Defense Ministry dispatched reinforcements from the republic of Turkmenia to the Osh area. Clashes also were reported in the nearby town of Uzgen, where six deaths and 18 injuries occurred. Police in Frunze also were placed on alert. A duty officer of the Osh police said in a telephone interview that a majority of shops and factories reopened Wednesday after being shut down on Tuesday. He refused to give his name. Tass reported that helicopters hovered over Osh and armored personnel carriers rolled through the streets of the city of 210,000 people. A state of emergency and a 10 p.m.-to-6 a.m. curfew remained in effect in the region. Tass reported that police and Interior Ministry troops set up roadblocks and restricted entry to Osh. The Soviet army newspaper Red Star reported that the only enterprise that stayed open Tuesday in Osh was a large bakery. In Uzgen, 35 miles from Osh, deaths and injuries occurred when the district police headquarters was attacked, the newspaper said. Lukyanov said the dispute was triggered by the ownership of 80 acres of fallow land. But Baktiyor Hamidov, head of the economic department of Uzbekistan's mission in Moscow, said in an interview that there is much more land at issue. He said 618,000 acres of cotton fields near the border are being made available by the Uzbek government and local Kirghiz authorities are controlling it. ``They began dividing it between the families'' of mostly Kirghiz descent, he said, and the Uzbeks demanded it be divided evenly. Hamidov said the region was among the nation's most densely populated, with 500 to 1,125 people per square mile. He said disputes over land have their roots dating back to 1924, when traditional boundaries were blurred by Stalin.

DOC.HEAD: Man Burned Trying to Save Cats
DOC.TEXT: A man was burned on 40 percent of his body Wednesday while trying to rescue five cats from his burning apartment, authorities said. At least two of the cats died. Two were missing. Emergency officials identified the man as Eugene F. Hastings II, who suffered burns on his chest, back, arms and hands. Hastings was listed in serious condition at West Penn Hospital, the hospital said. His wife, Carolyn D. Councill, was treated for minor smoke inhalation, authorities said. The fire broke out near electrical equipment in the living room while the two were upstairs, Ms. Councill said. She said that once they fled, she realized the cats hadn't escaped and Hastings went inside to rescue them. Firefighters rescued a black-and-white cat named C.J. that was covered with soot.

DOC.HEAD: Red Tape Parts British Woman and Her WWII GI Sweetheart
DOC.TEXT: A British woman and her GI sweetheart, who married 45 years after meeting in war-time Britain, say they are being kept apart again by American red tape. ``If I could hire a dinghy boat, I would row the Atlantic to get back. That's how I feel,'' Millicent Ramsey said Wednesday. She said she's been stranded in London since Feb. 17, and has been unable to get a visa to return to her husband in Charlotte, N.C. She married George Ramsey on Sept. 14 and had applied for U.S. residency, then returned to England five months later for a family celebration. When her sister suffered a heart attack, she said in a telephone interview, she stayed past the date she was to return to the United States. On her last visit to the Immigration and Naturalization Service Office in London, she said, she was told they were waiting for a report from the FBI. The U.S. Embassy press office said it could not comment on the case because of the restrictions of the Privacy Act. ``It's the darnedest thing,'' Ramsey, 65, said in a telephone interview from Charlotte. ``The lady has never done anything wrong in her life. All my neighbors keep on asking where my wife is.'' Mrs. Ramsey, 61, said it was love at first sight when she saw the young GI on Christmas Eve, 1943 at the Red Lion public house in Hampton, 15 miles southwest of London. ``I thought, what a great guy, if only I could have met him. And I looked again and he was gone,'' she said. Two days later, she found him standing behind her in a bus queue. They made a date for New Year's Eve, she said, and the romance blossomed. On a Wednesday in March 1944, she said, she went with Ramsey while he asked his commanding officer for a leave so they could marry on a Friday. ``So Friday evening came, and no George,'' she said. Ramsey said his unit had been shipped to France. Later that year, she gave birth to their son. ``He did get back on a very short leave to see and hold his son,'' Mrs. Ramsey said, but her parents decided she was too young to marry _ she was in her teens _ and would not permit her to join him. The two lost touch and married other people in their own countries. Her marriage ended in divorce, while Ramsey is a widower. Three years ago, Mrs. Ramsey said, her son contacted his father in North Carolina, and a correspondence began. ``He wrote to me asking if I wanted to see him and we found out that we still loved each other,'' Mrs. Ramsey said. ``He went his way and I went mine, but we still both loved each other,'' said Ramsey. ``We married (the first time) on the rebound.'' Mrs. Ramsey said a U.S. immigration official told her it might take three or four more weeks to clear the paperwork. ``Why won't they let me back to my husband?'' she said. ``We're not getting any younger, and this time that we're losing is very valuable to us.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Votes To Allow Reassignment of AIDS Suffers From Food Handling
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Wednesday endorsed a change in a major civil rights bill to allow AIDS sufferers to be reassigned from food handling duties. The vote was a major election-year victory for Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and a setback for Majority Leader George Mitchell. Helms is seeking a fourth term. On a voice vote, the Senate approved a non-binding motion by Helms to have the Americans with Disabilities Act include an exemption that would allow employers to reassign infected workers from food-handling jobs. Helms' motion instructs Senate negotiators to accept a House-adopted exemption when they work out a final version of the bill later this month. Sen. Tom Harkin, the Iowa Democrat who sponsored the Senate measure, said the amendment would ``codify ignorance'' about the disease and how it is transmitted. The House approved the exemption 199-187 last month before it finally passed the entire disabilities act 403-20. The Senate passed the bill 76-8 last September. The amendment ``goes right at the heart and soul of the Americans with Disabilities Act,'' said Harkin. ``To pass legislation ... in spite of the clear and convincing, overwhelming medical evidence that HIV, that AIDS, cannot be transmitted either through air or through food, is simply to codify ignorance.'' But Helms, renewing the House debate, argued that scientific knowledge and public perception clash. He expressed doubts over the certainty of knowledge about how AIDS is transmitted and argued that the amendment was needed because of public ignorance. ``We've been told over and over again ... AIDS is supposedly not communicable by food or drink or casual contact,'' Helms said. ``Now that is the conventional wisdom. But you try telling that to John Q. Public.'' Because the Helms motion was approved on a voice vote, no individual Senator's vote was recorded. However, the Senate voted 53-40 to reject an earlier motion by Mitchell, a Maine Democrat, to table the Helms motion. The House version of the amendment would allow employers to reassign HIV-infected workers from food-handling jobs, provided other positions exist for which they are qualified. Opponents say that means infected people could be fired or demoted. The House adopted the amendment even though Health and Human Services Secretary Louis W. Sullivan said it was unnecessary. The White House has not, however, spoken out against the amendment although it specifically endorsed another, unrelated change. The House amendment was introduced by Rep. Jim Chapman, D-Texas. It was endorsed by the restaurant and food-service industry as well as by the National Federation of Independent Business, a chief critic of the entire disabilities bill. ``We're enormously disappointed at the Senate vote today and view it as a significant setback in the effort to protect people with AIDS from unnecessary discrimination,'' said Gregory L. King of the Human Rights Campaign Fund, a lobbying group for gay and lesbian rights. ``Ten years into the epidemic, one can only be shocked that so many senators are unwilling to recognize that AIDS is not spread through casual contact or through food.'' The disabilities act has been hailed as the most significant piece of civil rights legislation since the 1964 Civil Rights Act, which banned discrimination against racial minorities. It would protect the estimated 43 million disabled Americans from job discrimination. It also would guarantee them access to businesses, entertainment, accommodations and professional services, as well as to public and private transportation and telephone service.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. and Soviet Scientists Call for Deeper Cuts in Nuclear Arms
DOC.TEXT: The superpowers could cut their arsenals of long-range nuclear weapons by three times the amount planned in a nearly completed treaty without endangering security, U.S. and Soviet scientists said Wednesday. The groups said in a jointly published book that the United States and the Soviet Union could reduce the number of strategic nuclear warheads to fewer than 2,000 each without giving either side an incentive to launch a first strike. In the Strategic Arms Reduction Talks in Geneva, U.S. and Soviet negotiators are trying to complete a START treaty to reduce to 6,000 the number of warheads on weapons capable of reaching each other's territory. That would represent about a 30 percent cut from current levels. At last week's summit meeting in Washington, President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev reaffirmed their commitment to completing the START treaty and agreed to pursue negotiations on further reductions once the treaty is signed and ratified. The Federation of American Scientists and the Committee of Soviet Scientists for Global Security proposed a new way of structuring arms reduction treaties. It would be based on eliminating warheads, not just the vehicles such as bombers, ballistic missiles or missile launchers that carry the warheads to targets. The START treaty as drafted includes no prohibitions against removing warheads from long-range missiles and converting them for use on other weapons. Both the American and Soviet governments say dismantlement of warheads would give away vital secret information about the design of their weapons. The scientists also said that for warhead dismantlement to be effective, the superpowers should agree also to halt production of new fissionable materials, including plutonium and enriched uranium, used in warheads. There is growing congressional interest in pursuing a U.S.-Soviet agreement to halt nuclear materials production, but the Bush administration is opposed. The scientists noted that both Moscow and Washington already have been forced to reduce their nuclear materials production because of safety problems in manufacturing. Just this week, new evidence emerged to indicate that problems at a key U.S. weapons plant are more serious that previously believed. A panel of nuclear safety experts commissioned by the Energy Department to advise Energy Secretary James D. Watkins on weapons production facilities said Tuesday that plans for resuming plutonium processing at the Rocky Flats plant in Colorado should be further delayed to correct numerous training and pollution problems. Rocky Flats, the nation's only supplier of plutonium triggers for nuclear warheads, was closed indefinitely in November because of safety and management concerns. Watkins had indicated recently that he hoped to restart Rocky Flats this month and that its operation was vital to maintaining the nation's nuclear weapons stockpile. He had no immediate comment on the advisory panel's recommendation. In a related development, the author of a new report by the private Arms Control Association in Washington told reporters that Congress was likely to slash 1991 spending for the Star Wars anti-missile defense by more than 20 percent from 1990 levels. Matthew Bunn, an arms control specialist, said it was likely Congress would approve about $3 billion in spending for Star Wars, officially the Strategic Defense Initiative, for the budget year beginning Oct. 1. The current budget is $3.8 billion, and the Bush administration wants $4.8 billion for 1991.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Affiliates Told No Plans for Jane Pauley to Co-anchor ``Nightly News.''
DOC.TEXT: There are no plans for Jane Pauley to co-anchor the ``NBC Nightly News,'' but that could change, NBC affiliates were told Wednesday. NBC News president Michael Gartner told affiliate executives that in a closed-door meeting at the end of their annual convention here, according to network spokeswoman Betty Hudson. ``He specifically said, `We never say never, but there are no current plans''' for Pauley to join Brokaw on the show, Hudson told reporters in a briefing. NBC Television network president Pier Mapes emphasized that Pauley's first priority is a series of prime-time specials she will anchor. Pauley, who left NBC's troubled ``Today'' show in December after controversial changes there, ``is really hot for the prime-time show,'' he said. Pauley, who got a standing ovation Monday from the station executives, also will do special reports for ``Nightly'' and fill in for Brokaw when he is on assignment or vacation. Her prime-time project, Mapes said, is ``a full-time job in itself.'' The question about Pauley's future on ``Nightly'' was raised by an affiliate executive after published speculation she may co-anchor the newscast. At the briefing, former affiliate board chairman James Sefert and his successor, Eric Bremner, also disputed a report that the three-day convention had been NBC's gloomiest since 1985. It was upbeat, said Sefert, president of Cosmos Broadcasting in Greenville, S.C. But he and Bremner, president of King Broadcasting in Seattle, said there was far more work done, including a mass march by affiliates on Capitol Hill, than ever before. Affiliates are worried about cable's growing effect on stations, and federal financial interest and syndication rules on NBC, and are seeking ways to help themselves and their network, he said. Although NBC has finished first in prime time for five seasons, Mapes said, the network faces a $200 million shortfall in advertising revenues because of lower prime-time ratings and problems he blamed on the ``people-meter'' ratings ssytem. ``... Half the problem is the people-meter problem,'' he said. The networks blame people-meters, the industry's national ratings standard since 1987, for what they call an undercounting of viewers. Nielsen officials say network drops in viewing are real. At the closed-door meeting, NBC executives fielded questions on a variety of other subjects, including cablecasts of pro football games not available to NBC stations in certain markets. Remedying that ``may end up being an FCC matter,'' Mapes said, adding that NBC officials will take it up with the Federal Communications Commission. Although there had been speculation that Gartner would be the target of affiliate grumbles over the ``Today'' changes and the show's drop into second place in the ratings, there was no criticism at Wednesday's meeting, several station executives said. ``I was quite quiet today,'' joked Rhode Island executive David Henderson, who last year sharply criticzed Gartner for what Henderson considered NBC's poor coverage of the bloody crackdown on the student revolution in Beijing. ``I think everybody is supportive'' of Gartner, now that he has announced changes aimed at making both ``Today'' and ``NBC Nightly News'' ratings contenders again, Henderson said. ``It's true, most affiliates were disappointed at what happened'' to ``Today,'' said another station executive, John Williams of Paducah, Ky. ``But he defused the criticism,'' Williams said, referring to Gartner's frank admission to affiliates Monday that he made mistakes with ``Today'' and his show-mending moves, including the hiring of former ``Today'' host Joe Garagiola as a third co-host with Byrant Gumbel and Deborah Norville. The convention was NBC's first in Washington and underscored the affiliates' increasing attention to making themselves heard on legislative and regulatory issues affecting broadcasting.

DOC.HEAD: Kayaker Who Plunged Over Falls Still Missing
With AM-Falls Stunt-List
DOC.TEXT: A kayaking enthusiast appeared to wave his paddle triumphantly before plunging over Niagara Falls. And that was the last anyone has seen of him. Jessie Sharp of Ocoee, Tenn., plunged over the 182-foot Horseshoe Falls on the Canadian side of the border Tuesday afternoon, as tourists and police _ unable to help him _ looked on. He was wearing neither a helmet nor a lifejacket. His paddle emerged from the mist at the base of the falls about 10 minutes after his plunge. The dented red kayak, inscribed ``Rapidman,'' surfaced about an hour later a few hundred yards downstream. A day after the stunt, Sharp's body had yet to surface. ``It could be down there for weeks,'' said Niagara Parks Police Constable Maureen Quinn. The river below the falls is too dangerous for divers to try to search for the body, Quinn said. Sharp, 28, was the 13th known daredevil to challenge the falls since 1901 and the fourth to lose his life. All previous attempts on record have involved barrels or inflated rubber containers. Had Sharp survived his trip, he would have been subject to a $10,000 (Canadian) fine for attempting an illegal stunt, Quinn said. Police interviewed three friends who accompanied Sharp from Tennessee, but decided not to charge them, Quinn said. ``They didn't assist him in any criminal way,'' she said. Jeff Latham, a parks police constable who watched Sharp's plunge, said the kayaker held his paddle aloft and twirled it in the air just before going over the brink. Latham said the gesture reminded him of a football player spiking the ball in the end zone, but kayakers said they generally lean back and raise the paddle above their head just before a fall as a protective measure. Ocoee, a small town 35 miles from Chattanooga in southeast Tennessee, is on the Ocoee River, a nationally famous whitewater stream. The U.S. Slalom Team Trials were held there in early May. Jim Snyder, an Albright, W.Va., author, predicted in a 1987 book that kayak technology and skill levels would evolve to the point that making it over Niagara Falls would be possible. That time is yet to arrive, he said Tuesday night. ``You need a very specific plan to do a falls over 80 feet,'' he said. ``You should be in a boat specially designed to support your back, and you have to have a perfect launch. Anything less than that spells disaster.'' A kayaker trying to navigate a tall waterfall also must paddle hard just before the brink so he shoots out away from the falling water to land in the foam below, Snyder said. ``If you fall with the water, you've failed,'' he said. ``If he and his boat were not visible during the fall, he was doomed from the beginning.''

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Urges U.S. to Press Release of Kidnapped Moslems
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS graf after 5th graf `But it' to UPDATE with U.S. comment. Pickup 6th graf pvs, `At Tehran's...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Middle East, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Hashemi Rafsanjani urged the United States Wednesday to press Israel and Kuwait to release Moslem prisoners in exchange for help in gaining freedom for the 16 Western captives in Lebanon. Rafsanjani also indicated Iran might soon begin direct peace talks with Iraq to formally end the Persian Gulf war. ``The irresponsible, arrogant attitude of the United States has created further difficulties'' in resolving the hostage crisis, Rafsanjani told a news conference for 200 foreign and local journalists. Iran and the pro-Iranian groups holding the hostages in Lebanon have often demanded the United States press Israel to free 350 Moslems it holds in Israel and in a strip of land it controls in southern Lebanon. But it was the first time in some months that an Iranian leader referred to 15 Shiite Moslems, most of Iranian origin, jailed in Kuwait since 1984 for car bombings in Kuwait directed against the U.S. and French embassies. In Washington, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said he had not seen Rafsanjani's remarks but that U.S. policy is to urge the ``immediate, safe and unconditional release of all hostages.'' At Tehran's bidding, two American educators, Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, were released in April. Iran has said Washington should make a goodwill gesture in return. President Bush has said he won't deal with Iran to secure further hostage releases. ``An appropriate response was expected after the Lebanese unconditionally set free the hostages _ release of hostages in Kuwait and Israel,'' Rafsanjani said. ``Why don't you help increase the necessary public pressure on those governments to release these hostages, so that the Western hostages can be freed in return?'' he asked the journalists. ``If the United States is serious about wanting relations with Iran in the future, it must begin to act, because talking is not enough,'' Rafsanjani said. Polhill and Reed were the first U.S. captives to be released in 3{ years. Six Americans are among the Westerners still held in Lebanon. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for the Associated Press. He was abducted in March 1985. The other hostages are four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Italian and an Irishman. Referring to Iran's death threats against British author Salman Rushdie, Rafsanjani said ties with London could be resumed if Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher condemns Rushdie's book ``The Satanic Verses.'' Ties between the nations were severed following the 1989 call for Moslems to execute Rushdie. Rafsanjani said, however, that there was no question of lifting the death sentence on Rushdie, who Iran says defamed Islam in his book. Rafsanjani said Iran's policy was ``to help secure the release of all the hostages, whether they be Western, Lebanese or Iranian. We continued ... to hold on to this policy.'' The Iranian president reiterated his country's claim that four Iranians _ two diplomats, a journalist and a driver _ who were kidnapped by the Christian Lebanese Forces militia in 1982 are still alive. ``We have learned officially from a government, and from reliable sources in east Beirut, that the Iranian hostages are alive,'' Rafsanjani said. ``The special envoy of a certain government has informed us.'' He did not identify the country. The Bush administration recently provided Iran with information, through the Swiss government, which Washington said indicated the four men were dead. Speaking about the gulf war, Rafsanjani said President Saddam Hussein of Iraq recently sent two letters to the Iranian leadership suggesting the two leaders meet for talks on a permanent settlement to the conflict, which ended in a cease-fire in August 1988. ``We have not given a negative reply to Iraq's proposal calling for a meeting of the two heads of state,'' Rafsanjani said. ``But issues must be sorted out in preliminary negotiations at expert level and in consultations with the United Nations secretary-general to guarantee the success of such a meeting, if there is going to be one.'' Hostilities between Iran and Iraq were halted under U.N. Security Council Resolution, but talks to turn the truce into a peace settlement have been stalemated ever since.

DOC.HEAD: `Joy of Living' Drove Alzheimer's Victim to Suicide Machine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmits a0680 to include bjt designation in slugline
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PD2
DOC.TEXT: Janet Elaine Adkins spent 13 years teaching hundreds of immigrants and refugees to become self-sufficient and independent _ the very qualities she knew were being stolen from her by Alzheimer's disease. Unwilling to relinquish her self-determination, the 54-year-old Portland woman instead chose to give up her life. On Monday, hooked to an intravenous device in a van at a campground near Detroit, she pressed a button that released a lethal drug into her veins and died within minutes. She told Dr. Jack Kevorkian, the retired pathologist who invented the device and was with her: ``You just make my case known.'' ``I have decided for the following reason to take my own life,'' Mrs. Adkins wrote in a short statement made public by her husband. ``This is a decision taken in a normal state of mind and is fully considered. I have Alzheimer's disease and do not want to let it progress any farther.'' People who knew Mrs. Adkins, even briefly, remarked on her enthusiasm and zest for life. She was a strong, decisive woman, family members said. ``She has a real joie de vivre, a real spirit for life,'' said her son Neil. Mrs. Adkins, a native of Longview, Wash., was the mother of three grown sons, Neil, Norman and Ronald, and had three grandsons. She was diagnosed as having Alzheimer's almost a year ago. ``She was an exciting person. She loved philosophy. She loved reading good literature. She was a good musician, loved playing the piano. And really, she loved life and to the fullest,'' said Ron Adkins, her husband of 34 years. ``She was always coming up with ideas of new places to go. ``She was an adventurer. She climbed Mount Hood. She went to the Himalayas and to Nepal and she went up in gliders and in a hot air balloon. And we did travel, we lived in Europe. She spoke French. She taught at the community college ... which she dearly loved. This was a woman that was a very, very special woman.'' As a teacher of English as a second language at Portland Community College, Mrs. Adkins helped Southeast Asian refugees and others gain the skills to survive in America, department chairman Joe Ponce said. She graduated in 1972 from Portland State University, where she majored in English and minored in French. She received her teaching certificate in 1979 and joined the English as a second language program in 1980, he said. In addition to her duties at the college, she had taught workers at Tektronix Inc. in Beaverton and did summer work at Wilson High School. She resigned in June 1989 because she wanted to pursue other personal interests, he said. ``She was a very fine teacher. Anyone who works with the refugee or immigrant programs has to have a lot of personal skills and has to care a lot,'' Ponce said. ``She was enthusiastic, she had a good sense of humor. She certainly enjoyed her work. I think that's a marked sign of a successful teacher, someone who finds the job enjoyable continuously _ certainly for that many years.'' Neil Adkins said his mother also had been an accomplished musician on the piano and had played French horn in college. In recent years, however, she had stopped playing the piano and had trouble reading. Alzheimer's disease is an irreversible degeneration of the brain cells leading to severe memory loss, dementia and death. ``The bomb, as we called it, was dropped on us in June of last year, and it was really very devastating to Janet,'' Ron Adkins said. ``She was very much aware of Alzheimer's and what happens.'' He said his wife knew exactly what she was doing this week and insisted upon it. ``Right up to the very end when she left me and we said our last goodbye, she was holding me up,'' said Adkins. ``And she was very up and very happy with the doctor that she was able to have this way of delivering herself.'' Mrs. Adkins had asked that she be cremated after death, with her ashes to be flown home and dispersed in the Pacific off the craggy Oregon coast. A memorial service was scheduled Sunday. Mrs. Adkins was a member of the National Hemlock Society, which advocates death with dignity, before her illness was diagnosed. ``She felt it was unfair that other people could tell you when to die,'' her husband said. ``She was a wonderful wife and great inspiration to family and friends ... But she didn't want to end up losing her dignity.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Greece Renew Old Friendship
LaserPhoto WX14
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs `Fitzwater said...' to ADD open quote marks
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Greek Premier Constantine Mitsotakis marked ``a new beginning of an old friendship'' Wednesday, with Greece's conservative new leader appealing for U.S. help to prod Turkey to end the stalemate over Cyprus. Bush, in turn, renewed a U.S. request for extradition of a Palestinian wanted in the 1982 bombing of a Pan Am jet over Hawaii that killed a Japanese teen-ager. Mitsotakis, the first Greek leader invited to the White House in 26 years, said the meeting ``inaugurates a new period of relations between the two countries.'' In the two months since Mitsotakis' New Democracy Party turned socialist Andreas Papandreou's government out of power, the United States and Greece have already initialed a new military base agreement that had eluded the two NATO allies. ``The two presidents agreed that this visit was important for a new beginning of an old friendship,'' said White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. Mitsotakis told reporters that he asked Bush to use his influence to help settle the dispute over Cyprus, which has been partitioned between Greek and Turkish Cypriots who have feuded over the island for generations. ``I told him that presently we are at a dead end and some gesture ... should be made from the Turkish side,'' Mitsotakis said. Mitsotakis told The Washington Post in an interview published Wednesday that he would urge Bush to prod the Turkish government to cut in half its forces that have occupied the island since 1974. Turkey has 30,000 troops in the northern half of the island. The Greek leader said efforts by the United Nations needed a boost, ``and I believe that the United States can play a very important role in the matter.'' Bush, he said, seemed very interested. Fitzwater said Bush made it clear ``that the status quo on the island was not satisfactory.'' Bush, according to Fitzwater, said action must be taken but ``reiterated that our view of the best course of doing that is within the U.N.'' Fitzwater said the two leaders ``agreed to combat terrorism wherever they can and however they can.'' Mitsotakis' son-in-law, Pavlos Bakoyannis, was assassinated on an Athens street by a terrorist group in September. Bakoyannis' widow, Dora, who subsequently won her slain husband's seat in parliament, joined her father in the White House talks. The Greek leader also Bush that the U.S. extradition request for Mohammed Rashid would be decided before September.
