Rashid is wanted in connection with the jet bombing that killed a Japanese teen-ager and wounded 15 other people. U.S.-Greco relations were often strained during Papandreou's eight-year tenure. The base agreement initialed by the two governments will allow the U.S. military presence in Greece to continue, but two of the four U.S. bases in Greece _ Helleniko Air Force Base near Athens and a naval communications station _ will be closed. Mitsotakis's New Democracy Party has 150 seats in the 300-member Parliament. A conservative deputy from a small party has given it a voting majority. As a NATO ally, Greece is slated to receive $345 million in military aid during the next fiscal year. No terms of the new agreement have been made public. Mitsotakis said Bush had accepted an invitation to visit Greece, and invited Mitsotakis back to Washington for an official visit. No dates were set. Mitsotakis met later with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, then was to attend Thursday's graduation of his son, Kyriakos, from Harvard.

DOC.HEAD: Regulators Say Tighter Standards Not To Blame For Tighter Credit
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators assured members of Congress Wednesday that a government crackdown on bank lending is not the cause of a credit squeeze in some regions Behind closed doors, however, bankers are pleading with the regulators to ease up. Senior federal banking officials, appearing before the House Small Business Committee, conceded that some banks are making it more difficult for businesses to get loans, particularly for commercial real estate projects. But they said that is mostly a justified response to a sluggish economy rather than a reaction to intensified scrutiny from government examiners. Meanwhile, chief executives of some of the nation's largest banks have asked the Federal Reserve Board to bend capital standards while they work off losses from sour real estate loans. The request came from the Fed's 12-member Advisory Council at a private May 3 meeting in Washington. The central bank keeps the minutes of the council's sessions secret for three years, but a copy from last month's meeting was obtained by The Associated Press. The council suggested that regulators should permit banks to deduct real estate loan losses from their earnings over a period of years rather than all at once. They also asked for relaxed capital rules to permit banks to hold on to repossessed real estate rather than selling it in a depressed market. Such accounting measures, while maintaining the appearance of balanced books, have been blamed for contributing to the savings and loan crisis. The council's request to the Fed for lenience was originally disclosed in Wednesday editions of USA Today. Regulators told the small business panel, chaired by Rep. John J. LaFalce, D-N.Y., that they have cautioned their examiners not to be overzealous in scrutinizing loans. But, for the most part, they stood firm in the face of strong congressional criticism that credit-worthy constituents were having trouble getting loans. ``A slowdown in certain markets seems entirely warranted given current economic conditions,'' said Federal Reserve Board member John P. LaWare. ``In my view, banks should be applauded for tightening lending standards,'' said Paul G. Fritts, supervision director for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. He said regulators' critics are confusing a normal credit contraction during a time of economic downturn with a credit crunch in which legitimate projects cannot attract financing. He said bankers often use regulators as an excuse for a decision that angers a customer. However, Rep. Richard E. Neal, D-Mass., whose state has been among the hardest hit by a slump in real estate, said, ``Regardless of what's been stated today, a perception has been created that a curtain has been dropped over some of the entrepreneurship that we've witnessed in New England over the last decade.'' Del. Walter Fauntroy, D-D.C., complained about scarcity of business loans in the nation's capital. ``Some banks throttled their lending down so sharply that some members of the (House) Banking Committee began to fear a full-fledged credit crunch,'' he said. ``I am here to urge the regulators to moderate their approach.''

DOC.HEAD: Feinstein Nomination is Milestone for California
LaserPhotos LA10, FX5
DOC.TEXT: More women candidates than ever will be on California's general election ballot in November, when Dianne Feinstein will ask voters to make her the state's first woman governor. Besides Feinstein, four of five women who were seeking nominations to statewide office won their party primaries Tuesday, and voters ensured that one general election race will be between two women. No more than two women have ever been on a California general election ballot before. Feinstein, the former mayor of San Francisco, made a special plea to women throughout her Democratic primary campaign to help her ``make history'' as California's first woman governor. U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson, the Republican nominee, immediately moved to defuse that appeal Wednesday. ``I think that women, as well as men, are going to be much more influenced by the quality of candidates, by their performance, by their ideas, than by their sex,'' Wilson said. After a costly, bruising primary campaign, Feinstein defeated state Attorney General John Van de Kamp by a 52-to-41 percent margin. In final, unofficial returns, Feinstein had 1,296,589 votes to Van de Kamp's 1,012,516. Wilson received 88 percent of the Republican vote against only token opposition. An exit poll by the Los Angeles Times reported that Feinstein won nearly two-thirds of the women's vote, and narrowly edged Van de Kamp among male voters. Asked Wednesday what her nomination proved, Feinstein said, ``No mountain is too high and no door is so closed it can't be opened.'' Other women who won Tuesday included: _State Sen. Marian Bergeson, who won the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor. _Kathleen Brown, daughter of former Gov. Pat Brown and sister of former Gov. Jerry Brown, who captured the Democratic nomination for state treasurer. _Democrat March Fong Eu and Republican Joan Milke Flores, who won their parties' nominations for secretary of state. Eu is the incumbent, and one of only two women to ever win a statewide office in California's 140-year history. Eu's victory marked a first of a different kind, since her son, Matthew Fong, won the Republican nomination for state controller. Never before have a mother and son run for state office at the same time in California. The only woman seeking a statewide office who didn't make it to the November ballot was former U.S. Treasurer Angela ``Bay'' Buchanan, sister of conservative political commentator Pat Buchanan. She lost the Republican nomination for state treasurer to incumbent Tom Hayes by 8 percentage points. Oakland Mayor Lionel Wilson, who was heavily criticized in his failed attempt to bring the Los Angeles Raiders football team back to Oakland, was soundly defeated in his bid for a fifth term. The primary balloting also marked _ both in symbolism and substance _ a reversal of political priorities from the anti-tax philosophy that dominated the 1980s as Californians voted to double their state gasoline taxes from 9 to 18 cents per gallon. The gasoline tax increase, approved by a 53 percent majority, is expected to raise $15.5 billion over the next decade for new highway and mass transit projects to ease the state's growing traffic congestion. In some of California's 45 congressional races: _Democratic incumbent Jim Bates was nominated for a fifth term, despite the negative publicity of a formal rebuke by the House Ethics Committee for sexual harassment of women employees. _Actor Ralph Waite, ``Papa Walton'' of the television series, won the Democratic nomination for a seat now held by Republican Al Mc Candless in the Palm Springs area. _Tim Stoen, attorney for the People's Temple before the cult's mass suicide with 912 deaths over a decade ago, lost the Republican nomination to oppose Democratic incumbent Doug Bosco in California's north coast redwood country.

DOC.HEAD: Woman's Trained Rats Hit the Nightclub Circuit
DOC.TEXT: Spiders, snakes, prairie dogs and about 40 rats roam Samantha Martin's apartment. And she wouldn't have it any other way. They're her pets, but they're also her livelihood. The professional animal trainer has hit the Chicago nightclub circuit with The Rat Company and Friends _ a menagerie of rodents, reptiles, chinchillas, one tarantula and a South American animal she describes as ``a honey bear, a raccoon and a monkey all rolled into one.'' ``People see the ad in the paper and they say, `No, this can't be,''' she said. ``But they come and see, and some of them come up after the show and want to pet them.'' The show has become a local cult hit, with some fans turning up at performance after performance. The rodent revue changes with the season _ the rats wear angel wings during the Christmas season and ride brooms during Halloween. John Herron of Evanston hired the show last year for a holiday party. ``The guests went into hysterics. It was fantastic,'' he said. ``The animals are comedians. Our cat, though, was pacing the house, because there were all these rats here and she didn't know what to do.'' Chicago animal control officials said they know about the offbeat performers, but haven't had any problems with them. Housing her rodent-dominated troupe at her apartment could be a problem, but she said she's been lucky so far _ her landlords never come over to visit. ``I mean, if they ask if I've got any pets, and I say, `Well, I've got about 40 rats and a tarantula,' I'd be homeless forever,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: No Andrew Dice Clay Rerun, NBC Says
DOC.TEXT: Raunch comic Andrew Dice Clay's ``Saturday Night Live'' performance won't be rerun by NBC, the network's entertainment chief said Wednesday. Brandon Tartikoff's promise came at a closed-door session of affiliate executives on the closing day of the network's convention here, NBC spokesmen said. His announcement came after what several affiliates at the meeting described as sharp criticism of the Clay show by Cliff Brown, a Hattiesburg, Miss., broadcaster. Tartikoff told the affiliates that Clay was a last-minute booking for the show broadcast last month after a previous guest host dropped out. He didn't identify the dropout. ``We didn't think it would create the controversy it did,'' Tartikoff said of Clay's booking, according to NBC spokesman Curt Block. ``It's too bad that show tarnished what was an otherwise good year'' for the program, Block quoted the NBC Entertainment president as saying. The appearance by Clay, whose routine is filled with sexually explicit language and disparages gays and women, prompted boycotts of the program by cast member Nora Dunn and guest singer Sinead O'Connor. The show drew more than 1,000 protests from viewers.

DOC.HEAD: Writer-Producer of PBS Series Dies
DOC.TEXT: James W. Jackson Jr., writer-producer for the old PBS series ``Lowell Thomas Remembers,'' has died of injuries sustained in a car crash. He was 66. He was killed in an automobile accident Tuesday when his car skidded out of control and struck a tree near Winnsboro, where he lived. Fairfield County Coroner Joe Silvia said Jackson's Porsche was traveling about 120 mph when it crashed. At the time of his death, Jackson was working on a television series about former South Carolina Gov. Robert E. McNair. In the mid-1970s, he was instrumental in helping the University of South Carolina get 20th Century Fox's Movietonews library valued at $60 million to $100 million. The library has footage from the old newsreels shown in movie theaters from 1919 to 1963. Jackson was director of college's news film library from 1980, when the newsreels were obtained, until he retired in 1988. Jackson produced and wrote for the acclaimed ``Lowell Thomas Remembers'' during the 1970s. He was a sports editor for The Columbia Record and an announcer and promotion manager for WIS-TV in Columbia. During World War II, Jackson was a pilot in the Army and worked as an education officer in the Korean War. Jackson is survived by his wife, Jackie; a daughter, Lynne, of Columbia; and two sons, James of Conroe, Texas, and Thomas of Morgantown, W.Va.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela To Meet Bush On June 25
DOC.TEXT: South African black leader Nelson Mandela will meet with President Bush on June 25 to discuss steps to abolish apartheid, it was announced Wednesday. The meeting at the White House will be a part of a tour that will include speeches before a joint session of Congress and the United Nations General Assembly. Bush invited Mandela to the White House after he was freed in February after 27 years in South African jails. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, will make a cross-country trip of the United States, beginning with a New York ticker-tape parade and ending with a rally at the Oakland, Calif., Coliseum.

DOC.HEAD: After 10 Years, Team Reaches B-17 Buried in Greenland Icecap
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: After a decade of trying to reach planes buried in Arctic ice since World War II, a thermal borer Wednesday banged against the skin of a B-17. The bomber is one of eight planes _ two B-17s and six twin-engine, P-38 Lightning fighters _ that crash-landed on the Greenland icecap; they ran out of fuel en route to Europe after being decoyed by false radio transmissions from German submarines in 1942. Pat Epps, who with Richard Taylor co-founded the Greenland Expedition Society, heard by radio from Greenland on Wednesday morning that the group had succeeded in reaching the plane. ``They're going to try to enlarge the hole to get into a hatch,'' said Epps, owner of an air service in suburban Atlanta. Taylor planned to descend 250 feet to the plane through a 42-inch shaft, Epps said. ``We plan to get the fighters out this year. We will work until September 1,'' said Epps, who returned from the icecap last week. The team left Atlanta on May 3 for Greenland. A second unit, led by Angelo Pizzagalli of Burlington, Vt., left a week later. While Taylor and the first group got to the first bomber, Pizzagalli, president of Pizzagalli Construction Co., and his men used a huge auger to bore a hole 16 feet in diameter to one of the P-38s, a plane the Germans called a ``fork-tailed devil.'' They fell behind schedule because of bad weather, including two blizzards after they landed on the ice in southeastern Greenland. The eight planes crash-landed July 15, 1942. Their crews camped in one of the B-17s for nine days until a sled dog team, which mushed into a spot fixed by radio triangulation, arrived to lead them to the coast. A month later, officials learned the Norden bombsight on one of the bombers had not been destroyed, so Army Air Force Col. Norman Vaughan went in alone by dogsled to get it before it could fall into the hands of the Germans, who had weather stations in the area. Vaughan, a vice president of the Greenland Expedition Society, is among the crew of a dozen men working on the icecap. The planes were forgotten until the early 1970s, when Col. Carl Rudder, one of the P-38 pilots, mentioned them to Roy Degan, a commercial airline pilot who brought the idea of an Arctic expedition to Epps. Epps and Taylor founded the Greenland Expedition Society in 1981. Vaughan, of Trapper Creek, Alaska, learned about the group from a newspaper story and joined up. The society eventually obtained search and salvage rights from the government of Denmark, which owns Greenland. In 1988, the society found the aircraft using low-frequency subsurface radar. Last year, expedition members drilled down to the B-17 and brought back poker chip-size pieces of its skin. Epps declined to say how much money the society has raised or spent on its efforts, but he estimated it will have spent $800,000 to $1 million by Sept. 1. It is financed by its own fund-raising efforts and the work of Rolls Ltd., Pizzagalli's non-profit corporation in Vermont.

DOC.HEAD: Petty Thieves Vandalize Lincoln's Tomb
DOC.TEXT: Petty thieves vandalized Abraham Lincoln's Tomb, creating a permanent eyesore while stealing $100 in small change. The vandals rolled a pair of 200-pound urns from atop the tomb onto granite steps leading to an observation deck, chipping the steps. And they broke into a vault where the 16th president's body was kept temporarily after his death, where they stole coins left by tourists. They didn't enter the 116-year-old chamber where Lincoln is entombed. ``The urns can be replaced, but the steps will always be broken,'' said monument manager Nan Wynn, estimating damage at $1,600. The thieves apparently used bolt cutters to get into the empty burial vault where Lincoln's body was kept until the tomb was built. There they stole coins worth an estimated $100 that tourists tossed into the vault through an iron gate, Ms. Wynn said. The damage and theft were discovered Tuesday morning by a maintenance worker. ``They obviously did it for the money,'' Ms. Wynn said. ``It's not something that's going to be a danger to anyone. It's just an eyesore.'' In 1987, five teen-age vandals spray-painted graffiti and racial slogans on the tomb, and knocked over or broke about 30 nearby tombstones.

DOC.HEAD: Workers Talk About Strikes, Ask for Ban on Replacement Workers
DOC.TEXT: A flight attendant, a paper mill worker and a tool and die employee, all stung by long labor disputes, asked a Senate panel Wednesday to approve a bill that would ban the hiring of permanent replacement workers. The three witnesses described how they had suffered because companies favored replacement workers or strikers who crossed picket lines. ``I will suffer the effects of filing bankruptcy for many years because it will be difficult to obtain credit and impossible to obtain a mortgage,'' said Norma Adams of New York, a Trans World Airlines flight attendant. She said she was on strike for two months but had to wait nearly a year before resuming her work. ``We only have to look at history to realize that greed and power are destructive,'' said Thomas J. Pratt of Livermore Falls, Maine, a former International Paper Co. employee. ``Let's balance the power between corporations and its employees and hopefully they can reconcile differences without the use of strikes or lockouts,'' he said. Ms. Adams, Pratt and Carol Miller of Woodstock, Ill., said their employers deliberately sought to anger unions during contract talks so they could hire replacement workers at a lower cost. Appearing before a Senate labor subcommittee, the three witofficials who will study the food processing systems of the two countries and determine how U.S. technology and methods can be incorporated into the Soviet system. A high proportion of Soviet food production has been reported to spoil because of inefficient distribution, handling and storage before it reaches the consumer. Nikitin said the agreement was a small step, ``but everything starts with a small step.'' ``For you, it's a key if you want to participate in the strengthening of our economy,'' he said through an interpreter. The pact was signed on the last day of a three-day conference sponsored by the Food Processing Machinery & Supplies Association and the National Food Processors Association. Fifty-five Soviet officials met with representatives of more than 50 food companies, administration and congressional officials seeking deals that could lead to increased business for Americans and modernization of food distribution for the Soviet Union. John Cady, president of the food processors association, said barriers are beginning to come down, though Americans still are concerned about getting paid for business with the Soviets. Soviet currency is of almost no value in the world market, leaving those companies doing business in the Soviet Union to either accept products in exchange or wait for long-term gains after the economy there improves. ``We have to understand when companies invest, it's not going to be a three-year turn-around, but probably eight to 10 years,'' said Cady.

DOC.HEAD: American Diet and Lifestyle Creates Cancer Risk, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Chinese immigrants who adopt the typical American diet and lifestyle are four to seven times more likely to develop colorectal cancer than those people who remain in China, a researcher said Wednesday. A lack of exercise and lots of rich American foods containing saturated fats make the difference, said Alice S. Whittemore of Stanford University. ``If you want to avoid the disease, I would by all means stay active,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``Even more importantly, take it easy on rich high fat dairy products and very fatty red meat. Eating fish and chicken is certainly prudent.'' The study, published this week in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, is based on interviews with Chinese in the People's Republic of China and with Chinese-Americans who immigrated to the United States or whose parents immigrated. About 90 percent of the Chinese-Americans interviewed came to the United States as young adults. Of those chosen for interviews, 473 Americans and 432 Chinese had either colon or rectal cancer. The researchers also interviewed 1,192 Chinese-Americans and 1,295 people in China who were free of disease but who lived near those with the cancers. The interviews probed diet, exercise and other habits of all the subjects. For the Chinese-Americans, Ms. Whittemore said, the interviewers explored every aspect of westernization, including such things as use of herbal medicines, languages spoken at home and even which newspapers were read. All those factors were correlated with the incidence of colon and rectal cancer. ``The strongest risk factor we found was saturated fat in the diet and the American sedentary lifestyle,'' Ms. Whittemore said. Chinese-American men, who had four to seven times more colon or rectal cancer than men of the same age in the People's Republic of China, got less exercise and were more likely to eat high quantities of food rich in animal or dairy fat. The colorectal cancer rates among the Chinese-American men are about the same as among white American men, Ms. Whittemore said. The cancer rates among Chinese-American women, however, was lower than among the Chinese-American men, but higher than among the Chinese women. ``We were puzzled by this at first, but what we found out is that the Chinese-American men have been here 10 years longer (than the women) on the average,'' Ms. Whittemore said. ``They migrated earlier and didn't bring their wives over until they had money to support them. The women haven't been here long enough.'' That finding, she said, showed that the duration of exposure to the American diet and lifestyle are important in the risk of colorectal cancer _ the longer the Chinese lived in the United States, the greater their risk of the disease. Ms. Whittemore said there were other impressive differences besides saturated fat in diets of the two countries. The Chinese tend to eat more calories every day, ``but they burn up far more calories.'' ``The calories (the Chinese) consume are mostly carbohydrates, mostly from rice,'' she said. ``The average guy over there does not eat like we do in a Chinese restaurant here. They have a hard time getting meat, so their diet is largely carbohydrates.'' Ms. Whittemore said the Chinese also eat more vegetables than Americans and that, to some degree, seemed to help block the formation of the cancers. ``Vegetables appeared to be protective,'' she said. ``The more vegetables you eat, the lower your risks.''

DOC.HEAD: California Spending Spree Could Mark End of Tax Revolt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf, `I believe ..., to UPDATE with Skinner remark, comparision with other states; pick up 9th graf, `Voters also ...
DOC.TEXT: California voters, who launched a tax revolt that spread across the nation a decade ago, may have given up their tightfisted ways. In a new shift of the political winds, they voted to double their gasoline tax and raise billions of dollars for mass transit, schools and the poor. ``It really does end the tax revolt in California, and sends a message to Washington which I dislike intensely,'' conservative economist Arthur Laffer said Wednesday, the day after the statewide spending spree. In the late 1970s, Laffer helped win voter approval of the twin foundations of the California tax revolt _ Proposition 13, a 1978 property tax-slashing measure, and a follow-up government spending lid that passed the next year. Proposition 111, which passed by a 52-to-48 percent margin Tuesday, will double the state's gasoline tax, from 9 cents to 18 cents, over five years. The tax will raise $15.5 billion for a 10-year freeway building and improvement program intended to slow the slide toward automotive gridlock. But it also eases the spending limit initiatives that formed the cornerstone of the tax revolt movement, reversing political priorities from the anti-tax philosophy that dominated the last decade. The measure was championed by Gov. George Deukmejian and a heavyweight business-labor coalition. It was extremely popular in freeway-laced cities but soundly rejected in the most rural regions. Supporters said the economy, environment, and quality of life were at stake in the vote. Last October's earthquake, which toppled a freeway in Oakland, also played a role. ``I believe it clearly says if you come with a good reason to spend the money, voters will approve and sanction what you've done,'' Assembly Speaker Willie Brown said. U.S. Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner said he was ``delighted'' with the vote. He said it validates the Bush adminstration's argument that voters are willing to raise taxes for highways and other transportation needs. California's gas tax currently ranks 47th in the nation, well below the national average of 15.8 cents a gallon. If other states' taxes were to stay the same, California would rank 23rd in the nation after Proposition 111 goes into full effect, according to Oliver Yandle of the Highway Users Federation in Washington. Voters also passed two bond measures, one a companion to Proposition 111 and the other sponsored by environmentalists, that together provide nearly $3 billion for mass-transit rail construction throughout the state. The ballot carried five other bond measures _ the most bond funding for a single election in California history. Voters approved them all. They include $150 million to house the homeless and four others to provide $2 billion to build new prisons, make state and local government buildings safer andupgrade public schools and universities. Altogether, Californians approved 15 of the 17 propositions on the statewide ballot, rejecting only two Republican-sponsored initiatives to take reapportionment of congressional and legislative districts out of the hands of the Democrat-controlled Legislature. Other successful ballot propositions impose strict new ethical standards on the Legislature and attempt to streamline criminal trial procedures and reduce potential appeals. Environmentalists scored a victory with passage of a mountain lion protection initiative. In local elections, San Francisco voters approved a record $332 million bond issue to help pay for repairs from last October's earthquake. Voters in two San Francisco Bay area counties _ Alameda and Marin _ voted down measures to create or strengthen ``nuclear free zones.'' But the multimillion-dollar standout among the propositions was the gas-tax hike that California Chamber of Commerce President Kirk West, who helped steer the campaign, called ``a referendum on California's future.'' The measure, expected to raise each motorist's costs an average of 16 cents a day, will supply the majority of funding for the largest single transportation investment in California history. Its companion measure, Proposition 108, will raise $1 billion through the sale of bonds to pay for a variety of mass-transit rail projects, including intercity Amtrak service, commuter lines and light rail systems, such as those that exist in Sacramento, San Diego and San Francisco. Proposition 116, supported by environmentalists, will raise an extra $1.99 billion by selling bonds to finance 29 mass-transit projects. Virtually all will be rail improvements, including about $280 million in work affecting Southern Pacific, which donated $150,000 to the campaign to pass the measure. Because road and rail construction has not kept pace with population increases, California drivers now waste more than 400,000 hours a day because the average speed on urban freeways has fallen to about 20 mph during commute hours.

DOC.HEAD: Offerings to Volcano Goddess Fails to Save Store
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd and ADDS two grafs with quotes from Yamaguchi
DOC.TEXT: Offerings to the Hawaiian volcano goddess failed to save the Kalapana Store and Drive-Inn, which succumbed Wednesday to lava flowing from Kilauea Volcano. Owner Walter Yamaguchi, 82, had defiantly proclaimed his store would remain untouched by the lava because of his special relationship with the volcano goddess Pele. But before dawn, a lava finger extending from the flow engulfed the last remaining landmark in this devastated rural seaside town, Civil Defense officials said. ``Well, what can you do?'' Yamaguchi said. ``Pele, she made me collect the insurance. If no burn, I don't collect.'' The store was the 161st structure destroyed by lava since Kilauea began its latest series of eruptions in January 1983. About 20 buildings remain. Yamaguchi said he had been making traditional offerings of gin and ti leaves to Pele every day in hopes of appeasing her. Two flows that snaked through the area last month passed within 5 feet of his store, adding to Yamaguchi's reputation as a volcano prophet. In 1977, he correctly predicted that a flow would stop before it reached his store, once the main public gathering in Kalapana. No other structures in the now-deserted community were hit Wednesday as lava continued to pour from the Kupaianaha vent at a rate of 650,000 cubic meters a day, officials said. Lava flowed into the ocean near the site of the Puna Canoe Club. There was little movement in other areas of the flow. The destruction of the store allows Yamaguchi to travel to California with a clear conscience later this month for dental work. ``Now my worries are over,'' he said. ``I made plans to go the Mainland. My false teeth are no good.''

DOC.HEAD: Finland Tries to Check Mysterious Cloud, But It Stays over USSR
DOC.TEXT: Finnish authorities sent a jet plane to check on possible danger from a mysterious cloud drifting west from the Soviet Union on Wednesday, but the large cloud changed course and stayed over Soviet territory. Weather analysts and radiation monitors in several Nordic countries described the cloud as about 60 miles long and 9,900 to 16,500 feet above ground. They said the cloud, warmer than the surrounding air, was emitting steam or smoke. ``It could have been caused by some sort of disaster or accident. But it could also be just an ordinary large cloud,'' said Markku Konttinen of the Finnish Meteorological Institute. Late Wednesday, the Finnish Center for Radiation and Nuclear Safety in Helsinki said in a telephone recorded message, ``It is apparent that the air samples already taken won't reveal the composition of the cloud. ... The origins of the cloud are not necessarily unusual. ``Increased monitoring will be continued as a safety precaution for the time being. But nothing unusual has been recorded at radiation monitoring point,'' the center said. Earlier, the center said safety checks ``to determine whether the cloud is radioactive have been put into force.'' Weatherman Jouko Korhonen said the cloud ``has all the appearance of a normal, large cloud and its direction is southeasterly at the moment.'' That would keep the cloud over the Soviet Union. ``We won't find out about the upper layers of the cloud ... now that it is moving away,'' Korhonen said. But he said air samples could still yield some information. ``If there really was something irregular there, then the lower layers of air, which are still heading in the direction of northern Finland, are more important,'' Korhonen said. Officials in Rovaniemi, a military aviation center on the Arctic Circle in Lapland, said a Finnish Air Force jet took samples from Finnish airspace. The samples were being sent to Helsinki for analysis. The officials said the plane did not encounter the cloud. Earlier, weather observers cited satellite photos as showing the cloud was headed from the Barents Sea toward northern Finland. The Barents Sea is north and east of the Kola Peninsula in northwestern Soviet Union. The Finnish Center for Radiation and Nuclear Safety quoted Soviet sources this week as reporting four nuclear power plants are operating on the peninsula. The report was provided under an information agreement made after the Soviet nuclear accident at Chernobyl. The April 26, 1986, explosion at the No. 4 reactor of the nuclear plant in the Soviet Ukraine was the world's worst atomic accident. Two workers died of burns they suffered in the explosion, 28 died shortly after the accident from radiation exposure, and one died of a heart attack while fighting the fire. The accident touched off angry protests from the Soviets' Western neighbors, because the first report came from Swedish officials after high levels of radiation discovered there. Norwegian Northern Defense Command spokesman Geir Anda said authorities have nothing to indicate the cloud ``is radioactive. From the information I have, it must have come from an area at sea, possibly north of Noveya Zemlya island.'' The island is north of the Soviet Arctic port of Murmansk. Torbjorn Norendal of the Norwegian Foreign Ministry said, ``We contacted the Soviets about this through our embassy in Moscow this afternoon, to ask what was going on. The Soviets say nothing strange has happened in their territory.'' In the Soviet Union, Olga Belikova of the Northwest Agency quoted Murmansk civil defense official Nikolai Sklyar as saying radiation levels in Murmansk were normal and that no accidents had been reported at nuclear sites in the region. The Northwest Agency is an independent organization based in Leningrad. Interfax, the Soviet news agency affiliated with state-run Radio Moscow, recently reported that millions of dead starfish and mollusks had washed ashore from the Barents Sea. The agency quoted a Soviet laboratory as saying radiation was not the cause.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Eating for Two, 1st Ld Writethru, a0645,930
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs to include comments from nutritional supplement industry; picks up 6th graf ``Weight gain.'' ^Experts Say Pregnant Women Can Gain Weight Safely, Don`t Need Vitamins
Eds: For Release After 6p.m. EDT. Time set by source.
DOC.TEXT: Pregnant women who eat balanced diets don't need extra vitamins and can safely gain more weight than previously believed, according to guidelines released Wednesday by the Institute of Medicine. The guidelines, based on a review of studies on nutrition, weight gain and pregnancy, said the average woman who gains 25 to 35 pounds during pregnancy is more apt to produce a healthy, normal-weight baby. The study said also that, with few exceptions, vitamins and other food supplements are of no value in pregnancy. In effect, said Lindsay Allen, a professor of nutrition at the University of Connecticut, the study committee concluded that Mother Nature may know best. ``Women, when they are not told to restrict their diet during pregnancy, normally gain this amount of weight (25 to 35 pounds),'' said Ms. Allen, who was a chairman of a study subcommittee. ``What we are doing is recognizing that dietary restriction in pregnancy is not a good idea. Normal weight gain is better.'' ``Evidence that the committee reviewed is the reported experience of large groups of women,'' said Dr. Roy M. Pitkin, a UCLA obstetrician who chaired the study committee. ``In a sense, this brings health recommendations in line with what is actually happening.'' Officials in the nutritional supplement industry were uick to dispute the committee findings that said vitamin pills were of no value in pregnancy. ``This outrageously anti-health report potentially dooms thousands of children to an early death or at best substantial disability due to serious birth defects,'' J.B. Cordaro, president of the Council for Responsible Nutrition, a vitamin industry organization, said in a statement. ``This report is a recipe for risk and the people who prepared the report must be held accountable for any potential harm which may come from following their advice.'' Cordaro cited studies that showed some nutrients, such as folic acid, may reduce the risk of spina bifida and other neural tube birth defects. Ms. Allen said, however, that the committee found earlier studies to be inconclusive. Furthermore, she said, the amount of nutrient sufficient to affect birth defect rates would be consumed in a normal, balanced diet. Weight gain in pregnancy has been a major issue in medicine since the 19th century, when physicians believed overeating led to large babies and difficult labors. In recent years, most doctors have followed guidelines established in 1970 by the National Research Council that advised women to gain no more than 25 pounds during pregnancy. But Ms. Allen, who gained just over 30 pounds during her own recent pregnancy, said members of her committee studied new statistical data that shows ``women can gain more weight and have babies who are bigger and healthier at birth. They used this new supporting evidence to say that weight gain should be higher than recommended previously.'' The report said weight gain during pregnancy should be evaluated on an individual basis, considering the woman's height and body type. Tall, underweight women, the study said, should gain between 28 and 40 pounds during pregnancy, while obese women should gain only about 15 pounds. Ms. Allen said this follows a weight gain pattern that women seen to follow naturally. How fast pregnant women gain weight is important. The committee said a gain of one pound a week is best during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy for the average woman, while overweight women should gain at half that rate. ``A smooth, steady weight gain usually is an indication of an increase in lean and fat,'' a committee statement said. ``Sudden or erratic gain may indicate fluid retention, a possible signal of toxemia or other problems.'' For normal women eating balanced diets, Ms. Allen said vitamin pills and other food supplements are not needed and could even be hazardous. ``We find it irresponsible to suggest that supplements are needed when we can't find any evidence that women taking healthy balanced diets will gain any benefit from them whatsoever,'' she said. ``We've done a very thorough search of the literature and the data are just not there to make a case that all women need the supplementation of nutrients.'' An exception is for iron pills. ``Supplements of 30 milligrams of ferrous iron are recommended daily during the second and third trimesters'' for the general population of pregnant women, the study said. But Ms. Allen said that even iron supplements should be used with caution since dosages above 30 milligrams interfere with the absorption of other essential nutrients. And Pitkin said that iron pills during the first trimester of pregnancy can aggravate nausea. Ms. Allen said an excess intake of some other nutrients, such as vitamin A, could adversely affect fetal development. As with weight gain, the use of supplements should be evaluated on a case-by-case basis, the committee said. Ms. Allen said added nutrients may be appropriate for women who do not eat a balanced diet, or who are carrying more than one baby, or for women at higher risk because of tobacco, alcohol or drug abuse. Ironically, the study was released a short time after Ms. Allen and her husband became parents. ``I gained 31 pounds _ well within the guidelines,'' she said. The study was organized by the National Research Council for the Institute of Medicine. Both are organizations affiliated with the National Academy of Sciences, a private organization chartered by Congress to advise on scientific issues.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Want U.S. To Help Bankroll Economic Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: A top Soviet trade official made it clear Wednesday that once the U.S.-Soviet trade agreement wins final approval in Congress his country will be looking for U.S. loans to help the troubled Soviet economy. Yuri N. Chumakov, deputy minister of foreign economic relations, said West European countries and Canada already were offering such loans and loan guarantees to make sales in the Soviet Union. The government of President Mikhail Gorbachev would expect the same from the United States, he said. ``The United States is our greatest food supplier. We have been paying with cash,'' Chumakov told a gathering of U.S. businessmen. ``We have the right to expect in this hard period to receive certain credits in order to withstand the pressure.'' Chumakov's remarks referred to the turmoil facing the Soviet economy, which is plagued by food shortages, sagging production and inflation as it attempts to move from a centrally planned system to one based on free markets. The United States currently is blocked from extending loan relief to the Soviets by the same law which keeps tariffs at high levels on Soviet exports to this country. The 1974 Jackson-Vanik provision says the Soviets cannot qualify for the most favorable tariffs or for U.S. government loans until a trade agreement is completed and the president certifies that the Soviet Union allows free emigration. Bush has said he will send the trade agreement to Congress along with a presidential request for favored trade status once the Soviet legislature passes an emigration measure, now expected this fall. Under the Jackson-Vanik provision, if Congress agrees with the president's recommendations, it would clear the way for millions of dollars in credit from U.S. agencies which promote export sales by American farmers and corporations. The agencies involved include the Export-Import Bank, which deals with sales of U.S. industrial products, and the Commodity Credit Corporation, which promotes U.S. farm sales. Chumakov's appearance before of a group of U.S. corporate officials interested in doing business in the Soviet Union was part of an orchestrated effort on the part of the Soviets to attract Western investment and technology. Chumakov was the leader of the Soviet team which negotiated the new trade agreement. Asked if he thought it was realistic to be seeking additional loans from the West at a time when the Soviets are falling behind in repaying loans they have already received, Chumakov replied, ``One seeks credit not when he is well-off, but when he is on hard times.'' Chumakov predicted Gorbachev's perestroika program for reforming the Soviet economy would succeed although he conceded ``we have already had a few mistakes (in implementation). These are inevitable.'' Chumakov said there was no ulterior motive in the decision by the Supreme Soviet to put off until the fall consideration of a law liberalizing emigration policies, saying it had fallen victim to time constraints caused by the need to consider emergency economic legislation. The delay was seen by the Bush administration as a plus, giving Gorbachev more time to craft a compromise on the question of Lithuanian independence, an issue that threatens congressional approval of the trade pact. Chumakov called the trade agreement a critical first step to ending nearly 50 years of commercial cold war between the two nations. He said it would lead to expanded opportunities in a number of areas, including space, telecommunications and aviation. He suggested that American companies should consider a Soviet offer to launch U.S. commercial satellites on Soviet rockets. ``We have a lot of rockets free now from military applications,'' he said. ``Why should we throw them away and lose money on them.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Ready for Runoff; Call For `New South' Leadership
DOC.TEXT: The two survivors of a four-way Democratic primary opened their runoff campaigns Wednesday, each accusing the other of being too stodgy for the New South. Teachers' lobbyist Paul Hubbert and Attorney General Don Siegelman will compete June 26 in a runoff to determine who will challenge Republican Gov. Guy Hunt in the fall. Hunt, Alabama's first Republican governor this century, won GOP renomination Tuesday in a landslide. Also winning renomination easily was Democratic U.S. Sen. Howell Heflin, who faces Republican nominee Bill Cabaniss in November. The Democratic primary for governor was a four-way fight until Hubbert and Siegelman pulled away. Former Gov. Fob James finished third and declined to endorse either of the top two candidates. U.S. Rep. Ronnie Flippo ran fourth and also intends to stay neutral, his campaign treasurer said. Hubbert, 54, the executive director of the Alabama Education Association, said he was the only progressive candidate in the race and questioned Siegelman's ability to push through a promised state lottery bill. Siegelman, 44, depicted Hubbert as a ``special interest lobbyist'' who has not worked for the state's best interests. ``The issue in this campaign is not whether Alabama should move into the New South. Of course it should,'' said Siegelman. ``The issue is who is best able to lead our state into the New South.'' Virtually complete but unofficial returns showed Hubbert with 229,589 votes, or 32 percent, Siegelman with 179,658, or 25 percent, James with 158,766, or 22 percent, and Flippo with 124,344, or 17 percent. Two other candidates split the rest.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Would Halt Foreign Sales of Pesticides Disallowed in U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee endorsed legislation Wednesday to prohibit chemical companies from selling pesticides abroad that are considered too dangerous to be used here. ``Because the Food and Drug Administration waives through virtually all imported food without inspection, these chemicals often end up on America's dinner tables,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., the committee chairman. About 25 percent of the fruits and vegetables consumed in the United States come from abroad. Leahy and other Democrats on the panel said the bill was designed not only to protect consumers from health hazards associated with certain agricultural chemicals but to protect the American farmer from unfair foreign competition. ``Foreign farmers are able to use made-in-the-USA chemicals that our farmers cannot,'' said Leahy. ``We effectively penalize U.S. farmers and growers for using safe pesticides and obeying the law.'' But Republicans on the committee said the bill penalizes American chemical manufacturers by stopping them from making a product that foreign competitors can make and sell. ``If we phase companies out, it would take other companies very little time to gear up,'' said Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo. The bill, which passed on a voice vote, will be inserted in the Senate version of the 1990 farm bill. The bill would also disallow imports of foods treated with pesticides outlawed in the United States. Sen. Richard Lugar, of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the panel, said he did not believe the legislation belonged in the farm bill and would argue his case on the floor. Congress passes a farm bill every five years to regulate agriculture policy. Both the House and Senate agriculture committees have more work to do on their bills before the full bodies can begin debate.

DOC.HEAD: Report: De Klerk to Lift State of Emergency on Thursday
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk is likely to lift the 4-year-old state of emergency on Thursday, according to a report by the independent South African Press Association. The news agency, in a report Wednesday that did not cite sources, said de Klerk was expected to announce his plans when he addresses Parliament in Cape Town on Thursday afternoon. If de Klerk ends the emergency, it would remove a major obstacle to black-white negotiations on a new constitution. De Klerk says he wants the document to allow the country's 28 million blacks to share power with the 5 million whites. Presidential spokesman Kobie Pieterse said the report by the South African Press Association was ``purely speculation.'' He confirmed de Klerk was to make a previously unannounced speech to Parliament, but declined to divulge the contents. The African National Congress and other leading anti-apartheid groups have said the repeal of the emergency is a precondition for full-scale negotiations. The emergency laws, which include some of the harshest measures ever imposed by South Africa's white rulers, must be renewed by midnight Friday if they are to remain in effect. De Klerk met Wednesday with his Cabinet, and they were expected to make a final decision on whether to lift or extend the emergency. Pieterse declined to discuss details of the Cabinet talks. De Klerk has eased some of the emergency rules, but among those remaining in effect are that police can detain people without charge indefinitely. Police also can still declare an ``unrest area'' and order all people, including journalists, to leave. They can conduct searches and seize materials without a warrant, and they cannot be prosecuted for their actions under the emergency if they act ``in good faith.'' De Klerk has said he wants to lift the emergency but will not do so until authorities are confident they can control violence that claimed more than 500 black lives in the first three months of this year. Leading newspapers and political analysts have been virtually unanimous in predicting the relaxation or lifting of emergency rules. ``I only hope that the government will see the necessity of lifting the state of emergency,'' ANC leader Nelson Mandela said last week before departing on a six-week tour of Europe, North America and Africa. ``It has been absolutely ineffective.'' The wideranging emergency rules initially banned most forms of peaceful protest and made it illegal to call for boycotts or foreign sanctions, to seek to undermine the security forces or to report on police actions or unrest without permission. More than 30,000 activists, almost all of them black, have been detained without trial for varying lengths of time during the emergency. Others went into hiding. Dozens of opposition groups were banned and several anti-apartheid newspapers were shut down temporarily. Police repeatedly raided black trade union offices and broke up political meetings and demonstrations in black townships and on university campuses. De Klerk has nullified some of the restrictions as part of a series of reforms implemented since he assumed power last August. He also has released scores of detainees and long-term political prisoners. About 300 activists currently are in jail under the emergency regulations, according to the Human Rights Commission, a private group. An estimated 6,000 blacks have died in the past four years, most of them in black-on-black violence in the southeastern province of Natal. But scores have been killed in clashes with police, including more than 30 deaths in recent months. Existing security laws permit detention without trial, allow the government to place people under tight restrictions, such as house arrest, and provide authority to ban peaceful meetings and demonstrations. De Klerk's predecessor, P.W. Botha, declared the nationwide emergency June 12, 1986, in a bid to quell mounting black unrest. The action unleashed a storm of protest both inside South Africa and abroad. The South African currency fell sharply. Foreign investors grew nervous and many subsequently withdrew. Also, efforts to impose economic sanctions against South Africa gained momentum.

DOC.HEAD: White House Denies Aide Tried to Sabotage Democratic Convention
DOC.TEXT: Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday that White House aide Ron Kaufman attended the state Democratic convention in Massachusetts as a commentator, not as a political saboteur. Massachusetts Democrats have accused Kaufman of orchestrating a police picket that created a four-hour delay in the start of the convention on Saturday in Springfield, Mass. Kaufman denied involvement with the picket. ``Kaufman says it's not true,'' Fitzwater said. ``That's about all we know about it. He was serving as a commentator to some media outlets in the Boston area.'' Fitzwater said President Bush was aware of the controversy and that Kaufman had been questioned about the events. No further White House inquiry was planned, he said. Republicans in Massachusetts are hoping to capitalize on a slumping economy, proposed tax increases and a state budget crisis to capture the governor's office for the first time since 1970. Democratic Gov. Michael Dukakis is not seeking re-election. It was Kaufman who arranged for Bush to cruise polluted Boston Harbor as a way of attacking Dukakis' environmental record during the 1988 presidential campaign. Kaufman also arranged for Bush to come to Boston and accept the endorsement of the Boston Police Patrolmen's Association. The Springfield police union, which conducted the picketing last Saturday, also endorsed Bush. The state Democratic Party has filed a civil suit against the Springfield police union, and party officials said they planned to amend the suit to include Kaufman. The Democrats claim the protest outside the Springfield Civic Center violated the delegates' rights to gather for a political assembly. Kaufman did not immediately return a phone call to his office for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Electrocution Problem Solved By Conn., Fla. Firms, CPSC Says
DOC.TEXT: Two major manufacturers of hair dryers have eliminated the danger of electrocution when their products fall into water, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday. The new hair dryers solve a problem which has plagued the industry since the early 1980s when an estimated 17 electrocutions annually were caused by hand-held hair dryers falling into tubs and other water, the commission said. Approximately 10 of these deaths were to children under 10 years of age, the agency said. ``The problem with this product in particular is that it is used in the bathroom'' near water, said commission spokesman Dan Rumelt. ``You've got people that are drying their hair that have just come out of the shower who've got wet feet, hands and hair,'' said Dick Bruno, vice president of marketing for Windmere Corp. of Miami, the nation's largest hair dryer manufacturer. ``We wanted to take a position of providing the technology that was available,'' he added. Windmere's new Guardian ESP hair dryers and curling iron and brush incorporate the new safety feature. The ``Classics Protection Plus'' hair dryer made by Conair Corp. of Stamford, Conn. also includes the new safety feature. The new dryers have rectangular-shaped plugs with a reset button at the end of the cords. A device called an appliance leakage current interrupter is built into the plug. This detects any change in the electric current in the dryer within a fraction of a second and shuts the appliance off. ``Consumers should look for hair dryers with this feature together with the certification mark of a recognized testing laboratory,'' said Commission Chairwoman Jacqueline Jones-Smith. ``We want to encourage companies to build safety into their products,'' added Jones-Smith. The new products offer protection against electrocution whether their switches are in the ``on'' or ``off'' position. Hair dryers manufactured since Oct. 1, 1987 need only protect against electrocution if they fall into water with the switch in the ``off'' position. The new dryers meet a new voluntary safety standard that becomes effective Jan. 1, 1991. Between 16 million and 20 million hair dryers are sold in the United States annually, according to Bruno. David Schmeltzer, the head of the commission's compliance division, estimated there are still some 80 million hair dryers in the hands of consumers that pose a danger of electrocution because they don't meet the 1987 standard. Despite the product improvements, the commission additionally warned consumers that ``electricity and water are a potentially deadly combination, and in their presence children should always be supervised.''

DOC.HEAD: Columbia to be Returned to Hangar, Delaying Astro Mission
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf ``We think ...' to CORRECT `good' to `cold'
DOC.TEXT: Columbia will have to be returned to a hangar to repair a fuel leak, indefinitely delaying the launch of the shuttle and its $1.5 million Astro observatory, NASA said Wednesday. The announcement came after a hydrogen leak reappeared during a test. ``Unfortunately, we don't like what we found,'' launch director Bob Sieck said. ``It's good news, bad news. It's good that we found it, and it's unfortunate that it's going to be an impact to fix it.'' Wednesday's test, in which liquid hydrogen was pumped into Columbia, confirmed the leak in a tight cavity between two metal plates that connect the orbiter and external tank, Sieck said. ``In order to fix anything in this area, we're going to have to de-mate the orbiter from the tank'' in the hangar, he said. ``We do know the leak is temperature-dependent, which is going to make it difficult to pin down once we do get access to this area.'' Sieck declined to estimate when Columbia might be able to lift off. Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration have said it will take about a month to return the shuttle to the hangar and perform repairs. Columbia's move will take place sometime next week, he said. Preparations for Atlantis' secret military flight in July would continue as planned, he added. Shuttles have been moved from the launch pad back to the hangar twice because of mechanical failures and another time because of payload problems. About 6 percent of Columbia's external tank was filled for Wednesday's test with liquid hydrogen chilled to minus 420 degrees. As the fuel flowed through the orbiter into the external fuel tank, sensors detected buildups of hydrogen in the aft engine compartment and between the two metal plates. The exact location and nature of the leak were not immediately known, Sieck said. Further checks were planned at the launch pad. ``We think what we're going to find in this when we finally nail this down is it's going to be something in the hardware that reacted to the cryogenic (extremely cold) conditions,'' he said. ``It's going to be a unique thing ... it's going to be one of these new things that pop up in a complex system.'' The suspected area from the start has been a 17-inch-diameter valve in a pipe that runs through both plates. Tests with helium at room temperature last week were unsuccessful. The external tank was drained following the 2{-hour test. Last week's launch attempt was scrubbed when the leak was discovered as Columbia was being loaded with more than a half-million gallons of combustible liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. The mission already was two weeks late because of cooling system repairs. The Astro mission is one of six remaining shuttle flights scheduled for 1990. It appears likely one of the missions will be pushed into next year as a result of Columbia's problems.

DOC.HEAD: Avenson Claims Democratic Nomination for Governor
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Terry Branstad and his newly annoited Democratic challenger, Don Avenson, opened their general election contest Wednesday with a preview of what could become a nasty fight over abortion. Branstad immediately dismissed Avenson's campaign _ supported strongly by abortion rights advocates _ as a ``typical special-interest'' effort similar to ones run by Democrats he has beaten in the past. And Avenson, the speaker of the Iowa House, joined his vanquished Democratic rivals in vowing to oust Branstad. ``The winds of change are blowing in Iowa and Terry Branstad better start watching the want ads,'' Avenson said. ``It's our turn.'' Avenson's win was solid, if not lopsided, in a record turnout of about 200,000 voters. His primary campaign had a solid core of backing from unions, teachers and feminists. ``You have nominated yourself a tiger, a tiger for the ordinary people,'' Avenson told cheering supporters as he claimed victory. Avenson built an 7 percent edge over Attorney General Tom Miller, but former banker John Chrystal also fared well, cutting into Avenson's pro-choice support. With all of the state's 2,567 precincts reporting, Avenson had 78,783 votes, or 39 percent, to 63,154, or 32 percent, for Attorney General Tom Miller and 52,039, or 26 percent, for former banker John Chrystal. Abortion was the major issue in the Democratic campaign. Both Avenson and Chrystal supported a woman's right to an abortion, but abortion rights groups endorsed Avenson and poured strong support into his campaign. Miller opposes abortion. ``I think the fact that we offered Iowans a choice made the difference,'' Avenson said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Upset That Secret Service Shoved Adviser
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Condoleezza in 2nd graf is cq, as is Conde in 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is ``very upset'' that a Secret Service agent shoved a top White House adviser as Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev left San Francisco, a spokesman said Wednesday. Condoleezza Rice, Bush's senior adviser on Soviet affairs and the highest ranking black woman at the White House, was among the VIPs at an airport reception line at Gorbachev's departure when she was singled out by a Secret Service agent. The unidentified agent reportedly ordered her to stay behind security barricades and then shoved her, even though she identified herself as a member of the official White House party. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said the agent ``pushed Conde Rice. Simple as that.'' Speaking to a roomful of reporters, Fitzwater added, ``You've all had it happen to you 100 times.'' ``The president is aware of it, he's very upset about it _ most unfortunate,'' Fitzwater said. There was no explanation for the incident. ``We have no idea what the factors were,'' Fitzwater said. Allan Cramer, a Secret Service spokesman, said, ``We're looking into it now. It's an ongoing investigation.'' He said he did not know what happened. ``As long as it's an ongoing investigation,'' he added, ``we wouldn't be commenting on it.'' Asked if Secret Service agents are authorized to shove people, he snapped, ``What kind of question is that? _ That's like, have you stopped beating your wife?'' Calls to Ms. Rice's office were referred to the White House press office.

DOC.HEAD: Montana Candidates Brace for Expensive Fall Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Max Baucus and his Democratic supporters say they're bracing for an avalanche of Republican cash in this fall's general election battle with Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad. But Baucus, a two-term Democrat who was nominated for re-election Tuesday, has his own pile of campaign cash, which Republicans are trying to turn into a liability rather than an asset. ``Senator Baucus will learn the hard way that Montana cannot be bought with an out-of-state war chest,'' said Montana GOP Chairman Barbara Campbell. ``Does he need $2 million to get re-elected to a job he's held for 12 years? That says he's very weak.'' Baucus coasted past two primary opponents Tuesday with 83 percent of the Democratic vote, while Kolstad won a four-man race with 43 percent of the GOP vote. Kolstad and the Republicans are hoping for a repeat of 1988, when upstart Republican Conrad Burns pulled off an upset victory over two-term incumbent Democratic Sen. John Melcher. Kolstad promised Wednesday to run an above-board campaign focusing on economic issues and refraining from personal attacks. But Democratic Party Chairman Bruce Nelson said he expects Kolstad to go on the offensive against Baucus. ``The pattern that Republicans set two years ago of a relentless negative attack is the same thing that they will do this year,'' he predicted. Baucus already has raised more than $2 million in campaign funds, smashing the state campaign-spending record of $1.2 million set by Melcher in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Opposes Additional Death Row Inmate Appeals
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Wednesday it opposes a House plan backed by some federal judges to give death row inmates more appeal rights than they now have. The department said also that it had ``technical problems'' with a Senate-adopted amendment to shorten death penalty delays by replacing state habeas corpus proceedings with a single federal court review. Defendants sentenced to death sometimes use habeas corpus hearings in attempts to win new trials or sentences. The Senate amendment was defeated, then passed 12 hours later on May 24 as part of a comprehensive anti-crime bill. The House and Senate proposals are among several under consideration in Congress to speed up death penalty appeals while ensuring defendants' rights. Deputy Assistant Attorney General Paul L. Maloney told a House Judiciary subcommittee that the House plan would cause delays and repetition in appeals, and that the Senate proposal contained ``defects.'' The House plan is sponsored by Rep. Paul Kastenmeier, D-Wis., chairman of the Judiciary Committee's subcommittee on courts. It would give death row inmates new appeal rights while ensuring that their attorneys met strict experience and performance standards. The bill also aims to end appeals delays by restricting multiple prisoner petitions, and establishing a one-year limit for inmates to file for federal habeas relief. But Maloney said the measure ``multiplies the opportunity for delay and abuse'' in capital cases. He quoted retired Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell, who said recently that a vote for Kastenmeier's bill ``would in practical effect be a vote to eliminate capital punishment in the United States.'' The bill was backed during Thursday's hearing by Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. He said a broader supervisory role by the federal judiciary was needed to stop the ``inexhaustible litany of racial discrimination cases in the courts in the rural south.'' The bill also has the support of several federal judges, including Gilbert Merritt of Nashville, Tenn., chief judge of the 6th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals. Maloney said also that the department was not ready to support the amendment requiring the filing of habeas corpus petitions within 60 days after final action by state courts. The amendment was authored by Sens. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., and Strom Thurmond, R-S.C. The Specter-Thurmond amendment raises ``interesting possibilities'' for reducing appeals delays ``through a stronger, more comprehensive system of time limitation rules,'' Maloney said. But he added, ``We do find that there are some defects, some technical problems if you will.'' Under questioning, he said the amendment was still under review and he was not prepared to specify what the problems were.

DOC.HEAD: Paraguay, Nicaragua Re-establish Ties
DOC.TEXT: Paraguay and Nicaragua on Wednesday re-established diplomatic and commercial ties severed 11 years ago following the ouster of Nicaraguan dictator Anastasio Somoza by Sandinista guerrillas. Vice foreign ministers Bernardino Caballero of Paraguay and Ernesto Leal of Nicaragua made the announcement at the annual meeting of the Organization of American States. Ties were broken in 1979 after a leftist Sandinista government took over in Nicaragua. The Sandinistas lost in elections last February and were replaced in April by a government headed by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. Paraguay's then-President Gen. Alfredo Stroessner granted asylum to Somoza, who was assassinated on an Asuncion street in September 1980. Stroessner's nearly 35-year rightist government was toppled in a Feb. 2, 1989, coup led by Gen. Andres Rodriguez, who three months later won a landslide election victory.

DOC.HEAD: New Rules May Allow Thousands of Palestinian Families to Unite
With AM-Israel-Soviet Jews, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A new policy halting the explusion of some Palestinians in the occupied lands affects thousands who have been separated from their families, a civil rights group said Wednesday. Under the government decision announced Tuesday, wives and children of Palestinians who live in West Bank or Gaza Strip without residency permits would be allowed to live in the occupied territories unless there is a ``specific negative security reason'' to deny the request. The decision came after Israel's Association for Civil Rights appealed the expulsions of 15 Palestinians and after U.S. criticism that expelling women and children without such permits was dividing Arab families. The new regulations say Arabs in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip will be allowed to ask for residency status for members of their families, who can remain as ``visitors.'' Netta Goldman, a lawyer with the Association for Civil Rights, said the group also won a court order specifying that as visitors, wives and children would be entitled to normal health benefits and schooling. ``This affects thousands and thousands of people,'' she said. Under past regulations, only Palestinians who lived in the occupied lands during a September 1967 census were automatically eligible for residency permits. That did not include thousands of Palestinian women whose families fled to Jordan when Israel seized the West Bank and Gaza in the June 1967 Mideast war, and who later married men from the occupied areas. Wives and children denied residency permits would enter the occupied lands on three-month guest visas, then had to abandon their families and return to Jordan for several months or stay illegally. According to the army, 251 Palestinians, including 88 women and 78 children, were expelled from the territories last year because they lacked residency permits. The army has no figures for preceding years. In January, the U.S. State Department questioned the expulsion practices. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin immediately ordered a temporary halt to the practice and promised to review it. According to Rabin, 88,249 requests for family reunification have been received since 1967, and 13,509 of those were granted. Palestinians activists have claimed the expulsions were part of a strategy to force Palestinians out of the occupied lands, but Israeli officials denied this. Still, the issue has been seen as part of a demographic war, with some Palestinians trying to increase their numbers in the territories, while Israel tried to limit the growth. About 1.7 million Arabs and 70,000 Jews live in the occupied lands. Palestinian activist and lawyer Jonathan Kuttab said Wednesday the new rules were ``a positive thing'' but would still leave tens of thousands of Palestinians as exiles. He said the decision was ``an attempt to reduce the damage from the glaring discrimination ... of allowing total strangers like Soviet Jews to come here while denying the basic rights of Palestinians, who have family and roots here, to come back to their land.''

DOC.HEAD: Michener Warns Young Men Sentenced to Study the Holocaust About Bigotry
DOC.TEXT: Author James Michener warned three young men that bigotry ``will corrode your soul and imperil your adult lives'' and offered to help them fulfill an unusual sentence for anti-Semitic vandalism. Michener wrote to the men after learning that a judge had ordered them to learn about the Holocaust _ the systematic destruction of 6 million Jews by the Nazis before and during World War II. Part of their assignment: reading a chapter from Michener's book, ``Poland.'' The letter was sent through the judge, John Carey, who said Wednesday he was moved that ``so eminent a scholar and author'' would take a ``sympathetic interest'' in the men's future. In his letter dated May 30, Michener said he was interested in their case because, as an orphan, ``race and inheritance have been of crucial importance to me.'' ``Fellows, what you're doing is wrong,'' Michener wrote of their bigotry. ``You will stain yourselves if you follow that route. Get off that doomed train right now. ... ``Grab at this chance to get home free and please, please drop your racial attitudes, for if you persist in them you will corrode your soul and imperil your adult lives.'' He offered to help the men understand the book chapter, titled ``The Terror,'' which deals with the Nazi concentration camp Majdanek in Poland. ``I could have no assignment more important than to help you retreat from what has been a fearfully wrong start,'' wrote Michener, the author of numerous books, including ``Chesapeake,'' ``The Drifters,'' ``The Source'' and the Pulitzer Prize-winning ``Tales of the South Pacific.'' The three men will be quizzed on the Holocaust on June 25 by three judges: one Jewish, one Catholic and Carey, who's Protestant. Carey, who sits in Westchester County Court, told the men in handing down his sentence that he wanted to educate them, not punish them. Michael Morano, 18, Michael Venturino, 18, and Neville Anthony Mason, 20, were charged with spray-painting swastikas and writing the words ``Jew'' and ``Hitler is Back'' on the walls of Ardsley High School on June 20, 1989. Morano pleaded guilty to criminal mischief in the third degree, a felony, and admitted that he had done the actual spray-painting. The other two pleaded guilty to misdemeanors. Referring to his orphan start in life, Michener wrote: ``I have no idea who my parents were. I could have been Jewish, I could be part Negro. I could easily have been born Catholic or Baptist. But as a spiritually free man I have made my way in the world as honorably as I could.'' He also noted that his wife was of Japanese extraction and therefore his family was ``intimately concerned with the problems of race and tolerance between groups. We have striven to prevent incidents like the unfortunate one in which you became involved, because we know how much damage such misbehavior can cause.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Urges Barry to Plea Bargain, Declare He Won't Run Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Fauntroy, Fitzwater comment, jury pool now at 25 in top 10 grafs, picking up in 8th graf pvs, Jackson moved, and CORRECTING number of counts from nine to 10 in 10th graf, Barry also; subs 1 graf for last 2 grafs pvs
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson urged Mayor Marion Barry on Wednesday to work out a plea bargain in his drug and perjury case and declare he won't run for re-election. The city ``should be spared'' a racially divisive trial and campaign, Jackson said. He made his comments as Barry lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy disclosed he had talked with Jackson about the mayor's criminal trial. The case went through a third day of jury selection with 16 prospective jurors sent into a jury pool that now numbers 25. Talk of a possible plea bargain dominated public discussion of the trial, as various figures hinted they were involved or declared they weren't. Walter Fauntroy, Washington's delegate in Congress and a candidate to succeed Barry as mayor, called a news conference to remind reporters he had earlier appealed to Barry and prosecutors to ``spare the city and the nation the agony of a trial'' and to say he had concluded ``that appeal has not fallen on deaf ears.'' At the White House, however, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said there was ``no basis'' to a report that Jackson, Fauntroy and other Democrats had called administration officials asking them to encourage prosecutors to soften terms for a guilty plea. Mundy said, ``I have spoken to Reverend Jackson.'' But he shed no light on the question of a possible role for Jackson in any plea bargain negotiations with the government. No discussions on a possible guilty plea were under way, Mundy said. He declined to answer whether that subject had come up in the conversation with Jackson. Asked whether he would rule out such talks with the prosecution, Mundy said he never says ``anything in absolutes.'' Various reports have indicated that negotiations between Mundy and the U.S. attorney's office in Washington reached an impasse several days ago over the government's insistence that the mayor plead guilty to one of the three felony perjury counts against him. Barry also faces 10 misdemeanor charges of drug possession and one of conspiracy. Jackson moved to Washington last year amid speculation he had his eye on the mayor's office, but he has since said he will not be a candidate in the November election. Barry has not formally announced for a fourth four-year term but had made numerous campaign-style appearances, and aides say he is likely to run. In an interview on WUSA-TV, Jackson expressed hope that the mayor ``would determine he would not run again ... and would really challenge the Justice Department to work out some settlement process.'' ``There's enough pain to go around,'' he said. ``If all this laundry comes out'' in a trial it ``will be a long and ugly and national and divisive campaign,'' Jackson said. ``We should be spared ... all of this,'' he added. It is ``very Republican-Democrat, it's very white-black, it's very nasty.'' Settling the case now would allow ``rebuilding a lot of fractures and wounds in this city that's now pouring over into the entire country,'' said Jackson. Jackson said a trial would embarrass the Justice Department, considering ``the amount of time and money spent'' by the government in pursuing Barry and ``the horror stories we now hear about the FBI's role.'' The bureau's sting operation resulted in a videotape of Barry allegedly smoking crack cocaine and is the centerpiece of the government's case. ``They used more than the amount of money that they would spend on a serial killer or an S&L thief that threatens to bankrupt the whole country,'' said Jackson. Jackson said his sense is that Barry ``feels if it goes the complete judicial process that he will emerge with some strength and a public airing of it. But he would rather spare the people of this long, drawn-out process as well as his family. ``My sense is that he would choose publicly not to run again, that he would be interested in serving out his term and obviously not going to jail and continuing his recovery process.'' Barry spent seven weeks in substance abuse recovery centers following his Jan. 18 arrest at the Vista Hotel. On Tuesday, nine prospective jurors were sent into a pool from which a panel of 12 jurors and six alternates will be selected for the Barry case. Among the 16 sent into the pool Wednesday was a man who expressed concern that his name would become known and that he might be subject to threats if he sat on the Barry jury.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge Declares Rap Album Obscene
DOC.TEXT: The hot-selling 2 Live Crew rap album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' was declared obscene Wednesday by a federal judge who cited its graphic sexual lyrics. U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez agreed with the Broward County Sheriff's Department that the album violates community obscenity standards. ``It is an appeal to `dirty' thoughts and the loins, not to the intellect and the mind,'' Gonzalez wrote in his opinion, which was read to a packed courtroom that included the rap group's members. The Miami-based group sued after deputies threatened shopkeepers with arrest if they continued selling the album.
