The group's attorney, Bruce Rogow, said he'd appeal the ruling, but predicted album sales, which are approaching 2 million, would get a boost from the decision. ``I think the demand for the record is going to be extraordinary,'' Rogow said, quoting a newspaper columnist who wrote: ``People will crawl naked over broken glass to get what someone tells them they're not supposed to.'' Gonzalez said the recording met the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court test for obscenity, as set by local community standards, and cited state laws in his ruling. ``Florida has declared obscenity a crime,'' he wrote. ``To repeat, violation of the law against obscenity is as much against the law as assault, rape, kidnapping, robbery or any other form of behavior which the Legislature has declared criminal.'' The judge, who listened to the album at a hearing in mid-May and heard arguments from witnesses and attorneys, did rebuke the sheriff's office for improper prior restraint of free speech. He said deputies shouldn't have approached retailers until the material had been declared obscene. Sheriff Nick Navarro said his department hasn't made any arrests for selling the album, which has virtually disappeared from stores countywide. ``We will enforce the laws,'' Navarro said. ``I intend to follow a very prudent and reasonable line.'' 2 Live Crew's leader, Luther Campbell, said the obscenity ruling wouldn't change the group's musical style or lyrics. ``We'll keep making the same music. We probably won't sell no records in Broward County,'' he said outside the courthouse. During the May hearing, Rogow played the double album for the judge and a packed courtroom. He also showed X-rated videotapes and displayed pornographic magazines obtained locally as evidence of the community's standards. Two music critics and a sociologist appeared as expert witnesses, testifying about the recording's artistic, political and literary worth. Sheriff's department lawyer John Jolly brought no experts. ``The tape speaks for itself,'' he said before the trial. In the 1973 case of Miller vs. California, the U.S. Supreme Court established guidelines for finding material obscene. The justices ruled that the material must, under the contemporary standards of individual communities, describe sexual conduct in a patently offensive way, appeal to the prurient interest, and lack serious artistic, literary or political value.

DOC.HEAD: Feds: Pursuing Alien Smuggling Charges Against Noriega
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf with two grafs to clarify status of other aliens caught in piepline
DOC.TEXT: U.S. immigration investigators say they expect Manuel Noriega to be charged with being at the center of the largest alien-smuggling ring ever uncovered. Tens of thousands of Chinese, Cubans and other immigrants paid millions of dollars to Panamanian officials to use that nation as an illegal gateway to the United States and Canada, said Robert Harris, chief criminal investigator for the Immigration and Naturalization Service here. The ring started as early as 1980, and about 4,000 Cubans used it to enter this country at Miami International Airport alone during the past seven years, authorities said. Sixteen thousand people were caught ``in the pipeline'' when the United States invaded Panama in December, said Robert Penland, who recently retired as assistant INS commissioner for anti-smuggling. ``Nobody ever operated an alien-smuggling operation to the extent of Panama,'' Harris said. ``It was operated by the government, and it was a well-organized, well-run operation.'' He said immigration officials could not recall any such state-operated alien trade. There is already enough evidence to seek indictments, Harris said, but INS and federal prosecutors decided to move cautiously because of the former Panamanian dictator's protracted drug-smuggling case, due to go to trial next year. ``We don't want to interfere with the current prosecution effort by the United States attorney,'' he said recently. Any indictment ``could be after the trial.'' In response to Harris' comments, U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen issued a statement Wednesday saying: ``There is no indictment currently planned or contemplated against General Manuel A. Noriega in this district that includes any allegations of alien smuggling.'' The allegations became public during a January bond hearing for a Noriega co-defendant, pilot Eduardo Pardo, when federal prosecutors said Noriega and Pardo helped smuggle aliens into the country. Noriega attorney Frank Rubino said he was surprised by the investigation, and questioned the U.S. right to prosecute his client in such a case. ``The United States may like to police the world ... but they've just gone a step too far,'' Rubino said. ``What may have occurred internally in the country of Panama is not within U.S. jurisdiction.'' The smuggling operation not only involved Noriega and top intelligence officials, but also Panama's consulates, the Cuban government, private attorneys and U.S.-based smugglers, investigators say. Panamanian officials, acting directly or through private attorney middlemen, charged from $10,000 up to $20,000 for visas into Panama, Harris said. He said the highest prices were paid by refugees from China, while those from Cuba, Hong Kong and other points paid somewhat less, Harris said. Cuban officials worked with Noriega on the visas to extract money from refugees leaving that island for Panama, and Miami-based Cuban rights groups also paid Noriega to ensure their countrymen were cleared to travel to the United States, Harris said. Trusted Noriega in-laws were put in charge of two of the most lucrative consulates, Taiwan and Hong Kong, said the investigator. All visa approvals had to come directly from the head of Panama's intelligence service, Lt. Col. Rafael Cedeno, or from Noriega himself, Harris said. Cedeno distributed a list to Panamanian customs officials, and no one could enter the country unless they were on it, Harris said. Entering Panama was only the beginning, however, Harris said. ``Once they arrived, they were further exploited. They would sell them residence visas, extensions of stay _ sometimes $3,000 to stay an extra year.'' Maj. Felipe Camargo, who headed Panama's immigration agency for only four months, was captured after the U.S. invasion and is one of several former top officials to give details on how lucrative the ring was, said Harris. ``In that four months, he admitted personally getting $300,000,'' said Harris. ``If he got $300,000, the higher-ups must have gotten at least that amount.'' All orders came directly from Noriega and Cedeno at the Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters, the Comandancia. ``And the money was then passed on to the Comandancia,'' said Harris. ``That would be Noriega, or Cedeno, or (Cedeno's predecessor) Guillermo Wong before the October coup attempt.'' After the invasion, the Panamanians apparently tried to destroy all financial records, but investigators found one set of wire transfers to Cedeno for $80,000 they believe are linked to the alien-smuggling. Even when the aliens made arrangments to sneak into the United States, they still had to pay Panamanian officials to get on Cedeno's exit list, said Harris. Smuggling into the United States from Panama was accomplished in various forms, said Harris. While Cubans could simply show up in the United States and claim political asylum, Chinese aliens had more difficulty. ``They take a different route _ they try to evade the INS through fraudulent documents, or cross over land borders,'' he said. As far as the INS can tell, the new government of Panama has stopped the alien trade into the country, officials said. But about 7,000 Chinese were stranded in Panama after the invasion, so the smuggling operations out of that country continue, even though no longer organized by the government, immigration officials said. The 8,000 others were either in the home countries, in third countries or were still making their way into the United States, officials said. A flight of illegal Chinese immigrants from Panama was recently intercepted in Canada, and Harris said arrests are still being made in Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Metropolis Residents Shun Puny Superman
DOC.TEXT: Sure, Superman's super. But he's short _ even puny. That's the feeling of some Metropolis residents who express concern that a 7-foot-5 statue of the Man of Steel is dwarfed by a supermarket's 32-foot statue of a burly lumberjack. As the Ohio River city of 7,200 begins its four-day annual Superman Celebration on Thursday, a move is afoot to replace the Superman replica with a 15-foot version. ``I took a good, long look at it one day, and I decided we needed a new Superman,'' said O.D. Troutman, one of six people on a committee organized to acquire a new statue. ``We just want to get a larger one, a better looking one and one that is better proportionally built.'' The current superhero was built for $1,000 four years ago, but his stature now seems downright diminutive compared to Big John, the statue of a lumberjack that stands at the entrance to Big John's supermarket a few blocks from Superman's lowly brick pedestal in front of the courthouse. Though he says bigger is better, Troutman isn't ready to top Big John: ``It would be higher than the courthouse and it wouldn't blend in with the surroundings.'' Besides, a Superman the size of Big John would thwart camera-toting tourists trying to snap a few photos of the kids clambering on the Man of Steel. Residents would readily contribute toward a new statue, Troutman said, explaining: ``I've had folks tell me, `If you get rid of the statue, we will give you $100 for a new one.''' A new steel-and-fiberglass model could be built within three months and have a grand unveiling at the 1991 Superman Celebration, he said. The celebration has been held annually since 1979 and is expected to draw more than the 20,000 visitors it attracted last year, said Jenny Walters, celebration committee chairwoman. Metropolis _ the name of Superman's fictional hometown _ adopted him in 1972, and the celebration honoring him with skits, picnics and other family-oriented events gets bigger every year, so a larger Superman is a good move, Walters said. But what about the old Superman? ``It would look good on top of our 150-foot water tower,'' Troutman said.

DOC.HEAD: Lavish Welcome in Paris As Mandela Starts Europe-America Trip
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: A welcome fit for royalty awaited Nelson Mandela as he arrived Wednesday on the first leg of a six-week trans-Atlantic trip aimed at persuading the West to maintain pressure on South Africa's white rulers. Mandela, freed Feb. 11 after more than 27 years in prison, was met at Orly airport by France's first lady, Danielle Mitterrand, head of a human rights foundation that has lobbied against apartheid. The 71-year-old African National Congress leader later was to attend a twilight outdoor concert in his honor at the Place du Trocadero, across the Seine river from the Eiffel Tower, in the company of President Francois Mitterrand. Highlights of the program included a rendition of ``God Bless Africa,'' the anthem of the anti-apartheid movement, by jazz violinist Didier Lockwood and 100 supporting violinists, and a spiritual sung by black American opera star Grace Bumbry. The Culture Ministry invited the public ``to come honor the man who embodies the hopes for the liberation of South Africa.'' On Thursday, Mandela is to confer with Mitterrand and Premier Michel Rocard as well as leaders of the Socialist, Communist and neo-Gaullist parties. Mandela _ making his third and most extensive foreign trip since his release from prison _ is scheduled to visit Switzerland next, followed by West Germany, Italy, Canada, the United States, Ireland and Britain, as well as several African countries. He is due back in South Africa on July 18, his 72nd birthday. He is expected to urge Western leaders to maintain existing sanctions and embargoes on South Africa, despite the reform initiatives of President F.W. de Klerk. De Klerk has freed several African National Congress leaders, lifted a 30-year ban on the guerrilla movement, and moved to dismantle several segregation laws as prelude to proposed negotiations on a post-apartheid constitution. Mandela, at a news conference Tuesday in Botswana, said foreign pressure should be maintained because de Klerk's government had not yet addressed the back majority's basic demand of a one-person, one-vote political system. However, he reaffirmed his positive attitude toward de Klerk and hinted the president might lift the 4-year-old state of emergency within the next few days. The emergency was imposed June 12, 1986 by de Klerk's predecessor, P.W. Botha. De Klerk, intent on ending South Africa's international isolation, visited Mitterrand and other Western Euorpean leaders during a nine-nation, 18-day trip last month. Mitterrand and other heads of state told de Klerk that the status of sanctions would be discussed at a European Community summit in Dublin, Ireland on June 25-26. In South Africa, police searched two houses belonging to African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela on Wednesday, claiming they were seeking a murder suspect. Police Brig. Vic Haynes said the suspect was not connected with the Mandela family. The ANC condemned the raids as ``the height of provocation'' and demanded ``such acts of intimidation'' cease immediately. ANC officials said a small brick house that Mandela had rented for 40 years was searched, along with a ranch-style house in another section of the black township of Soweto, outside Johannesburg. A newer mansion where the Mandelas now live was not searched.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Names 12 White House Fellows
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday tapped a dozen young professionals to spend the next year on special high-level government assignments as White House Fellows. The fellows, chosen from nearly 1,000 applicants, will begin their 12 months of government service on Sept. 1. A presidential commission helped make the final selections from 33 national finalists. They are the 26th class of fellows chosen since the high-level internship program was launched in 1964. They will work as special assistants to Bush's own staff, the vice president and members of the Cabinet. The new fellows are: _Andrew I. Batavia, 32, of Washington, a disability expert who directs the Health Services Research Program at the National Rehabilitation Hospital Research Center. _Samuel Dale Brownback, 33, of Topeka, Kan., the Kansas secretary of agriculture. _Robert Bruce Chess, 33, of Palo Alto, Calif., president and co-founder of Penederm, a biotechnology company. _Jody Ann Greenstone, 32, of Greenville, S.C., vice president in public finance of the Robinson-Humphrey Co., a subsidiary of Shearson Lehman Hutton. _Robert R. Grusky, 32, of Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., a vice president in the investment banking division of Goldman, Sachs & Co. _Air Force Capt. Willie Arthur Gunn, 31, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a circuit defense counsel defending service members in complex criminal cases in five Western states. _Air Force Maj. Randall Herman Kehl, 36, of Albuquerque, N.M., an attorney with the Judge Advocate General's office in Washington. _Navy Lt. Cmdr. John William Miller, 32, of Annapolis, Md., the head of the leadership section in the Naval Academy's Department of Leadership and Law. _Eric McLaren Phillips, 37, of Maplewood, N.J., a Guyanese-born district manager for AT&T International Communications Services. _Air Force Maj. Edward Augustus Rice Jr., 33, of Yellow Springs, Ohio, a manager in the Air Force's directorate of plans and operations in Washington. _Joseph E. Samora Jr., 34, of Albuquerque, who is chairman of the New Mexico Public Service Commission. _Kimberly Till, 34, of Prattville, Ala., an international management consultant with Bain & Co. in London. Appications for the 1991-92 program are available from the President's Commission on White House Fellowships, 712 Jackson Place, N.W., Washington, D.C. 20503.

DOC.HEAD: IRA Bomb Blast Kills Retired Policeman
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb explosion killed a retired police reserve officer on Wednesday and wounded his wife and two pedestrians, police said. The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility for the blast. The Royal Ulster Constabulary identified the slain man as James Sefton, 65, and said his wife, Ellen, was in critical condition in a hospital. Two people walking along the road were also injured, the constabulary said. Sefton, who retired from the police reserve three years ago, was the fifth person killed in 11 days by the IRA. The IRA has made police and army members a prime target of a 20-year-old campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland. The IRA wants to unite Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland with the overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland. In Annaghmore, Catholic priest Seamus McGinley urged mourners at the funeral of Patrick Boyle, 60, to make the father-of-five's funeral the starting point for building a new, peaceful way of life. ``Forget about retaliation because retaliation brings nothing, only violence and more violence,'' he said. Boyle was killed at his home near Portadown, 25 miles southwest of Belfast, on Monday. The Ulster Volunteer Force, an illegal Protestant organization, claimed responsibility but indicated it had meant to kill someone else. Boyle's two sons were wounded by gunfire.

DOC.HEAD: Fat City Gets Slimmer
DOC.TEXT: A private project to improve rural Americans' cardiovascular health resulted in an average nine-pound loss of body fat as well as reduced cholesterol and blood pressure, organizers said Wednesday. ``We're talking about an impressive improvement in the quality of life, about people being more productive and less stressed,'' said Bill Reger, director of Bayer Co.'s $3.3 million, two-year study. ``Our success has been phenomenal.'' Participants were encouraged to follow a low-fat, high-fiber diet, to exercise, and to use stress management techniques. Free cooking and aerobics classes were offered along with lectures on heart disease, nutrition and weight loss. Stop-smoking clinics also were available. Those in the study, which began in May 1988, had their blood pressures, cholesterol, pulse rates and other factors checked every three months. The program's final screenings were completed late last month. Results from that screening will be distributed to the participants beginning Thursday. The program, one of the first privately funded public health education programs for rural areas, was sponsored by Bayer and its New York-based parent company, Glenbrook Laboratories. Organizers chose Wellsburg, a town of about 4,000 people, about 45 miles southwest of Pittsburgh, because of its small population. The 517 people who went through the program from start to finish lost an average of 8.6 pounds of body fat, Reger said. An average 5.2 pounds of that fat was converted to muscle tissue, resulting in an average weight loss of 3.6 pounds. The participants also saw their cholesterol reduced from an average reading of 220 at the start of the study to 208. ``The reduction may not seem to be that much at first blush,'' said Reger. ``But if you look further, the people at the most risk were the ones who made the greatest positive changes and we're thrilled with that.'' Average blood pressures of those in the study dropped from an average 132 over 81 to 126 over 78. ``Again, the changes may appear modest, but the people at most risk had the biggest reductions,'' said Reger. ``Overall, people in the program are using far fewer high blood pressure medications now than they were two years ago.'' West Virginia has one of the highest obesity rates in the country at 29 percent, according to a 1988 report by the federal Centers for Disease Control. The same study found that 27 percent of West Virginians smoked. Nearly everyone in the study reported reducing their salt and fat intake. And 57 percent of those who smoked when they started the program have quit, Reger said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Asks Interim Extension of Endowment
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration moved Wednesday to defuse controversy over government financing of potentially objectional art by proposing a one-year interim extension of the National Endowment for the Arts. Endowment Director John E. Frohnmayer told a Senate panel he hoped time would allow ``the temperature to go down'' on the dispute over federal aid of allegedly obscene art. He urged that a 12-member advisory commission, half of it appointed by Congress and half by the White House, be given time to reach some recommendations about the future of the endowment and its grant-making procedures. ``This problem must be solved and I pledge to you my full attention to it,'' Frohnmayer said. ``This controversy has been debilitating to my agency.'' Frohnmayer appeared before a Senate appropriations subcommittee considering the budget for the NEA. The agency's legislative authorization is scheduled to expire at the end of this fiscal year. President Bush has recommended another five-year renewal, or reauthorization, of the NEA with no restrictions on its grant-making authority. But the NEA has drawn opposition among conservatives because of federal grants for controversial works by the late photographer Robert Mapplethorpe and photographer Andrews Serrano, and congressional supporters have acknowledged it would be difficult to win full renewal with no restrictions. Frohnmayer told the panel that the Bush administration continues to prefer a five-year reauthorization of the NEA without restrictions but would accept ``a three-year or even a one-year'' extension while awaiting the commission's recommendation. At the White House, deputy press secretary Alixe Glen called a one-year extension ``the prudent thing to do.'' ``Given the political climate, this isn't something we want to do hastily,'' she said. The advisory commission met separately Wednesday for the first time to review the agency's grant-making procedures. Its first meeting came more than a month after it had been directed by Congress to make a report on the NEA. Frohnmayer cited administrative delays and urged that the commission's life also be extended beyond its October expiration. Frohnmayer received a lecture from the subcommittee chairman, Sen. Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., and Sen. James A. McClure, R-Idaho, about the peril posed to the endowment by the controversial grants. Byrd said some of the subsidized works of art were ``so repulsive'' that if viewed by the general public there would by a far greater outcry that could force an end to the NEA altogether. ``It's too bad that a few little rotten apples will spoil the barrel, but they surely will,'' Byrd said. McClure said he wanted to continue supporting the arts but complained of an ``attitude out there'' among the arts community that Congress has no business exercising control on grants. Frohnmayer acknowledged the controversy has damaged the NEA and said the endowment has taken steps to ensure grants go through careful review. ``I would hope we could put Mapplethorpe and Serrano behind us, because we have really bloodied ourselves,'' he said. Mapplethorpe's works included homoerotic photographs and Serrano's works included a depiction of a crucifix in urine. The one-year plan was decided upon at a meeting Tuesday including White House officials and Frohnmayer as a way to head off further restrictions on NEA.

DOC.HEAD: Some Senators Want to End PLO Talks
DOC.TEXT: Several senators moved Wednesday to end U.S. talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization because of the group's involvement in a foiled terrorist attack on Israel. ``The terrorist raid on Israel last week was the last straw in a continuing pattern of unacceptable behavior by the PLO,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn. Abu Abbas, a member of the PLO's executive committee, claimed responsibility for the foiled boat attack against civilians on a beach in Tel Aviv. Lieberman and three others senators _ Iowa Republican Charles Grassley and Democrats Connie Mack of Florida and Frank Lautenberg of New Jersey _ introduced a resolution that would force the State Department to end talks with the PLO until it renounces terrorism and recognizes Israel's right to exist. Lisa Klinghoffer, daughter of terrorist victim Leon Klinghoffer, said a ``cold chill ran down my spine'' when she saw Abu Abbas on television recently. Abbas was convicted in absentia by the Italian government of directing the terrorist takeover of the cruise ship Achille Lauro in the Mediterranean in 1985. Klinghoffer, confined to a wheelchair, was shot and killed; his body dumped overboard. The State Department, in a report released earlier this year, said there was no evidence that PLO officials directed terrorism, even though there were scattered incidents of violence. Under existing law, the United States can't deal with the PLO if it endorses terrorism. U.S. officials have said they are reviewing last week's attempted boat attack.

DOC.HEAD: Supervisors to Appeal Federal Ruling They Diluted Hispanic Voting Power
DOC.TEXT: A federal court ruling that the county Board of Supervisors drew district boundaries to dilute Hispanic voting strength will be appealed. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon ruled Monday in a voting rights lawsuit that board members conspired to ``protect their incumbencies and (those) of their allies'' when they redrew the county's five voting districts in 1981. The board's conservative majority voted Tuesday to appeal. The two-year legal battle over redistricting already has cost $3 million. Liberal supervisors dissented regarding the appeal and called for a settlement that would expand the five-member board to offer more representation. `It's time for at least nine supervisors,'' Supervisor Kenneth Hahn said. Hahn left before the closed-door vote and fellow liberal Ed Edelman abstained. Conservative Pete Schabarum, who is retiring, favored the appeal, as did Mike Antonovich and Deane Dana. The 1988 lawsuit claimed the supervisors deliberately spread the county's Hispanic population across several districts when they changed voting boundaries following the 1980 federal census. Hispanics make up an estimated 35 percent of the county's 8.7 million people, but no Hispanic has been elected to the board since 1875.

DOC.HEAD: Pop Singer's Chest Pains Caused by Bruised Ribs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jacki in 13th graf is cq. Jackson brother in earlier grafs is Jackie.
DOC.TEXT: Chest pains that put entertainer Michael Jackson in the hospital were caused by bruised ribs suffered during a vigorous dance practice, his doctor said Wednesday. Laboratory and X-ray tests of Jackson's heart and lungs revealed no abnormalities, said Dr. Mark Zatzkis, a cardiologist. Jackson complained of chest pains when he was admitted to St. Johns Hospital and Health Center on Sunday. The singer-songwriter suffered from costochondritis, or cartilage inflammation of the front part of the ribs, Zatzkis said in a statement released by Jackson's spokesman, Bob Jones. Jackson should be released in about two days and then will visit the hospital for more treatment, Jones told a news conference. The singer apparently suffered the injury during a two-hour solo dance session in the bedroom of his Los Angeles home, a regular Sunday routine. Jones said Jackson demands to be left alone during the workout. ``No one dares disturb him,'' he said. Jackson visited with his hospital floormate, Elizabeth Taylor, Jones said without offering details. Miss Taylor has been at the hospital for several weeks, recovering from a severe bout with pneumonia. Jackson's brothers, Jackie, Marlon, and Randy, entered the hospital shortly after the news conference. ``He's a strong person, and I know he's going to pull through,'' Jackie Jackson said. Hospital security guards detained a man and handed him over to police for allegedly making threats against Jackson. Jacki Lee Adams, 28, was arrested after saying he was going to kill the singer, said Sgt. John Meile. Adams was booked for investigation of giving false information to a police officer and trespassing, both misdemeanors, and felony threatening to cause bodily harm. It was the second arrest at the hospital involving Jackson's stay. On Monday, a woman who claimed Jackson is the father of her children was taken into custody by police. She allegedly violated a court order to stay at least 500 yards from the entertainer.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian President Asks Calm on Eve of Rallies
DOC.TEXT: President Petar Mladenov appealed for calm and city fathers banned the sale of alcohol Wednesday on the eve of separate rallies by the governing Socialist Party _ the former Communist Party _ and the opposition. Bulgaria holds its first free elections Sunday. The rallies were set for the same time and in close proximity Thursday evening in downtown Sofia. Hundreds of thousands were expected to attend, raising fears of incidents. Mladenov, a senior member of the Socialist Party, pleaded for restraint, saying the only way to behave was peacefully, avoiding conflicts. In a goodwill agreement published Wednesday, campaign managers Petko Simeonov of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces and Luben Gotsev of the Socialists also asked rally participants to stay peaceful. The city government of Sofia issued a ban on the sale of alcohol effective immediately. It will stay in force through election day.

DOC.HEAD: At Budget Talks, Administration Defends Its Defense Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf: ``Most Democrats,'' to clarify significance of $64 billion figure; INSERTS 9th graf: ``Cheney and,'' with bargainers studying option of cutting defense strength by 25 percent
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney joined White House-congressional talks Wednesday but offered no indication the Bush administration was ready to accept significant defense cuts, participants said. Cheney entered the negotiations amid differences over how the talks might be affected by Tuesday's vote in California to double that state's gasoline tax. Democrats said it signaled that Americans don't necessarily reject higher levies. But most Republicans discounted the notion that the California vote would make budget negotiators less fearful of boosting federal taxes. Most Democrats and some Republicans see the Defense Department budget as a source of big savings next year. Budget negotiators are trying to find a way to reduce next year's deficit to $64 billion, the target set by the Gramm-Rudman law. However, the administration has said the deficit could reach as high as $206 billion without special attention. President Bush has proposed spending $303.3 billion on the military for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. Opponents say that recommendation ignores warming East-West relations and want to cut it by at least $8 billion. ``No new numbers,'' Cheney said during a break when asked whether he had offered a new defense proposal. The defense secretary, joined by Republicans, instead justified the administration's spending request, which calls for slight decreases in future years. Democrats said they were disappointed. ``The administration appears to be holding strong to the position that defense should not be cut,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. ``If we indeed are in a crisis situation with regard to the federal budget ... then defense is going to have to take its fair share of reductions.'' Cheney and lawmakers agreed to examine how much money could be saved by reducing military forces by one-quarter, an option the secretary said was already under study at the Pentagon. Negotiators said this would allow the two sides to work from common figures, and was not an indication of a final agreement. While defense was the topic of the negotiations, many lawmakers were mulling the 53 to 47 percent margin by which Californians voted to double their gasoline tax to 18 cents. The money is to be used to improve highways. ``It's an indication that the tax revolt ... has been tempered by a realization that we have to make investments in the country,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``This confirms what the polls have been saying, that people are willing to pay additional taxes if they know they are going for a specific purpose,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. Panetta and Sasser agreed that on the other hand, raising local taxes could make people more resentful of federal tax increases. ``This does make it more difficult for people to accept higher federal taxes on top of it,'' Sasser said. Most Republicans said the California vote would not affect the budget talks. ``California is a state unto itself,'' said Rep. Bill Archer of Texas, ranking Republican on the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee. ``That's not relevant to what we're doing here.'' House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., said it has always been difficult for Congress to enact excise taxes on products such as gasoline. But he said the California voting ``represents some little change of heart, at least on the part of Californians.'' Meanwhile, House Republicans and Democrats skirmished over plans by Democrats to immediately begin writing spending bills for next year. GOP lawmakers complained that the spending measures would be overly expensive unless budget bargainers were first given a chance to work out a deficit-reduction deal. They urged House leaders to set June 28 as a deadline for completing the budget talks. Democrats said work on the spending bills must begin now with the new fiscal year less than four months away.

DOC.HEAD: Former Communist Leaders Rounded Up in Czechoslovakia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with additional names of former Communist officials quizzed, major politician denounced by government minister, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The government rounded up at least seven former Communist Party leaders Wednesday in a move likely to hurt the chances of Communist candidates two days before the nation's first free election since 1946. The party is running a distant third in opinion polls. Detained was Vasil Bilak, the former party official thought to have invited in the Soviet troops who crushed the ``Prague Spring'' reform movement of Alexander Dubcek in 1968. At least six other former senior Communists were questioned. In another political development, Josef Bartoncik, a major Christian Democratic politician accused of having been a secret police informer, was denounced by the minister charged with investigating past secret police operations and urged to quit politics. Wednesday's developments seemed likely to benefit the Civic Forum movement of President Vaclav Havel, already favored to win Friday`s elections. The Christian Democrats are running second in the surveys. Rumors consistently cited Bilak as the man who encouraged the Soviets to invade in 1968. The state news agency CTK said Bilak was held ``on suspicion of committing serious criminal activity.'' Prominent Communists questioned Wednesday included former president and party chief Gustav Husak; Milos Jakes, the party chief ousted in last winter's pro-democracy revolution; and former Premier Jozef Lenart, state TV news said. All three are associated with the purge of a half-million party members and the imposition of orthodox Communist rule after the 1968 invasion. Former Slovak Communist official Peter Colotka was also questioned, said an informed source who spoke on condition of anonymity. All with the exception of Husak spent the day at local police stations. Husak, 76, is frail and was questioned at home. Deputy Interior Minister Andrej Samel said the questioning dealt with the 1968 invasion and ``other criminal activities.`` State television news said it also touched on illegal acquisitions of property and mismanagement of hard currency accounts. The move appeared timed to satisfy popular demand that Bilak, Jakes and others be punished for their part in the invasion and the 21 years of tough Communist rule that followed. Communists excluded, all parties contesting the parliamentary election on Friday and Saturday have campaigned heavily on an anti-Communist platform. In the past few weeks, state television has repeatedly broadcast film of the invasion and other episodes associated with the hated Communist rule, the horrors of which also are chronicled in a recently opened exhibit. Bilak, 72, a former chief Communist ideologue, was picked up at his home in the Slovak capital of Bratislava at midnight Tuesday, Samel said. He will be held for 48 hours, state television said. One of the other officials summoned for questioning was Rudolf Hegenbart, formerly in charge of security for the Communist party and identified last week in a British Broadcasting Corp. documentary as the man who allegedly conspired with the Soviet KGB to oust Jakes. The names of the others interrogated were not immediately available. Last April, Czechoslovak prosecutors began investigating the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion, which they termed a ``criminal offense against peace.'' Deputy Prosecutor General Lubomir Veleta said then the inquiry was intended to find all those responsible. An ``offense against peace'' carries a maximum sentence of 15 years in jail and does not fall under Czechoslovakia's 20-year statute of limitations. The investigation has been stymied to date by Soviet refusal to hand over all documents connected with the invasion. Prague is particularly interested in a letter allegedly chronicling Bilak's invitation to the Soviets to intervene. In a recent interview with the youth daily Mlada Fronta, Bilak denied writing such a letter. In a statement on TV news, Deputy Interior Minister Jan Ruml accused Bartoncik of breaking his word after promising Tuesday to quit politics. Bartoncik is chairman of the People`s Party, which is in the mainstream Christian Democratic movement. Bartoncik repeatedly denied being a secret police informer, but made the pledge after being confronted with what Ruml termed facts that made Bartoncik unfit to be a parliamentary deputy. Bartoncik's party said he was hospitalized Tuesday after reported cardiac arrest. Ruml accused Bartoncik of trying to hide his past and said he felt compelled to speak out, which may prompt more revelations about leading politicians who once cooperated with the STB, the now disbanded secret police. Civic Forum spokeswoman Jana Ryslinkova said Wednesday some Forum candidates had resigned after being screened for past links with the Communist secret police. She said she would not identify them because there were an estimated 140,000 collaborators with the STB, and it would be unfair to publish the names of some agents and omit others. ``Let`s give them a chance to live, but not to represent the Civic Forum,`` she said.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Offered $4 Billion Weapons Sale
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration has informed Congress it intends to sell Saudi Arabia more than $4 billion worth of light armored vehicles, TOW anti-tank missiles, and modernization packages for five AWACs surveillance planes, the Pentagon said Wednesday. If Congress doesn't object within 30 days, the sales are allowed to go through. In the formal pre-notice period during which the proposed arms sales were made known to members of Congress, no objections were raised by lawmakers. The sales help fulfill Saudi Arabia's defense needs and support U.S. strategic interests in the region, the Pentagon said. The sales also help boost U.S. weapons producers, many of whom face the prospect of sharp reductions in U.S. defense spending. For the most part, the Saudi's military arsenal is U.S.-made, though the desert kingdom concluded a $30 billion, multi-year deal with British companies several years ago for fighter planes and other weapons. ``This sale will contribute to the foreign policy and national security of the United States by helping improve the security of a friendly country, which has been and continues to be an important force for political stability and economic progress in the Middle East,'' the Pentagon said. The largest of three separate packages announced by the Defense Department carries a $3.4 billion price tag and is destined to support the Saudi National Guard, the Pentagon said. That package includes 1,117 Light Armored Vehicles; 2,000 TOW 11A anti-tank missiles; 116 TOW missile launchers; 27 M-198 155mm howitzers; ammunition; support equipment; the design and construction of ranges and maintenance facilities for the equipment; and U.S. government and contractor managment, training, logistical and technical support for the items, the statement said. The LAV is a multi-purpose vehicles that carries a 25mm automatic cannon and a machine gun. It is used by the U.S. Marines primarily as a reconnaisance vehicle, as a troop carrier, or as a light-armored command and control center. The other two packages include: _A $600 million ``modification and system integration'' program for five AWACS (Airborne Warning and Control System) surveillance aircraft and eight KE-3 tanker aircraft to improve their mission, navigation, engine and aircraft protection systems, the Pentagon said. The Pentagon said the systems were necessary for a common configuration with similar U.S. aircraft, and to provide Saudi Arabia with an ``effective air defense command and control network, capable of countering all potential threats in the Persian Gulf region.'' The AWACS were the subject of a bruising battle in Congress in 1981 over the introduction of such sophisticated aircraft into the volatile Mideast region. _A $26 million sale of 12 M88-A1 recovery vehicles with additional weapons and equipment, including 12 M-2 .50-caliber machine guns, spare and repair parts. The sale augments and earlier sale of nine such vehicles, which are heavily armored and designed to tow damaged tanks or other tracked vehicles from the battlefield. The prime contractor for the AWACS and tanker equipment sale is Boeing Aircraft Co. of Seattle. The prime contractor for the LAV sale is General Motors of Canada. For teh TOW missiles, the prime contractor is Hughes Aircraft Corp., of Tombstone, Ariz. The prime contractor for the recovery vehicles is Bowen McLaughlin York Corp., of York, Pa.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Oilman Nominated As Ambassador To Austria
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Wednesday he will nominate Houston oilman Roy M. Huffington to be ambassador to Austria. If confirmed by the Senate, Huffington would succeed Henry A. Grunwald, former editor-in-chief of Time magazine, who has held the diplomatic post since 1987. Huffington, a one time geology instructor at Harvard University, got into the oil business with the Humble Oil and Refining Company. Since 1956, he has run a company that bears his name. To fill other diplomatic openings, Bush said he would nominate: _Frederick Vreeland to be ambassador to Burma. Vreeland, a one time contributing editor of the ``Conde Nast Traveler'' magazine, is vice president of John Cabot International College in Rome. _Aurelia E. Brazeal to be ambassador to Micronesia. A Foreign Service officer, she has been minister counselor for economic affairs at the American Embassy in Tokyo since 1987. Bush also accorded the personal rank of ambassador to John F. Maisto in his capacity as vice chairman of the U.S. delegation to the Organization of American States' General Assembly.

DOC.HEAD: Andersen Nominated To Head Wage And Hour Division
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will nominate William Eric Andersen to be administrator of the Labor Department's Wage and Hour Division, the White House said Wednesday. Andersen, 35, a graduate of West Point and Vanderbilt Law School, is currently a deputy assistant secretary of labor. The native of Bristol, Tenn., now lives in Washington, D.C. If confirmed, he would succeed Paula V. Smith.

DOC.HEAD: Genscher: Obstacles to Unity Will Be Solved
With AM-Baker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said Wednesday the latest round of talks has left him confident about solving the major stumbling block to German unification. The West German official, as part of the consultations aimed at establishing the military stance of a united Germany, will meet with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Monday in the Soviet town of Brest near the Polish border. The Foreign Ministry in Bonn said the two men will visit the grave of Shevardnadze's brother, a Soviet soldier who died there during World War II, as a sign of reconciliation. As Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev explains his nation's wariness about a militarily powerful Germany, he has been reminding Western countries of his 20 million compatriots killed during World War II. East Germany's prime minister, Lothar de Maiziere, flew to Moscow on Wednesday to take part in a Warsaw Pact leaders' conference, the government in East Berlin said. De Maiziere will fly to the United States this weekend for four days of talks that will include a meeting with President Bush. On Tuesday, Secretary of State James A. Baker III discussed with Shevardnadze a package of Western concessions to try to win Moscow's approval of NATO membership for the powerful new German state. Asked if they had made progress, Baker said: ``I think we did.'' ``The area of mutual understanding on the complex issues seems to be broadening,'' Shevardnadze told reporters at the Soviet Embassy. In an interview Wednesday, Genscher said he shared the superpowers' confidence. ``I have a positive assessment of my talks with the American secretary of state and the Soviet foreign minister, which went late into the evening,'' Genscher added. Genscher told the Norddeutsche Rundfunk radio network he is still hoping to present a German unification plan to a European summit this year, saying he hopes the meeting can take place before December. Genscher will fly to the Soviet town of Brest for the Shevardnadze meeting Monday, the Foreign Ministry said. ``It was an invitation from Shevardnadze,'' said a ministry spokesman. ``Shevarnadze's brother died there during the fighting. Shevardnadze invited him to visit the brother's grave, which in light of the past, is certainly not an unmeaningful gesture from the Soviet side.'' Asked whether the visit was meant as a sign of ``reconciliation,'' the spokesman replied ``yes, certainly.'' The spokesman, asking not to be identified by name, said Shevardnadze's brother died in June 1941 but did not know the fallen soldier's first name.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Concerned About Election Violence In Bulgaria
DOC.TEXT: The State Department voiced new concern Wednesday about election campaign violence in Bulgaria, and the White House said President Bush plans to post a new ambassador there. Richard Boucher, the State Department's deputy spokesman, urged ``all political groups to abstain from violence and intimidation'' as Bulgarians head to the polls Sunday in the country's first multi-party elections since World War II. ``We also emphasize that the Bulgarian government must take a strong stand against intimidation and violence,'' he said. Bulgaria is moving toward democracy after more than four decades of communist rule. Boucher called for an investigation into reports of fatalities under mysterious circumstances. President Bush intends to nominate Hugh Kenneth Hill, a career envoy, as the next ambassador to Sofia, the White House announced. Hill, if confirmed, would succeed Sol Polansky, whose three-year term in the Sofia post ends in September. Hill, 52, is chief of the State Department's senior officer division. He was deputy chief of mission in Sofia in 1982-84. Polansky journeyed to Copenhagen, Denmark, to brief Secretary of State James A. Baker III, on Tuesday about reports of election violence and intimidation by the ruling Bulgarian Socialist Party, formerly the communists. Meanwhile, a U.S. delegation to monitor the election left on a six-day mission to Bulgaria. It is chaired by Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon. Also on the delegation are: Polansky; Jack Perry, a former U.S. ambassador to Bulgaria who now teaches political science at Davidson College in North Carolina; Richard D. McLellan, a lawyer from Michigan; Marshall L. Miller, a lawyer from Washington, D.C., and Eunice B. Whittlesey, a Republican National Committeewoman from New York. Bellmon was joined by his wife, Shirley, on the mission.

DOC.HEAD: One Killed, Three Wounded in Luxury Car Drive-By Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen firing from a limousine killed a man and wounded three other people in an apparent street gang attack, police said Wednesday. The assailants got away late Tuesday after firing a volley of at least 10 shots, Detective J.D. Furr said. The victims were standing in front of a home in the city's gang-plagued south-central area. Robert Lewis Riley Jr., 19, was shot in the chest and died at the scene. A 15-year-old boy was in serious condition at County-USC Medical Center with a chest wound. A 28-year-old man, wounded in the right leg and hand, and a 20-year-old man shot in the left leg and right foot were in good condition at Martin Luther King Jr.-Drew Medical Center.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Dangle from Bridge to Protest Battleship Arrival
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with battleship passing, fresh quotes and protest details; picks up 8th graf pvs, `The New ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto pursuing
DOC.TEXT: Eight Greenpeace protesters dangled from the 205-foot-high Astoria Bridge on Wednesday in a futile effort to block the battleship USS New Jersey from entering the Columbia River. The protesters hung about 50 feet below the 4{-mile-long bridge and unfurled banners that read, ``Nuclear Free Seas.'' The 887-foot battleship waited offshore to enter the river as authorities tried unsuccessfully to dislodge the protesters. The activists raised themselves on ropes when a freighter approached, said state police Detective Mike Schacher. They remained high enough to clear the ship when the New Jersey came through later and ``a couple of them went up a little higher,'' he said. Greenpeace spokeswoman Cynthia Rust said the protest was to ``prevent the USS New Jersey from endangering the health and safety of the citizens of Oregon and Washington by bringing nuclear weapons'' up the Columbia. She noted that voters have declared coastal Clatsop County a ``nuclear free zone.'' Schacher said police did not plan to physically hoist the protesters into custody. ``We can get to them, but we're not going to,'' he said. ``The reason for that is the safety of our people and for them.'' The protesters would be arrested ``at such time as they either come down or come up,'' Schacher said. He said the demonstrators had enough rope to lower themselves into Greenpeace rafts on the river. ``I think they're just going to hang around, literally,'' Schacher said. Ms. Rust said the protesters planned to raise themselves to the bridge one at a time, but did not say when. ``We feel our protest was a huge success,'' she said. ``Our intention was not to endanger the vessel or endanger the climbers.'' The protesters face state criminal tresspassing charges and federal charges of violating the 200-yard safety zone around the ship, Schacher said. Greenpeace wasn't certain what kind of weapons were aboard the New Jersey. The Navy has a policy of not commenting on whether its vessels are carrying nuclear arms. The New Jersey is renowned for its 16-inch guns, each of which is capable of delivering nearly a ton of high explosives at a rate of one shell every 30 seconds. Firing of the guns and those aboard the three other Iowa-class battleships has been suspended pending investigation of an April 19, 1989, explosion on the USS Iowa that killed 47. The New Jersey was en route to Portland, where it planned to join 30 other ships that traditionally tie up at the waterfront for the Rose Festival.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Late President Nasser Arrested on Return to Egypt
DOC.TEXT: The eldest son of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser was arrested Wednesday after flying in for his trial in connection with terrorist attacks against Israeli and U.S. diplomats, the Middle East News Agency reported. The charges against Khaled Abdel Nasser, 40, an engineer and a professor at Cairo University, and 19 other defendants stemmed from attacks that left two Israeli diplomats dead and six Israelis and two Americans injured. Nasser and 10 others were charged with murder, undermining Egypt's security and damaging its relations with Israel and the United States. The indictment demanded they be condemned to death. The state-owned MENA news agency said Nasser was arrested immediately after he arrived at Cairo International Airport, but gave no details. Nasser was known to be living in self-imposed exile in Yugoslavia. He was outside Egypt when he and the others, alleged members of a group calling itself Egypt's Revolution, were indicted in February 1988. Nasser had protested his innocence in newspaper interviews in Yugoslavia and pledged to return to attend the trial, which started in November 1988. Also listed as a defendant was Mahmoud Nour el-Din el-Sayed Ali Suliman, a businessman and former administrator at the Egyptian embassy in London. Nasser, whose father was president from 1958-70, was specifically charged with helping form the group and providing members with weapons and money. Nine defendants, including President Nasser's nephew, Gamal Shawky Abdel Nasser, were charged with complicity of various kinds and could be sentenced on conviction to prison terms of up to 25 years. Egypt's Revolution has claimed responsibility for three attacks on Israeli diplomatic personnel, in 1984, 1985 and 1986, in which gunmen killed two Israelis and wounded six. Two American diplomats among three diplomats attacked in May 1987 by gunmen riding in a passing car. The two suffered minor injuries.

DOC.HEAD: China Frees More Protesters, But Official Attitudes Unchanged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS two grafs for 18th graf, `Most of,' to UPDATE with Yao back in Hong Kong. Picks up 19th graf pvs, `Xinhua said...'
DOC.TEXT: China freed 97 pro-democracy protesters, including two student leaders, after the anniversary of the June 4 army attack on last year's demonstrations passed without major unrest, officials said Wednesday. The releases bring to 881 the number freed the past six months, out of thousands arrested. But new arrests have been reported as recently as last week, and the releases did not signal a softening by the aging leadership. The leaders still maintain last spring's massive protests for democratic reform and an end to corruption were part of a coup attempt and that Western-style democracy is inappropriate for China. Rather, the leaders appeared to be trying to put the protests behind them and improve their image at home and abroad. China's most-favored-nation trade status remains under review in the U.S. Congress, and foreign tourism and investment far below their pre-June 1989 level. There still was no word on the fate of three participants in last year's movement who dropped out of sight last week, as they planned to issue an open letter to the leadership calling for the release of jailed protesters. The three had been the only Chinese to continue speaking openly for democratic reform. Two of the three, Gao Xin and Zhou Duo, were jailed after the June crackdown and released in December and May, respectively. The third was well-known folk singer Hou Dejian. Sources indicated they were taken into police custody, possibly as a protective move before the June 4 anniversary. Three Beijing University students were arrested May 25 for alleged counterrevolutionary activities. The latest prisoner release, announced by the official Xinhua News Agency, included for the first time two top student leaders. Xiong Wei and Zhou Fengsuo, both students at Qinghua University in Beijing, were arrested last June after being included on the government's list of 21 most-wanted students. Zhou was turned in by his sister and Xiong surrendered in his mother's company, according to official accounts. The No. 1 student on the list, Wang Dan, remains in jail. Xinhua said 19 other students also were freed. Most of the releases were from Beijing jails, but 21 were freed in Shanghai. Among those was Yao Yongzhan, a Hong Kong student who was released Tuesday, according to the Hong Kong government. Yao, who was arrested at Shanghai airport in June 1989 as he was about to board a flight to Hong Kong, returned to the British colony Wednesday. Xinhua said the 97 were given lenient treatment after having ``voluntarily confessed their wrongdoings and expressed a willingness to repent.'' None had been charged or tried. It said the government combined punishment with leniency in dealing with the protesters, ``and made every effort to educate those who can be educated. Those who obstinately stick to an incorrect course and refuse to repent will be punished strictly in accordance with the law.'' In another deveopment, grass-roots Communist Party committees in a region of China where a minority rebellion occurred in April will undergo a shake-up. The Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region party committee ``will spend the next two to three years carrying out a rectification of party grass-roots organizations and grass-roots power,'' the Xinjiang Daily newspaper said. Rectification is the party's euphemism for an intense investigation followed by purges of anyone failing to measure up to the political standard. Moslem ethnic minorities declared a holy war in April in Baren Township in Xinjiang, near the western border with the Soviet Union. Official reports say 22 died in an attempt to set up an independent republic of East Turkistan. The attempt was put down by soldiers and armed police.

DOC.HEAD: Grenade Thrown At U.S. Embassy In Somalia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to clarify that grenade did explode
DOC.TEXT: Someone threw a grenade last week at the U.S. Embassy in Somalia, and U.S. officials are concerned about growing anarchy in the strategically placed African country, a U.S. official said on Wednesday. The grenade, which exploded without significant damage or injuries, was lobbed into the embassy compound by an unknown assailant, an administration official said. The embassy complex, the largest in sub-Saharan Africa, boasts three swimming pools and a nine-hole golf course. The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the seaside capital has been beset in recent months by fuel shortages, water and electricity interruptions, and rampant crime. ``The security situation is at a nadir,'' he said. Foreign reporters are usually denied access to Somalia, at the tip of the Horn of Africa on the eastern approaches to the Red Sea, and reliable information about the situation there is hard to obtain. The government of Siad Barre has been losing power over the past year to various coalitions of rebels fighting to unseat the aging, often-ruthless leader. ``The military is just not defeating them,'' said the official. Despite the deterioration of security and the widespread opposition to Barre, U.S. officials do not think he will be toppled in the near future. ``Somalia is unstable, but we're not expecting anything like that imminently,'' the official said. One reason is the disunity among the rebel groups and the lack of a leader with sufficient popularity or clout to replace Barre, who seized power in a 1968 coup. Barre's repressive government has become increasingly isolated and the United States, once one of Somalia's main backers, has cut off virtually all aid. Plans call for the U.S. Embassy staff of 430 to be reduced by half by year's end. The United States still has an agreement to use the Somali port of Berbera as a contingency base in case of an emergency in the region. Human rights groups say that as Barre's control has slipped, his abuses have grown in an effort to exert control. A three-member delegation from Amnesty International will leave for Mogadishu on Saturday to discuss ``gross violations of human rights'' with Somali authorities, an official with the human rights organization said. The group last visited in June 1989. A report commissioned by the State Department last summer concluded that the Somali army murdered at least 5,000 people over an 11-month period.

DOC.HEAD: Severe Thunderstorms Move Through Central Plains; Storm Along West Coast
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms boomed through the central Plains on Wednesday and into the mid-Mississippi Valley, spawning tornadoes in parts of Indiana and Kentucky, and a storm stretched along much of the West Coast. Neither state reported injuries or major damage from the severe weather. But cleanup work was halted and the first burial of one of Saturday's tornado victims was cut short Wednesday as nervous residents in Petersburg, Ind., took cover from a threatening thunderstorm. The memory of Saturday night was still fresh in the minds of many. Six people were killed as a tornado tore through the city, damaging or destroying two-thirds of the community. Two others were killed elsewhere as tornadoes skipped across southern and central sections of Indiana. Rain fell in Missouri, with Kansas City reporting at least 2 and St. Louis up to 4 inches. Missouri's Clay County reported flash flooding, as 5 inches of rain fell; flash flooding was also reported in southwestern Illinois. More than a half-inch of rain fell along the Oregon coast; Washington state and northwestern California also had precipitation. The Southwest remained quite hot; by early afternoon the temperature was more than 100 degrees in Lubbock, Texas, and Carlsbad, N.M. The weather was chilly in the Northeast and East. Temperatures dipped into the 20s and 30s in sections of Maine. It was 53 degrees in Cape Hatteras, N.C., a new record for the date. Winds gusted over 50 mph in Southern California, causing a dust storm in the Rosamond area of Kern County. Temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 102 at Carlsbad to 26 at Guilford, Maine. Thursday's forecast called for showers from the northern Rockies into the northern Plains, and showers and thunderstorms from the Midwest to the Chesapeake Bay. High pressure was expected to produce dry weather from Minnesota to the Great Lakes.

DOC.HEAD: Protocol Chief Slams Minnesota Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 2nd graf to include denial from Minnesota governor.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's protocol chief, Joseph Reed, Wednesday accused Minnesota Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich of behaving ``very badly'' in barring the state's two Republican senators from a luncheon for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. ``It was my understanding with Governor Perpich that they were to be invited. As far as I'm concerned he reneged on that understanding,'' Reed told reporters at he White House. In St. Paul, Minn., Perpich angrily denied that he ever agreed the senators would be invited to the Gorbachev luncheon. ``I feel very badly that such a successful visit could be marred by petty politics,'' the governor said. Reed said Sens. David Durenburger and Rudy Boschwitz showed up at the door of the governor's mansion and were turned away from Sunday's luncheon for the visiting Soviet VIPs. They were directed instead to a luncheon next door for other politicians who were not invited, said Reed, the State Department official who was sent along by President Bush to help facilitate Gorbachev's swing through Minnesota and San Francisco after the Soviet leader left Washington last Sunday. ``And when I learned this, there was nothing that could be done,'' Reed said of the slight to the two senators. ``After all, I was only a guest also, I was not the host. So I urged directly with President Gorbachev that he meet the two senators and the entire congressional delegation, which he did following the luncheon.'' Gorbachev held a hastily arranged hand-shaking session with the senators and other members of Congress who had been excluded from the lunch. ``The governor of Minnesota behaved very badly,'' Reed said, citing the incident as the only flaw in Gorbachev's visit to the United States. The two senators were not neglected by Gorbachev. Both were invited to fly with him from Washington to Minnesota. Only Boschwitz could accept, and he had a long conversation with Gorbachev on the flight.

DOC.HEAD: One Dead In Derailment
DOC.TEXT: A train smashed into a tractor-trailer rig Wednesday, killing the driver of a pickup truck crushed by one of 15 cars that derailed, authorities said. The collision occurred around 3 p.m. at a rail crossing on a dirt road off Alabama 69, said Tuscaloosa County Sheriff's Deputy Richard Greene. The truck didn't stop at the crossing and the train smashed into the trailer, Greene said. One of three train engines that derailed toppled onto a pickup traveling on a road alongside the tracks, killing the truck's driver, authorities said. The victim's name was withheld pending notification of relatives. The tractor-trailer's driver and the three men aboard the train were not hurt, Greene said. Twelve other train cars derailed. The crossing had no lights or crossing gates, but was marked and the train's engineer told authorities he was blowing his horn as he approached, Greene said. No charges had been filed, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Venezuelan Soldier Charged American Tourist's Death
DOC.TEXT: A soldier has been charged with the shooting death of American tourist Thomas Atkinson and is awaiting trial in the military prison of La Pica, U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Barbara Moore confirmed Wednesday. She did not identify the soldier, but said he had been held since the death last February of Atkinson, a teacher from Wellington, N.Y. Formal charges were filed two weeks ago. This was the account received by the embassy: A group of U.S. tourists were being driven to the Caribbean resort city of Puerto La Cruz when they were stopped at a military checkpoint, where soldiers were fumigating vehicles as part of a Health Ministry campaign to stop a dengue epidemic from spreading. An argument broke out when the driver refused to have the minivan fumigated, and the driver stepped on the gas and tried to escape. The soldier fired at the fleeing van, hitting Atkinson, who was in the back seat. Atkinson died hours later after an emergency operation at a Puerto La Cruz hospital. A warrant was issued charging the minivan driver with ``verbal abuse and trying to run over the soldier,'' Ms. Moore told The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Judge Orders Arrest of English Mercenaries
DOC.TEXT: A judge ordered the arrest of five Englishmen on Wednesday for questioning about their alleged training of a drug trafficker's private army. A communique from the administrative offices for federal courts in Bogota identified the five as Peter Stuart MacLeese, Brian David Tomkins, Andrew Gibson, Dean Shelley and John Owen. A judicial source told The Associated Press all five are presumed to have left Colombia in 1989 after allegedly giving weapons training in 1988 and 1989 to men working for Medellin drug cartel leader Gonzalo Rodriguez. Rodriguez was killed last Dec. 15 in a gunbattle with police. The judge has asked the Foreign Ministry to extradite the five to Colombia, the source said. Names of judges handling cases involving drug traffickers are not made public lest the judges be singled out for death. The court source spoke on condition of anonymity for the same reason.

DOC.HEAD: West German Elected Mayor of Leipzig, East Germany
DOC.TEXT: A West German official was voted in Wednesday as new mayor of East Germany's second largest city, Leipzig. Heinrich Lehmann-Grube, 57, a left-leaning Social Democrat and former city director of Hanover in West Germany, drew 88 of 118 votes in the Leipzig city council. He was given a leave of absence to run for the job, previously held by Guenter Haedrich, a former member of East Germany's old Communist party. Leipzig, with 550,000 people, is second to East Berlin, with 1.2 million residents. Leipzig was the cradle of East Germany's pro-democracy movement. Lehmann-Grube is the second West German to be chosen mayor of an East German city since the country's first democratic elections in March. West German businessman Dieter Noll, a member of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative Christian Democratic Union, was elected mayor of the former city of Karl-Marx-Stadt last week, when the city was officialy renamed Chemnitz. The city population is 308,000.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS ``shutter'' to ``shudder'' in 7th graf: ``If it,''
DOC.HEAD: Army, Pilots Praise Night Goggles
DOC.TEXT: Army officials and two pilots involved in the U.S. invasion of Panama hailed the use of night-vision goggles Wednesday as lawmakers expressed concerns about accidents when the devices were used. ``The U.S. Army and Army Aviation own the night,'' Maj. Gen. Rudolph Ostovich III, commanding general of the U.S. Army Aviation Center, told a House panel. The Army officials said use of the goggles during the December nighttime incursion provided the U.S. military with a significant advantage in stopping the Panamanian Defense Forces. Night-vision goggles electronically amplify moonlight and starlight, displaying images on two tiny video screens. Capt. Tim Jones, whose helicopter was shot down during the invasion, said he was in the area near Fort Amador for 20 minutes, seeking out the enemy before his craft was fired upon. He attributed the shootdown to a gunner sweeping the area or firing in the vicinity where he could hear helicopters. ``If it had been the daytime, I shudder to think what the results may have been had they been able to see us as well as the 20 plus other helicopters that came into that area,'' Jones said. Chief Warrant Officer Larry Mann, who has worked with night-vision goggles for 10 years, said without the devices it would have been ``a lot more catastrophic for us.'' Rep. Frank McCloskey, D-Ind., an outspoken critic of the goggles, said the use of the devices apparently contributed to the success of U.S. invasion, but stressed that there was no excuse for unsafe training procedures. McCloskey noted recent statistics that show 7.7 night-vision goggles accidents per 100,000 flying hours for the third and fourth quarters of 1989 and the first quarter of 1990. The Army's overall flight accident rate is 1.8 accidents per 100,000 hours. The lawmaker said that since March 1988, there have been 22 accidents and 70 deaths. ``I realize semantic differences exist between myself and the Pentagon as to whether a specific accident was caused by the goggles or by pilot error,'' McCloskey said. ``However, the goggle technology, while impressive, does have limitations and these limitations must be recognized when the goggles are used in aviation.''

DOC.HEAD: Communist Albania Says It Will Adhere to Human Rights Accords
DOC.TEXT: Communist Albania pledged Wednesday to adopt basic reforms _ short of free elections _ and seek equal status with the 35 nations that signed the Helsinki security and human rights accords. Albanian representatives to an East-West human rights meeting said their country would also seek full membership in the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe ``as soon as possible.'' Adhering to the Helsinki agreements and joining the conference would be major steps for the isolated Balkan nation of 3 million, the sole remaining hard-line Communist country in Eastern Europe after democratic reforms swept across its East bloc neighbors the past year. ``The game is that we adopt all the rules of the conference and, of course, take care to accept what has been accepted by the other participating counrties,'' said Petriti Bushati, Albania's ambassador to Sweden, who led the delegation. But he said Albania needed a transition period to study the international conventions, which it would have to affirm as a condition for membership. A consensus of conference members would be required to admit Albania. On Tuesday, the delegation was granted observer status to a conference meeting. The 35 nations are holding a four-week session to consider proposals on political pluralism and the rule of law in the member states. Albania is the only nation in Europe that refused to sign the 1975 Helsinki agreements. The group also includes the United States and Canada. Despite some reforms, Albania has no intention to hold multiparty elections, Bejo Sazan, an Albanian Foreign Ministry official, told a news conference. Sazan said Albania had no history of organized political opposition, and he claimed the ruling Communist Party represented the interests of all the people. ``No society anywhere, where there is full approval of the government by the people, (would) artificially create an opposition to this government,'' he said. ``We cannot see what will happen in 50 years or 100 years, but that is the situation today in Albania.'' There were reports earlier this year of politically or economically inspired riots outside the capital, but they were never confirmed by the government. Asked about political prisoners, Bushati confirmed 85 prisoners are being held, but said they were guilty of using violence to try to overthrow the government. Albania announced a series of reforms last month, including freer travel for its citizens and abolition of restrictions on religious publications. It also adopted economic reforms relaxing government control over enterprises. Premier Adil Carcani told the Parliament in Tirana in May that Albania wanted to join the conference and establish diplomatic relations with the United States, the Soviet Union and the members of the European Community.

DOC.HEAD: British Bandleader Joe Loss Dead at 80
DOC.TEXT: Bandleader Joe Loss, a favorite of Britain's royal family, died in a London hospital Wednesday, his agent said. Loss was 80 and recently celebrated his 60th anniversary in the music business. He had suffered from kidney problems, agent Robert Holmes said. Loss was born Joshua Alexander Loss, the son of a cabinetmaker who wanted him to become a classical violinist. Loss' first job was playing the violin in silent films for about $2.50 a week. He was fascinated by dance band music and at 20 became Britain's youngest band leader, playing at the Astoria Ballroom in Charing Cross Road in London. Loss once said he had married more couples than any clergyman because of the number of people who wed after meeting at his dances. The Joe Loss Orchestra played many years on the cruise ship Queen Elizabeth II and entertained the royal family at Buckingham Palace and Windsor Castle. Dame Vera Lynn was accompanied by Loss' band on her first radio broadcast. His signature tune ``In the Mood,'' sold 1 million copies. Loss claimed the secret of his long career was his energetic foot-tapping. ``I once put on a pedometer and discovered that I had walked eight miles in a three-hour performance,'' he said. Loss announced his retirement last year, but played in London in February and had planned more appearances.

DOC.HEAD: Company Admits Making False Statements in Providing Steel for Army Copter
DOC.TEXT: An aerospace company accused of providing cheaper, less durable steel for the Army's Apache attack helicopter for nearly six years has agreed to pay $232,518 in fines and restitution, the government announced Wednesday. Royce Aerospace Material Corp., of North Amityville, N.Y., pleaded guilty to one count of making false statements, the U.S. attorney's office said in a statement. Sentencing was set for Aug. 13 before U.S. District Judge Paul G. Rosenblatt. The government said Royce provided a different type of steel than that specified to a subcontractor for AH-64 Apache helicopters made by McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Co. of Mesa. The substituted steel wears out sooner and costs less than the specified type, the government said. The substitution had been taking place from 1983 through 1989, and had cost the government $77,000, the U.S. attorney's office said. ``In an effort to disguise the subsitution, Royce provided false certification and false documents to the subcontractor,'' the U.S. attorney's office said.

DOC.HEAD: City Finds $500 Celebration Dinner (for Two) Hard to Swallow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Moran eventually ...,' to UPDATE with civil service board upholding punishment.
DOC.TEXT: For his 20 years of service, city employee James Moran was awarded a plaque and a certificate for a free dinner for two. After three lobster tails, 33 orders of jumbo shrimp cocktail, four dozen steamed oysters and an assortment of steaks and other seafood, Moran and his date amassed a $510 bill _ and the city was stuck with the tab. ``When somebody goes out and does something like this it's a shame,'' City Manager Gene Strickland said Tuesday. ``It absolutely flabbergasted me. ... It only takes one person to mess up a good program for everyone else.'' Moran's supervisors at Lakeland Electric and Water also were not amused. They recommended he be fired from his $38,771-a-year job. City officials modified the punishment to a two-week suspension and a demotion that will cut Moran's pay by more than $11,000 a year. Moran eventually paid the April 19 dinner bill himself and appealed his suspension and demotion Wednesday before the city's civil service board, which voted to uphold the punishment. He could not be reached for comment, but his attorney, Robert Grizzard II, defended his client's heavy meal. Moran enjoys spending lavishly on an occasional night on the town, and he and his fiancee have spent $200 or more for dinner on other occasions, Grizzard said. ``They ordered lots of food and had a wonderful time,'' Grizzard said. ``They were told there was no limit on the ticket so they didn't worry about it.'' Meals, service pins and retirement plaques are paid out of the city's employee service award account. Of the 22 free meals given out last year, the highest bill totaled $60, the lowest about $34.

DOC.HEAD: 22 Killed When Plane Crashes Just Short of Amazon Airfield
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with more deaths, airline revising count of those on board, account by survivor. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A turboprop plane carrying 42 people crashed Wednesday in a jungle clearing just short of an airport in the eastern Amazon, and an airline official said 22 people died. The plane nosedived about a half-mile short of the runway in the Amazon city of Altamira, said Roberto Saquette, a spokesman for TABA airlines. Altamira is 2,100 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. Nineteen passengers and the co-pilot were killed on impact and the pilot and a passenger died en route to the hospital, Saquette said by telephone late Wednesday. ``There was no warning,'' crew member Rodolfo Lopes de Miranda told the Manchete TV network. ``There was a great screeching noise and the floor rose up and threw us up against the ceiling. Then everything went black.'' Another TABA spokesman, Odacil Catele, said: ``There was no explosion on impact and the plane didn't catch fire. God was with them.'' Officials have not determined the cause of the crash, Catele said. Soldiers from the Altamira army base pulled survivors from the wreckage and carried them on stretchers to army jeeps. The air force later transported all 20 survivors 460 miles to the Amazon port of Belem, where they were in satisfactory condition at the Air Force Hospital, Saquette said. The plane, a British-made Foch-Hiller turboprop, took off from Belem for Altamira, the first of five stops. The route also included stopovers in the Amazon cities of Santarem, Itaituba, Alta Floresta and Cuiaba.
