DOC.HEAD: Baltic Presidents Ask Gorbachev to Start Talks
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of the Baltic states of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia asked President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday to open talks at once on their drives for independence, a Latvian spokesman said. The Council of Baltic States ``appeals to you, Mr. President, to call a joint meeting without delay to define the issues and the order of full negotiations,'' the telegram said. Aris Jansons, an aide to Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov, translated the telegram unofficially in a telephone interview from the republic's capital of Riga, where the three presidents signed it. The meeting was the second gathering of the council since it was re-established last month. It came a day after Gorbachev returned from the superpower summit in Washington to face renewed unrest in the southern Soviet Union and impasse in the Baltics. Gorbachev's tough stance with the Baltics, particularly Lithuania, has brought him censure from the West, but President Bush still signed an agreement with him last week opening the way to trade benefits for the Soviet Union. Members of the U.S. Congress, however, predict Bush will have a hard time gaining needed support for the measure as long as Gorbachev refuses to negotiate with Lithuania. At a news conference after the signing, presidents Gorbunov of Latvia, Vytautas Landsbergis of Lithuania and Arnold Ruutel of Estonia generally reserved judgment on what effect the superpower summit would have on the secessionist Baltic region. But Jansons said Gorbunov noted because neither Gorbachev nor Bush appeared to have changed his position on the issue, ``in that sense we can conclude that the summit in Washington was nothing new for us.'' Landsbergis said it was too early to predict what the summit's effect would be, and Ruutel said it may help strengthen Soviet democracy, said Jansons. He said they kept their remarks brief and did not go into specifics. Lithuania declared its independence on March 11, and Latvia and Estonia have since announced the beginning of transition periods to full independence. Gorbachev clamped a partial economic blockade on Lithuania in response and refused to recognize Latvian and Estonian independence moves. He told Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania he would not open negotiations with her republic until it suspended its declaration. The Baltic Council also ratified a pledge Wednesday that non-native permanent residents of the republics would be guaranteed full human rights, Jansons said. Many Russians in the Baltic republics say they fear they may become second-class citizens or be forced to leave when the three states become fully independent. The telegram to Gorbachev complained that delays in settling relations between the Baltics and the Kremlin have led to ``the disorder of the economy and abnormal relations between peoples,'' Jansons said. In Latvia, panic buying spurred by fears that the Kremlin would include it in the partial blockade prompted authorities to introduce rationing on several food items last week. In Lithuania, more than 400 factories have cut back their working hours and about 50,000 people have been laid off, reports said. The three independent Baltic states were annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. They revived their pre-World War II alliance on May 12; it was orginally established in 1934.

DOC.HEAD: Doe Reported to Ask Help in Leaving Liberia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. officials now saying that Doe did not ask for help in leaving country but assistance in dealing with rebellion; picks up 3rd graf pvs, bgng: Meanwhile, other ...
DOC.TEXT: Liberian President Samuel K. Doe has asked the United States to help him deal with an increasingly powerful rebel movement that threatens to topple his government, an administration official said on Wednesday. The official said earlier Wednesday that Doe has asked for help in getting out of the country. But that same official later said he was unsure of his facts and knew only that Doe had sent a letter asking for help in resolving the issue. U.S. diplomats told Doe he should attempt to reach an accommodation with insurgent leaders, said the official, who asked not to be identified. Meanwhile, other officials said the administration is arranging special flights to allow several hundred American citizens to leave Liberia because of the deteriorating situation there. The officials said the U.S. government is in contact with an air carrier that will fly the Americans to the neighboring Ivory Coast from where they will be flown to the United States. The intermediate stop in the Ivory Coast is necessary because the biggest airport still operating in Liberia is too small to accommodate large jetliners. The operation is expected to begin on Saturday. But some Americans are expected to be on two regularly scheduled Air Guinea international flights Thursday and another on Friday. The State Department is strongly urging all of the more than 3,000 Americans still in Liberia to leave the country because of the concerns about personal safety. The U.S. Navy has a four-ship flotilla in international waters off the Liberian coast to evacuate the Americans and possibly foreign diplomats if departures cannot be carried out through commercial means. In response to a request from the Soviet Union, the United States has said it would be willing to include Soviet diplomats along with others in any evacuation, State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said. Commenting on Doe's situation, the officials said the State Department has been quietly asking several African countries whether they would be willing to provide him with a safe haven if he is forced to flee. The officials refused to say which countries have been approached or what the responses were. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater had no comment on U.S. diplomatic efforts in Liberia except to say that both the government and the rebels have been asked to find a way to end their conflict. The inquiries about a safe haven for Doe underscore the administration's impression that his 10-year old rule will not survive much longer and that what began as a tiny rebel movement last December probably will assume power shortly. The rebels have seized the headquarters of the world's largest rubber plantation owned by the Japanese tire-maker Bridgestone Corp., Liberia's biggest employer, and are now believed to control every major industrial concern in the West African country. The officials said there is little in the background of the rebel leader, Charles Taylor, to suggest a strong commitment to democratic principles. The extent to which the rebels have been able to generate support is less a reflection of Taylor's appeal than of the widespread opposition to Doe's government, according to the officials. Doe is widely accused of mismanaging the economy. His problems have been compounded by tribal divisions and mass desertions from the Liberian army. Taylor, 42, is a former high Liberian government official who five years ago escaped from a Massachusetts prison where he was awaiting extradition to his homeland on charges he had embezzled millions of dollars in public funds. Taylor, who has studied in the United States, has denied U.S. charges that his group received backing from Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. Historically, the United States has had close ties with Liberia because the country was founded by descendants of freed U.S. slaves more than 150 years ago. Liberia also serves as a center for U.S. military communications and as a relay station for Voice of America broadcasts to Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Desegregation Lawsuit After Nine-Year Battle
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Justice Department was considering its next move Wednesday after a federal judge threw out a desegregation lawsuit against the Charleston County School District. U.S. District Judge Sol Blatt Jr. late Tuesday dismissed the 1981 lawsuit, which challenged a 1967 law creating the nearly 43,000-student countywide school district. In another decades-old desegregation battle, school officials in Jacksonville, Fla., and NAACP leaders agreed on a countywide desegregation plan with reduced mandatory busing. In the South Carolina case, Blatt found no intent to discriminate by state lawmakers who passed the 1967 law. He ruled that some schools in the district remain predominantly black because of the makeup of neighborhoods, geography and decisions by white parents to put their students in private schools. Justice Department spokeswoman Amy Casner said the department was reviewing the decision and had not decided whether to appeal. Notice of appeal must generally be made within 60 days, she said in a telephone interview from Washington. The 1967 act created a countywide school board to oversee eight local school districts and spread tax money among them. The local boards retained control of faculty and student assignments, however, making it ``slightly more difficult'' to achieve greater desegregation, Blatt found. The Justice Department, later joined by The NAACP Legal Defense and Education Fund, asked that the local districts be abolished and Blatt order a better integration plan. Fifty-six percent of the district's 42,774 students are black; 35 percent of the black students attend classes in schools that are 90 percent black. But Blatt said this was not necessarily evidence of illegal segregation. It is possible that even without the local districts, ``true integration would be impossible in Charleston County because of its rather unique geography,'' the judge wrote. ``With all of its rivers and bridges and its nearly 100-mile area, extensive busing would be extremely dangerous,'' he said. Blatt's decision followed years of delays in the case, and 11 months of arguments in a non-jury trial involving 80 witnesses and more than 2,600 exhibits. Arthur McFarland, an attorney representing student plaintiffs in the case, said the decision will have to be reviewed before an appeal is considered. In Jacksonville, the Duval County School Board and U.S. District Judge John H. Moore II must approve the agreement school officials reached with the local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. It would eliminate the busing of some 14,000 students, change groupings of grade levels, provide $60 million for inner-city school improvements and set up programs to attract students of all races to schools that have predominantly black enrollments. Superintendent Larry Zenke called the agreement reached Tuesday after almost six months of negotiations a ``win-win'' proposition for both sides. The Rev. Henry Green, president of a coalition of about 60 black ministers, said black residents must ``take a wait-and-see attitude to make sure that promises that have been made are kept, because so many promises that have been made in the past have been broken.'' Duval County was ordered by a federal judge in the early 1960s to desegregate its schools. Court-ordered crosstown busing began in 1971, and the NAACP sued again in 1985, claiming the school system was not fully desegregated. Moore ruled in 1988 that students in Duval County were getting an equal education, but last fall an appeals court disagreed and placed the school system back under court review, leading to the recent negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Four Honored, Including Reporter Killed While Investigating Drug Lords
DOC.TEXT: The 10th annual Livingston Awards for Young Journalists were given Wednesday to four journalists, including a special posthumous citation for a reporter killed while investigating drug lords and revolutionaries in South America. Todd Smith, a columnist and reporter for The Tampa (Fla.) Tribune, was nominated for a story published in September connecting Peru's ``Shining Path'' guerrillas to drug lords in Colombia. While following up the story in Peru, Smith was kidnapped Nov. 17; his body was found on a soccer field in Uchiza, Peru, four days later. The Livingston Foundation created the posthumous award for Smith, who would have been 30. Peter Gumbel, 32, a Wall Street Journal reporter in Moscow, won the award for international reporting for a story on the perils of perestroika. Tom Ashbrook, 34, foreign editor of The Boston Globe, was awarded the national reporting prize for a story on how Asia was moving ahead of the United States in the world. Michele Norris, 28, of The Washington Post, won the local reporting prize for a story on a 6-year-old boy's life at home with a crack-addicted mother. More than 500 entries were submitted by editors from stories published or broadcast in 1989. Each winner receives a citation and $5,000. The awards are administered by the foundation at the University of Michigan and are meant to encourage excellence among journalists under 35.

DOC.HEAD: Visa Requirement Dropped for Argentina, East Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th pvs, `The two...' to UPDATE with OAS call for Argentina, Britain to resolve further differences. Pickup 7th pvs, `Argentine forces...'
DOC.TEXT: Argentines and East Germans no longer require visas to enter Britain, the Home Office said Wednesday. The requirement will be dropped as of Thursday, said the Home Office, which is responsible for immigration regulations. The lifting of the curbs on East German citizens follows a joint agreement signed by Common Market countries last month. There has been no announcement from Argentina that it will allow British citizens to travel there without visas, but such an announcement is expected. An agreement signed earlier this year by Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd and his Argentine counterpart, Domingo Cavallo, paved the way for the restrictions to be lifted. The two met in February, and agreed to restore diplomatic links broken during the Falklands war. Direct air travel had resumed earlier. In a related development Wednesday, the Organization of American States urged Argentina and Britain to continue negotiation until ``they reach definitive solution to all their differences'' over the Falklands Islands. None of the British-Argentine negotiations nor the steps taken so far imply any change in Argentina's clim to sovereignty over the islands, Argentine delegate Juan Pablo Lohle told the OAS, which is meeting in Asuncion, Paraguay. Britain has ruled the Falklands since 1833, but Argentina, which calls the islands the Malvinas, claims it inherited them upon declaring independence from Spain in 1810. Argentine forces in 1982 seized the Falklands, 300 miles off Argentina's southeast coast, but a British task force retook the islands during the 74-day war, in which 712 Argentines, 255 Britons and three islanders were killed. A peace treaty was not signed until February.

DOC.HEAD: Legislative Panel Considers Abortion Bill
DOC.TEXT: Lawmakers took testimony Wednesday on a bill intended to test the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. A gynecologist who said she stopped performing abortions because she felt like she was working in a slaughterhouse was among the witnesses who appeared before the state House Criminal Justice Committee. ``I just asked myself one day, `What am I doing ripping apart these beautifully formed bodies?''' testified Dr. Beverly McMillan of Jackson, Miss. The Louisiana Legislature has a history of enacting tough abortion laws, all of which have been stayed or declared unconstitutional over the past 15 years. Opponents of the latest bill acknowledge it will pass and be used to take advantage of what anti-abortion activists hope is a readiness on the increasingly conservative Supreme Court to reverse its 1973 decision. The Supreme Court, in effect, ruled in Roe vs. Wade that ``nobody can know at what moment life begins,'' geneticist Jerome Lejeune of Paris testified Wednesday. But, in the past 17 years geneticists have proven that ``the precise starting moment is the time that all genetic information is gathered in the fertilized egg,'' Lejeune said. That moment is conception, he said. Lejeune's testimony in a Tennessee case was instrumental in a ruling last year that seven frozen embryos were human beings with constitutional rights. That ruling will be considered by a state appeals court. The committee was to hear testimony from opponents of the bill on Thursday, then take action. Rep. Woody Jenkins, a leader of the anti-abortion effort, pleaded with the committee not to amend the bill with exceptions, such as for cases of rape and incest, which he said would be inconsistent with past Louisiana law. The bill makes an exception only to save the life of the mother. Gov. Buddy Roemer, a Democrat, has said he will veto any bill that does not also make exceptions for victims of rape and incest and to protect the health of the mother.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Troops Kill Rebel Commander, U.S. Arranging Exit Flights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Bush administration official correcting earlier statement to stay Doe seeking U.S. help, not help in fleeing country. Pickup 7th pvs, `Doe met...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MON4,100, Lasercolor MON101
DOC.TEXT: Loyalist troops killed a commander of rebels bearing down on the capital, and U.S. officials said Wednesday they were arranging special flights to evacuate Americans from Liberia. The special flights, which begin Saturday, would allow several hundred American citizens to leave Liberia because of the deteriorating situation there, said U.S. officials in Washington. The State Department is strongly urging the estimated 2,000 Americans in this West African nation to leave because of the concerns about personal safety. Several miles off Monrovia, four U.S. warships carrying 2,000 Marines remained poised for a fourth day to evacuate Americans and other foreigners, officials said. Another American official in Washington said President Samuel K. Doe had asked for U.S. help. The Bush administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, corrected his earlier statement that Doe had requested American help to leave Liberia. Diplomats in Monrovia said Doe had refused a U.S. offer of safe passage. One Bush administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Doe had requested American help but was told by U.S. diplomats he should attempt to reach some sort of accord with insurgent leaders. The official earlier said Doe had asked for help in getting out of the country, but he later amended his comment, saying he knew only that Doe had asked for U.S. help. Doe met Tuesday with Christian and Moslem leaders who offered to mediate between him and the rebels. The meeting was stormy, with Doe angered by church leaders' suggestion he resign, an official source said. Doe took over the country of 2.5 million people in a bloody coup 10 years ago. The rebels accuse his administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. Information Minister Emmanuel Bouwier and rebel forces on Wednesday reported the death of the U.S.-trained rebel commander, Elmer Johnson. Both sides gave no details of his killing. Johnson said he served with the U.S. military and was a member of the American forces that invaded Grenada in 1983, though his claim could not independently confirmed. Refugees reaching Monrovia, meanwhile, said rebels killed dozens of Krahn and Mandingo civilians in their advance toward Monrovia, a city of 400,000 people suffering widespread shortages of foodstuffs due to the insurgency. An African ambassador said only that the slayings occurred in several towns. One Mandingo woman said that in her town, rebels burst into a mosque and began firing on people who spoke the Mandingo dialect. ``They just shot the people,'' she said. The civil war has pitted Mandingos and Krahns, who support Doe, against Gio and Mano peoples, which back rebel leader Charles Taylor. Troops supporting Doe, who is a Krahn, are accused of killing hundreds of rebel supporters. The seeds of the ethnic war began in November 1985 when Brig. Gen. Thomas Quiwonkpa, largely backed by Gios and Manos, tried to overthrow Doe. Quiwonkpa managed to take over much of Monrovia before he was killed. In revenge, hundreds of Gios and Manos were killed, according to international human rights organizations. Taylor's rebels launched their invasion from eastern Nimba County, the homeland of Gios and Manos. They have been within striking distance of Monrovia since reaching the gates of Robertsfield International Airport on Tuesday. In the past day, the rebels have made no attempt to advance. Since Monday, international carriers have refused to fly into the airport, 25 miles from the capital. Retreating soldiers on Wednesday opened fire on two American journalists at a roadblock at Scheiffelin Barracks, between the capital and the airport. Neither man was wounded. ``They yelled at us and gesticulated with their guns saying give us the car. We tried not to run and then got into the car, the driver made a U-turn and then they fired at us, I think two, maybe three, shots,'' said Stephen Smith, of Milford, Conn. He is a reporter for the French newspaper Liberation. He said the shots did not hit the car. ``We looked back and saw a soldier kneeling down and firing at us _ it was not a warning shot,'' said Smith, who was accompanied by Michael Roddy, a New York-based reporter for the Reuters news agency. Smith said they saw dozens of soldiers commandeering cars, forcing passengers out, and crowded into the vehicles. On Tuesday, rebels captured a large rubber plantation and several other government strongholds. Plantation residents said dozens of rebels crossed the Farmington River _ the last natural barrier before Monrovia _ and moved onto the huge Firestone Tire and Rubber Co. plantation. The company is a subsidiary of Japan's Bridgestone company. Residents said on Wednesday rebels gathered about 28 expatriates managing the plantation and told them the installations would not be damaged. Rebels ordered them to remain at home, residents said. Diplomats say about half the Liberian soldiers have deserted since the fighting began Dec. 24, reducing the army to 3,000 to 4,000 men. That would be about the same size as the rebel army. Taylor had been a close aide of Doe, heading the government agency responsible for disbursing public funds. He fled the country after the Liberian leader accused him of stealing $1 million from state coffers. Taylor denies the charges.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Question Administration Commitment To China Trade Agreement
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS grafs 5-7: ``Biden asked,'' poison gas discussion
DOC.TEXT: The Chinese government still clamps down on political freedom, bans labor demonstrations and imprisons dissenters a year after the killings near Tiananmen Square in Beijing, U.S. officials said Wednesday. Despite that, the Bush administration wants to retain trade benefits for the Chinese government, a State Department official told senators. Members of a Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee clashed with Richard H. Solomon, assistant secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, over the administration's China trade decision in a prickly session. ``You really can't defend China here,'' Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., told Solomon. ``You can't defend them on trade, you can't begin to defend them on human rights. I find them absolutely reprehensible in the way they have conducted themselves.'' Biden asked Solomon about reports that China was providing missiles and poison gases to the Middle East, and Solomon replied that officials have received ``some indication that something might be going on'' in regard to China's role in developing poison gas for others. A congressional aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, said there have been reports that China has helped Libya in the production of poison gases. Solomon said U.S. officials have relayed to top Chinese officials their concern over reports about Beijing's exports of warmaking technologies to the Middle East. The Chinese have promised not to sell missiles to Syria, he said. ``There are many evil regimes in this world today, but none more deserves to be overthrown by its people than the one in Beijing,'' said Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. A number of lawmakers have promised an attempt to block President Bush's decision to continue most favored nation trade status for China for another year. The designation would allow the lowest possible tariffs on Chinese goods. Solomon acknowledged the Bush administration is concerned about events in China, a country where he said the ``underlying anger'' of the citizens towards the regime remains great. Labor unrest is a particular serious problem for the Chinese, prompting the government to raise salaries in an effort to contain workers, Solomon said. At the same time, he said demonstrations are banned. Solomon said also that U.S. officials are disturbed about reports that the Chinese are using forced labor to work in factories, including those that make clothing exports for the United States. Between 10,000 and 15,000 people were imprisoned after the bloody massacre at Tiananmen Square, U.S. officials said. Today, some 2,000 remain in prison, although U.S. officials said their reporting techniques were imprecise. U.S. officials have been disappointed by the Chinese government's efforts to bring about reconciliation with students protesters, Solomon said. Still, he added, Bush and his aides believe it would be counterproductive to halt trade with China as a means of showing disapproval. ``Our policy towards China seeks to encourage reform and human rights through a considered mix of engagement and sanction,'' he said. Should most favored nation trading status be withdrawn from China, ``the real losers would be China's economic reformers and workers in export industries,'' Solomon said. U.S. diplomats in Beijing believe most pro-democracy advocates would object to Washington cutting trade ties with China, Solomon said, but he acknowledged there were divisions of opinion among the Chinese. Solomon also tried to play down the significance of most favored nation status as a diplomatic tool. He pointed out, for instance, that some other countries criticized for human rights violations _ among them Syria, Iraq and South Africa _ receive the same treatment. But Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., said the argument for U.S. engagement as a way to bring about reform was one that was rejected by Congress when it imposed economic sanctions on South AFrica. The congressional hearing came as Chinese student leaders made the rounds on Capitol Hill urging lawmakers to take ``concrete actions'' to promote human rights in China.

DOC.HEAD: Legislature Completes Work on School Finance Reform Compromise
DOC.TEXT: State lawmakers finished work on a $528 million public school finance reform package Wednesday, sending it to Gov. Bill Clements for his promised signature after months of special sessions on education. ``I do think it's a good bill. I think it's a great step forward,'' Clements said. ``We made some very significant changes in the way we're going to do business in public education in the state of Texas.'' Lawmakers continued work on other bills but planned to end this session _ a record sixth, and their fourth on court-ordered school finance reform _ on Thursday. They have been meeting on education since February. The funding reform package represents a compromise between Democratic legislative leaders and the Republican governor for meeting a state Supreme Court order to make more money available to poor school districts. The House Wednesday approved 136-12 a bill outlining reforms in school funding and administration. It also passed 142-2 a measure making budget cuts and fund transfers to help raise money for education and financially strapped social service programs. Both bills earlier passed the Senate. The House and Senate on Tuesday passed a fee-and-tax package to raise the bulk of the $528 million for the school plan and about $100 million for social services. The tax bill includes a quarter-cent boost in the state sales tax, currently 6 cents on the dollar. Clements killed two previous school finance reform plans because they each relied on a half-cent increase in the sales tax. But he said he agreed to the quarter-cent increase to compromise and fend off the prospect of a court-written funding plan for schools. ``I think that the quarter-cent sales tax will be dropped in due course. I don't think that it's really necessary for school funding for that to continue, and I'm optimistic that in the next ... regular session, it will be dropped,'' Clements said. The Legislature convenes in regular session in January. Some lawmakers said the legislation does not go far enough to meet the court's order to develop a constitutional system. Rep. Gregory Luna said that among other things, it includes no funding for school facilities. ``Members, we will be back ... Don't fool yourself. We haven't resolved the issue,'' Luna, a Democrat, told lawmakers. Clements said, ``I think that what we have passed here and what we have agreed upon will more than satisfy the courts. ``That's my personal opinion, and being a non-lawyer and a non-jurist and non-everything else, why, you know what my opinion is worth,'' he added. The $528 million would be pumped during the 1990-91 school year into the $13.5 billion-a-year school system, which relies on state aid, local property taxes and some federal money. The package also includes increased testing of students; exempting exemplary schools from certain state regulations, and giving the governor authority to appoint the state education commissioner, currently named by the state Board of Education. Texas is one of a dozen states where courts have overturned school finance systems in recent years. The others are Kentucky, New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. Clements, who is not seeking re-election, said he hopes lawmakers will continue working to reform the education system.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Explode Car Bomb near Peru's Government Palace
With AM-Peru-Election
DOC.TEXT: Shining Path rebels exploded a car bomb on Wednesday near the Government Palace, the second to hit downtown Lima in 24 hours. Police said the attacks signaled a rebel offensive against Sunday's presidential elections. Police said the blast destroyed a small car parked behind Lima city hall and wounded one person. Hundreds of military police quickly swarmed through the area and sealed off the Plaza de Armas in front of the palace. In Lima's middle-class Jesus Maria neighborhood, four rebels with machine guns took over an electoral office, forced electoral workers outside and set the office ablaze. Firefighters said electoral workers' identification and most other documents were destroyed. The attack came four days before runoff presidential elections pitting novelist Mario Vargas Llosa against agricultural engineer Alberto Fujimori. The first car bomb exploded one block from the palace on Tuesday night, seriously wounding a passer-by. Rebels launched a wave of overnight violence around the capital. They blew up at least three high-tension power pylons, blacking out parts of the capital and other coastal cities where most of Peru's 22 million people live. Power was restored to most areas within a few hours. In pre-dawn attacks Wednesday, guerrillas threw gasoline bombs at a city bus and at a stove factory owned by a senator-elect of Fujimori's Change 90 party, police said. They planted a bomb in the doorway of a public high school along with a red flag with the hammer-and-sickle symbol of the Maoist-oriented Shining Path. Police defused the device before it exloded. Police said the attacks also may be in response to last week's discovery of an elegant house in a Lima suburb apparently used as the group's Lima headquarters. Police said the house may have been used as a hideout by Abimael Guzman, Shining Path's founder and leader. Police arrested 31 people in the raid last Friday and found personal possessions that appeared to belong to Guzman, who has not been seen in public in more than 10 years. More than 18,500 people have died in political violence since the Shining Path began its insurgency in May 1980.

DOC.HEAD: `Dr. Death': Why Don't They Call Me `Dr. Suicide'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf, `Thompson asked ...,' to UPDATE with state licensing board investigating Kevorkian; picks up 12th graf, `Kevorkian's disdain ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DT1, DT2
DOC.TEXT: The pathologist whose friends call him ``Dr. Death'' said Wednesday he had no regrets about his role in ending the life of an Alzheimer's disease victim with a machine he devised. ``Why shouldn't they call me that? Or even `Dr. Suicide?''' Dr. Jack Kevorkian said during an interview at his home in this Detroit suburb. ``Why should it bother me? Death is a concept. We're all going to face it.'' Janet Adkins flew 2,000 miles from her home in Portland, Ore., to face death Monday afternoon in Kevorkian's 1968 Volkswagen van. Kevorkian, 62, and a relative drove with Mrs. Adkins to a park where they attached her first to a heart monitor and then to an intravenous tube. Mrs. Adkins, 54, pressed a button that delivered a muscle relaxant and fatal doses of chemicals that put her into a coma, then stopped her heart. Death came minutes afterward, said Kevorkian, who delivered the body to police. ``Her last words to me were something like, `Thank you, thank you very much,''' he said. ``I wished her a good trip, and as I leaned over her she seemed like she was rising to meet me, perhaps to give me a kiss of gratitude.'' Kevorkian said Mrs. Adkins had asked him to publicize her method of death to help others. Her dying wish was granted; Kevorkian's name appeared Wednesday on the front pages of newspapers nationwide. ``I don't think I've broken a law,'' Kevorkian said. ``I don't expect to be prosecuted, but you never know what happens in a highly emotional society.'' Oakland County Prosecutor Richard Thompson said Wednesday he has yet to determine whether Kevorkian committed a crime. State police impounded the retired pathologist's van. Thompson asked Circuit Judge Hilda Gage to issue a temporary restraining order preventing Kevorkian from letting anyone else use his device in the county. Gage scheduled a hearing on the request for Friday. The Michigan Department of Licensing and Regulation on Wednesday began investigating Kevorkian's role in Adkins' suicide, said Mary MacDowell, director of the department's Health Investigation Division. If the investigation determines that Kevorkian violated the state public health code, the State Board of Medicine could impose sanctions ranging from a reprimand to suspension or revocation of the physician's medical license, McDowell said. Kevorkian's disdain of prosecution is matched by his scorn for the medical profession, which he said is dominated by a Dark Ages morality hostile to his pro-euthanasia views. ``Everyone says to me, `Hey, you're taking on yourself like God.' Well, then, come on and do something,'' he said. ``If it's legal, let me do it. If it's illegal, stop me.'' The Pontiac native received his medical degree in 1952 from the University of Michigan. He had developed a reputation as an outsider by the time he completed his residency in 1958, said a colleague who has known him for more than 40 years. ``He's had unique ideas. He thinks differently,'' said Dr. Murray Levin, 60, of Bloomfield Hills. ``He wanted to use cadaver blood for blood transfusions. That's something they maybe do in Russia.'' ``He's always been a free thinker,'' said Dr. Gerald Abrams, a former classmate of Kevorkian's and now a professor of pathology at the University of Michigan medical school. ``He always impressed us as being very bright, very sincere. His aren't exactly mainstream ideas.'' Kevorkian joined Pontiac General Hospital in 1959 and spent about 10 years there before opening a diagnostic clinic in Southfield. He worked from 1969 to 1976 at Saratoga General Hospital in Detroit, then at several small hospitals in the Los Angeles area before returning to Michigan. Kevorkian, a bachelor, said he retired in 1982 to study ethics, write articles for European medical and law journals and dabble in surrealistic paintings with medical themes _ and titles like ``Nausea,'' ``Fever'' and ``Coma.'' ``They're pretty powerful,'' Kevorkian said. ``They're not great art but they've got a lot of impact. I like to shake people up.'' But developing his suicide device has taken up the time he used to spend painting. ``He's a loner,'' Levin said. ``He's dropped out of medical circles as far as I know. It bothers me why a guy so competent and well-abled is retired.'' In 1988, Kevorkian asked the Hemlock Society, which advocates the right to death on demand, to refer terminally ill members to a center he wanted to open in California, said Derek Humphry, the society's founder and executive director. ``I persuaded him not to take up in California,'' Humphry said by telephone from the Netherlands, where he was presiding over a convention of the World Federation of Right to Die Societies. ``We didn't want to be involved in law-breaking. ``Dr. Kevorkian is to be praised for his courage and his compassion,'' Humprhy said. ``The history of the world shows that it sometimes takes a zealot to change people's thinking.''

DOC.HEAD: Bhaktipada Says He's Innocent
DOC.TEXT: MORGANTOWN, W.Va. _ A Hare Krishna swami said Wednesday the federal racketeering and mail fraud charges against him are a ploy to seize his 4,000-acre commune. ``Why else would they offer to drop the charges if I turned over the land?'' Kirtanananda Swami Bhaktipada said in a telephone interview from Washington. It was his first response since the indictment was issued by a special grand jury in Elkins two weeks ago. ``I thought it was very strange that they would announce the indictment while I was in India,'' the swami said. ``I didn't have to come back. I'm innocent. I'm going to plead innocent. I'm going to fight this.'' Bhaktipada was charged with five counts of racketeering, including conspiracy to commit murder-for-hire, and six counts of mail fraud in an indictment handed up by a special federal grand jury. One of the racketeering counts alleges a conspiracy involving the death of Stephen Bryant, a dissident member of the Krishna community gunned down on a Los Angeles street in May 1986. Another accuses Bhaktipada of authorizing the murder of Charles St. Denis in 1983 on the grounds of Bhaktipada's New Vrindaban community near Moundsville in the northern panhandle. A former New Vrindaban resident, Thomas Drescher, 40, was convicted of the St. Denis murder and sentenced to life in prison without parole. Drescher has also been charged with Bryant's murder.

DOC.HEAD: Malek Fails to Attend Wiesenthal Regional Dinner
DOC.TEXT: An executive who once drew up a list of Jewish officials for President Nixon did not attend a Wednesday dinner an anti-Nazi organization inadvertantly invited him to. Controversy over the list had led Frederic Malek, president of Northwest Airlines, to resign from George Bush's presidential campaign in September 1988. The Simon Wiesenthal Center acknowledged last month that it overlooked the matter when it invited Malek to be one of 30 vice-chairmen for an event honoring journalists who covered the Nazis' genocide of Jews. ``Witness to the Truth'' awards were presented to CBS veterans Andy Rooney, Eric Sevareid and Bill Shadel, syndicated columnist Max Lerner and photographers Walter Rosenblum and Leon Rosenmann. Janet H.B. Murrow accepted an award on behalf of her late husband, Edward R. Murrow. Malek has told numerous Jewish groups that he is not anti-Semitic and that he compiled the list under intense pressure from Nixon, who thought a ``Jewish cabal'' was trying to undercut his record on the economy. The list involved Jewish officials in the Bureau of Labor Statistics in 1971. Malek accepted the center's offer to serve as a vice chairman and his name appeared on invitations to the $500-a-plate dinner, but he did not attend. Rhonda Barad, Eastern regional director of the Simon Wiesenthal Center, said at least nine other vice chairmen were unable to come. She said Malek would have been welcome at the event. ``We consider Mr. Malek a very good friend of the Jewish community,'' Barad said. She said he had contributed at least $2,500 to the center, a human rights agency that provides information and guidance on the Holocaust and Jewish issues. In remarks at the dinner, Rabbi Marvin Hier, dean of the center, warned of efforts to alter or erase the Holocaust from history. Hier also said the Soviet Union is correct in demanding a say in the unification of Germany. But, he said, so should Soviet Jews who have lived ``as pariahs in a society that did not really want them.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Pat Paulsen $233,337 In Lawsuit Against Ex-Wife
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 4 grafs after 1st graf to UPDATE with comments from both sides. SUBS last graf to CORRECT that Paulsen gained fame on ``Smothers Brothers'' show, sted ``Laugh-In.''
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Wednesday awarded comedian Pat Paulsen $233,337 in damages in a lawsuit that accused his ex-wife of diverting funds from his business while working as his booking agent. Paulsen joked after the award that it will help in in his next whimsical campaign for the presidency. ``This makes me a more viable candidate, with a scandal, and this is really a big one,'' he told the Rocky Mountain News in a telephone interview from a hotel near Washington. Whether he ever collects any of the money is ``not the point,'' Paulsen said. ``It's a moral victory more than anything. Ten million dollars wouldn't be worth all this hassle and all the stress.'' Linda Chaney Paulsen, whose $162,000 counterclaim against the comedian was rejected, was not in court Wednesday either. Contacted later, she told the News, ``I didn't do what I've been accused of, which will become very clear in future legal proceedings.'' The Jefferson County District Court jury deliberated six hours before reaching its verdict in the trial that began May 29. Paulsen had accused Linda Chaney Paulsen, whom he decided to divorce two months after their 1988 marriage, of diverting up to $200,000 in 1987 and 1988 from Pat Paulsen Enterprises Inc. of Lakewood, where she was booking agent. He also claimed his ex-wife hid business records from him, leaked harmful stories about him to the National Enquirer and faked illnesses and nosebleeds to get his sympathy. In testimony in the case, accountant Robert Arshagouni said he was aware the woman kept at least $157,000 more than she was supposed to from Paulsen's performance fees. She denied the allegations, and filed a countersuit claiming Paulsen married and divorced her simply to take over the business. Paulsen first gained national popularity on ``The Smothers Brothers Comedy Hour,'' a 1960s TV show. Since then, he has sporadically mounted tongue-in-cheek campaigns for president and kept busy on the lecture circuit.

DOC.HEAD: Former Church Member Spots Alleged Embezzler Eight Years After He Vanished
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `Womer, 67 ...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Womer waiving extradition, police saying he denies theft; picks up 6th graf, `Womer disappeared ...' SUBS 10th graf pvs, `He was ..,' to INCLUDE second alias; SUBS 12th graf, `Womer's assets ...,' DELETES last graf to conform.
DOC.TEXT: A former church treasurer who allegedly embezzled $267,000 and vanished eight years ago was arrested after a member of the congregation spotted him at a New Mexico crafts show, officials said Wednesday. ``The odds of finding him in Taos, New Mexico, are one in a million or one in a billion,'' said District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz. A detective who'd worked on the case and a priest from Christ Episcopal Church flew to Taos and identified former treasurer Clyde Womer, who'd taken a new name, Gribetz said. Womer was arrested Tuesday. He was living with another woman, having left his wife and children in Rockland County northwest of New York City, and was the manager of a J.C. Penney store in Taos, Gribetz said. Womer, 67, waived extradition during a hearing Wednesday before Magistrate Betty Gonzales in Taos. Gonzales ordered Womer held for New York authorities on a fugitive warrant. He will be returned to New York, where he faces six counts of grand larceny, the district attorney said. ``He denies doing it,'' said Taos Detective Sgt. Hidalgo Trujillo. ``He said he wants to get back to New York as soon as possible to straighten out this mess.'' Womer disappeared in January 1982. A few days later, $267,000 was discovered missing from the treasury of the church in Suffern. Gribetz said Womer had persuaded members of the church to put the funds into liquid accounts, which he controlled. Womer then looted the accounts, depositing the money in his own bank account, the prosecutor said. Investigators were unable to trace Womer until last month, when a church member told police she had seen him and spoken to him in Taos, where she was attending a crafts fair. The woman said she did not let on she suspected the man was Womer, but said he said he knew people in Rockland County. He was using the name Lawrence Krantz, which is his son-in-law's name, Gribetz said. Gonzales said Womer also had used the name Howard Simpson. Gribetz says that in addition to the identification by Detective Leo Kosta and the Rev. John Andrews of the Christ Episcopal Church, Womer was identified through a scar on his torso. Womer's assets were seized, Gribetz said, but he could not detail them.

Dianne Feinstein reached out for Democratic unity today after winning her party's nomination for governor of California and criticized Republican ``caretaker government.'' North Carolina Democrats picked a black man to try to dethrone GOP Sen. Jesse Helms. But the biggest winner on a nine-state primary night Tuesday was arguably Sen. Thad Cochran of Mississippi. Uncontested for the GOP nomination, he also was assured of a third term when no candidate ran in the Democratic primary. A half-dozen other senators gained nominations for new terms. Democrats Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Howell Heflin of Alabama and Max Baucus of Montana easily overcame challenges within their party, while Democrat Tom Harkin of Iowa and Republicans Larry Pressler of South Dakota and Pete Domenici of New Mexico were unopposed. Incumbent governors in Alabama, Iowa and South Dakota also were renominated.

New Jersey joined a dozen states where courts have struck down school-funding systems for shortchanging the poor. In one of those states, Texas, an education-finance overhaul package was speeding through the Legislature. In a 7-0 ruling Tuesday, New Jersey's Supreme Court ordered lawmakers to ensure by the 1991-92 school year that poor districts are able to spend about as much per student as wealthier districts in the 1.3 million-student system. The decision is widely expected to force lawmakers to raise taxes, as has happened in Kentucky, Arkansas, Wyoming and other states. Texas' House and Senate approved tax increases Tuesday. The wave of court orders rejecting the way states fund schools is a legacy of the rich-get-richer, poor-get-poorer 1980s, one expert said.

Train ridership is up, small bus companies are picking up more passengers and Lera Dwyer's van service is keeping two dozen Texas towns linked to the big city. As Greyhound Lines Inc. tries to reorganize its finances under bankruptcy laws while pledging to continue most service with replacements for striking drivers, many travelers already are finding ways to cope without America's only nationwide bus system. They may be paying more, waiting longer for connections and resorting to other transportation modes, but few have complained to Washington since 6,300 Greyhound drivers walked out March 2 in a pay and job security dispute. ``I haven't received a single call from any legislator, mayor, governor or anyone complaining about a lack of service because of the Greyhound strike,'' said Wayne J. Smith, executive director of the United Bus Operators of America.

Hungry for more studies analyzing the ``big issues'' of our time, but tired of the predictable pap from established research organizations? Clyde Prestowitz has just what you need _ a new think tank. But in a town with a think tank on nearly every corner, a new kid on the block has to find a niche. According to its creators, the Economic Strategy Institute will be the first research organization geared to the post-Cold War era, a time when America's standing will be based not on its nuclear arsenal but on its ability to compete economically with countries such as Japan. ``When you consider the question of international trade and international economics, virtually all of the think tanks are saying the same thing,'' Prestowitz told a news conference Tuesday.

Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev may have returned to Moscow bearing trade and arms agreements, but he and his wife Raisa were laden with other souvenirs as well _ including two of President Bush's horseshoes. Among the many gifts the Bushes gave the Gorbachevs during the superpower summit was an orange pitching horseshoe mounted on a wooden plaque. It was the lucky shoe that Gorbachev had tossed for a first-time ringer at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains, as he and his wife relaxed there last Saturday with the Bushes. Bush presented the horseshoe plaque to Gorbachev at dinner that night.

DOC.HEAD: First Published at Age 70, Wesley Tops Best-Seller List
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mary Wesley's mailbox is frequently filled with letters from frustrated would-be novelists. ``I get letters from people who say they've always wanted to write a book and they want to know how I did it,'' she says. At 77, Wesley is a newcomer to fiction. She published the first of her seven novels when she was 70. Her latest, ``A Sensible Life,'' topped the British best-seller list its first week of publication, and will be published in the United States this summer. The diminutive author, dressed in navy blue sweatshirt, light blue jeans and pearl earrings, had been writing for 40 years and tearing up the pages, except for two children's books. She only started writing seriously after her husband of 25 years, journalist Eric Siepmann, died in 1970. ``My husband used to tell me I could write but I thought it was just because he loved me,'' she said in an interview at her timbered Elizabethan house in southwest England. ``I was unhappy, very poor. Writing purged myself of the destructive desperation.'' She describes writing as ``a compulsion. ... It's companionship, but it's not always enjoyable. It can be painful and frustrating like a dog digging at a rabbit hole, when the rabbit is long gone.'' A friend persuaded her to find a publisher for her first novel, ``Jumping the Queue,'' a black comedy about a middle-aged widow on the brink of suicide. It got enthusiastic reviews and sold respectably. ``A Sensible Life'' traces the life of Flora, who achieves her childhood ambition of loving three men she meets as a girl. Abandoned by her self-absorbed parents, Flora matures into a tough, confident and attractive woman and eventually, in middle age, she settles down with one of the three men. Wesley captures the flavor of blacked-out wartime London, boozy weekends at country houses, a lonely child's desperation. Her description of Flora's feverish cold makes the reader sniffle. The book includes the ingredients Wesley fans have come to expect: a carefully drawn wartime setting, upper-class English characters, jaunty dialogue and racy scenes. ``People go on about sex in my books because I'm so old,'' Wesley said. ``When I was 30 I thought that I wouldn't have sex when I was 40, and when I was 40 I thought I'd stop at 50 and so on, but sex goes on no matter how old you are.'' Her plots can be complicated, but her style is simple and unadorned _ an attribute she says comes from her frugality with paper in less prosperous times. ``I hate overwriting. The expense of foolscap helped my writing. It made me more concise,'' she said. The author denies her vivid characters are modeled on herself. But gutsy women from privileged backgrounds, unafraid to defy convention, are consistent with Wesley's persona. Wesley, like Flora and Helena, dared to breach accepted behavior and was divorced, as one of her characters would say, ``when it was simply not done.'' After the divorce, many suitors were interested, but it was Siepmann who spotted her in the Ritz Hotel and gave her unbroken happiness. Wesley still feels the loss. She often catches herself making a mental note to tell Eric something amusing she has heard. Gardening, writing and answering fan mail fill her day. After an appearance on a popular radio program, she says, she got three letters: ``One was an invitation to a literary lunch, the second said if you're afraid to die, here are the phone numbers for three clairvoyants and the third said they'd seen a picture of me, admired my teeth, and wanted the name of my dentist.'' Wesley said she is afraid of the process of dying, but not of death itself. ``I'm interested to know what happens,'' she said. ``I cannot believe there is nothing beyond and if there is then, well, that's that.'' She is energetic and swims three times a week. ``I don't feel that old. I don't think about it,'' she said. ``I resent getting tired, but I can see, hear and chew. I find it tiresome the way people talk about their age and illnesses.'' Publicity makes the author uncomfortable. ``I feel very overexposed,'' she said. ``It's a creepy feeling because I'm used to observing others and now I'm being observed.'' Her advice to those frustrated novelists who write to her is: ``read, read and keep on reading.'' Books have been her education. But she cautions that writing is much harder than it may seem. ``I've been lucky,'' she says. ``I wouldn't recommend it for anyone.''

DOC.HEAD: Seminaries Include Wider Diversity Of Future Ministers
DOC.TEXT: Enrollment in American seminaries, the source for filling pulpits across the country, turned upward last term after declining slowly but steadily for the past five years. There are now more older students involved, and more women. So far, the seminary output is about keeping up with the needs for new ministers in Protestant denominations, but there's a shortage in a growing number of Catholic dioceses. The new figures on seminarians were compiled by the Association of Theological Schools, based in Vandalia, Ohio. It includes most accredited Protestant and Roman Catholic seminaries in the country _ 203 of them. Their total enrollment reached 56,083, up 5.1 percent over the 55,405 at start of the 1988-89 term, which had been the low point in a gradual slide since 1984, when enrollment peaked at 56,466. While Roman Catholicism is experiencing priest shortages, most major Protestant denominations are ``just about replenishing'' their needs, says the Rev. William Baumgaertner, the association's associate director. ``They're reasonably well supplied, but there's no great surplus,'' he added in an interview. Noting signs that a growing proportion of the current crop of seminarians plan careers other than the ordained ministry, he said: ``The sharp increase this year may well reflect the success of school efforts to serve a broader constituency with a variety of graduate level programs.'' He said an increasing percentage of unordained, but trained specialists ``now share responsibilities'' with clergy as music directors, religious education leaders, pastoral counselors and other ministries. ``The base of ministry has shifted away from all being ordained to a lot of others who are not, but who have advanced degrees for their specialities,'' Baumgaertner said. He said the prevelance of older students has remained high, with the average age about 31. Many ``second career'' students, those pursuing ordination after working in other fields, are in their late 30's or 40's. They make about a fourth of the entire seminary enrolment. The number of women students _ and their proportion of the total _ stays on the upgrade, a trend that has gone on since 1972 when they constituted only 10 percent of seminary students. At that time, women were a relatively small, but pioneering band of 3,358. Now the total is five times greater _ 16,270. They amount to 29 percent of the total seminarians, up 2 points in the last two years. Their ranks are not growing, ``as rapidly as before,'' Baumgaertner said. But their steady increase has brought predictions that a fourth of mainline Protestant pastors will be women by the century's end. Most major Protestant bodies _ United Methodist, Episcopal, Presbyterian, American Baptists, Lutheran and Reformed _ now admit women to ordination, although they're barred from it in Roman Catholicism and Eastern Orthodxy. Among Southern Baptists, it's a controversial issue, but some of their congregations have ordained women. Black students in seminary have increased steadily for two decades, the gain averaging 5.5 percent per year for the past five years, and now totalling 3,814. Blacks now make up 6.8 percent of the total seminary enrolment, compared to 4.2 percent a decade ago. ``There is reason for encouragement in these statistics,'' Baumgaertner said. However, he said, the increase in Hispanic seminarians has been too slow to meet the needs, up only 2.8 percent to a total of 1,483. ``Continuing efforts of denominations to reach out to this group will be a challenge to the existing programs of theological schools,'' he said. Students of Pacific@Asian ancestry have increased much more rapidly and their total of 2,058 now exceeds that of blacks. ``The determination of this group to provide an educated ministry is obvious,'' Baumgaertner said. Despite overall seminary growth, the number of full-time students continued to drop, now totalling 36,431, or 65 percent, down 3.5 percent in the last two years. The proportion has declined 11 percent in the last decade from 76 percent. ``Schools have been focusing their energies on increasing endowment for student financial aid in order to reverse this trend and to permit more applicants to become full-time students,'' Baumgaertner said. ``It is obvious that more needs to be done.''

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Who Arrived in U.S. with $10 Heads Successful Bus Company
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Jose Espinosa fled Fidel Castro's Cuba in 1961 with $10 in his pocket. He now heads a $3 million-a-year company that caters to Latins by operating up to 15 buses daily between Miami and New York. English is a second language on Espinosa's La Cubana buses, except for the movies on the overhead VCR system that entertain riders traveling the 1,300 miles on Interstate 95. Like many Cuban exiles, Espinosa settled in Miami for what he thought would be a temporary stay. ``After Castro took over, everybody I knew who came to Miami agreed Fidel would be out of power within months. Everybody was mistaken,'' he said of the Cuban strongman, in power since 1959. Espinosa came to Florida alone, but was able to get his wife and young daughter out of Cuba when it became apparent Castro's reign would not be short. His parents and most other relatives eventually moved to Miami, too. His business began with a simple notion: that many of the Cuban exiles who traveled between New York and Miami to visit relatives or work feared using a carrier that conducted business only in English. ``He saw that Spanish-speaking people weren't getting the service they need,'' said Espinosa's daughter, Rosa Theodorou, manager of the company's New York-area branch office in Union City, N.J. But getting the bus business off the ground proved to be a decade-long fight. Espinosa applied for a permit from the Interstate Commerce Commission, but bus-giant Greyhound Lines Inc. opposed him, and the battle dragged on until 1978, when Espinosa finally convinced the commission his line would be unique. ``I proved to the (commission) judge that there was a market for my service that other companies weren't providing,'' he said. ``Our passengers were not like other passengers. Our passengers didn't speak English. They couldn't talk to the drivers.'' To make ends meet, Espinosa worked at a freight-forwarding company, unloading goods and driving trucks. And he began shuttling passengers without a license. In an old station wagon, he picked up fellow exiles in Miami at their doors before dawn, drove all day and night to the New York area, dropped them off, and then reversed the whole trip within days. ``It was so much work,'' he said. ``That was before I had the permit. I wasn't supposed to do it, but I needed to make a living.'' Espinosa likened his pre-license hustling to Nicaraguan vendors, new to the country, who today sell fruit on the streets of Miami's Little Havana section without a permit. ``It was a way to bring some food to the home,'' he said. Through word-of-mouth, his business grew. He bought a van and attached a trailer to carry passengers' possessions. Once, weary from a long haul to New York and a quick turnaround, he forgot to lock the trailer door, only to discover in South Carolina that the goods had been strewn somewhere earlier along I-95. He was on the road constantly to meet demand, so Espinosa expanded again, buying a bus that he drove for years until singer Andy Williams purchased it for his tours, his daughter said. Now the business is established and Espinosa, 71, no longer has to drive for a living. He has about 25 employees, including bilingual reservation clerks who answer phones in New York and Miami. Cubana, in step with the times, has a toll-free 800-number. The company has at least two buses on the road daily between Miami's Little Havana and New York, and up to 15 traveling each day during the busiest season _ Christmas and July. ``I don't know why the Latins pick July to spend the month in Miami Beach,'' Espinosa said with a laugh. He advertises on Spanish TV and radio in the Miami and New York-New Jersey markets, but Cubana generates most of its traffic from satisfied customers. ``They feel like they're in a family atmosphere,'' said Ms. Theodorou. Passengers on a recent trip southward were unanimous in their praise. ``I like the music, and it's a fun atmosphere,'' said Katia Chamah, 18. But at $69 each way, the trip isn't much cheaper than the lowest airfares; some air carriers have restricted one-way fares between Miami and the New York-area as low as $79. And Greyhound's fares range from $68 to $99, one way. Many Latins, however, fear flying, said Ruben Dario Lugo, a Miami security guard who boarded the bus at Cubana's small storefront in Manhattan, even though the trip takes an entire day and sometimes longer if there are any breakdowns along the way. ``The thing to remember is if this falls,'' Lugo said, patting the seat of the bus on a recent journey, ``it doesn't fall nearly as far as a plane.'' Added Ms. Theodorou, ``We tell them, `If you were on a plane and it broke down, you wouldn't be here to tell us.'''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, June 11

DOC.HEAD: A Long Latin Ride from New York to Miami
With Cubana Bus
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ABOARD CUBANA BUS NO. 8801 (AP) _ The trip is already four hours behind schedule when the bus leaves its Union City, N.J., terminal for Florida. No one seems to mind. Passengers sip thimbles of sweet black Cuban coffee as the bus rumbles onto Interstate 95. ``Musica, musica!'' shouts someone from the rear of Cubana bus No. 8801, which is carrying 34 passengers 1,300 miles southward. Luis Niebla looks at his co-driver, Osvaldo Rodrigues, smiles and puts on a cassette tape of Roberto Carlos, a Latin singer. Rodrigues takes out a microphone and in Spanish tells the passengers what's ahead: at least 22 hours on the highway, including dinner at a Latin cafe, a stop in Washington, D.C., to pick up passengers, breakfast in north Florida, and arrival in Miami the next afternoon. He warns passengers no drinking is allowed on board, or drugs, and that anybody in violation will be turned over to the highway patrol. As the bus heads down the highway, Carlos croons on, ``En otras palabras, yo soy un romantico,'' or ``In other words, I'm a romantic.'' An hour later, the bus stops in Elizabeth, N.J., for dinner at El Pimiento Rojo, a Salvadoran cafe with its menu painted in Spanish on the wall. The drivers quaff down a yerba mate (Latin tea) soda, and passengers order bacalao (codfish), carne asada con arroz blanco (roast beef with white rice) and frijoles negros (black beans). We seem far from America already. Back on the road, Niebla puts on a videotape of the movie ``Aliens.'' Most are quiet on board as the bus crosses into Delaware at sunset, except Ruben Dario Lugo, a night security guard who has been chatting with passengers almost nonstop since he got on board. ``I talk a lot, don't I? There's no one to talk to in my work and when I get home every day, I sleep,'' says Lugo, born to Puerto Rican parents in New York and now living in Miami. Night sets in, and people straggle up front for a shot of Cuban coffee from a Thermos. A Philadelphia radio station plays oldies as we cross into Maryland. A Venezuelan girl walks by wearing a ``Who Killed Roger Rabbit'' T-shirt. ``Avenging Force,'' a violent B-grade film about a secret white supremacist society involved in killings in Louisiana, comes on, and again the bus quiets, most passengers transfixed by the TV screen above Niebla. A slim crescent of moon rises in the sky; soon the bus exits at Chevy Chase, Md., and heads into Washington, D.C., to pick up a family of four. ``A lot of people travel with us because they're afraid to fly,'' says Niebla, whose bus was delayed by a breakdown on the previous run. ``It's not just the Latins either; we get some Haitians, too.'' Katia Chamah, 18, comes up front as we pass the lighted Lincoln Memorial and Washington Monument; she and Niebla, 33, begin talking, mostly in Spanish. They switch easily between the two languages. She speaks of vacations, her college studies and dreams of a career as a forensic psychologist. Niebla talks of fishing in the Florida Keys and serving in the U.S. military. We pass Richmond, Va.; it's been six hours on the road. The seven children on board seem well-mannered, and none of the adults are misbehaving. Cuban-born Niebla says he fled to Florida with his parents in 1967. His father, a schoolteacher, had opposed Fidel Castro, and been publicly scorned by the Cuban government. His mother helped the anti-Castro underground, Niebla says. ``She used to stick ammo in her shirt and take it to people hiding out in the mountains,'' he says. The heads of the sleeping passengers bob in the night. Daylight comes in a light fog in southern Georgia. The bus pulls into a truck stop for breakfast outside Jacksonville, Fla., then it's back on the road for the final run to Miami. At this point in the trip, most of Florida looks the same _ mile after mile of palmettoes, palms and wild Brazilian pepper trees. The bus continues on to West Palm Beach, where a few passengers are let off. Many of the remaining travelers order coffee, sandwiches and pastries from the adjacent Cuban diner. Weary, most everyone is quiet when the bus pulls into the one-room Cubana terminal, which has a faded map of Cuba on one wall, in the Little Havana section of Miami. Niebla is rewarded by Chamah with a bag full of tips she collected from he passengers as the bus pulled into Miami. He's greeted by his wife and one of his daughters, who clings to him. ``He's on the road so much,'' his wife says, wringing her hands.

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Soviet Trade Policy Not a Model of Consistency
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: As a lesson in capitalism, U.S. policy on trade with Moscow loses something in the translation. In this case, business doesn't come before pressure. Commercial decisions hinge on Soviet behavior and on American politics, not on the marketplace. And consistency is not part of the package. Pressing Soviet trade, the old communist, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, argued like a businessman, the course that now suits his economic purpose. He told political leaders in Washington and business leaders in Minneapolis and San Francisco that if American traders and investors don't move quickly into newly opening Soviet markets, other interests will be there first. That concerns administration officials, but they also have to deal with political realities, one of which is that Congress will not agree to a new trade deal until Moscow offers at least a gesture toward granting Lithuania independence. The trade agreement Gorbachev took home from the summit was described by the White House as a symbol of support for Soviet economic change, but it is only a symbol; it will not be completed any time soon. The Soviet parliament may put off until fall its final action on an emigration law President Bush said must be enacted before he sends the trade deal to Congress. Even when that step is taken, the agreement is not going anywhere without some easing in Gorbachev's economic crackdown on Lithuania. At same time, a renewed grain sales agreement is taking effect without regard to Kremlin behavior on Lithuania's independence drive or anything else. The five-year grain deal extends agreements dating from 1976. U.S. negotiators wanted that one. It is an economic boon to the Midwest, it expands the business American farmers already are doing, and putting it in any doubt would be politically perilous. When then-President Carter imposed a partial grain embargo in 1980 to punish the Soviet Union for the invasion of Afghanistan, Republicans denounced the step. They said wheat should not have been made a diplomatic weapon, argued that Moscow would simply buy its grain elsewhere. Ronald Reagan lifted the embargo shortly after he became president. The trade agreement, and the most-favored-nation tariff status Gorbachev wants, are new business, and politically vulnerable, with no domestic constituency involved. The grain sales are big business, with powerful U.S. voting interests behind them. Soviet negotiators apparently didn't want to sign the grain deal unless the trade deal also was signed. Grain sales, including wheat sold at subsidized prices, account for most current U.S. trade with the Soviet Union. Under the new agreement those sales are supposed to increase to $6 to $8 billion a year. Soviet exports to the United States did not reach $1 billion last year. The trade agreement could open the path to greatly expanded commerce between the two powers, although at this point the Soviet Union does not have much to sell. Its major U.S. exports now are vodka, caviar and furs, all subject to steep tariffs that would be sharply reduced by most-favored-nation treatment. The trade deal also would make it easier for U.S. companies that want to do business in the Soviet Union. Gorbachev's bottom line was a businessman's: there's money to be made, and the people who get there first will do best. ``We need some economic moves, some economic steps now,'' he said during the summit visit. ``If America lags behind, then others come in ... We want America to be in.'' He argued his case for the trade deal to congressional leaders and in his summit sessions with Bush, who finally offered the gesture of a conditional agreement. Congressional critics called it a cave-in on Lithuania. The Senate had voted 73-24 on May 1 for a resolution saying that there should be no trade agreement without an end to the economic crackdown on Lithuania. Sen. George J. Mitchell, D-Maine, the majority leader, said Monday that Bush clearly expected Congress to do what he wouldn't do, and tie trade to Soviet moves toward Lithuanian independence, not only to free emigration. The latter condition dates from 1974; it was set by Congress to press for emigration rights for Soviet Jews. Bush also faces a trade policy dispute over his renewal of favorable tariff terms for China despite its repression of democracy demonstrators and the killings in Tiananmen Square a year ago. Congressional critics are trying to block the extension, but they probably lack the votes. Bush had said his action on China sent no message except that isolation is bad and economic development is good. The U.S. message on Soviet trade terms isn't quite the same.

DOC.HEAD: Upstart Fox Network is Riding High on Rating Successes
DOC.TEXT: These are halcyon days for Fox Broadcasting Co. In the latest Nielsen ratings, the television network that refuses to call itself one broke into the top 10 for the first time in its young life. ``The Simpsons'' was the No. 4 show in the country last week, ``Married ... With Children'' was No. 11 and ``In Living Color'' placed 19th. Never before in its four-year existence has Fox placed three shows in the top 20. At its annual convention this week for affiliated stations, Fox is beside itself. So what's an upstart network to do? Well, try not to let it go to your head, for starters. Or at least, don't let it look like it's going to your head. And when you roll out your fall schedule, don't let it appear that you're going toe-to-toe with the big boys, even though you are. Before about 600 advertisers, affiliate representatives and reporters Monday, Fox trotted out sneak peeks and the stars of its fall lineup. Out came Keenen Ivory Wayans and his brother, Damon, whose ``In Living Color'' skits include black, gay, limp-wristed film reviewers giving movies ``two snaps up'' and the ``Homeboy Shopping Network,'' featuring two black thieves auctioning stolen goods. Also on the stage of the Beverly Hilton's Versailles ballroom were two of the stars of the new ``Babes'' situation comedy about a triumvirate of extremely large sisters who are ... well, they're fat. And they make jokes about it. There were Fox executives talking about Fox being ``unique,'' ``special,'' ``young'' and ``high-octane TV,'' and about how, with a recent Federal Communications Commission waiver in hand, the network has bumped its programming to 18{ hours without being bound by federal network rules. But probably the most talked about and written about aspect of the upcoming season is Fox's decision to put the grousing, animated Simpsons up against kingpin Bill Cosby and ``The Cosby Show'' on NBC. ``The Simpsons'' actually placed four slots higher than Cosby last week, with both programs still in their original time periods on separate nights. ``Cos is gonna have a cow, dude,'' screamed last week's headline in the L.A. Daily News. ``Fox's Family Feud,'' wrote the San Francisco Chronicle. But Peter Chernin, head of the Fox Entertainment Group, says no way, man. The point is not to beat Cosby. The point is to walk into no man's land and settle for second. ``We'll be happy to be No. 2,'' Chernin said Monday in an interview at the Beverly Hilton. Because Cosby has owned the 8 p.m. EDT Thursday slot for the last few years, ABC and CBS simply walked away, Chernin said. And now, with rumors abounding that the fall season will be Cosby's last on the show, Fox strutted in with its top-rated program. ``If Bill does leave after this year,'' Chernin said, ``then we'll step in.'' Fox does not, Chernin said, expect to beat Cosby in the fall. Rather, it's just one more example of ``guerrilla warfare,'' a phrase Chernin is partial to using when describing his network. Uh, make that broadcasting company. With only 131 stations across the country carrying Fox programming (compared to top-rated NBC, which has 208 affiliate stations), the success of Fox really does seem like a guerrilla war. Couple that with the fact that it's not always easy to find the Fox station in your hometown _ especially if you live in, say, Lexington, Ky., where the Fox affiliate is WDKY, located on channel 56. Overcoming such obstacles is not lost on Fox, which spared no expense in wining and dining its affiliates. ``Fox is no longer an alternative,'' the affiliates were told amid much fanfare. ``Now, it's an essential.'' Lest they get too carried away with themselves, Fox executives did try to put a mute in their horn-blowing. ``We believe in taking risks,'' Chernin told the packed ballroom. ``Next, we believe in aggressiveness. We can't afford to get comfortable. We've got to keep challenging ourselves.''

Elsewhere in television ... MORE FOX: Except for Monday's fall presentation ceremony, Fox's three-day affiliates convention was closed to the press. Up for discussion in closed-door sessions: Fox's long awaited news network, which, according to one Fox executive, will be available in a year and will consist of up to 60 minutes of sports, news and entertainment ``packages'' that stations may pick up as they desire.
