DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE: The Supreme Court's nine members are among the most private of public officials. They wield enormous power but rarely hold news conferences or give interviews. A recent poll indicated only one in three Americans can name any of the nine. This, the ninth and last in a series, offers an up-to-date look at one member of the nation's highest court.
DOC.TEXT: Justice Harry A. Blackmun says he is one of the Supreme Court's ``three old goats'' whose inevitable departure will solidify conservative domination of the court for the next 40 or 50 years. Labeled a conservative when he joined the court two decades ago, Blackmun now is an outspoken critic of the court's rightward shift. He demonstrated his candor during an interview with The Associated Press. ``Last year the cluster of five (conservative members) emerged, and certainly this year they have control of the court completely, and are making the most of it,'' Blackmun said. He listed Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia and Anthony M. Kennedy as members of the court's conservative majority. ``I had a feeling until last year that, while they could have had control of the court, they didn't really seize it,'' the 81-year-old justice said. ``I suppose as long as I am not a member of that group it is difficult. But we shouldn't resent it,'' he said. ``That's the way the system works. That pendulum swings. It will stay this way now 40 or 50 years, I'm sure.'' Blackmun, who Saturday marked his 20th anniversary as a justice, predicts the court will grow more conservative after the departure of its three octogenarians _ himself and Justices William J. Brennan, 84, and Thurgood Marshall, 81. None of the three has indicated he is considering retirement. Brennan and Marshall are the court's most liberal members, often joined in the most divisive cases by Blackmun and Justice John Paul Stevens, 70. ``Time will take its toll on the three old goats,'' Blackmun said. ``We will be replaced by appointees of the current administration or the next one, which is probably going to be another Bush administration. So it seems to me that before too long the court could be nine conservatives, and that surely will last well into the next century.'' When appointed by President Nixon, Blackmun had the reputation of a politically and judicially conservative federal appeals court judge from Minnesota. Early in his high court tenure, he was ridiculed for his perceived dependence on then-Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, an old friend. Even after Blackmun wrote the court's 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion he was considered a dependable conservative vote. By 1980, however, he had emerged as an independent force on the court. In the past decade, he increasingly sided with the liberal wing. ``I don't believe I've changed in fundamental outlook,'' Blackmun said. ``If one goes back and reads my opinions on the court of appeals, you'll find that they are not rock-ribbed conservatism of the type that seems to be popular today.'' As a lower court judge, Blackmun said he and his colleagues ``always had the comfort of knowing that if we're wrong, those nine jokers down in Washington will straighten us out. Here, it's the end of the line. When one gets here, he has to develop an in-depth judicial philosophy.'' He added: ``One has to develop his attitude toward the (Constitution's) great phrases. What does `equal protection' mean? What is `cruel and unusual punishment'? I would hope that I have grown in that respect over the years. But as far as shifting from conservatism to liberalism, I don't believe I have done that.'' On the bench, Blackmun most often displays a judicial scowl and can be snappish with lawyers. Off the bench, warmth and humor emerge. The justice turns downright effusive when discussing his three daughters and grandchildren or swapping baseball gossip. He is less willing to discuss the possibility of retirement. ``I think one has to have good health in this job. I don't believe one can keep up without it, and I am very conscious of the fact that some former colleagues of mine who were my age are long gone,'' Blackmun said. After noting that he undergoes a complete physical exam at the Mayo Clinic each year, Blackmun smiled and said, ``There are two or three out there who promise they will let me know when my level of senility reaches the unacceptable point.'' Blackmun has suffered from recurring cancer of the prostate gland. Most recently, he was treated for it in 1987. No further problems have been reported. Blackmun realizes his role in court history will be defined largely by his writing the Roe vs. Wade decision. ``Author of the abortion decision,'' he once said. ``We all pick up tags. I'll carry this one to my grave.'' He has remained an ardent defender of a woman's right to end her pregnancy and last year dissented bitterly from a decision that gave states more power to regulate abortion. But Blackmun said he hopes other aspects of his tenure will not be eclipsed. ``I hope I would be remembered as a person of judicial integrity who wrote acceptably well and contributed in more than one field,'' he told the AP. ``I'd like to be known just as a good worker in the vineyard who held his own and contributed generally to the advancement of the law.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 10

DOC.TEXT: Legislation that would give the Securities and Exchange Commission powers to curb the controversial practice of program trading during stock market emergencies was passed by the House. The Securities Markets Reform Act, passed by a voice vote Tuesday, would allow the SEC to limit program trading ``during periods of extraordinary market volatility'' _ the sharp climbs or drops in stock prices.

Greyhound Lines Inc. said it would continue service during its bankruptcy reorganization, while an official of one striking union said labor might ask the bankruptcy court to oust company management. The Dallas-based company listed liabilities of almost $540 million in filing Monday for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors. Meanwhile Tuesday, Greyhound Dial Corp., which sold the bus lines in 1987 and leases some buses and facilities to Greyhound Lines, set $100 million aside from after-tax earnings to cover possible losses related to the bankruptcy.

Late-May sales of domestically made cars and trucks continued a slide begun last October, dropping 3.3 percent compared with the same period a year ago, automakers said. ``Although the sales pace picked up sharply from mid-May's disaster level, I would not label overall demand as strong,'' analyst Tom Webb with the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va., said Tuesday.

Savings and loan regulators are moving to ease a controversial new lending regulation after builders complained it was unfairly choking off their credit, an official said. The Office of Thrift Supervision has proposed a temporary increase in the limit on how much a thrift may lend to one borrower, said an agency official who spoke Tuesday on condition of anonymity.

Coors Brewing Co. has forged a deal with Stroh Brewery Co. to purchase Stroh's Memphis, Tenn., brewery _ an acquisition marking the first time Coors will make beer outside of Golden, Co., officials said. The sale price for the 500-employee brewery was not disclosed. With an annual capacity of 5.5 million barrels, the Memphis brewery will increase Coors' annual production by nearly a third.

R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., juggling a $5.67 billion debt load, said it was looking at ways of restructuring its liabilities. The news heartened investors, who bid up the price of the retailer's junk bonds. The news was contained in a letter to stockholders that also disclosed Macy's lost $63.1 million in its fiscal third quarter ended April 28, compared with a $64.1 million loss a year earlier. The company, which is still paying down debt from its $3.74 billion leveraged buyout in 1986, told its stockholders, ``We have been actively examining opportunities to reduce or refinance our debt.''

Bloomingdale's said its poorly performing branch stores in Dallas and Stamford, Conn. will close late this summer. Marvin S. Traub, chairman of Bloomingdale's, said Tuesday the decision to close the two branches came after a regular chainwide review of financial performance and future potential. The department store operator has been under intense pressure to generate sales and income. Its parent company, Campeau Corp.-owned Federated Department Stores Inc., is trying to reorganize under bankruptcy court supervision.

Prices of junk bonds used to finance part of Donald Trump's casino and real estate empire fell again amid speculation that negotiations between the developer and his bankers would further reduce the value of the risky securities. Meanwhile Tuesday, bondholders filed a class action lawsuit seeking to block Trump and his associates from promoting the Taj Mahal at the expense of the Trump Plaza and Trump Castle holdings in Atlantic City. The suit also seeks unspecified damages for the sharp decline in value of the bonds.

Broadway set a box-office record for the third consecutive year, rising 8 percent to $283 million in ticket sales during the 1989-90 season. Attendance climbed to 8.03 million during the season that ended Sunday, the League of American Theaters and Producers said Tuesday. That was up from 7.97 million the previous season but lower than the 8.14 million tickets sold two years ago. Ticket prices climbed 7 percent to an average of $35.25.

Stock prices declined Tuesday in heavy trading as investors reacted to lower bond prices and took profits after Monday's rally. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.19 to 2,925.00, erasing about one third of the Monday gains that had pushed the market barometer to a record high. The dollar was mostly lower while gold rose in New York after a mixed performance overseas. Energy futures prices fell sharply on reports Saudi Arabia is cutting prices on crude oil. Grain and soybean futures were mostly higher, precious metals and copper climbed, and livestock and pork rose sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Sales Drop 3.3 Percent in Late May
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Late-May sales of North American-made vehicles dipped just 3.3 percent from last year's strong pace, but analysts say real demand is weaker than the figures show. The 10 major U.S. car- and truck-making companies Tuesday reported they sold vehicles at an average of 51,002 a day during May 21-31, compared with a rate of 52,767 during the same time last year. A 5.9 percent drop in car sales more than offset a 1.6 percent rise in sales of trucks, spurred mainly by General Motors Corp. minivan and Ford Motor Co.'s Explorer sport-utility vehicle sales. ``Although the sales pace picked up sharply from mid-May's disaster level, I would not label overall demand as strong,'' said analyst Tom Webb with the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. The late-May sales drop came against a strong period last year, when incentives were luring consumers into showrooms. Automakers lately have been trying to wean car buyers from rebates and low-interest financing. The latest figures would have been worse if not for another surge in sales of transplants, cars made in the United States at Japanese-owned factories. Late-May sales of cars made in North America by GM, Ford and Chrysler Corp. fell 10.7 percent while transplant sales rose 23 percent. Auto analyst David Healy of Barclays Bank in New York said the strength of the transplant sales figures was a statistical quirk. For instance, U.S. sales arms of Toyota Motor Corp. and Honda Motor Co. Ltd. reported they sold as many cars in the last 10-day selling period of the month as they did in the first two periods combined. ``We have another end-of-the-month dramatic recovery in cars sales that doesn't mean a thing,'' Healy said. ``I think you've got to look at car sales in the last 30 days and if you do that, it's going to smooth out that end-of-the-month bulge.'' For all of May, domestic producers reported a 7.8 percent decline in car and truck sales. With imported vehicles included, sales ran 7 percent behind the May 1989 level. The Big Three's share of the U.S. car market stood at about 61 percent last month, down from 66 percent a year before. The transplants' share of the market was about 12 percent in May, compared with 7.3 percent a year ago. Imports made up the balance. The industry softness reinforces a report issued Monday by the Conference Board saying consumer confidence slipped slightly last month. So far for the year, sales of domestic and imported vehicles were 4.3 percent behind last year's pace, with sales of domestic cars and trucks down 3.9 percent and import sales off 5.6 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Prices Reach Lowest In A Year; Some Fear More Drops May Lay Ahead
With PM-Dollar-Gold
DOC.TEXT: A surge in stocks has taken the glitter off gold, analysts say. Rumors of heavy selling by the Soviet Union and Saudi Arabia also have contributed to a slump that has pushed gold to its lowest level in a year. The price could tumble to four-year lows if it doesn't stabilize soon, analysts say. In recent days, gold has traded in the high $350 range, its lowest level since last June when the low for the month in London was $358.70. ``If it breaks $350, I think there will be more selling to $335,'' said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst at PaineWebber Inc. The last time gold prices were that low was in June 1986, when the monthly low was $336.75, according to the World Gold Council, a non-profit mining companies association. Gold was quoted at $358.10 an ounce at London's afternoon fixing Tuesday. Gold for current delivery settled at $359.80 later on the New York Commodity Exchange, up $1.20 from Monday. That marks a decline of about 15 percent since February, when gold hit a near-term high of $423.75. The slide has been especially painful to investors because, unlike stocks and bonds, gold pays no dividends or interest. Some analysts said the slump stems from the rally in the stock market, which has attracted investment money. An ebbing of inflation fears because of recent signs of weak economic growth also has hurt gold, which traditionally is bought as a hedge against higher prices, they said. Rumors of large selling by the Soviet Union and Middle Eastern countries also have hurt the market. Twice since March, sharp price drops have been attributed by market watchers to gold selling by Saudi Arabia. The steep decline has scared many traders who are now afraid to bet on a rebound, said Mark Kadlec, a vice president at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``Nobody knows how low `low' is. There is a half-decent possibility the low is around this level,'' said Fred Bogart, a gold trader and executive vice president at Republic Bank in New York. ``If it drops below $350, all bets are off and anything could happen.'' John Lutely, managing director of the Gold Institute in Washington, said reports that the Soviets have had trouble meeting debt payments have made many traders fearful that the world's second-largest gold producer may begin selling more gold to raise hard currency. The fear, rather than any evidence of actual selling, may be forcing the market down, he said. ``They're smart traders and they know when it's not in their best interest to sell. And it's not in their interest,'' Bogart said, dismissing talk of big Soviet gold solds. Some traders and analysts said it's more likely that investors have left the gold market in favor of stocks, judging by the rise in the Dow Jones industrial average toward the 3,000 level in recent weeks. The easing of inflation worries also has triggered a big rally in bond prices in recent weeks. ``People have been going to paper rather than hold on to precious metals,'' Kadlec said.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Unveils Plan for ``One Market'' in Stock Index Futures
DOC.TEXT: A Bush administration plan to transfer authority over stock index futures from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to the rival Securities and Exchange Commission could tie up needed legislative reforms for both agencies, say officials. The Treasury Department unveiled the measure Tuesday _ almost a month after indicating it would propose legislation to end the turf battle between the futures market overseer and the stock market regulator. The CFTC and the SEC have been locked in an escalating war of words over which should oversee financial products that have elements of both a security and a futures contract. Such hybrid products include stock index futures, which allow investors to speculate on movements in the stock market without having to buy the underlying stocks. The administration's bill would ``unify regulation under the SEC of the `one market' of stocks, stock options and stock index futures,'' according to a Treasury fact sheet. But in a speech delivered earlier Tuesday, Mary L. Schapiro, an SEC commissioner, worried that the bill had slim prospects for passage in the dwindling congressional session because ``this is a highly divisive, emotionally charged issue on Capitol Hill.'' And ``while we wallow in the jurisdictional quagmire, other critically important legislation may be held up,'' Ms. Schapiro told the National Economists Club. She favors an outright merger of the SEC and CFTC. The chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, Rep. Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said switching authority from one agency to another ``is not a solution.'' The courts have interpreted the Commodity Exchange Act as giving the CFTC regulatory authority over any financial product with even the slightest aspect of a futures contract. But SEC and Treasury officials have complained that this has led to long and costly legal battles while innovative financial products are being developed or copied in overseas markets _ hurting American competitiveness. The administration bill would modify the ``exclusivity clause'' of the Commodity Exchange Act to give the SEC authority over stock index futures. The move has been opposed vehemently by the CFTC and its supporters on Capitol Hill, mostly on the agriculture committees of the House and Senate. They have claimed that giving stock index futures to the SEC will hobble the CFTC's ability to regulate other futures contracts and reduce liquidity in the markets. De la Garza asked the Treasury to submit legislative proposals ``to improve CFTC's regulation of the markets for stock index futures.'' Noting that a CFTC reform bill has been passed in the House but remains tied up in committee in the Senate over the stock index futures issue, de la Garza called on the Senate to ``act on the CFTC reauthorization bill at the earlist possible time so we can go to conference and produce a final bill that gives the CFTC the powers that it needs.'' In proposing the bill, Treasury officials maintained Tuesday that the only real change would be the name of the regulator because stock index futures would be regulated ``under the basic structure of the Commodity Exchange Act, not as securities.'' The administration claimed the disruption to the futures markets would be minimal because ``stock index futures represent less than 10 percent of the futures volume under CFTC jurisdiction.'' The bill also would give authority for setting margins _ the downpayment investors must make when buying securities on credit _ on stock index futures to the SEC. Currently margins on futures contracts are set by the exchanges themselves, usually at a fraction of the 50 percent required in securities transactions. Stock market margins are set by the Federal Reserve Board. The Fed favors placing margin-setting authority under one agency, although it hasn't said which agency it favors.

DOC.HEAD: Macy Says It's Examining Ways to Restructure Debt
DOC.TEXT: Investors bid up the price of R.H. Macy & Co. Inc.'s junk bonds after the retailer said it was looking at ways of restructuring its ponderous $5.67 billion debt. Macy disclosed the news Tuesday in a letter to stockholders that accompanied its third-quarter results. Investors and creditors have been concerned about Macy's financial health since the retailer suffered a $39 million loss in its second quarter, which includes the crucial Christmas shopping season. The company, which is still paying down debt from its $3.74 billion leveraged buyout in 1986, told its stockholders, ``We have been actively examining opportunities to reduce or refinance our debt.'' ``We will continue to explore these alternatives in the hope of benefitting from current market conditions and opportunities,'' the letter said. The company also said it expected its results from the current quarter ``to be somewhat improved'' from the same period of last year. Word of the letter reached trading rooms in late afternoon and boosted the price of Macy's 14{ percent bonds due in 2001 by $2.50, to $67 per $100 face amounte. The retailer's 14{ percent bonds due in 1998 rose $3 to $56.50. The company's bonds took a hit recently after several creditors _ known as factors _ said they were reconsidering their standards for financing shipments to Macy. Some of the concerns were eased May 25, when the company said its cash flow, the key to paying down its debt, rose 4 percent during the third quarter. On Tuesday, Macy said it lost $63.1 million in its fiscal third quarter ended April 28. It lost $64.1 million in the same period a year earlier. Sales in the period edged up to $1.49 billion from $1.48 billion. For the first nine months of its fiscal year, Macy reported a loss of $135.3 million, compared with a loss of $10.5 million a year earlier. Sales rose to $5.64 billion from $5.38 billion. Macy ran into trouble during the Christmas season _ a time when it hoped to earn about half of its annual profits _ because it was forced to slash prices to compete with Campeau Corp.'s department stores. Campeau's chains had cut their prices as they tried to bring in customers and avoid filing for bankruptcy court protection from their creditors. The attempt was in vain _ the chains filed for Chapter 11 reorganization in January. ``It is no secret that we had a down Christmas quarter last year,'' Macy said Tuesday. ``Our game plan is working and it should yield significant improvement in cash flow and a return to historical levels of profitability for our November through January quarter,'' the retailer said. The company said it had discussed its outlook with several factors, and, ``We feel that this information was appreciated by the factors.''

DOC.HEAD: Eckerd Acquiring 220 Revco Drugstores
DOC.TEXT: The Jack Eckerd Corp. is acquiring 220 Revco drugstores in five states in a deal that will make Eckerd Drugs the nation's second-largest pharmaceuticals chain, both companies announced. Jack Eckerd Corp., which owns 1,575 Eckerd Drugs outlets in 13 states, said Tuesday it is buying the Revco stores for an undisclosed price from Revco D.S. Inc., based in Twinsburg, Ohio. Revco filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act two years ago. If completed, the sale would make Eckerd's drug store chain the nation's second-largest, with a total of 1,795 outlets. Jack Eckerd Corp. is buying the Revco stores through its holding company, Eckerd Holdings II Inc. The holding company was formed by management with Merrill Lynch Capital Partners, a New York-based investment banking company. Under the deal, Eckerd is to buy Revco stores in Florida, Louisiana, Mississippi, Oklahoma and Texas. The sale is subject to approval by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court. A hearing is expected later this month, according to a statement issued by Eckerd. In Florida, Eckerd will purchase 43 of Revco's 55 stores. In Twinsburg, Ohio, Revco announced Tuesday it plans to to sell its remaining 12 stores in Florida. Last January, Revco announced plans to sell 712 of its stores in 17 states in a bid to reduce the number of its stores to about 1,100 in 10 eastern states. The trade magazine ``Drug Store News'' reported at the end of last year that Revco was No. 2 in the nation. The industry's largest chain, according to the publication, was Rite Aid Corp., based in Shiremanstown, Penn., which has 2,353 stores. Jack Eckerd Corp. also operates 233 Express Photo Labs, 33 Visionworks and 57 Eckerd Optical Centers in 13 states.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Files Fraud Charges Against Drexel Unit Officers
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor has filed criminal charges against three former officers of the Spanish unit of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. for alleged fraudulent trading practices. Madrid Superior Court prosecutor Jesus Silva Pinto's filing Tuesday accused the three men of using fraudulent business documents to obtain shares during the partial privatization of the state-controlled Repsol SA oil firm in April 1989, court sources said Wednesday. The criminal charges were believed to be the first filed against a securities firm in Spain for actions that until now have been handled through administrative sanctions, according to the sources, who asked to remain anonymous. If convicted, the former executives of now defunct DBL Capital Markets Espana SA could face maximum prison sentences of 12 years. Spain's National Securities Commission opened an investigation into the case in June 1989 and ruled DBL Capital Markets Espana had committed ``a very serious infraction'' of trading practices during the Repsol privatization. Last November, the watchdog agency recommended the Economy Ministry fine the brokerage $556,725, or five times the amount of gross profits made in the operation, the maximum fine under law. The watchdog agency then turned over its evidence to the Madrid Superior Court prosecutor's office to determine whether the infraction constituted criminal fraud punishable by law. The Spanish unit's U.S. parent company has filed for federal bankruptcy protection after pleading guilty last year to charges in connection with a widespread probe of insider trading.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-A&P Executive and 5 Others Charged in SEC Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: A former top executive of the A&P supermarket chain gave inside information about proposed supermarket takeovers to five friends and business associates, the Securities and Exchange Commission has charged. The charges were made in a civil lawsuit filed Tuesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Alan C. Goulding, A&P's former senior executive vice president and chief operating officer, and five other men who allegedly traded securities based on the information from Goulding. The commission said the defendants had agreed to settle the charges, without admitting guilt. Goulding, 60, of Allendale, N.J., will pay a penalty of $635,000, and the other five will pay a total of $1.46 million in penalties and alleged illegal profits. A&P, the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Co. Inc., operates a nationwide chain of supermarkets based in Montvale, N.J. The lawsuit said that from May 1986 through March 1987, Goulding learned, through his position at the company, of proposed takeovers by A&P of three competitors _ Shopwell Inc., Delchamps Inc. and Waldbaum Inc. Knowing it was non-public, Goulding improperly passed on the information to three friends or associates who then bought and sold stock in the targeted companies, the SEC said. One of the recipients, Murray Verlin, 68, of Miami, a part owner of a food distribution company called Pure Maid Inc., in turn tipped off two of his friends about the information from Goulding, the lawsuit said. The SEC alleged that Goulding also told Verlin about a favorable earnings report in March 1987, before A&P released the figures to the public and that Verlin made money trading on A&P stock. Goulding took early retirement from A&P in July of 1987, company spokesman Michael Rourke said. In addition to Goulding and Verlin, the other defendants in the lawsuit are: Robert J. Foley, 68, of Redwood City, Calif., a self-employed food marketing consultant; Joel Lopate, 56, of Miami, no occupation given; Kurt Goldman, 65, of Boca Raton, Fla., ex-president of Johanna Farms Dairy, a New Jersey supplier of dairy products; and Peter Goldman, 62, of Boca Raton, Fla., a former executive vice president of Johanna Farms Dairy.

DOC.HEAD: Entrepreneurial Spirit Rises from Corporate Restructurings
Laserphoto, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: When Tony Quiroga received his termination notice from Clairol Inc. last year, he quickly found a new employer: himself. Quiroga, a former factory manager at the leading beauty products firm in Stamford, Conn., decided to ditch the corporate mainstream and start his own small business. Now he sets his own hours and signs all the checks for a franchise branch of Mailboxes Etc., an office products and postal services chain, in the nearby town of Fairfield. Quiroga's new life hasn't freed him from worrying about the amount of cash in the bank. Accustomed to company health plans after 19 years, he panicked when his 17-year-old son got hurt a month ago and had to be rushed to the hospital. He wasn't sure if his wife's insurance policy would cover the bill. Nonetheless, Quiroga said, he likes running a small business. So, apparently, do other former executives who have started their own companies after losing jobs in corporate overhauls. Thousands of lower-and mid-level executives have been laid off in the dizzying era of mergers, takeovers and restructurings that have reshaped the face of corporate America in recent years. The National Planning Association, a Washington-based business research organization, estimates that based on government statistics, plant closings and other corporate staff reductions have displaced an estimated 2 million workers a year since the late 1970s. Most executive victims of this workforce readjustment have sought jobs with other businesses, where they find comfort and security in a steady salary and benefits, said Joan Learn, president of The Greenwich Group, an executive counseling firm that encourages executives to consider self-employment. But evidence suggests a growing number of these people are viewing pink slips as golden opportunities to become their own bosses, selling everything from flowers to computer software. Experts say part of the reason is the insecurity that layoff victims feel by going to work for someone else again. Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a Chicago-based consulting and executive placement company, estimates the number of laid-off executives who have become entrepreneurs has tripled in the past five years, from 7 percent of the total in 1985 to about 20 percent today. The company bases the estimate on its own quarterly surveys of 600 displaced managers around the country. ``There is no question that a prime factor in the decision to become an entrepreneur is concern over another discharge,'' said James Challenger, company president. ``These people are hoping to guarantee that they will never again hear an employer tell them they no longer have a job.'' Kathleen Purdy walked down both career paths when she was laid off as director of internal management consulting for Infilco Corp. of Meriden, Conn. She started looking for new jobs with help from Learn, but also drafted a plan to form her own consulting firm. She chickened out when time came to launch the plan, instead accepting a job as a marketing director for Onsite Energy, a subsidiary of PacifiCorp. in Portland, Ore. But when she got laid off from that job two years later, she took the plunge. ``I decided to go for it, and I'm just delighted,'' said Purdy, whose consulting firm opened in January. ``It's working out very well.'' Going it alone isn't always easy for the corporate type, however, especially middle managers who have staked their professional careers on loyalty to a well-established business with thousands of employees. ``You miss the camaraderie of your associates. You miss the second-family society that a large company has to offer. You make a lot of good friends when you're working at large corporations,'' said Dan McCarthy, a former senior executive at Pitney Bowes Inc., a leading office-equipment maker in Stamford. McCarthy left the company on his own last September when it announced a restructuring that watered down his job. He's just getting started running a franchise branch of Remedy Temporary Services, an employment agency. Many displaced executives find they must readjust their focus away from expense accounts and profit-and-loss statements, and toward concern for their customers, whom they are often meeting face to face for the first time. ``Having been senior management for the last 18, 19 years, there is a management syndrome you have to be careful of _ you can't just sit at your desk and feel you're going to be firing off a lot of orders to people,'' said McCarthy, who spent 29 years at NCR Corp. in Dayton, Ohio, before he went to Pitney Bowes and then ventured out on his own. ``There is a big difference in coming out of a corporate structure, where things are much more formalized and there are many long meetings and a certain amount of politics that exist in every company,'' he said. ``That's fine for that way of life, but it doesn't work for the entrepreneur. You have to keep the customer in mind every time.'' Many former executives who turn to self-employment say they find a new source of energy and excitement in their layoff afterlife that compensates for the anxieties. ``I'm getting more of a kick out of doing this than I'd ever anticipated,'' McCarthy said. ``It allows me to bring forth all the experiences I had in the past and use that effort and energy on my own behalf.'' Learn, who runs The Greenwich Group with her husband, said the firm has grown steadily since its founding four years ago, largely because of corporate restructurings and growing interest in self-employment. They estimate they will help 300 to 400 people from 50 to 60 companies this year. So far, only one of the firm's would-be entrepreneur clients has given up _ an executive who underestimated his need to be around people. He sold the business and went back to work for someone else. The rest appear to be thriving, Learn said. ``Even though it's risky, it just feels right,'' Purdy said. ``You start creating things and you realize you have the power to create the income, to create the business. In a way, it's more security because you control it. It's not a company that may have to downsize. There isn't security in corporations anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Five-Pound Note Shrinks And The Queen Ages
DOC.TEXT: Britain introduced a smaller five pound note Wednesday that includes a new engraving of a gracefully aging queen. The change _ the first in two decades _ is designed to combat high-tech forgeries and cut production costs. The new note is scheduled to be released into circulation on Thursday. ``No item created by man can't be recreated,'' said Nigel Bevitt-Smith, manager of design and development at the Bank of England's printing works. ``What we try to do is to make it time-consuming and as expensive as possible.'' The five-pound notes have been reduced in size from 5.7-by-3 inches to 5.3-by-2.7 inches. Among the other changes, the dominant blue in the notes was lightened from navy to turquoise, and a blend of background colors was created to challenge sophisticated forgers who use modern color reproduction machines. Also, the position and color of the numbers was changed and a silver-colored windowed thread running through the note was added. The Bank of England, which already has printed 200 million of the new notes, said Queen Elizabeth's new portrait shows the monarch ``gracefully aged,'' rather than as a delicate brunette young enough to be Prince Charles' sister. Railway pioneer George Stephenson replaces the Duke of Wellington on the new notes. All English notes will be redesigned over the next four years and will be between 16 percent and 22 percent smaller, the Bank of England said.

DOC.HEAD: My Name is Donald J. Trump, Millionaire ... For Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, Trump _ whose name ..., with one graf to RESTORE Trump's first name. A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: For years he's played a real-life game of Monopoly with such swagger that it seemed the stakes were play money. Now a cash crunch may force the tycoon to trade away his yacht, his hotels or his casinos. Donald Trump _ whose name adorns everything from airplanes to board games, usually in large letters _ may also have to wave arrivederci to the glitzy, fast-lane lifestyle he enjoyed during his rise in the 1980s. Creditors reportedly are pressing the multimillionaire for cash, and negotiations that are under way could compel Trump to sell huge chunks of his empire. The real estate and casino magnate has a reported $2 billion in bank debt. His holdings, once estimated at $1.5 billion, had been sliced to $500 million, Forbes magazine reported last month. The Taj Mahal, his centerpiece Atlantic City casino, is said to be for sale. The Trump Princess, his yacht, is on the block. The Trump Shuttle, his airline, is up for grabs. On Monday, bondholders filed a lawsuit accusing Trump of promoting the Taj Mahal at the expense of the Trump Plaza and Trump Castle in Atlantic City. Add to the equation his estranged wife, Ivana, who awaits her share with a $25 million prenuptial agreement that's looking better all the time. ``He'll have to trim the fat: get rid of the boat, the mansions, the helicopter,'' one banker involved in the Trump talks told The Wall Street Journal. While this answers the question ``What do you give the man who has everything?'' _ cold, hard cash _ it raises another: what will Donald be left with? Trump: The Living Room Carpet? The Trump Motel and Drive-In Theater? Trump, through spokesman Dan Klores, declined to comment further on the situation Tuesday. But The Donald never foresaw such problems in his first self-congratulatory book, ``Trump: The Art of the Deal.'' ``I don't do it for the money. I've got enough, much more than I'll ever need,'' Trump wrote in the 1988 best-seller. As recently as April, the developer claimed he was selling off assets only to become ``the king of cash.'' Marvin Roffman was not swayed by such talk. The Philadelphia gaming analyst predicted problems for the Taj Mahal, and he claims Trump had him fired for saying so. Roffman, apparently vindicated by the reports of layoffs and losses at the palatial resort, bit his tongue Tuesday and cited a pending legal action. ``My attorneys have cautioned me, and I really can't talk,'' he said. The New York tabloids had no such concerns, and the rumors of impending financial crisis produced a round of entertaining Trump-bashing. ``Uh-Owe!'' headlined the front page of the Post beneath a photo of Trump. Inside, the paper posed the question ``The Taj: Eighth Blunder Of The World?'' ``Trump In A Slump'' announced the Daily News. ``To me, Trump sounds about two steps away from selling used magazines on the sidewalk,'' wrote Daily News columnist Gail Collins. At least one expert felt she might not be too far off. ``Trump just thought the real estate market was heading upwards indefinitely and people would keep buying at higher and higher prices. He forgot that whatever goes up must come down,'' said Abe Wallach, an executive at the development firm First Capital Partners. At the very least, his financial problems could postpone publication of Trump's latest laudatory book. Its unfortunate title: ``Trump: Surviving at the Top.''

DOC.HEAD: Budget Bargaining Resumes With Visit From Cheney
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs with talks beginning; picks up 2nd graf pvs, The session ... A version moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Administration and congressional bargainers resumed their slow-moving budget talks today with a visit from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, whose agency is a prime target for spending cuts. Many congressional Democrats have been arguing for months that with the breakup of the Warsaw Pact, the Pentagon's budget should be cut. Republicans are more reluctant to make such reductions. ``I'm going to give them an old-fashioned Gospel revival-hour on defense,'' the ranking Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee, John Warner of Virginia, said before entering the closed-door meeting. The session, the fifth since bargaining began last month, comes as Democrats and Republicans begin maneuvering for political advantage over the annual spending bills for next year. Congress' majority Democrats said they would start working on the appropriations measures in the House and Senate this week. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, argued, however that those bills should not be enacted until negotiators work out a deficit-cutting deal for next year. He contended that if Democrats begin working on the spending bills before a budget deal is reached, the measures will be too expensive because they will not reflect any cuts set by the budget bargainers. ``If they do that, it would represent a virtually insurmountable obstacle to negotiating a good-faith compromise on the budget,'' said Gramm, one of the budget negotiators. But Democrats noted that the start of fiscal 1991 is Oct. 1, less than four months away. ``We are reaching a critical stage here,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. Democrats planned to begin subcommittee wok on spending bills in the House as early as Thursday. Democrats said the full Senate could begin considering a 1991 budget within two weeks. The budget is a non-binding fiscal blueprint that lays the groundwork for spending measures. The budget talks between the White House and Congress were resuming after a break of nearly two weeks for lawmakers' Memorial Day recess. So far, negotiators have reached an informal consensus to try reduce next year's federal deficit by $45 billion to $60 billion. They also want to find a total of $425 billion to $600 billion in savings over the next five years. But there is still a long way to go. Democrats tend to prefer deficit cuts in the high level of those ranges, while Republicans favor lesser reductions. And the bargainers have not yet traded proposals for shrinking the deficit by cutting spending and raising taxes. Such negotiating is not expected to begin for at least a week. Because of easing East-West tensions, the Pentagon is expected to bear a heavy portion of whatever spending cuts are worked out. Cheney was stating the Defense Department's case at today's meeting. When President Bush submitted his budget in January, he proposed spending $303.3 billion for defense in fiscal 1991. The House approved a spending plan with $295.4 billion for the military, while the Senate Budget Committee has earmarked $293.9 billion for defense in its blueprint. The goal of the talks is to find a way to limit next year's red ink to no more than $64 billion, as required by the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law. The White House says that unless something is done, the 1991 budget gap could be $206 billion. That would be more than double the $100.5 billion shortfall Bush predicted in January.

DOC.HEAD: Hitachi Developes World's Fastest General-Purpose Computer
DOC.TEXT: Hitachi Ltd. of Japan said Wednesday it has developed the world's fastest mainframe computer, the first time the company has beaten industry leader IBM and other manufacturers to a new-generation release. The Hitachi M-880 Processor family, to be released Friday, will ``allow us to catch up with IBM, and has increased our competitiveness,'' Hitachi Vice President Takeo Miura told reporters. He said the new generation computers will use about 20 percent less power and take up about half the space of the latest processor family developed by International Business Machines Corp. Hitachi, however, was not expected to ship the new models in Japan until the fall and in the United States until the second quarter of 1991, about the same time IBM was expected to have its latest mainframe ready, said Don Young, an analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein in New York. With IBM's next generation still an unknown quantity, ``I think what we've got here is apples and oranges. Apples is Hitachi today and oranges is IBM tomorrow,'' Young said. He added, however, that the announcement ``really makes (Hitachi) an incredible player in this market and puts them into the range of competing with IBM.'' Hitachi said monthly lease charges on its new mainframes would range from $512,450 to $1.02 million, about 10 percent to 15 percent better than the pricing currently offered by IBM. ``I would surprised if we don't see a 10 to 15 percent price improvement from IBM'' next year, Young said. Such general-purpose computers are mainly used for information management systems in large corporations. IBM currently controls more than 70 percent of the U.S. mainframe market; Amdahl Corp. is No. 2 with 10 percent to 15 percent and Hitachi is a distant third with about of half of Amdahl's share, Young said. In Japan, Hitachi also lags behind IBM and Fujitsu Ltd. The four new Hitachi models were developed in response to customer demand for faster, more powerful computers, Miura said. All are IBM-compatible, he said. The top-of-the-line M-880-420 is capable of performing at 155 million instructions a second, compared to 88 for Hitachi's current high-end model and 122 for IBM's top-line model, the 3090 600J, the company said. This is the first time Hitachi has beaten IBM and other competitors such as Fujitsu and Amdahl to a new-generation release in the mainframe market.

DOC.HEAD: IHI to Join Rolls Royce in Producing New Plane Engine
DOC.TEXT: A Japanese manufacturing conglomerate announced Wednesday that it has joined forces with Rolls Royce PLC of Britain in producing parts of Rolls Royce aircraft engines for use in Boeing Co.'s as-yet undeveloped 777 jetliner. The agreement in principle calls for Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries Co. to undertake 5 percent of the production of a proposed Trent 800 engine, said IHI official Masahide Wakamatsu. IHI would produce such parts as a turbine blades and shafts, he said. IHI and Rolls Royce will discuss details of the project after Boeing decides whether to use the Trent 800 engine for the 777, Wakamatsu said. Boeing expects to begin development on the 350-to-360-passenger jetliner this summer. A Boeing spokesman said Wednesday the three major builders of large engines _ Rolls, General Electric Co. and Pratt & Whitney Co. _ would probably all come up with engines suited for service on the 777. If Boeing accepts the Rolls engine, the company would in turn offer it to its customers, who would make the decision on which engine to use, the spokesman, John Wheeler, said from the company's headquarters in Seattle. Wheeler said first deliveries of the 777 jetliner are expected in mid-1995.

DOC.HEAD: Grain and Soybean Futures Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly higher Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The market was heavily influenced by reports that a cloud with unidentified contents was heading towards Finland from the Soviet Union, said John Frazier, an analyst with Gerald Inc. in Chicago. The cloud was first spotted over the Soviet Union on May 26, according to Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Authority. An agency spokesman said Wednesday the USSR had not informed them of any radioactivity in the cloud. The reports triggered speculation about possible damage to farmland in those areas that could mean stronger demand for U.S. grains and soybeans. Also influencing the market was a weather outlook by a private forecaster that calls for unusually hot, dry weather in the Midwest in late July and early August. The heat is forecast for a period when corn and soybeans mature. In addition to news of the unidentified cloud, soybean futures received a boost from strong cash markets for soybeans, light selling by farmers and the continuing Brazilian port shutdown. Wheat futures received some support from commercial and speculative buying, although forecasts of warm weather that would speed the harvesting of the winter wheat crop weighed on prices. DOC.TEXT: The Seagram Co. Ltd. said Wednesday its profit fell 4.6 percent in its first fiscal quarter, citing sharply lower results from its investment in the Du Pont Co. The beverage company said its net income fell to $187 million, or $1.97 per share, in the three months ended April 30 from $196 million, or $2 per share, in the same period a year earlier. Revenue rose 5.4 percent to $1.29 billion from $1.23 billion in the same period last year. Operating income increased 25.6 percent to $157 million from $125 million in the same period of 1989. But Seagram said unremitted earnings from its 24.3 percent stake in E.I. du Pont de Nemours and Co. tumbled to $79 million from $108 million a year earlier. Its dividend income from the Du Pont investment rose to $66 million from $58 million a year earlier, however. ``We are pleased with the increases in operating income and sales, which reflect the strength of our international spirits and wine operations as well as an unexpectedly strong performance from our Brazilian affiliate,'' company President Edgar Bronfman Jr. said in a statement. Seagram makes and markets distilled spirits, wines, wine coolers, fruit juices and soft drinks. Its brands include Glenlivet Scotch Whiskies, Seagram's Extra Dry Gin, Martell Cognacs, Barton & Guestier Wines, Seagram's Coolers, Tropicana Pure Premium Orange Juice and Soho Natural Sodas.

DOC.HEAD: No Bidders Emerge for Sakowitz Chain; Liquidation Planned
DOC.TEXT: All but one of the Sakowitz specialty stores were slated for liquidation after no bids were received for the Texas-based retailer at a bankruptcy court hearing Wednesday. The once-proud chain, which includes four stores in Houston, one in Dallas and another in Cincinnati, is 80 percent owned by L.J. Hooker Corp. Hooker has been disposing of its assets under bankruptcy court supervision. U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Tina Brozman indicated she would approve the plan to liquidate all of the Texas Sakowitz stores and a formal order was expected to be issued soon. Going-out-of-business sales would start soon thereafter and run through the end of July. The Sakowitz in Cincinnati's Forest Fair Mall would remain open. Business at the shopping mall, another Hooker holding, could suffer if the store closed. Similar arrangements were made when Hooker divested its Bonwit Teller and B. Altman & Co. department store chains. Hooker has kept the Altman's and Bonwit Teller stores open for business at the Forest Fair Mall. Hooker also has continued operating a Bonwit Teller in a Columbia, S.C. mall that it owns. The Sakowitz chain, headquartered in Houston, has about 450 employees. It has focused on women's apparel and accessories. During much of its 88 years in business, the chain enjoyed a good reputation for quality and fashion sense. But in the mid-1980s a struggling regional economy due largely to the oil price slump proved too much for Sakowitz. It entered bankruptcy court proceedings in 1985. Sakowitz reorganized in Chapter 11 of the federal Bankruptcy Code and emerged from court protection under the stewardship of a new company that teamed up with Hooker. At that time, Hooker acquired its 80 percent stake. An attorney for Hooker, Sheldon I. Hirshon, said at the hearing that Sakowitz never succeeded in really turning itself around. In the year ended Jan. 31, 1990, Sakowitz suffered a net operating loss of $4.4 million and lost $1.3 million in the past three months, Hirshon said. At the hearing, Hooker invited bids for either its interest in Sakowitz or the assets of the chain. No bidders came forward. An attorney for Robert T. Sakowitz, formerly president and chief executive officer of the chain, told the court that Sakowitz had wanted to make an offer but needed more time to arrange financing. Sakowitz didn't make a formal bid and Judge Brozman moved the case forward. Sakowitz, who attended the hearing and spoke with reporters, expressed regret at the chain's fate and disputed the implication that it was beyond redemption. He distributed a personal statement in which he said the complications of Hooker's bankruptcy proceedings discouraged many domestic and foreign investors from joining him in bidding for Sakowitz. With the liquidation of Sakowitz, Hooker will have disposed of the bulk of its retail holdings that were acquired since 1986. The Atlanta-based company, which still has various commercial and residential property holdings, is a subsidiary of Australia's Hooker Corp. Sydney-based Hooker is being managed by a court-appointed provisional liquidator in a process similar to what its American subsidiary is experiencing in the U.S. bankruptcy court.

DOC.HEAD: Slumping Brokerage Announces Major Overhaul
DOC.TEXT: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. overhauled its operations Wednesday, reviving a respected investment banking name and dumping a vestige of its expansionist 1980s in a bid to rebound from record losses on Wall Street. The restructuring marks another step by parent American Express Co. to reverse the fortunes of the nation's second largest brokerage, which lost $915 million in the first three months of the year. Shearson said it was grouping into two divisions from four: Shearson Lehman Brothers for individual investing and asset management, and Lehman Brothers for investment banking and capital markets activities. The full firm will be known as Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. In the investment banking division, Shearson hopes resurrecting the 140-year-old Lehman Brothers name will mean more respect and cache during one of the slowest periods in Wall Street history. ``We hope the Lehman Brothers name will have the magic still,'' Shearson Chairman and Chief Executive Howard L. Clark Jr. said in an interview. ``A little magic wouldn't hurt.'' Shearson acquired the Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. investment bank in 1984 as part of a rapid growth strategy during the deal-heavy '80s, dubbing the new firm Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. _ same as the new one. Lehman Brothers dates to 1850, when it was founded by immigrants from Bavaria as a commodities house in Montgomery, Ala. The investment bank was among those dominating Wall Street in the early 1900s and grew rapidly after World War II. About 1,000 Lehman brothers veterans still work at Shearson, the No.2 brokerage behind Merrill Lynch & Co. Under then-chairman Peter Cohen, who was ousted earlier this year by American Express Chairman James D. Robinson III, Shearson acquired E.F. Hutton & Co. shortly after the 1987 stock market crash. By dropping Hutton from its name, Shearson erases the public connection with a merger that fostered a clash of corporate cultures and has been called the firm's biggest expansion mistake. Clark said the new structure organizes the firm along customer lines, with Shearson Lehman Brothers for individual investments and Lehman Brothers for institutions. He said the new shape would ``focus accountability and responsibility of the business ... to respond to client needs and interests.'' Clark is part of the American Express invasion running the Shearson overhaul. When he was picked to head the firm, he was chief financial officer of American Express and his father is a former chairman of the company. The credit card and travel service giant in recent months has put more than $1 billion in capital into Shearson and is buying all of the brokerage's remaining common stock. American Express now holds 61 percent of Shearson. Shearson lost an industry record $915 million in the first quarter, in part because of expenses to pay for a restructuring including about 2,000 layoffs. Most Wall Street firms have been forced to cut back because of an industry slowdown since the stock market crash. Shearson also has been criticized for bad management, overexpansion and excessive spending during the last decade. Shearson said its Boston Co. money management subsidiary would remain a separate business. Richard S. Fuld Jr., a Lehman veteran and current president of Shearson's capital markets group, and Sherman R. Lewis Jr., president of investment and merchant banking, were named co-chief executives of the new Lehman Brothers division. That division will serve corporations, governments and institutions, including capital markets sales, research and trading, as well as investment and merchant banking. As expected, Jonathan S. Linen, an American Express executive, was named president and chief executive of the Shearson Lehman Brothers division. Linen currently is president and chief executive of American Express' direct marketing and travelers checks group.

DOC.HEAD: Yeutter Says Costs Of No Mulitlateral Trade Agreement Would Be High
DOC.TEXT: Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter warned Wednesday that an agricultural trade war could result if a deadlock over the United States' demands at international trade talks continues through the end of the year. The United States is seeking the removal of European farm export subsidies over 10 years. If no agreement is reached, ``I guarantee you the costs for some of our trading partners would increase dramatically,'' said Yeutter, the luncheon speaker at a forum sponsored by The Journal of Commerce and the National Foreign Trade Council. ``The United States has to protect its own interests,'' Yeutter said. ``I've thought about how we can do that and hope I can keep those thoughts in the back of my mind and never have to surface them.'' Yeutter, while conceding that U.S. farm policies also distort trade, said U.S. export subsidies amount to less than $1 billion a year, while European help for farm exports comes to $10 billion annually. ``We all have to go down the reform road together,'' Yeutter said. Yeutter said proposals for cutting European subsidies in half are insufficient. The Common Market's export subsidies are intended to help relatively expensive European farm products compete against lower-priced goods in the world market. U.S. negotiators unsuccessfully pushed their call to stop export subsidies, as well as an end to import barriers and domestic subsidies, at a meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development last week in Paris. ``I am never surprised about intransigence on the part of the European Community,'' Yeutter said of the deadlock. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills and other officials have said the agricultural issue is the ``linchpin'' for all other topics in the current round of negotiations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, or GATT, a forum for promoting freer trade. The talks, known as the Uruguay Round, began in that country in 1986 and are to end this December in Brussels. The negotiations involve about 100 countries and are designed to reduce barriers to trade. U.S. officials estimate that ending the farm subsidies could boost U.S. agricultural exports by $11 billion annually. Common Market officials say the subsidies can be reduced, but not eliminated because so many small farmers depend on them. Earlier at the forum, Andreas Van Agt, European Community ambassador to the United States, said Europe would not agree ``unrealistic solutions that are politically unachievable,'' such as abandoning subsidies. Among the areas of discussion held up by the deadlock are textiles and services. Third World countries want fewer barriers to textile trade. The United States, under pressure from the domestic textile industry, has been seeking less comprehensive reduction of existing tariffs and quotas. GATT doesn't cover textile trade, which is handled by the Multi-Fiber Agreement between about 80 countries. The United States, however, is seeking to have GATT cover financial services. Poorer countries are opposed to GATT regulation of banking, investment and insurance so they can protect their infant financial industries. The next formal meeting of negotiators is scheduled for July 23 in Geneva, Switzerland.

DOC.HEAD: Gerald Greenwald Forsakes Chrysler, Straps into UAL Buyout Cockpit
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When Lee Iacocca hired Gerald Greenwald to help him rescue Chrysler Corp. from collapse, it began with a discreet phone call to Greenwald's home in Caracas, Venezuela, where he worked for Ford Motor Co. More than a decade later, a similar secret offer confronted Greenwald again. Only this time, a UAL Corp. union coalition was making the surreptitious contact, luring the Chrysler vice chairman with the job of leading its effort to buy the airline company for $4.54 billion. Why Greenwald vacated Chrysler, especially at a time when its financial health again appears to be sliding dangerously, may be debated for a long time. Greenwald and people who know him say he was lured away by the enormous challenge of carrying off the UAL buyout, a debt-financed deal that would result in the largest employee-owned company in the country _ if successful. ``Here I am having a second chance to go through a major industrial event in American history,'' Greenwald said when he made the surprise announcement May 31 that he was quitting. Some auto industry people familiar with Greenwald, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they're skeptical about his chances of assembling the financing needed to purchase UAL, which has seen several earlier buyout proposals fall through. The current climate of tight credit won't make it any easier for him to meet an Aug. 9 deadline for raising the money. But others said that if anyone can coordinate the UAL effort it is Greenwald. His calm and reassuring manner was critical in winning the confidence of skeptical lenders to Chrysler in the early 1980s and helped convince the federal government to provide $1.5 billion in loan guarantees. ``I could not think of anybody better suited to put together the awesome financial arrangements that the buyers of UAL are trying to do. He has tremendous talent with bankers,'' said Jerry H. Pyle, a former Chrysler executive who now is president of Gulf States Toyota in Houston. ``Mr. Iacocca handled the Feds and Jerry handled the bankers and I'm not sure he didn't have a tougher job than Lee did,'' Pyle said. In Greenwald's 11-year tenure with Chrysler, he established himself as a careful, deliberate, diplomatic and soft-spoken complement to Iacocca, the scrappy chairman of the No. 3 automaker. Greenwald is considered largely responsible for imposing the financial discipline that resurrected Chrysler's profitability and made himself and Iacocca wealthy in the process. The two men could hardly be more different. Iacocca, 65, is a profane, flamboyant engineer and the son of Italian Catholic immigrants. Greenwald, 54, is son of Russian Jewish poultry wholesalers. He grew up in St. Louis, attended Princeton on an Eagle Scout scholarship, rose in the auto industry as a financier and is known to think carefully before making any important move. ``Iacocca was bombastic,'' one former Chrysler executive said. ``Jerry would examine off-the-wall ideas all the way to the obvious. A lot of times he would take the more obtuse direction. He was very much solicitous of the opinions of other people. But he would come to the point of having examined this whole thing and say, `OK, this is the way we should go.''' Despite their contrasting styles, both men developed a warm friendship, and Greenwald widely was considered Iacocca's likely successor. But Greenwald always treated the talk about taking Iacocca's place with self-effacing modesty. ``I don't think anyone is going to step into Lee's 21-inch shoes and walk the way he does,'' Greenwald once said. Greenwald's early experience in the auto business may have helped him prepare for his tenure at troubled Chrysler, which lost $1.1 billion in 1979 and $1.7 billion in 1980. His first job came with Ford in 1957, as a personnel administrator for a new division called Edsel. It collapsed in three months. Greenwald later recollected: ``I wondered how I could have done so badly so soon.'' But his career fared better than the Edsel. He moved into financial analysis and by the late 1960s was concentrating on Ford's Latin American operations. The company promoted him to management positions in Brazil, Paris, London and Caracas over most of the following 10 years. It was a life of 12-hour workdays and regular household-moving upheavals for wife Glenda and their four children. Greenwald liked life abroad, but the prospect of rising further in Ford's hierarchy remained unclear. So the phone call from Iaccoca in the spring of 1979, offering Greenwald a quantum leap in stature, wasn't unwelcome. Despite the close Iacocca-Greenwald relationship that developed over the next decade, speculation persisted about the succession question at Chrysler. The question was compounded by Iacocca's vague plans about retirement and the automaker's financial backslide in recent years. ``Clearly there was some kind of a battle shaping up over there,'' a former executive said. ``There is a certain amount of satisfaction and adrenalin that goes into the kind of situation that he and we all had at Chrysler _ putting it all back together and making it succeed. ``Once you've done that, then it didn't work out too well, it's down-on-your-knees time again.'' Some people familiar with Greenwald speculated privately that he was excited at the prospect of going into a new industry and defying the skepticism that a large employee-owned airline will succeed. ``I think he figures he's got a better chance of doing that than taking over an unhealthy Chrysler Corporation and making it work,'' one former Chrysler official said. Greenwald isn't considered extravagant or publicity hungry, and is known for quiet demonstrations of generosity. For example, he set up a college scholarship program for 50 fifth-graders in the public schools of University City, Mo., where he grew up. It could cost him $775,000 if all go on to get undergraduate degrees. Greenwald's wife, who established an independent writing career while the family was abroad, founded and runs the magazine Michigan Woman. It appears there will be no immediate changes in her professional life while her husband jets from home in the Detroit suburb of Bloomfield Hills to UAL's base in Chicago and to New York, where lies much of the money he seeks. ``We jokingly say if you've got to commute,'' Greenwald said, ``have one of the spouses run an airline.''
