DOC.HEAD: Central Bankers Optimistic About German Currency Unification
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the central banks of Japan, France, England and the United States expressed confidence Wednesday in the ability of West Germany's central bank to control inflation after East and West Germany merge their currencies next month. There has been concern that the plan could lead to inflation in West Germany because East Germans will be able to exchange some of their non-onvertible Ostmarks for the West German mark, leading to a vast increase in the spending power of East Germans. Inflation in West Germany, the dominant economy in Europe, could force the nation's central bank, the Bundesbank, to raise interest rates. That could unsettle world financial markets and lead to higher rates in other countries. But central bankers gathered at the annual International Monetary Conference told reporters they are unconcerned about that prospect because of the careful plans for monetary unification laid out by the West German government. Robin Leigh-Pemberton, governor of the Bank of England, said he believes there will be a 10 percent increase in West Germany's money supply as a result of much of East Germany's currency being converted into marks. That increase is roughly equal to the expected rise in the gross domestic product of the nations due to the unification, he said.``So it looks as though the immediate monetary situation is one of match, and therefore the immediate effect on interest rates may be neutral,'' he said. He said the Bundesbank ``has been confronted with a novel, difficult political situation, and in my opinion, they've handled it extremely well.'' Jacques de Larosiere, governor of the Bank of France, said, ``The way this process is being handled, the rapidity of the elaboration of the (monetary unification) treaty, the way things have been carved out in terms of the monetary devices _ all goes well for the stability of system and for interest rates.'' Takeshi Ohta, deputy governor of the Bank of Japan, said he also was confident about the ability of West Germany's monetary authorities to ensure a smooth transition to a unified currency. Federal Reserve Board Chairman Alan Greenspan said world interest rates already have a ``presumed forecast'' for the impact of the monetary unification, but that many unknown factors remain. ``There are a number of market forces that are involved in this process which will override whatever particular agreements are made,'' he said. ``It is quite conceivable (that) to the extent that events deviate from the markets' expectations, that rates either in Germany or elsewhere could either go up or down,'' he added. Bundesbank President Karl Otto Pohl originally was scheduled to attend the session but canceled several weeks ago, apparently due to constraints on his time in the face of the unification plan, conference organizers said. The conference brought together government and commercial bankers from 22 nations. On another topic, Greenspan was asked why the Federal Reserve has not acted recently to ease U.S. interest rates in light of signs of domestic economic weakness. ``The signs in the economy at this stage are really quite ambiguous in that respect,'' he said. He said it is true that the rate of economic growth is ``exceptionally slow,'' but that the unemployment rate has hardly changed in recent months. ``What we are seeing is a really quite unusual phenomenon, namely, very slow labor force growth and a corresponding rather slow economy associated with it, but we do not as yet see any underlying (economic) deterioration,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up in U.S.; Gold Off
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against all major currencies except its Canadian counterpart in sluggish domestic trading Wednesday marked by various international considerations. Gold prices posted moderate declines in the United States after moving slightly higher abroad. Foreign exchange dealers reported trading volume was light. A series of concerns depressed the Swiss franc and West German mark, steering investors to the dollar. Confirmation that Switzerland is seeking to join the International Monetary Fund and speculation about possible declines in Swiss interest rates encouraged selling of the franc, said Richard Levine, a first vice president at Merrill Lynch Futures. The West German mark came under renewed pressure amid reports of a potential strike by thousands of workers in East Germany. Unconfirmed rumors of a possible accident at a Soviet nuclear power plant _ stemming from reports that Finnish authorities were checking a large cloud drifting toward their country _ also weakened the mark. But Levine said the nuclear accident rumor didn't have a significant impact on currency trading overall. The dollar started out higher in Tokyo, rising 0.17 Japanese yen to a closing 152.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 152.45 yen. By the time trading finished in New York, the dollar was quoted at 152.68 yen, up from 152.35 yen late Tuesday. The British pound was quoted at $1.6880, compared with $1.6820 late Tuesday. Sterling weakened in later U.S. trading, dipping to $1.6875 late in New York from $1.6880 late Tuesday. Selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.6885 West German marks, up from 1.6840; 1.4365 Swiss francs, up from 1.4280; 5.6905 French francs, up from 5.6785; 1,242.00 Italian lire, up from 1,240.00; and 1.16975 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17605 Canadian. The Canadian dollar's strength was tied to various political developments in that country. There was talk in the market that a rift between the Maritime Provinces and the rest of the country wasn't as serious as previously believed. Other late rates for the dollar in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's levels, included: 1.6870 West German marks, down from 1.6910; 1.4280 Swiss francs, down from 1.4340; 5.6870 French francs, down from 5.7020; 1.8980 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9070; 1,241.00 Italian lire, down from 1,244.25; and 1.1723 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1752. Gold prices were mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for June delivery settled at $357.40 a troy ounce, down $2.40 from Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a troy ounce of gold bullion at $356.75 as of 4 p.m. EDT, $2.25 lower than Tuesday's late bid. In London, gold bullion traded late Wednesday at a bid of $359.50 a troy ounce, up 25 cents from late Tuesday. In Zurich, the bid was $358.60 an ounce, unchanged from late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.55 to close at $361.42 an ounce. Silver prices also were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for June delivery settled at $5.030 a troy ounce, down from $5.065 Tuesday. Silver rose slightly in London at a bid of $5.085 per troy ounce, compared to $5.08 late Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Midwest Seen as Most Popular Region for Real Estate Invesment in Early 90s
DOC.TEXT: The Midwest, California and the Southwest will see the biggest increases in real estate investment in the next two years, leading real estate executives and economists predicted in a study released here Wednesday. The specialists, however, see a sluggish real estate market overall through 1995, citing recent overbuilding as the major detriment. They expect the market to grow more slowly than the consumer price index in the first half of the decade. The experts also expect a decline in available capital, including foreign investment. Some respondents see a catastrophic impact on real estate from the savings and loan crisis, but others believe the worst already has come. The nationwide survey, mailed in January, compiles responses of 400 real estate specialists to forecast the real estate market for the next five years. The study was conducted by Ernst & Young Real Estate Advisory Services and the National Real Estate Index, a computer service that tracks real estate values and rents. Houston was cited as offering the best overall potential for real estate investment over the next five years. Dallas-Fort Worth was the second choice, followed by Los Angeles, Seattle and Washington. Despite the overall prediction of a slow market, 28.4 percent of the respondents said their firms would increase investment in the Midwest in the next two years compared with spending in 1989. The specialists appear less enthusiastic about individual markets in the Midwest, however. Only Chicago was selected among the top 10 investment markets nationwide, and only two others made the top 30 _ Columbus, Ohio, at 29 and Minneapolis-St. Paul at 30. ``I think part of that's a lack of knowledge'' about many Midwestern cities, said Michael L. Evans, national director for Real Estate Advisory Services in San Francisco, a branch of the accounting firm Ernst & Young. ``I think a lot of people view the Midwest as being Chicago,'' he said. ``I think they were looking at the principal cities in each region and perhaps didn't have the information about other cities.'' Almost 26 percent of the respondents expect to spend more in California, and 24 percent will invest more heavily in the Southwest, the survey showed. But 21.4 percent of the specialists think they will spend less on real estate in the Northeast, compared with 17.3 percent who expect to spend more in the region. The decrease can be traced to the belief of 28.6 percent of the analysts that New York City is the most overpriced market in the country for real estate investment. Los Angeles finished second in the balloting for most overpriced market, but also was identified as the metropolitan market likely to produce the best real estate performance in the next five years. ``I think it reflects the fact that Los Angeles placed high in every category,'' said Evans. ``It's just a feeling that the Southern California economy doesn't want to stop.'' Other top overall performers are expected to be Atlanta, Seattle, Washington and Chicago. Other markets viewed as overpriced were Boston, chosen by 9.9 percent of the respondents; San Francisco, 7.5 percent; and Washington, D.C, 5.6 percent. The survey also examined projected growth in specific property sectors: apartments, warehouses, retail space, and central and suburban office space. Prospects for building apartments are best in Los Angeles, the specialists said. Atlanta is next, followed by Seattle, San Diego and Washington. Atlanta topped the list of candidates for warehouse space, followed by Chicago, Los Angeles, Dallas-Fort Worth and Seattle. Seven of the top 20 projected retail markets are in California. The specialists chose Orange County and Los Angeles as the best two retail markets, followed by Atlanta, San Francisco and Seattle. Washington was rated as the best market for central and suburban office space in the first half of the 1990s. Rounding out the top five markets for office space in the central business district were San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago and Seattle. Los Angeles was second in the voting for prospects for suburban office space, followed by Orange County, Calif., Atlanta and New York.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Rebound After Opening Sharply Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices finished higher Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, rebounding from early losses. On other markets, grains and soybeans were mostly higher, precious metals declined, and livestock and pork futures were mixed. Energy futures rallied after opening sharply lower in reaction to inventory figures released after the close of trading Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute. The API report showed an increase of 2.5 million barrels in crude oil stocks, a 2.3 million barrel increase in gasoline stocks and a 4.1 million barrel increase in distillates, which include heating oil. But prices soon reversed course and began to rise. The feeling is that all the bad news is out, and from the fundamental perspective, little more could adversely affect the market, said Nauman Baraket, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Andrew Lebow, an analyst with E.D.&F. Man International Futures Inc. in New York, said the market was also helped by Tuesday's announcement by the Saudis that they will stick to their oil production quota set by OPEC in May. Kuwait also said it would stick to the production quota set by the 13 members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Rumors of a possible nuclear power accident in the Soviet Union, which would increase demand for crude oil and reduce Soviet exports, also fueled the market, Lebow said. A mysterious cloud was first spotted over the Soviet Union on May 26 and was moving towards Finland, according to Vienna-based International Atomic Energy Authority. An agency spokesman said Wednesday the USSR had not informed them of any radioactivity in the cloud. West Texas Intermediate crude oil was 4 cents to 24 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $16.92 a barrel; heating oil was .12 cent to .29 cent higher with July at 47.31 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .40 cent to .56 cent higher with July at 58.36 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher on the Chicago Board of Trade. The market was heavily influenced by the reports of the cloud heading towards Finland, said John Frazier, an analyst with Gerald Inc. in Chicago. The reports triggered speculation about possible damage to farmland in those areas that could mean stronger demand for U.S. grains and soybeans. Also influencing the market was a weather outlook by a private forecaster that calls for unusually hot, dry weather in the Midwest in late July and early August. The heat is forecast for a period when corn and soybeans mature. Soybean futures received a boost from strong cash markets for soybeans, light selling by farmers and the continuing Brazilian port shutdown. Wheat futures received some support from commercial and speculative buying, although forecasts of warm weather that would speed the harvesting of the winter wheat crop weighed on prices. Wheat was 2\ cents lower to a { cent higher July at $3.31{ a bushel; corn was 1\ cents lower to 2} cents higher with July at $2.79} a bushel; oats were unchanged to a { cent lower with July at $1.46\ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 4 cents higher with July at $5.94 a bushel. Precious metals futures declined on New York's Commodity Exchange. Craig Sloane, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York, said the market tried to keep the positive tone seen in Tuesday's trading but was unable to do so. ``The market is continuing a trend downward,'' he said. ``People are not interested in the market. And there is nothing in the way of news that is significant to the market.'' Gold was $2.40 to $2.80 lower with June at $352.40 a troy ounce; silver was 3.3 cents to 3.5 cents lower with June at $5.030 a troy ounce. Livestock futures were higher and pork lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .07 cent to .37 cent higher with June at 75.22 a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .48 cent higher with August at 85.45 cents a pound; hogs were .98 cent lower to .05 cent higher with June at 66.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.25 cent lower to .37 cent higher with July at 66.05 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Pickens Uses Videotape to Appeal to Koito's Stockholders
DOC.TEXT: It's not exactly Michael Jackson's ``Thriller,'' but corporate raider T. Boone Pickens is turning to similar pop technology to step up his battle for changes in a Japanese company _ he's done a video. In an 8-minute, 22-second videotape mailed this week to about 4,100 shareholders of Koito Manufacturing Ltd., Pickens appears on horseback wearing a cowboy hat, playing racquetball and with his family. Pickens claims that the company's unwillingness to seat him on Koito's board of directors or make other changes that he wants is a symbol of Japan's unwillingness to open its markets to foreign competitors. In the video, in which he speaks under the voice of a Japanese translator, the Texas oilman appeals for support on seven proposals he is asking Koito shareholders to adopt at the auto parts manufacturer's June 28 annual meeting. Finally, Pickens exhorts Koito shareholders to do their part to change Japan's economic system, or ``your children will not find opportunities to better their lives.'' Pickens is Koito's largest shareholder with 26 percent of the common stock. The company has rebuffed him for more than a year, claiming he is after greenmail, in which a company pays a shareholder a premium price to fend off a hostile takeover. The tone of the tape, produced at a cost of about $20,000, resembles U.S. political television advertising. Pickens' assistant, Andrew Littlefair, conceded Wednesday that the pitch had little chance of success because so-called stable shareholders _ companies such as Toyota Motor Co., Nissan and Matsushita Electric Products Co. _ control more than half of Koito's outstanding stock. But ``it would seem to make a statement if a lot of the small, individual shareholders vote with us,'' Littlefair said. Pickens claims he is being blocked by Toyota, Koito's second-largest shareholder and largest customer. He also has attempted to enlist the U.S. government in his fight, claiming he is the victim of unfair and illegal barriers to foreign investment in Japan. He complains that Koito, Toyota and other companies are members of an automotive ``keiretsu,'' a business group that forces their auto parts makers to sell them parts at artificially low prices. ``I have discovered something pretty disturbing,'' Pickens says on the tape. ``The leadership of Koito is deliberately keeping us out of the global marketplace and holding back financial returns to stockholders.'' ``If something isn't done to break down the practice of keiretsu, things will never change,'' Pickens says. ``Your children will not find opportunities to better their lives. Eventually, since the marketplace is becoming increasingly global and competitive, they may even fall behind.'' Koito plans to respond with its own proxy statement next week, a U.S. spokeswoman for the company said. ``It sounds like Pickens is using pressure tactics to coerce Koito shareholders and disrupt Koito business,'' said a U.S. spokeswoman for Koito.

DOC.HEAD: Food Processing Agreement Signed With Soviet Union
With AM-US-Soviet Trade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wirtes.
DOC.TEXT: Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher signed an agreement with the Soviets on Wednesday to share information on food processing. He said the agreement was a start toward expanding trade between the two superpowers. ``We are the two largest industrialized nations in the world,'' said Mosbacher. ``We have one third of the world's GNP. But we do only a tiny fraction of world trade. ... We have nowhere to go but up.'' The agreement Mosbacher signed with Vladilen Nikitin, the Soviet agriculture minister, creates a team of U.S. and Soviet government officials who will study the food processing systems of the two countries and determine how U.S. technology and methods can be incorporated into the Soviet system. A high proportion of Soviet food production has been reported to spoil because of inefficient distribution, handling and storage before it reaches the consumer. Nikitin said the agreement was a small step, ``but everything starts with a small step.'' ``For you, it's a key if you want to participate in the strengthening of our economy,'' he said through an interpreter. The pact was signed on the last day of a three-day conference sponsored by the Food Processing Machinery & Supplies Association and the National Food Processors Association. Fifty-five Soviet officials met with representatives of more than 50 food companies, administration and congressional officials seeking deals that could lead to increased business for Americans and modernization of food distribution for the Soviet Union. John Cady, president of the food processors association, said barriers are beginning to come down, though Americans still are concerned about getting paid for business with the Soviets. Soviet currency is of almost no value in the world market, leaving those companies doing business in the Soviet Union to either accept products in exchange or wait for long-term gains after the economy there improves. ``We have to understand when companies invest, it's not going to be a three-year turn-around, but probably eight to 10 years,'' said Cady.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Last Bauxite Mines Closed
DOC.TEXT: About 200 workers were left without jobs when the last bauxite mines in the United States were closed by the Aluminum Company of America after 91 years of operation, the company said Wednesday. The mines, located near Little Rock, Ark., are adjacent to Alcoa's Arkansas Operations, which includes a bauxite refinery and chemical facilities for processing alumina, an oxide of aluminum present in bauxite. Some of the employees retired and others were laid off when the mines closed last week. The refining operations also are being shut down, Alcoa said. The mining and refining operations were ended because the reserves of bauxite were no longer economical to mine and refine, the company said. The bauxite was used to make about 275,000 metric tons of alumina a year. Alumina once was used in the production of aluminum but recently was used mostly to produce chemicals for cements, ceramics, fire retardants, paper and pharmaceuticals, the company said. About 700 employees who will remain at the plant will make chemicals from alumina feedstocks from other Alcoa locations, the company said. The world's largest reserves of bauxite are in Australia, Brazil, Guinea, Jamaica, Suriname and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Cloud, Technical Trading Boost Energy Futures
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices regained some ground Wednesday, aided by technical factors and rumors of a nuclear accident in the Soviet Union. The July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 24 cents to $16.92 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange after having lost 82 cents over the first two days of the week. Later months also rose Wednesday. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for July delivery, which plunged nearly 3 cents over Monday and Tuesday, moved 0.54 cent higher to 58.36 cents a gallon Wednesday with subsequent months also advancing. And the July contract for home heating oil picked up 0.20 cent to settle at 47.31 cents a gallon after skidding 1.62 cents earlier in the week. Later months also advanced Wednesday. Analysts said the market opened lower, but rumors about a Soviet nuclear disaster sent prices higher. The rumors were sparked by the appearance of a dark cloud sighted over the western Soviet Union. Finnish authorities, who were monitoring the cloud, said it could have been caused by some kind of accident or it could just be an ordinary cloud. Traders bought up futures on the theory that if the cloud were the result of a nuclear accident, the Soviets might need other sources of energy. Technical buying throughout the day also boosted prices, the analysts said. In natural gas trading, the July contract declined to $1.560 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.567 on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Manufacturers Hanover to Purchase Midlantic's Credit Card Receivables
DOC.TEXT: Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. plans to purchase the $252 million credit card accounts and receivables of Midlantic Corp., the companies said Wednesday. The premium on the sale is expected to be about $60 million, Manufacturers Hanover said in a news release. The deal should be completed in the second quarter, but it is subject to federal regulatory clearance, the release said. Charles R. Walsh, head of Manufacturers Hanover retail card services, said the transaction would further his company's expansion in the credit card business. The holding company's portfolio of credit card receivables after the sale will exeed $3.3 billion, according to the release. The deal will continue Midlantic's restructuring efforts, said Frank P. Garnevicus, executive vice president and treasurer. ``It will enable Midlantic to concentrate its efforts on its more traditional lines of business,'' Garnevicus said.

Federal regulators told members of Congress that more government regulation of bank lending is not responsible for a credit squeeze in some regions. Senior federal banking officials conceded Wednesday before the House Small Business Committee that some banks are making it more difficult for businesses to get loans, particularly for commercial real estate projects. But they said that is mostly a justified response to a sluggish economy rather than a reaction to intensified scrutiny from government examiners.

The Federal Housing Administration, which suffered massive losses in 1988, will continue to have financial problems unless changes are made, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp said. Kemp told a Senate subcommittee Wednesday that the FHA's mutual mortgage fund, which insures low downpayment mortgages on single-family homes, has not been operated soundly. He said the problem is manageable if Congress adopts recommended changes.

The biggest increases in real estate investment in the next two years will occur in the Midwest, California and the Southwest, according to a study released by leading real estate executives and economists. But the report released Wednesday says the real estate market will remain sluggish overall through 1995, citing recent overbuilding. They expect the market to grow more slowly than the consumer price index in the first half of the decade.

Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. overhauled its operations, reviving a respected investment banking name and dumping a vestige of its expansionist 1980s in a bid to rebound from record losses on Wall Street. Shearson said Wednesday it was grouping into two divisions from four: Shearson Lehman Brothers for individual investing and asset management, and Lehman Brothers for investment banking and capital markets activities. The full firm will be known as Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

All but one of the Sakowitz specialty stores were slated for liquidation after no bids were received for the Texas-based retailer at a bankruptcy court hearing. The once-proud chain, which includes four stores in Houston, one in Dallas and another in Cincinnati, is 80 percent owned by L.J. Hooker Corp. Hooker has been disposing of its assets under bankruptcy court supervision. U.S. Bankruptcy Court Judge Tina Brozman indicated Wednesday she would approve the plan to liquidate all of the Texas Sakowitz stores. The Sakowitz in Cincinnati's Forest Fair Mall would remain open.

Officials of the central banks of Japan, France, England and the United States said they are confident in the ability of West Germany's central bank to control inflation after East and West Germany merge their currencies next month. There has been concern that the plan could lead to inflation in West Germany, which could force the nation's central bank, the Bundesbank, to raise interest rates. That could unsettle world financial markets and lead to higher rates in other countries. But central bankers gathered at the annual International Monetary Conference told reporters Wednesday they are unconcerned about that prospect because of the careful plans for monetary unification laid out by the West German government.

Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter warned of an agricultural trade war if a deadlock over U.S. demands at international trade talks continues through the end of the year. The United States is seeking the removal of European farm export subsidies over 10 years. If no agreement is reached, Yeutter said Wednesday he would ``guarantee you the costs for some of our trading partners would increase dramatically.''

The House voted to forbid the sale of sophisticated U.S. computers, telecommunications equipment and other high-tech goods to the Soviet Union until it ends its economic boycott against breakaway Lithuania. In the first congressional action since President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev signed a trade agreement last week, the House also voted Wednbesday to ban such sales if Gorbachev carries out a threat to slow the emigration of Soviet Jews.

Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher signed an agreement with the Soviets to share information on food processing. He said the agreement signed Wednesday was a start toward expanding trade between the two superpowers. It creates a team of U.S. and Soviet government officials who will study the food processing systems of the two countries and determine how U.S. technology and methods can be incorporated into the Soviet system.

Stock prices retreated Wednesday in a second straight session of moderate selling after the market's recent runup to record highs. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 10.19 on Tuesday, dropped 13.35 points to 2,911.65. The dollar gained against all major currencies except its Canadian counterpart while gold declined moderately. Bond prices were mixed in light trading. Energy, grain and soybean futures prices finished higher, precious metals declined and livestock and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Troubles Changing the Way Some Americans Get Around
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 11-12, beginning `Amtrak ridership...' with 3 grafs to ADD full quote by Amtrak spokesman, UPDATE with increase in air travel. Picks up 13th graf pvs, `Several small...' Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: ``Greyhound refugees'' left in the dust by a 3-month-old strike of the only nationwide bus line are turning to planes, trains and automobiles, and analysts say the survival of coast-to-coast bus travel is in jeopardy. Greyhound has vowed to continue service with replacement drivers while trying to reorganize its finances under bankruptcy las, but many people are choosing alternate transportation. Some bus riders are paying more, finding it harder to make connections and having to stay overnight where the pre-strike Greyhound schedule allowed them to return the same day. Bus industry officials say they see little concern in Washington over the state of interstate bus travel. ``I haven't received a single call from any legislator, mayor, governor or anyone complaining about a lack of service because of the Greyhound strike,'' said Wayne J. Smith, executive director of the United Bus Operators of America. Jeremy Kahn, a Washington lawyer who represents scores of bus lines, said bus travel is ignored because ``congressmen and newspaper people don't ride the bus.'' Most travelers affected by the strike are rural, poor or elderly, he said. ``This is not a very vocal constituency.'' Kahn said that whatever results from the strike and Monday's bankruptcy filing, the Greyhound of the future will be considerably scaled down. ``If Greyhound goes down, it probably will be virtually impossible to go from coast to coast by bus,'' said John Sim, another lawyer who has represented bus companies for 40 years. Greyhound says it's continuing to run buses to communities that provided 98 percent of its revenue last year, but the use other modes of transportation is increasing. Amtrak ridership is up 12 percent over last year, with increases of 30 percent or more on some routes. Spokesman Cliff Black said train travel was booming before the strike, but added, ``We have gathered some Greyhound refugees and made them our own.'' Car travel is expected to increase 2 percent this summer, said American Automobile Association spokesman Geoffrey Sundstrom, but he said it's impossible to tell how much of that, if any, will result from the Greyhound strike. Airline travel is also up, and a summer fare war has made some trips more affordable for people who might have taken the bus. Several small bus companies report increased ridership. More than a dozen bus lines have been granted new routes by the Interstate Commerce Commission since the strike began. ``We were getting a fair share of the traveling public before the strike,'' said Phil McBride of Peter Pan Bus Lines in Springfield, Mass. ``Now we're getting the lion's share.'' Jim Harmon, operations manager of Cascade Trailways in Tacoma, Wash., said his line, which has daily runs to Sacramento, Calif., used some of its tour buses to serve Greyhound routes in the early days of the strike. ``We backed out when they came back, because the market couldn't support two of us,'' he said. But if Greyhound fails, Cascade is ready to run buses to every town Greyhound serves in Washington, he said. While Greyhound is the only bus system operating nationwide, about 200 smaller lines run limited routes. Most of the other 1,800 lines carry tours and charters. Overall, it's a $12 billion industry. Charter lines that can charge more now that Greyhound has scaled back its low-priced charter services also are benefiting from the strike, said industry officials. But some bus companies say they are hurting, because Greyhound does their ticketing and hasn't been turning over the revenue and because the image of bus travel in general has been sullied by violence during the Greyhound strike. Greyhound and police have reported more than 30 shooting incidents involving buses or terminals since the strike began. In some areas, enterprising small businesses have replaced the sleek Greyhounds with homey little passenger vans that make runs like stagecoaches to isolated towns. ``When Greyhound stopped, the buses were able to keep running on the freeways, but some of the little communities were without bus service,'' said Lera Dwyer of Wichita Falls, Texas. ``And I've always been service-oriented.'' Mrs. Dwyer, who owns Skylark Transportation, said business for her has quadrupled since the strike, with 10 small vans making daily round trips to Paris, Texarkana, Abilene and stops along the way abandoned by Greyhound. But even her company relies on Greyhound to make connections for passengers and shipments of vital farm machinery parts, fresh produce that has to arrive overnight, thread to keep a clothing plant running and valuable bull semen. ``It would be a great blow if we lost Greyhound everywhere,'' Mrs. Dwyer said. ``An awful lot of people who cannot or would not fly, I don't know how they would get around.''

DOC.HEAD: New Chief Executive Says Bad Business Judgment to Blame
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS to Harshfield sted Harshfeld.
DOC.TEXT: Edward Harshfield, the new head of Columbia Savings & Loan Association, told shareholders bad business judgment rather than government intervention wiped out their assets. Harshfield, who took over as chief executive three months ago, did not mention predecessor Thomas Spiegel by name during his speech at the annual shareholders' meeting on Tuesday. But he said executives of the thrift put the firm ``in harm's way'' as far back as 1986, long before the collapse of the junk bond market. Earnings slipped from $193 million in 1986 to $65 million in 1988, he said. ``The bottom line is that all but $17 million in stockholder equity was wiped out, not by government action, but by the business judgements and management actions over those several years,'' he said. Columbia, which holds an extensive portfolio of the high-risk, high-yield junk bonds, reported a $591 million loss in 1989. The firm must sell its junk bond portfolio, once valued at $3 billion, by 1994 to meet tough capital requirements imposed on the thrift industry by Congress last year. ``Ed has been here for three months,'' Spiegel said after the meeting. ``He has his perspective of the situation being here three months. I have my perspective being here 13 years.'' Spiegel resigned as chief executive on Dec. 31. He and his family still own about two-thirds of Columbia's common stock.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Presents Reorganization Plan to Creditors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with confirmation and details of plan, comment from Drexel attorney; PICKS UP 16th graf pvs, Drexel has...
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. on Wednesday presented creditors with a bankruptcy reorganization plan that promises to pay in full the debts of the collapsed Wall Street firm. Drexel attorneys said the plan envisions creating a separate business entity out of Drexel's junk bond holdings and giving creditors an interest equal to their claims. Creditors of the brokerage firm and about a dozen smaller subsidiaries of parent Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. would be paid in cash, Drexel attorney Alan B. Miller said. Creditors of the parent and two commodities trading subsidiaries would receive promissory notes. The plan also proposes creating a separate fund for settling more than 400 outstanding lawsuits by investors who say they were defrauded by trading activities by Drexel, whose admission to securities felonies last year sped the firm's demise. The plan was announced by Drexel attorneys at a two-hour meeting with about 100 creditors and their representatives and was not formally entered into bankruptcy court. Drexel's parent filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection in February and its brokerage subsidiary followed suit last week. Drexel has said it plans to emerge from bankruptcy court as an operating entity on Wall Street, although it is unclear what shape the firm would take. Under the reorganization, Drexel would create a separate business entity out of its holdings. Creditors would receive promissory notes valued at the amount of their individual claims and backed by Drexel's assets, Miller said. Drexel says its holdings are worth about $2 billion, but a large portion consists of junk bonds the firm has been unable to sell because of their low quality and a severe downturn in the high-yield bond market. The holdings also include so-called bridge loans, which are temporary loans made to clients that remain unpaid, typically because permanent financing has not been obtained. Miller said Drexel was confident ``there would be sufficient backing in assets for all our constituents and hopefully value left over for our equity shareholders.'' Drexel employees owned the firm's stock, the value of which vanished when the firm collapsed. Barry Dichter, an attorney representing Banco de Portugal, one of Drexel's largest creditors, said determining the value of the holdings ``will be the great debating point in this case.'' ``This is really the first step in what will be a lengthy negotiation process,'' he said. ``Creditors will require a lot more information than they now have in order to evaluate the concepts that were put forward.'' Under the proposal, creditors would be free to sell their notes in the open market if they can find a buyer, giving them a way to recoup cash for what they are owed, Drexel attorneys said. Drexel would redeem a small portion of notes periodically or buy them back if it had the money. It was left up in the air how and when Drexel planned to value the assets in the unit. Creditors' lawyers said they presumed the holdings would receive a value at the time Drexel files its reorganization plan with the bankruptcy court. Drexel would manage the portfolio and be allowed to conduct other business activities at the same time. But the composition of Drexel's management after it emerges from bankruptcy is an open topic for debate, Miller said. Drexel would seek to liquidate the junk bond holdings for maximum value and recoup the outstanding bridge loans from former clients. ``We think you could return 80 percent of those bonds probably within a two-year period,'' Miller said. Creditors' attorney have said they likely would oppose allowing current management to be in charge. Another unresolved issue is some $260 million in bonuses that Drexel paid to executives in the months before the bankruptcy filing. Drexel has requested a 120-day extension from a June 13 deadline to file a reorganization plan in U.S. Bankruptcy Court. A spokesman declined to discuss the plan and Drexel attorneys did not immediately return calls seeking comment. The firm, which rose to power on Wall Street by dominating the high-yield bond business, failed to recover from a government securities fraud investigation. Drexel last year pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay $650 million to settle insider trading and other allegations. As of March 30, Drexel said it had total assets of $3.26 billion and total liabilities of $2.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Hands States Regulation of Enhanced Phone Services
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court Wednesday gave states the authority to regulate new telephone services such as voice mail and computer access, a move one Baby Bell company said could raise costs to consumers. The decision could force the seven regional Bell telephone companies to set up separate corporate entities to handle their regulated telephone services and their newer, unregulated services, officials said. The 9th Circuit Court of Appeals opinion vacated a 1985 Federal Communications Commission rule that had required the Baby Bells to keep finances separate for regulated and unregulated services but not create separate corporations. Seven lawsuits had been filed to overturn the rule. The court's ruling allows each state to decide whether to require separate corporations. The California Public Utilities Commission, which filed three of the lawsuits against the FCC, heralded the decision. The plaintiffs had contended that the Baby Bells could have subsidized unregulated services by charging higher prices on regulated phone service. ``It properly gives the states greater freedom to promote the development of enhanced services and the terms and conditions upon which those services are provided,'' Commission President G. Mitchell Wilk said. Steven Harris, director of planning and policy for Pacific Bell, said the company supports state regulation but fears state control could lead to a costly corporate division of regulated and unregulated services. ``It's not clear that we are going to have to split off,'' Harris said. ``It's up to the states. But we strongly believe that independent subsidiaries are not necessary and would make it more difficult to provide the services to the public.'' An FCC spokeswoman said the opinion is a setback for the communications industry. ``We adopted the rules because we believed they would be in the public interest,'' said spokeswoman Jane Mago. ``So, of course, we're disappointed in the outcome. We have to start from scratch.'' Unregulated communications services have developed rapidly in the past 10 years into a multi-billion-dollar industry that ranges from voice and electronic mail to automatic teller machines, Harris said. The appeals court ordered the FCC to develop new rules to help regulate new telecommunications services offered by the Baby Bell companies. Those companies had been prevented from providing information services under a court decree that stripped AT&T of its local operating companies in January 1984. Later that year, the FCC allowed the Baby Bells to offer unregulated services through separate subsidiaries. But in 1985, the federal agency dropped the requirement for separate subsidiares. The court said the FCC arbitrarily and capriciously reversed itself without showing that cost-shifting between unregulated and regulated services wouldn't occur and raise the bills of ``captive telephone customers.'' ``The record yields no evidence that the (Bell Operating Companies) power to extract monopoly rents from local telephone customers has diminished,'' the court said.

DOC.HEAD: Skinner Says California Vote Shows States Will Hike Taxes For Roads
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS $18.5 billion to $15.5 billion in 2nd graf. Higher figure includes bond funds for other projects. SUBS 8th graf: ``Skinner said,'' to note federal tax is currently 9 cents
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Calif Propositions
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of Transportation Samuel K. Skinner said Wednesday that approval of a gasoline tax increase by California voters validates the administration's argument that states can and will raise their taxes to pay for highways and other transportation needs. In a referendum on Tuesday, Californians voted to increase the gasoline tax from 9 to 18 cents a gallon to finance a $15.5 billion freeway construction program. ``I am delighted with that result,'' said Skinner, architect of the administration's national transportation policy, which looks largely to state and local financing to meet increasing needs. He told reporters the California vote shows that states are willing to act to meet those costs, so long as the voters know where their money is going. ``I think the best validation of that principle is the vote yesterday in California,'' Skinner said. He said the average voter would say no to a gasoline tax increase that wasn't earmarked for transportation, and yes to one specifically targeted for roads, bridges and other infrastructure needs. ``I think that's what happened in California,'' he said. Skinner said he assumed there would be discussion of increases in the federal gasoline tax, currently 9 cents per gallon, during the current negotiations on the federal budget and deficit. He said he does not support or advocate an increase in that tax, but when and if there is one, it also should be earmarked for the infrastructure. Asked to name other states he believes should follow the California example, Skinner said 18 states have increased gas taxes in the past year, and pointed to New York as one that has not. He said it should be considered there. ``I think it's a good potential'' in a state with major infrastructure needs.

DOC.HEAD: Armstrong, Belzbergs Agree To Resolve Remaining Litigation
DOC.TEXT: Armstrong World Industries Inc. and the Belzberg family have dropped all lawsuits stemming from their hostile takeover fight in a settlement that makes the Canadian family $4.4 million richer. Under the agreement, which Armstrong announced Wednesday, the Belzberg group will limit its holdings of Armstrong stock for a period of 10 years to no more than 50,000 shares. The family, whose investment vehicle is First City Financial Corp., agreed not to interfere in any business aspect of the floor-covering company. ``We have entered into this agreement because it will put an end to the many disruptions caused by the litigation, not to mention the substantial expense,'' Armstrong spokesman John Scheldrup said. ``Now we can devote all our resources and energies to running the business, which is certainly in the best interests of the corporation,'' he said. Last week, First City Financial Corp. announced it would abandon its bid to acquire the Lancaster company. The pullout came about a month after the Belzbergs failed to seat three of four nominees on the Armstrong board and the state of Pennsylvania enacted legislation requiring corporate raiders to surrender short-term profits from thwarted takeover bids. First City said the takeover law and the largely unsuccessful proxy fight played a role in the decision. The agreement calls for First City to pay Armstrong $605,000 and for Armstrong to pay First City affiliates $5 million. The payments are in part reimbursement of First City's expenses related to the proxy fight, Scheldrup said. In addition, the Belzbergs have agreed not to pursue their petition proposing changes in Armstrong's articles of incorporation. The state's anti-takeover legislation was drafted last year after the Belzbergs first disclosed an interest in acquiring the company. In addition to garnishing raiders' profits, the law also restricts the voting rights of raiders and preserves labor contracts when corporations exchange hands.

DOC.HEAD: Metromedia Awarded $46 Million in Lawsuit Against Fugazy
DOC.TEXT: Metromedia Co. was awarded $46 million in damages Wednesday in its civil racketeering lawsuit against William Fugazy, an operator of travel agencies and limousine services. The lawsuit was over Metromedia's 1985 purchase of Fugazy Express Inc. car service, which is now in bankruptcy proceedings. A six-member jury in U.S. District Court found that Fugazy had misrepresented to Metromedia the company's financial condition and certain liabilities. The jury awarded $15.6 million in damages, which under civil racketeering statute is trebled to more than $46 million. Anthony Princi, Fugazy's attorney, said he would appeal. The lawsuit also named Fugazy's son, Roy, and two of Fugazy's companies, but the jury rejected all charges against them. The trial lasted three weeks and included testimony from Fugazy and billionaire John Kluge, who controls Metromedia. Metromedia is a privately held partnership that owns companies in the telecommunications, software, restaurant and hotel industries. It previously sold its television stations to the Fox network. The Fugazy family owns a chain of travel agencies and a separate limousine service in New York. Metromedia attorney Martin Shelton said Fugazy had overstated the value of Fugazy Express by $7 million to $8 million and had given Metromedia inaccurate earnings figures. Shelton also said that Metromedia had invested about $30 million in Fugazy Express.

DOC.HEAD: The Donald Takes a Beating While He's Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, `Despite the ...,' to UPDATE with statement from Mrs. Trump; picks up 5th graf, `Trump, in ...' SUBS 14th graf, `Ivana's spokesman ...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with statement; picks up 15th graf, `Strangely enough ...' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: He was riding high in April, shot down in May. Donald Trump's highly publicized financial woes have turned June into open season on the tycoon, with columnists and cartoonists lining up to kick the man while he's down. ``The Donald in disarray. Is this a great country or what?'' asked Tony Kornheiser of The Washington Post in a column headlined ``When Trump Went Thump.'' ``It's a cash flow problem. A slump de Trump. From `Trump: The Art of the Deal' to `Thump! My Life as a Shlemiel,''' the column continued. Despite the mounting abuse, Trump maintained his silence Wednesday while negotiations continued between the developer and his creditors. ``We won't be making any statements today,'' said Trump spokesman Dan Klores. His wife, Ivana, was talking Wednesday. She came to Trump's defense, promising to stand by her estranged husband ``through thick or thin and for better or worse.'' Trump, in need of cash to pay off a reported $30 million debt on June 15, could be forced to sell off some assets _ the Trump Shuttle and the Taj Mahal casino have been mentioned _ to make the payment. In April, Trump claimed he had no cash flow woes; last month, that turned out to be untrue. The real estate magnate and casino operator has long been the target of Trump-bashing, even when things were going well. Spy magazine, which dubbed Trump ``the short-fingered vulgarian,'' mounts monthly attacks at him. But Trump's legal woes have stepped up the pace. ``At last, all of us who've so loved the game of kicking Donald Trump while he's up will have the fiendish thrill of kicking Donald Trump while he down,'' wrote New York Newsday columnist Robert Reno. A New York Post cartoon showed a bedraggled Donald panhandling from inside the ``Trump Carton.'' Others suggested The Donald might have trumped up his money misfortunes to keep his estranged wife, Ivana, from getting too big a piece of the pie in any divorce settlement. ``A Trump Stunt?'' asked the Daily News, which quoted an anonymous Ivana pal as saying, ``He is just trying to convince Ivana that he has no money, so she'll soften up and go easy on him.'' Newsday raised the same possibility in an editorial titled ``Art of the Fall?'' ``After all, there's always the possibility The Donald has pulled off the most artful deal of his career: Could it be an elaborate scam to keep the Empire out of Ivana's hands?'' it asked. But in a statement issued through her lawyer, Michael Kennedy, Mrs. Trump made it clear she plans to stand by her man. ``Donald and I are partners in marriage and in business. I will stand beside him through thick or thin and for better or worse,'' said Ivana, who was not alone in refusing to kick Donald while he's down. Strangely enough, ex-mayor Ed Koch _ a charter member of the ``Down With Donald'' movement _ declined to join the Trump-bashers. While at City Hall, Koch constantly feuded with Trump and trashed the multimillionaire developer as ``piggy, piggy, piggy.'' ``I don't believe in kicking someone when they are down, so I have nothing to say about Donald Trump,'' Koch said. ``Call me when he's back on his feet.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday morning while the dollar dipped against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average gained 148.97 points, or 0.45 percent, ending the morning session at 33,102.47. The index rose 31.88 points the previous day. The dollar was changing hands at 152.46 yen at late morning, down slightly from 152.49 yen at the opening and down from Wednesday's 152.60-yen finish. It ranged narrowly between 152.40 yen and 152.49 yen during morning trading. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond inched up to 87.98 points from Wednesday's close of 87.89. The yield slipped to 6.94 percent from 6.99 percent. Arbitrage dealings supported the Nikkei index, stock traders said. Thursday was the last day for transactions in June delivery stock index futures and many participants bought stocks and sold futures, said Akihiro Sezaki, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co. Currency trading was very thin, said Chemical Bank dealer Chizuko Satsukawa. ``Trading between major currencies, including the dollar and mark, dollar and yen, and mark and yen were all stuck and would not move, mainly because of a lack of market-affecting news,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Reportedly Sought Rule Relaxation on Real Estate Loans
DOC.TEXT: Commercial bankers have asked federal regulators to bend capital rules to help them work out of problems with troubled real estate loans, a newspaper reported. Bankers on the Federal Reserve Board's Advisory Council sought help at a closed-door meeting on May 3 with the Fed's Board of Governors, USA Today said in Wednesday's edition. The newspaper said it obtained secret minutes of the meeting. The bankers suggested that the governors allow banks to take real estate losses over a period of years, easing the squeeze on bank earnings and allowing them more time to set aside reserves, the newspaper said. They also suggested relaxing capital rules to allow banks to hold and manage troubled real estate loans without a big increase in capital, the newspaper said. One council member said the Fed governors did not respond to the requests. ``Some members delivered the suggestion and the governors listened intently,'' Ronald Steinhart, chairman of Team Bank, Dallas, was quoted as saying. ``They're asking for forebearance. That's exactly what got the savings and loans into trouble,'' said Lee Cross, spokeswoman for the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which regulates the nation's banks. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., said bankers have requested similar breaks from his agency. ``It needs to be explored,'' he was quoted as saying, but he sees no need for such breaks now. The 12 council members head some of the nation's biggest banks and meet with the Fed governors four times a year. Fed spokesman Joseph Coyne said minutes of the meetings usually are not released publicly for three years.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Declines Unsolicited Offer for Its Holding of Continental Bank
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said it had declined an unsolicited offer for its 26 percent stake of Chicago's Continental Corp. _ a move that angered the bank's officials. FDIC spokesman Alan Whitney on Tuesday declined to reveal the amount of the offer or the investors who made it except to say they included the bank itself and certain members of its management. He said the offer was made in the last several days. ``I'm dumbfounded that in a little more than six months, the FDIC has passed up two legitimate offers to sell its minority interest in Continental,'' Continental chairman Thomas C. Theobald said Tuesday. `` Not only have they failed to turn their asset into cash, but their continued ownership in a healthy bank is a wholly unwarranted role for a regulator.'' The FDIC became a shareholder of Continental after rescuing the former Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Co. in 1984. The rescue was expected at the time to cost the federal agency $4.5 billion, but Continental's return to profitability has drastically reduced estimates of the cost. In a brief announcement from Washington, the FDIC said it had rejected the latest offer for its Continental holdings but still remains committed to realizing full value for them. It said it would explore all options for divesting its stake. Since the 1984 bailout, the FDIC has made three sales of its Continental common stock, selling 12.5 million shares in November 1986; another 12.5 million shares in December 1988 and 9 million shares in August 1989.
